The purple rice and yogurt is a MUST TRY when visiting Chinatown. It's shocking to me that there are not more reviews on Yelp as it may be my favourite drink in NYC. It's very easy to miss the storefront as it's tucked away at the basement level, but it'll be worth your visit. I've travelled from uptown just to grab the drink, and have tried to find another shop that may have something similar to no avail-- I think the secret is that they allegedly make their own yogurt, so it's hard to replicate. The purple rice is always cooked to perfection, and is a healthy alternative to boba. I can not stress enough how much of a hidden gem this shop is and would recommend it to anyone who'd listen.

Purple Rice Yogurt - 100/10

On a trip to Sydney, Australia over two years ago, I was walking and saw a massive line out of a shop. Curious, I went to investigate, and turns out it was an Asian drink place.

A variation on the boba concept where you get a drinkwith a textural contrast to chew on, this is a yogurt based drink with rice. The rice reminds me of a red/wild rice that has a nice texture and chew to it.

I was obsessed and had this drink multiple times while I was over there. Given the success in Australia, I was convinced this would come to the US at some point.

Now years later, when I was walking around Chinatown and saw this sign for this place inside Happy Veggie, I got super excited. But unfortunately it did not match the original at all. It was gummy, and had a raw powdery taste to it. It's a great chain, and probably staff just needs more training on how to make the drink.

If you're curious about this drink, and you like yogurt, I'd say this is well worth a try. Don't go in expecting a variation on boba, because it really isn't. The purple rice in their signature drink is a major component, not just a topping. Also - this is a given, but just in case - don't come if you don't like yogurt.

Yomie's Yogurt is located in the Happy Veggie restaurant on Mott St. Their menu is comprised of desserts with a drinkable yogurt base, though when thickened by purple rice or other starchy mix-ins, it's more of a spoonable texture. It's not exactly the same, but very reminiscent of the yogurt you'd get in China - drinkable, but also a unique kind of tartness.

I had the purple rice yogurt last month, i.e. when the store was so new it wasn't even on yelp, and returned today with a friend for more fruit-based yogurts (passionfruit and mango pomelo sago). We shared and enjoyed both - these fruity combinations work really well with this yogurt. I did not personally experience anything resembling gumminess or chalkiness in any of these drinks. They're literally not even paying me to write this lol but the sole preexisting review was not at all my experience over my two visits, so I feel obligated to share my own.

Orders cost between $5-8. Other combinations include ube, oatmeal, melon, avocado, melon AND avocado, and dragonfruit (and more). They're very filling and not too sweet. I don't know if they're healthier than boba, but I love both boba AND yogurt in general, and I'd definitely go back again. In Chinatown, where there are a lot of boba shops and dessert cafes, this is a very specific but unique addition.
The one in queens is maddd good... this one not so much.. we had ice crunch in the drink when it's usually velvety smooth

Even if they never win awards for their sub-standard Canto fare, I'm still extremely thankful Yue Wong is even around. As a post-pandemic version from their previous iteration as Yee Li (#1), they are now among the few classic Chinatown Canto spots with the window siu mei (#2). The Chinese name is still mostly the same (旺 instead of 利) but nothing has changed with the food, staff, most of the menu, and the vibe. I'm here for it.

As a corner establishment on Bayard and Mott, this place gets a lot more visibility than other places on the same block. If it's not the hanging roast duck or bbq pork in the windows that hook most onlookers, it's the guarantee of knowing that the Canto game is alive and well is enough for me to step in.

The staff works hard and the place is pretty busy on the weekends. The seating will feel tight with the low ceilings and cramped round tables, but small groups will tend to do well here. Most of the wait staff speaks Canto and cash is generally preferred.

To be honest, I'm not sure much of anything stands out here food wise. I've had my share of their bbq meats (roast duck, bbq pork, siu yuk roast pig, etc.) and it was all decent. The same goes for their seafood, I think their steamed fish and ginger scallion lobster is also solid. The other dishes are somewhere in the middle, from their yee stir fried noodles to the yeung chow fried rice. I haven't found a super memorable dish, but I'm definitely open to trying more.

I'm hoping in time that things change for the better. The bathrooms aren't all that fabulous and the food while decent overall, could always use a bit of improvement. I sense it'll be only be matter of time before I'm back and when I am, I am hoping things will be on the up and up.
___________
(#1) yelp.com/biz/yee-li-rest…
(#2) Canto BBQ.

I I liked the atmosphere in this place. However, the food was not super tasty. The soup dumplings lacked in taste and were not very well down as they easily broke. Buddha's delight, a vegetarian dish, was more or less tasteless while the noodles were oversalted. The roasted duck was very good though.
They then sat random couples together on one big round table even though there was enough other seating....
Fresh seafood fresh seafood. Quick service and a great location in the heart of Chinatown. There is zero ambiance. Still the food was amazing. Tip: you might need to share a table

Yesterday I stopped by here while waiting for my dog to finish being groomed. I ordered the Char Siu/Roast Pork and the wonton soup.

Wonton Soup: This was good, you could tell these were homemade. They were generous with the pork and the wonton skin was not too thick.

Roast Pork: Unbelievable sweet, it was way too sweet. I thought I was going to go into hyperglycemic shock from how sweet it was. The meat was also slightly overcooked. The presentation was good, but the flavor was not there and was certainly nowhere near Wah Fung no.1 in terms of taste.

Overall: It seems some dishes can be hit or miss here, stick with the wonton soup.  I likely will not be back though since there's better places nearby.

Fantastic place to grab a quick bite. Ample seats and there is a restroom for guests. Roast pork had a good amount of fat and the skin was very crispy. Interior was clean and the space filled up quickly during lunchtime. Right next door to Mei Lai Wah too!

Came in on a weekend afternoon for a little pick me up.

No tap water available, and the noodles (we got the house signature) wasn't super flavorful. The meat was good though.

They have some big tables for bigger groups. They also assigned their own tip amount on the bill...

It's an okay spot - just lots of other great places in the area that I'd rather be trying. I'd possibly pick up to-go BBQ Pork in the future, though!
very pleasant hospitable and accomodating service..food is on time and tasty..the place is clean.

So the Great NY Noodle town is currently closed down for renovations. I came to China Town for some Cantonese BBQ items and my wonton noodle soup.

This place is so disappointing that it gave me EMOTIONAL DAMAGE.

Lets start with the wonton noodle soup - the broth is bland. It tasted like watered down chicken stock. The wonton had pork and shrimp filling - the filling had no flavor and it was poorly wrapped and thick. The noodle in the soup was clumpy and sticking together. It seems they made the noodles and just let it sit for a WHILE before adding the soup. You know you screwed up when i had to add soy sauce and siracha into the soup.

Next thing we ordered was the seafood pan fried noodles. It was a soggy mess with no flavor. My husband thought that they just put too much sauce and I said no - they didn't correctly pan fried the noodles. They just coated the noodles with oil. Two very different things.

Third thing I ordered was the soy sauce chicken. This item was not bad. Probably the best thing they had there. At this point I'm not sure if it was good because the other two items were pathetic.

Failure in both cooking technique and flavor.

0/10
Came here on Chinese new year day. Waited about 30 minutes for a table (as expected) Food came out quick and everything was delicious. Service was great considering they were swamped.

Was hungry after a day of vacationing in New York City.

Menu selections included 2 noodle dishes and a fried rich.

Orders came out hot and tasteful!

Hot water for tea filled regularly.

Price was reasonable.

One of my favorite places to grab lunch or dinner from. They offer all the classic Cantonese dishes as well as your choice of bbq and roasted meats. Everything from their crunchy skin pork and bbq pork (cha siew) to roast duck or scallion chicken is succulent and tasty.
The roast meats are average at best. It was good but definitely not overwhelming that I would run back to

Not seeing any Asians in Yue Wong Restaurant should have been a clear signal that something was amiss. Steamed shrimp dumpling were okay. Roasted duck over rice was not. The duck meat was not flavorful and the color of the skin lacked the glistening inviting color and taste that Great NY Noodletown is famous for. Equally pale sliced cabbage was served with this dish. I ate as much as I could as I was paying and don't like to waste money. What I do know is that I won't be returning.

Skip Wah Fung No 1 and come here. The BBQ meats are better here and are of higher quality. I love going with this trio on rice: roast duck, char siu and roast pig on rice. The roast pig was super crispy and caught my attention while gawking at the meat chopper. It looked super juicy and well marbled with fat. Just a little bit of this once in a while will fill your heart favorite  

Cheers

7/10 food
7/10 service
5/10 ambiance

I came on a Tuesday night and sat down for dinner. I ordered the bbq pork over rice, roast duck, wonton noodle soup and Xiao long bao. The food was ok, nothing amazing but also not bad. Pork and duck weren't too dry and soup dumplings were juicy. Service was prompt with the exception of forgetting our tea when he had gone to refill it. Ambiance is what you'd expect from a typical Chinese takeout restaurant. Casual, no frills kind of establishment.

Wednesday, May 24, 2023 @ 2 p.m.
Ordered a Beef Stew and a filled of fish with dry tofu sheets.
They asked me to pay before order was put in which was fine with me
When my order came up from the kitchen not, the lady who took my order but, the other older lady opened my fish dish and took half of it out while I watched her.
This is a horrible practice and I do not recommend any business that does this nor will I be returning here.

Sometimes we just come here for a quarter roast duck ($6.50... I think). Omggg they consistently make the best roast duck in Chinatown! (But don't quote me on that, double check the window to see what you're working with first!!) it's perfectly cooked- crispy skin, great sauce, not too fat, super meaty!!

This corner over the last many years has been occupied by various different Chinese restaurants and I've gone to at least 5 or 6 of them.
Currently, the Restaurant is 'Yue Wong', what I look for besides fresh tasty well cooked food when I go to Chinatown is a wait staff that's friendly and responsive.

I went last week and had an urge for Singapore Mai Fun which I don't have that often but I like a bit of curry flavor now and then.
The Singapore Mai Fun was very good, came out hot (not just warm) and surprisingly an abundant portion size... couldn't finish it and took the remainder home.
Very tasty with a good amount of shrimps, pork/ham/eggs/onion/green and red bell peppers.

Another thing I like is roast pork over rice, I can ask for "lean" and the 'chopper' gives me lean pieces not the usual common fatty pieces you get in most places.

I have been going to Chinatown for 63 years... since I was 6 years old, I usually go once a week and shop for my vegetables and fruits.

I have 3 different places I go for food 'Yue Wong' is one of them, the others are '456' on Mott street and 'New Green Bo' on Bayard street.

The Soy Chicken was surprisingly the best thing. It was the best soy chicken I've had in new york, literally so tender and juicy.  Then the crispy pig, then the roast pork and the Duck, the duck was tasty but I found it to be too oily. This place has only a few review yet I see a larger line here then most places which means the locals know.
Tip: when you order the roast pork and pig you give them a weight in pounds or half pounds and when you order duck or chicken you order either half or full.
Roast Pig = crispy pork
Roast pork = bbq pork
1/2lb= is half the container
1lb is the full amount you are seeing in the photos

This place is a scam and the food is bad.

They charged me 4.00$ for a can of ginger ale (the price was not listed on the menu), and my friend 4.00$ for a can of coke. Absolutely outrageous. Without notifying the customer they factor a 25% tip into the check despite terrible service (they refused to come to our table twice to take our order, and seated us with people we did not know). Mind you we were a party of two so said factoring made no sense. They wrote the items on the check in Chinese so we had no way of verifying the prices, and when I confronted this warner he seemed very dismissive and annoyed. Very sketchy place, and the food was mediocre Chinese at best.  Please avoid these scam artists.

1 Star.

If you get BBQ rice plates here be sure to check your order. They are very disorganized here. I asked for some ginger scallion sauce and asked the lady if she heard me because she seemed to ignore my request. She said she heard me but then of course I didn't get the sauce.

*Quarantine Pick-up Review*

Yue Wong used to be Yee Li, which was my grandparent's favorite restaurant in Chinatown. I saw on Yelp that they had re-opened under Yue Wong, so I decided to check it out for some Chinese BBQ. Their hours right now are 10:30 to 6. I arrived a little before 10:30 and there was already a line of people waiting outside. I ordered some siew yook and some cha siew and both were great. The siew yook came with this sticky and sweet sauce that I really liked. The cha siew is very sweet and a bit on the saltier side, but it's nothing a steaming hot bowl of white rice can't fix. My only regret is not ordering some of their non-Chinese BBQ items. My favorite when it used to be Yee Li was the General Tso's chicken (yes, I know - not very authentic but it was SO good!). Will definitely be back!

Disappointing all around.  While the portion size was generous, meals were rather bland.  The menu photos made it seem as though the "over rice" dishes came with fried rice but it was bland white rice.  The meats had many many little bones making it necessary to eat carefully.  Was only given a fork and couldn't cut the meat.

The floor was sticky and slippery.

However, my wife thought the spring roll was delicious

I ordered the roast duck over rice and the shrimp dumplings since they didn't have half their appetizers available. When I asked about the rice rolls the waitress just quietly shook her head and I was confused what she meant by that. But anyway I was served tea first (wondering if I was even charged for it based off someone else's review) and shortly the duck came out first and it was not hot. It had lots of bones making it difficult to get a bite of the meat but it was pretty fatty and good. The waitress didn't really speak as she brought out our food either so the overall vibe here was a bit sad. The shrimp dumplings came out late and we just went to the front to pay. I thought I would just be able to pay and go, but the waitress quickly asked me to tip her because she served me. I didn't mind tipping but I'm realizing it was awkward because I paid in cash and couldn't calculate anything so if you're not from here make sure to tip them for subpar service!

Saturday night, mostly a non Chinese crowd. They ran out of wonton noodles by 8 pm so ordered the fried beef chow fun instead. Also ordered a plateroasted pork. Food was below average. The chow fun was not hot, just luke warm, it was also not seasoned, no flavor. It also seemed like they haven't cleaned the wok in a while, getting burned pieces mixed in with the dish. Added a bunch of soy sauce because the noodles came out almost white. None of us finished our dishes. Would not recommend.

8.2/10

Three meats over rice: very flavorful; soy sauce chicken juicy; char siu was tender; duck was far too fatty with very little meat; overall, great flavor, not exceptional

I believe this restaurant is only selling take out meats at the moment. I ordered the crispy roast pork ($11/lb) and half a duck ($13). The roast pork was delicious, lean with the skin still crispy, just as I like it. They probably has fattier cuts if you prefer that. The duck was also very good and not as oily as the ones from other places. They also sell whole roast pigs which are around 33lbs.

FOOD IS NOT CLEAN. I got the singapore lo mein. Taste was ok, 6/10. But the real kicker is, not even an hour later my stomach was CHURNING. Sorry if this is tmi but I had explosive diarrhea from eating here. And I can be sure it was this place because I didn't have outside food during the morning, I ate at home and then had an early dinner here. Had nothing after this place. DON'T COME HERE.

after not eating anything for the day I was starving and our family was heading to Chinatown. this was the first place we saw so we went here. The first thing I noticed was the prices, for being NY they where extremely cheap. The size of the portions are super big and tasted extremely good. if customer service is important to you I might reconsider going here as it wasn't the best, but I dont care about customer service as long as the food is good

Came here for lunch with Boo Boo and mi Ma. This place changed owners. There's a noticeable face lift after Yee Li left. There's new floor, new tables, and the fish are in clear water.

We shared the soy sauce chicken, roasted duck, Buddha delight casserole, land casserole, roasted pork and Chinese broccoli.

I was disappointed they don't serve congee. Almost every time I'm at Ctown I get congee with black fermented egg and I ask that it's topped with ginger oil that is served with the soy sauce chicken.

I also brought home the BBQ pork for my work meal prep. That was tasty too.

Overall, the cooked dishes needed more seasoning. It's more for the older generation's palate like my mom's. But, the BBQ items like the roast pork, soy sauce chicken and duck were great fresh.

It has been a while since I been to Yue Wong Restaurant. Currently- the restaurant dining area is closed. One patron behind us waiting asked for a menu. Staff said no menu. The only items sold here were hanging duck, chicken, and roast meats hung up that were visible at the window display area. Yes, staff all wearing mask and plexiglass barrier between store and patrons. Place order- pay and staff pushes bag out for you to take.

Got whole chicken chopped for $24 bucks. Had the scallion chicken it was not salty and very delicious. Will be back for more roast meats.

Once we entered the restaurant the girl told ask to the 1st table. I asked if we could sit on the back and she said the 1st table you don't need to mix with other people. We did agree with her and we sat.  After a few minutes she put 2 other people to our table. Is this making any sense she just said? After 5 minutes when a couple of people went in  she told them to sit in the back. Clearly she knows those people. She is a liar!

HORRIBLE! AVOID! They literally tricked money from us. When we came back and complained that the amount on the receipt didn't go along with the prices on the menu they made something up and refused to give us our money back.

Btw. the food was bad too.

The dining room's back open for business.

Significant uplift on the prices for the takeout bbq meats windows.

When we lost Yee Li at this site I was happy to see Yue Wong emerge. While I loved the staff and food at Yee Li, the new management here has cleaned the place up with a new basic interior and restrooms and a more inviting live fish tank as you enter. The food now, however, is mixed. The BBQ meat appetizers are good--but they've raised the price for roast duck to $11.50 (higher than the roast pig for instance) and the portions are smaller. The dim sum and soup dumplings are fine. When I asked for the curried rice noodles (Singapore Mei Fun) with chow fun noodles they accommodated me, but the other entrees are more problematic. We ordered their pork belly with vegetables ($18.95) and while the vegetables were good the pork belly was as tough and chewy as could be. (Pork belly needs to be slow cooked to be tender not stir fried.) If you want pork, stick with the roast pig appetizer. They made a beef with string beans dish for us (off menu for $18.95) as it was one we loved at Yee Li. But while the beef was tender enough the string beans were sadly overcooked. At one visit they provided glasses of iced tap water when asked. At another they outright refused and said we had to order bottled water if we wanted it. That is really unacceptable. They put (lukewarm) tea on the table when you sit down.

Have only gotten roast Duck to go from here. Comes with duck sauce. It's ok, but they place older meat under the new cut meat. The place is no frills and not that appetizing to eat in, but  for take out it's ok.

This place used  to be Yi Lee Restaurant. They closed a  few months ago for renovations. I was worried they wouldn't be coming back. This definitely seems to be the same operation under a new name.

I love coming to get the roast pork and roast duck available for take-away. The prices can't be beat.

Definitely worth a stop while you're in Chinatown!

This place deserves all your attention. I'm from the SGV born and raised where this was all I ate growing up and I haven't had better than this place. The roast pork is so juicy and not over marinaded. The ducks fat is perfectly rendered.

Fire Sam bo fan. I think this place is way better than wah fung. Their meats are tender. Super juicy and very flavorful. They give a perfect portion of veggies rice and meat. Hands down the best. I always come back for more.
Food was amazing. They are very generous with their portions. Tips are included. Friendly staff.

Just got their half lean & fatty roast pork on rice & it came with broccoli. The price is good it nice it comes with a veggie, but there's this weird spice taste to the broccoli which I thought @1st was the rice which it wasn't. As for the pork is good but the seasoning they use...doesn't make to tasty. They only use 5 spices but old authentic Cantonese roast pork has a nice honey glazed which this doesn't have. Using 5 spices is a cheaper & faster way to cook but doesn't necessarily mean the food is tasty. I may try this place again for the bbq pork and duck...let's see if they can redeem themselves.
The duck was cold and everything else was quite subpar. The fried rice was ok, nothing special

I usually only go to Sun Sai Gai but they are still closed due to COVID. I found parking in front of this place and decided to give it a try...: I'm so glad I did! The duck was so succulent, well seasoned and not super fatty or greasy. Absolutely delicious. The roast pig with crispy skin was amazing and the roast pork was just okay. I wish they had noodles or fried rice etc available but they are currently only serving the roast meat from the window with white rice and regular steamed, unseasoned broccoli. I didn't care though because I was there mostly for the duck which did not disappoint!

Generous size portions, service is great, free tea and house soup during lunchtime. I ordered bitter melon with beef in black bean sauce over rice. The meet was very flavorful and marinated well and tender.   這家餐廳的食物和服務都很好。
Great Chinese shao la. Reasonably priced. Chicken liver and stomach also very good. Some times open late.

Came here with the family on a Sunday night. Food was okay. However, the staff were quite absent minded. One server tried to take the menu away from us while we were still in the process of ordering and had the audacity to throw the menu back at my father (red flag one).  It was clear they were trying to rush us as they served us cold duck (red flag two). Then, we had to ask multiple times for water for the table and to go boxes -- we ended up getting the boxes ourselves as the servers were busy -- counting money.
Was so happy to see Yee Li reopen as Yue Wong. The roast duck here is as good as ever! They are very generous with their meat over rice combination portions

Covid-19 Pickup: I hadn't been down to Chinatown since March, and I'm glad I didn't look up Yee Li, because I would have been too sad to know that they closed. Yesterday I just crossed my fingers and hoped that the duck was there and hanging in the window - and it was! Not currently open for sit-down service (don't know if that will change by the end of the month). But the roast duck is still incredible and very decently portioned and priced. So grateful that they still exist and are keeping up the delicious standards!

This place is a gem! We might have seen this place on IG or TikTok, to be honest, so maybe a hidden one for not so long.

We got here with a party of maybe 6 or 7 and waited 45 minutes.

Let me tell you, the wait was worth it. We all got ourselves a bowl of noodles. The spicy original was not too spicy but spicy enough for all the hot food lovers out there. Each bowl came with a variety of toppings/ingredients to put into the hotpot. There are unlimited rice noodles if that's the noodle option you get, which is partly the appeal of this place, but honestly, after one bowl of noodles and a taste of a few sides, I was full! Satisfied, too!

I found out about Yunshang through Tiktok as one does, where they advertise themselves as an unlimited refill noodle shop. Challenge accepted.

When I visited early Friday evening, the restaurant was packed and I waited outside for about 15 minutes until a table was ready. Throughout my meal, I saw plenty of people come and go so this joint is definitely a popular one. They offer a more casual interpretation of a Yunnan style crossing-the-bridge noodle, where for $12 you can choose your preferred soup flavor and noodles. Your meal comes with 12 little side dishes; some, like a quail egg or bean curd skin, are quite traditional and some, like fish tofu and corn, are a bit more modern. I tried three of the soups (tomato, spicy sauce, and spicy pickled pepper) and would definitely recommend the tomato as it is on the milder side. I also ordered some lamb skewers ($2 ea) which were surprisingly stellar. They were juicy and meaty and well-seasoned; definitely would recommend.

Not bad but not great. Yes, this place does bottomless noodles but I'm not too sure it that makes this place worth it.

I think you can be deceived by the sides but it tastes its been out for an entire day and not really fresh. The octopus legs were way more gamey than normal and not fried like advertised, very... soggy instead. Overall food taste was mediocre, not to mention the service here is really terrible.

Apps:
-Fried tofu (crispy & tasty) can be less sauce
-Spicy beef (yummy) prefer less peanuts
-shredded potato (good)

Noodle:
-tomato soup based rice noodle with beef
Delicious! Hot! Would order again! Huge portion.

Service:
EXCELLENT!

The only thing is the bathroom smelled very bad :(

What a good deal! For only ~$11 dollars, you can get a classic noodle soup with 12 sides in Chinatown. While each side is pretty small, I loved the variety and combined with all the noodles and soup, it became a very filling meal. Apparently, this style of sides and rice noodles in pork broth is a classic Yunnan-region dish.

The restaurant is quite nice by Chinatown standard with clean tables and a decent amount of seats. The food came out super quickly after we ordered but the service was a bit inattentive when trying to pay the check at the end or get water refills.

Overall, the service slowness was very minor and I would strongly recommend this place if you want a cheap and filling meal!

Exactly what we needed on a rainy day in NYC - warm, comforting, and a great deal considering how much food you get for the price. Walked in at 5pm and were seated immediately.

Taiwan Style Sausage - 4/5

Original Rice Noodle Soup + Fish Fillet - 4/5

Rice Noodle Soup with Tomato - 3.8/5 (friend's rating)

Overall, great food and service. My only complaint would be that the bathroom wasn't the cleanest.

This is a great deal!! All in, the meal was around $15, which I think is really great. I loved the platter of toppings and being able to pick and choose what was going into my soup. The soup was super hearty, and the rice noodles were nicely chewy. My friend and I were both too full to go beyond the one bowl of rice noodles that was given in the beginning, but I think that just goes to show how filling this meal is. It's always great to have the option for more if you want it!

The restaurant was small but didn't feel too cramped. The service was nice and everything came out quickly.

Wifie saw a tik-tok on this restaruant which seemed fun so we made it a point to stop by.

It was around noon on Sunday and the place was all packed. There was a wait list  kiosk in front of us as soon as we entered.  We entered a name and a cell phone number.  Immediately we got a text, stating we were #12.   We wondered around the neighborhood for 15 minutes and decided to go back and check even though we did not get any text.  Strangely, we got seated after we asked for status of the waitlist.  Seriously, it appeared that no one ever get texted - at least that's how we felt.  So it pays to check personally instead of relying on text.

The menu look complicated and we were a bit lost because the a la carte add-ons are listed below each soup base choice. It's not clear if the soup base comes with anything.  Once you know, it's really easy and I'm telling you now:  

Just pick a soup you like, and choose the default rice noodle.

THAT IS ALL YOU NEED TO DO!   You pay the price listed for the soup base, which comes with 10 toppings by default.  You can change the rice noodle to glass noodle or Shanghai noodle for $1.50 more.   You can have unlimited noodles, but I don't think most people can handle more than 2 servings.  We came out totally stuffed.

It was indeed fun place to try.  In a way it's like a mini hot pot.  That being said, the service was really a big mixed bag.  First, the wait-list system seems state of the art but I don't think the staff processed the workflow at all!  Second, we waited for nearly 20 minutes for the soup base to come.  That was a long time, but we suspect they were batched and we simply missed the previous batch.   Finally, there was just 1 super waiter who handle the entire store, (plus one guy at the register, and a bus boy who served out the food).  As a result, we had to request 3 times before we finally got the extra serving of rice noodle and we had to request twice before getting our bill -- even though we were so impressed each time they acknowledged us even though they were totally swamped. Effectively, they acknowledge as a way to placate but had no plan for action.   It's frustrating and amusing at the same time.  Rare experience.

I got the mushroom broth and added beef. The broth here is very clean and definitely a good bang for your buck. You put the noodles and toppings in and let the clay pot cook everything.

I also got a chicken skewer which was crispy on the outside, very flavorful and was juicy on the inside.

4/5 overall - solid spot, good price, though nothing jaw dropping.

My friend and I decided to come here for a dinner date in Chinatown during a hot summer night. It was my first time but I was already excited to try the food based on all the rave reviews on Yelp!

I was impressed with how affordable the noodles were, it gave off a hotpot vibe when I was looking at the options. Both my friend and I went with the tomato base soup for a more refreshing meal. There was a bunch of toppings (enough to fill a whole tray!) for you to put in the soup broth, along with some strips of pork belly. Although there was a lot of variety, after I put it in the soup, it disappeared and I feel like barely made a difference. They only served 4 pork belly strips so it would help to order another side dish to go with it. Tomato base soup was exactly as I imagined - a little tart and savory at the same time. We got the cold spicy chicken and that was pretty decent. Service was good and quick. I would definitely come back to try their other soup bases if I'm looking for a quick cheap meal.

Their hours are till 5AM as of the time i'm writing this review so it's a nice spot for late night food. Most places in Chinatown are closed by 10PM so I'm really glad this spot exists. They have a lot of different soup bases for their noodles but my favorite are tomato and curry. They also offer 3 types of noodles: regular, shanghai noodles and glass noodles. They offer free refills of the regular noodles. They recently expanded their menu to include crayfish.

Servers are bilingual and they're nice even when they're busy. Place is clean and they accept credit card.

Ordered the Yunshang rice noodle with spicy sauce. It comes with 10 toppings. The portion of the meat (pork belly) was small, but it's $12 dollar, so I am not complaining. I did add a lamb topping to fully enjoy this.

Also it offers unlimited noodle refills (whaaat?!)

Good service and typical Chinese restaurant vibes. Pretty clean overall

Love this spot in Chinatown! I've been here with friends and just on a solo lunch as well. Incredibly affordable comfort meal with so many offerings. We had some of the appetizers too -- the chicken was so juicy and flavorful and the fried tofu was a great starter.

Essentially, you get your own bowl of very hot soup and they give you noodles and 10+ toppings to include in the soup.

A cute spot for really affordable noodle sets!

Sets start around $11 and they give you 10 free sides to put in your noodles!
It's less dingy than hole in the wall chinatown spots and service is quick! Great spot for groups too- they have larger tables in the back to accommodate large groups.

Soups are well seasoned and if you like things like hotpot or kbbq- putting all of your own noodles and sides in is a delightful experience :)

The food is good, but the service is lacking. When our server came to take our order, he basically half-heartedly grunted when I ordered the spicy noodles, and my friend ordered the pork with pickled cabbage. I found it kind of funny, but then a few seconds later, he came back to clarify what my friend ordered because he completely forgot... We only ordered 2 things!
The table, menu, and utensils aren't the cleanest, but I mainly come here for a hearty noodle dish at a good price. There is a variety of side dishes that come along with it, and you are allowed refills on the noodles.

A small chain that mainly serves a steaming stone pot soup where you add a variety of toppings and chewy noodles. Its a great spot if you're craving noodles or a warm broth. The texture of the noodles was great, though I think the soup lacked a bit of flavor (still pretty good though). I would recommend the original soup if it's your first time trying, the pickled soup was slightly odd.

Other than the food, the place is well decorated and service is responsive. Food was also extremely affordable and their appetizer was HUGE.

Party Size - 2
Price - $40 (we were extremely full).

Cheap, good hot meal, open (very) late and leaves you satisfied!
It definitely doesn't hurt that there's options for an "all you can eat" noodle refill and for some noodles under $15, seems unheard of for NYC standards!

It's not a fancy place, but it's not a complete dive either! The huge warm broth comes in many flavors and I got to sample the sour fish and tomato. It's what we call in Chinese "appetizing" in a way you just want to keep eating. The variety of toppings are fun and the noodles are good and bouncy.

My friends insisted that I should stop by to visit this place and I finally did. First, the food was cheap and the service was fast. It was everything I pictured. The noodles were delicious, but the cripsy salt chicken and soup needed extra seasoning/more flavor. I ordered the coconut curry but I found myself adding extra spices. The place was clean and spacious and it was not overcrowded. In terms of customer services, I was not pleased. We asked the waiter a few questions and he was sassy and rude with his response. Besides that, I highly recommend this place. If you want noddles and soup then you should visit!

We were in Chinatown for a different Yelp Event, I think it was for Kam Hing Bakery and we decided to try a place in the area. I was hunkering for noodles (as I always am), and my husband found this place.
I wasn't sure what to expect because when you look at the menu it's a little confusing. I don't remember which one we got but I think we both got the original. It comes with separate toppings and a large clay-pot bowl with the noodles. You add the toppings first and then add the noodles. It looks like a lot when you see it but it's not that large of a portion when you actually start eating it. Everything is really good and I would go back and try something different next time around.
It's not expensive, the service is fast, and the place is always bustling. We got there when it was still a little empty, but halfway through it filled up. So get there early if you want a seat. Unfortunately, I did not take a great photo but next time I go I will take more pictures.

Ordered extra beef for the rice noodles. But they just directly put the beef into the boiling soup instead of preparing it separately, causing blood foams floating in the soup.

Aside from that the soup base was actually quite good considering that they claimed there was no MSG in their foods.

The toppings for the rice noodles weren't good at all. I think it'll be a huge improvement if they increase the quality of toppings through raising the price per bowl.

Looking for a spot for noodles without a line, we dropped by yunshang rice noodle house in Chinatown, NYC.

This noodle house is a small chain where you get a steaming stone pot of soup with noodles and a ton of toppings. Drop your rice noodles in the soup and release them with your chopsticks and drop all the toppings with your meal. It's simply a warming bowl of yunshang style rice noodles. On our trip here, the food hit the spot - however the service didn't as we were awkwardly asked to wait while there were several open and available tables for 4 since we were a party of two.

Service aside, this is a great spot if you are craving noodles during the later night hours since restaurants usually close before 10pm in this area. Also, it is Vegetarian friendly - but just make sure to ask your waiter/waitress to get you the vegetarian version of the soups and replace the meat toppings when you order.

This place is excellent! You get what you order so there's no mystery. I like spicy so I ordered curry soup base and rice noodles. All the toppings the soup comes with complement the whole dish nicely. Even when the place gets crowdy, it doesn't get too loud. I'll try their other spicy soups on my next visit.

Came here with my boyfriend on a Saturday afternoon for some rice noodle to warm ourselves up in this cold weather! I normally like to order spicy broth whenever I'm eating rice noodle but since I was wearing white that day and I didn't want to ruin my shirt, I went with the mushroom broth with rice noodle. Other than rice noodle, we also got fried squid tentacle and 2 lamb and 2 beef skewers.

Skewers: 5/5! These skewers were a little different from the Chinese skewers that I have tried in the past. These skewers had some sauce on it and had less cumin. Different but still delicious! I personally like the lamb more because the beef was a little chewier.

Squid tentacles: 5/5! I love eating squid especially the tentacles! Love the cumin seasoning on them!

Mushroom rice noodle: 4/5 The broth was in a stone bowl that kept the broth hot the whole time. The broth was good but I wish the flavor would be more intense. I wasn't aware that the noodle itself already came with some pork slices and I ordered extra beef for 2.99. I don't think it was really worth it since they didn't really give a lot of beef slices. I would recommend to get the skewers instead if you want more meat.

Overall, both my boyfriend and I enjoyed our meals here! The total was around $65 with tips and tax which was not bad since we got extra toppings for the noodle and some appetizers! This place allows you to get unlimited refill on rice noodle for FREE! We didn't get any extra noodle since we were already full with all the food that we ordered but this is a great place to go if you're starving and want to save some money!

Food (5/5): I got the Yunnan original and some others in my group got the Yunnan spicy. The original was really delicious. The texture of the noodles were amazing and I liked how this was a mini hotpot experience. It was also nice how you get free noodle refills.

Venue (3/5): It's an OK venue with a decent amount of seating and some interesting Asian decorations. There was only one bathroom. Overall average setup.

Service (2/5): Some friends of mine can't eat pork due to religious dietary restrictions. Shockingly the server acted extremely rudely when they asked if they can substitute out any pork ingredients with an alternative. The server flipped out and said no they can't switch out ingredients and provide pork alternatives, they'll be given the pork regardless, and he ignorantly seemed to have zero care of their dietary restrictions. We had to calm him down before he finally gave some care about how important that dietary restriction was. Finally he recommended some soups that didn't have pork but still couldn't switch out the pork in the set. Fortunately the ingredients were separated and my friends just avoided the pork. I still don't understand why the server acted so rudely. Besides that, the service was OK with food coming out fast and they checked up to give us water and noodle refills.

I stumbled upon this place as it was one of the only dine -in places open nearby after 11pm and I am so glad I did! I needed a late night filling meal and this definitely did the trick! I was seated at this casual restaurant within 10 mins.

As the name suggests, they are a noodle house and their entrees are filling noodle soups. They also do have an array of appetizers ranging from fries to chicken wings.

To start, I got the salty crispy chicken!  I got this ordered right away and was enjoying it within the next 5 mins! I was impressed with the fast delivery of the the food and service I received. The chicken was well made and there was a spicy dipping sauce to accompany them. Then, my soup came out. The main star of the meal was definitely the rice noodle soup. I got the original and added mushrooms to mine. The soup came piping hot with an assortment of free soup additions. The broth was flavorful and rich. There were pieces of pork in it as well! I wanted a kick to my soup so I asked the servers for some hot sauce. Once I added that in, it was a 10/10. The rice noodles were perfectly chewy and as a bonus, they offered free refills! I couldn't even finish the first serving but for those looking for more, I would definitely suggest coming here.

Overall this meal was hearty and super affordable. If you're looking for a comfort meal at a reasonable price point, pay this place a visit.

We happened to walk by this place and were pleasantly surprised by our discovery. We ordered spicy and original as well as the skewers.
As soon as we walked in, we were seated in and the service was great and fast. Plenty of people in the restaurant.
They teach you how to eat the noodles on the menu and every broth comes with 12 ingredients to place in the broth.
Overall a great experience and amazing taste

First time trying this place and would come here often whenever I'm craving some hot noodle soup. Me and my friend got the tomato soup and the spicy soup, both were good but I prefer the tomato soup. Tomato soup was so flavorful and I really love how you can ask for unlimited noodles. All noodle soup dishes comes with 12 free toppings.
Service was fast and quick, workers were friendly. Came on a Friday night at around 8 and they still had couple of tables open.

I would always walk pass the restaurant, but have not had a chance to try it out until recently when I had the chance to dine-in. We arrived early evening for dinner and the restaurant was just full so we waited for a bit before getting seated.

Once seated, we looked at the menu and ordered the original rice noodle soup (2), salty crispy chicken, and fried buns with condensed milk. The soup was well seasoned and there was a variety of different ingredients into the soup so one can always have something with the noodles. The two appetizers were also good.

Overall, I enjoyed the rice noodles and would go back again to try the other noodle soups.
Tip for those who order a few things to try along with the noodle soup itself, one can request to have all the ingredients that would go into the soup pre-added to be cooked together before it is brought out so that it would take up less space on the table. However, if one would like to add in each ingredient him/ herself then this is not necessary.

I wanted noodles so badly after my 20K+ step day in NYC so we headed right to Chinatown.  The tomato broth was very delicious as was the beef. The fried tofu was really good and i'm glad our waiter recommended it. Overall a solid place to fill your noodle cravings.
Food was very tasty. However, they don't give you much of the other toppings, so we got extra meat. I love soup so this was amazing to me, overall very positive experience.

Hearty, flavorful, delicious, and way worth its price.
For starters, you get a lot of small little banchan-like side dishes which make the experience more fun and delicious! I have definitely returned in less than a week after the first nood entered my mouth and ordered about an indefinite amount more times after that.

Service is incredibly fast, and the place is pretty clean too! You can't really go wrong with anything you order here.

What we got:

Hot Noodle Soup - 9/10 Great flavor and great heat! Pleasantly painful which should be the point. You need a little pain in life.

Sauerkraut Fish Stew - 10/10 Best I've ever had. Explains why I've ordered this so many times afterwards.

Lamb Kebabs - 7/10 I usually like these DOUSED in spices. Cook was perfect though!

Side dishes - 9/10 I love this concept so much and if you don't like one of the side dishes you can forgo them anyways! Doesn't matter since they're all great and introduce different textures and flavors. Wish they gave more but that's just my stomach talking.

Best late night noodle shop in Chinatown. Simple menu ended up being perfect for indecisive and slightly inebriated friends late at night.

Best part is the unlimited rice noodle refills. Yes, you heard me correctly. UNLIMITED. FREE. NOODLES!

Also the price was super affordable, especially given the super large portions we received.

Food doesn't taste good as it looks.  Won't go again.
Service staff are OK but sometimes too busy to get back to request.

Great choice for a casual meal of rice noodles in Chinatown. Have been here a few times getting the Original Rice Noodle Soup with the Pork and Fish Balls and with either the Fish Filet or the Seafood.

The soup base is flavorful without being overly salty or greasy and the noodles are plentiful.

Second time here and still really liked the spicy broth rice noodle 米线 added beef balls and cilantro. Also got the lamb, beef, and chicken skewers. They were good but were a tad sweet for me. Service was attentive and friendly!

I am obsessed with this simple noodle and soup place. I love that you get to add in the toppings that you want and that there are soup options. The first time I visited YunShang Rice Noodle was at the Brooklyn location for an event. The noodles were perfect on a cold day and warmed me up.

The food is also delicious and the service is pretty good. Always happy with the food. The service is pretty good. They don't hover over you and to get there attention you just raise your hand. When they are not busy the serve is on his phone and not looking around much, so you might have to go up to his to ask him for what you need but that isn't a big deal. A

Noodles are always delicious. They also serve unlimited noodle refills for eating in. It will cost $1 per additional noodle serving if you want to take the food to go.

They also have crawfish that I didn't really like, but the star here is the noodle soup, so I'll just continue getting the noodle soup, forget the crawfish.

Tl;dr - delicious noodle soup, can add on stuff and choose what you'd like in it, super cozy on a cold day

The noodles here are unlimited refills. You can keep asking them to give you a new bowl of noodles when you finish. You also pour the ingredients yourself.this pla e stays open very late. This spot is always packed. Food is pretty good. Would come here when I get the chance.

Came here to have lunch one day. The place is no frills, many diners dining alone or couples dining together. They provide you with a whiteboard menu where you can check off what you would like. Service was a little slow, part of my order was forgotten even though they weren't all that busy. I opted for a tomato based noodle soup and added seafood. My seafood was forgotten so they cooked my seafood by itself and I added it to my pot. Soup and noodles come out piping hot which is why they five you a plate of extras that has raw meat and stuff so you can add it to the boiling stone pot. My cold dish came out way after my noodle was served, was surprised it even came out. Though the spicy cold chicken looked unappealing, it was actually really good. Guess you can't judge a book by its cover. Will be back to give this place another try, hopefully it was just an off day.

Excellent food and very affordable. The rice noodles are unlimited refill, and a subset of the noodle soups also come with a set of 12 sides. I also tried the fish and pork meatballs, which were great. Would be a great meal on a cold day!

Second time at a Yunshang and this time was much better! The first time, I went to the Brooklyn location and it was okay. This time here and it was much livelier and food was also better. I got the preserved cabbage soup base and extra seafood for $2.00 more. The sides were free and it came with pork strip, corn, pickled cabbage, Chinese sausage, tofu strip, and mushed pork? It came with a lot and was super affordable. The soup was definitely flavorful but I was super dehydrated after the noodle soup. I was full with just one serving of noodles but for those who can eat more, there's definitely enough soup and toppings to basically give you a second noodle soup bowl. It was sort of difficult to flag down a waiter to refill my glass of water and to pack the leftovers. To pack the leftovers, it's 75 cents per container.

There was only one bathroom. I really hate when there's only one restroom. Overall, a better experience and I wouldn't be opposed with coming back again.

This place is perfect on a cold day when you want noodles and soup. The toppings were impressive, such a good value spot. I got the tomato broth :)

Each bowl of noodle comes with toppings. Heads up that if you can't finish that a to go box is $0.75!

You'd be hard pressed to find a better deal than this-- a big bowl of noodle soup for ~$12 with a bunch of toppings and unlimited noodles if you dine in. My friend and I were seated immediately, but I do see how it could become busy quite quickly.

I ordered the coconut curry soup which was flavorful and just the right amount of spicy for a spice weakling like myself (I'm working on it). When you get your soup, it's literally just the broth with all of the toppings served next to it in these little bowls. Part of the experience seems to be dumping it all inside and being very proud of yourself. I will say that I found it fun in a little kid in a candy store type way, but I was underwhelmed by the amount of toppings there were. Like... exactly one shrimp? One tofu? One little slice of ham? It was a bit lacking.

I loved that they gave us unlimited bowls of noodles though. And the noodles were great-- soft and slightly chewy like rice noodles should be. Will definitely be back if I'm in the area!
This is literally one of the best noodle houses I've ever been to, plus if you dine in, you get unlimited noodles!!!

Stopped by this noodle shop when it was getting late and the rest of chinatown seemed to be asleep (around 10pm). I usually don't get rice noodles at restaurants but thought it would be worth the try. They have a deal where you can get unlimited rice noodle refills, which we didn't even use because we were so full to begin with haha! I got the original broth which was pretty good and my friend got the tomato broth. We were quite full after, so I now wish I got the shanghai wheat noodle instead (i like wheat noodles more but was swayed against getting it because the free refills only applies to rice noodle, not shanghai noodle. Little did i know how full i would be off one bowl though...). Overall, i enjoyed the meal and although wouldn't go back again because i can make rice noodles myself, it was fun to try

Came here randomly on a cold day. The broth really hit the spot. Got the tomato base. The noodles were good. But be careful of the add one. It looks cheap. But once you keep adding on sides it adds up. Overall pretty good place.

This place is amazing! I got the original soup and it was very flavorful. I loved that it came out piping hot and it stayed pretty hot throughout. The noodles are nice and chewy. The meat included as part of the toppings isn't a lot. I was pretty full after just one helping of the noodles. The chicken wings were very crispy and served with some spicy mayo looking sauce but was actually just sweet sauce. They also have unlimited soda!

The service is alright. I think they could really use another two or three people in the front. When I went there was really only one person taking orders and serving tables - and all the tables were full!

It is a smaller space and not really comfortable to wait inside. Doesn't seem to be great for large groups.

I'm starting to get sick of this place,  but my bestie loves it a bit to much. So we go there ALMOST every other week or so. These photos were within a month and ordering the same thing

Here's a recap
- fried bao with condensed milk
- salty fried chicken
- fried tofu with garlic sauce
Personal clay pot noodle
- coconut curry addons seafood, fish balls
- coconut curry addons bo choy, fish balls, scallions
- pickled vegetables and shredded pork addons bo choy, mushrooms, cilantro, scallions, fish balls
- mushrooms addons fish balls, bo choy, cilantro,  scallions

Nearby trains D,B to grand st or RWJNQ6 to canal st
Cash/Cards
Street parking

This is our go-to place late night because the food is so good.  The stand out dishes that I have had here have been the fried squid and the cold chicken with chili oil and peanut sauce. Wow. So good.

This unique restaurant and food in the middle of Chinatown is underrated.   If you are tired of regular Chinese food and want to try food from a different region, this is the place to go.   I've been here several times and the first time I went, I was a bit intimidated since I wasn't sure what to do with all the little dishes.  Their menu shows you step by step what to do.  Their appetizers are AMAZING!  Must get are the fried chicken wings, takoyaki and the cold cucumber dish.  Their chicken wings are really the best in Chinatown and even rival some of the major chicken chains.  I had the minced pork with sour mustard green broth but all the broths are great.   Servings are huge and soup stays super hot in the stone bowl.  You also get additional free rice noodles but I find first bowl filling enough.  Definitely go here for something different and delicious!

Service was great, we were seated quickly. Only 2 people on staff and they were polite and attentive. I ordered the spicy broth and got a veggie platter with it. I also ordered bok choy and that was simmered in the broth. The rice noodles were perfectly chewy . We had unlimited rice noodles so I ordered a second bowl. The cucumbers were the showstopper, if I could bottle the sauce and carry it with me everywhere I would. Can't wait to go back!
The soy milk and jelly was really good and mainly cheap. The value was just fantastic.

One of the Mott Street Eatery's stalls. Some other reviews mention this place as being a Hong Kong dessert place. While they do sell some desserts like tofu pudding and soy milk, their menu might have changed since then. This place actually sells a menu of Hong Kong snacks.

You'll find a lot of classics like fried rice noodles, scallion pancakes, pan fried tofu with fish, sticky rice in lotus leaf wraps, and more. We tried some of these snacks. They were okay quality but not any better than you can find anywhere in Chinatown. Everything is slightly overpriced though compared to what they charge at other places, but that is probably because this food court gets a lot of non locals.

SKIP THIS PLACE! WAY OVERPRICED!!
The tofu pudding not only tasted bland, but it was also very watery. They partially filled up the quart with water, so I didn't get a full quart of tofu pudding even though I paid full price for it.
The three fried stuffed treasures tasted only ok. The fish paste they gave on each piece was like paper thin.
SAVE YOUR MONEY TO TRY OTHER PLACES!
The sisters really know their soy-based desserts! It's as authentic as can be, and they're very knowledgeable.
Delicious tofu dessert!  Very authentic Hong Kong style.  The tofu is very soft and smooth.  It is in a food court setting.

This is a nice dessert place in the Mott Eatery Food Court. They sell variations of soy bean desserts /tofu pudding/dofufa and soy milk. I got the 'soy bean dessert with herbal jelly' it was delicious. The tofu pudding I highly recommend, though the grass jelly was okay. The tofu pudding was the best I've had. The pudding was a great color, soft, and fresh. I asked for the brown sugar to go with the tofu pudding which very nicely complimented everything.

In Chinatown, there's a food hall called Mott Street Eatery. There's all sorts of Chinese food offered here. Yan Wo Dou Bun Inc is one of the vendors. My friend encouraged me to try their soybean dessert. I didn't know how to feel about this. It's like jello made out of soy milk, with liquid sugar poured over it. There is just one size, it's really large, maybe 10 ounces, and it's only $2.50. Hmm.. I wish they offered a smaller size. I'm typically not a fan of tofu, but this isn't bad. It's sweet only as much as you pour liquid sugar or syrup over it. Real maple syrup would be a nice choice. The texture is nice and silky. This is totally a unique type of dessert to me. I wish the portion was smaller, because I have a bad habit of not leaving things behind when I don't have access to a fridge. This is a unique dessert, where you can easily modify the sweet level. I can't say it's my favorite, but I enjoyed it and I'm glad I tried it.

This is an amazing tofu snacks spot. The tofu pudding is super silky. Get the sesame flavored one, their black sesame sauce is very good. Their soy milk is very fresh and not grainy at all.  I'm not downgrading them for this, but their grass jelly is not very good. Also their "quart" and "half quart" plastic ware look..  smaller than a quart and half quart. I am interested in trying their other items, including their tea eggs. Their sugar syrup is excellent, spend a little for the ginger flavor, it's worth it.
We had the salmon and tuna onigiri and both were delicious. The bubble tea was very good and not too sweet

Pros and Cons from our first time trying Yaya Tea - delivered.

We got the fried chicken, japanese, plum, and salmon onigri and for a drink, we got the lychee mango white tea with lychee popping boba.

Pros:
The onigiri (rice balls) were still warm upon arrival
They tasted fresh and were overall pleasant
We got the small onigiri to taste and they were surprisingly pretty big
The portion of the fillings were also good
The rice itself was tasty
Prices were all between $3:50-$4:50 each

Cons: Overall, the onigiri didn't have much flavor and the fillings didn't make much of a difference.
The fried chicken wasn't crispy at all
The plum was overly sour
The japanese onigiri's seaweed's artificial green coloring made the egg and imitation crab completely green as well so it wasn't appetizing to look at and didn't taste great either.
The drink ($7) was artificial as well unfortunately with no hint of real mango or lychee in it. It could have been any flavor really and you wouldn't know the difference bc it's just your typical artificial powdered drink mix.

So, will we order again from here? Probably not. Well, I don't think I'd mind getting a plain rice onigiri if I was in the mood for it and nearby, but that's about it. :)

I'd like to update this review with a note letting everybody know that the owners have not reached out to me about this issue. I bought a boba tea and got a $1400 ambulance ride with it and noooothing :)

I've been a costumer of Yayas since before 2014 and it tasted just as it did back then... AMAZING!! The people here are just super sweet. Helpful, comforting and just overall good. I would travel miles just to come here because of how fresh everything is.

The service is impeccable compared to other tea spots I've been too. There are so many business you wanna make sure you find the place that fits YOU.

Yayas has more than one location but this one specifically is my favorite. Everything is set up beautifully and is aesthetically pleasing as well as simply welcoming for everyone!

It's been awhile and I remember the days I'd love stopping by Yaya's if I'm in the area. A friend saw me eating onigiri and told me about  her favorite shumai onigiri from Yaya's. I knew I had to try it! That was what led me to stop by Yaya's recently and I was disappointed, there were barely any filling inside. Felt like it was just pieces of savory fried crumbs with minimum flavor and barely any shrimp shumai pieces.

My favorite is still their Japanese rice ball with crabmeat, seaweed, and egg. Not a fan of their milk tea drinks, too powdery and the fruit drinks taste like diluted flavored syrup. I'll stick to their freshly brewed teas for a light refreshing beverage. The Aries:  Jasmine, and Chrysanthemum is worth trying.

There is no indoor dining at the moment but it makes it more space for you to check out the great variety of snacks, cute accessories, decorations they have around the store.

The graphics alone makes this place worth checking out at least once.

I was in the area after a Yelp event and was craving some boba and Yaya Tea was the closest one to me. I decided to check it out because they also have onigiri!

There's two kiosks to order from but you can also order at the counter. I decided to get the Boyfriend (mango and lychee tea) and a shrimp and tuna onigiri.

I only had to wait about 5 minutes for my order to be ready and the onigiris stayed warm even on my commute home.

The tuna onigiri is nothing to write home about - I think it would be better if they added more sauce. The shrimp tempura onigiri was pretty good - I would get that one again. One of the things I liked about the onigiris here was that it was really easy to remove the packaging. At other places, the onigiri ends up falling apart when I take off the plastic, so I was impressed that the onigiri kept it shape and nothing fell out here.

The Boyfriend drink was pretty good - I added lychee jelly too. It's one of their specials, so you can't go wrong with it if you are looking for something fruity. I liked the graphics on the lid too! I wish they sold it as a card/print because I would totally buy one.

There's also a mini market inside the shop selling various plushies and snacks. I didn't have a chance to take a closer look at the merchandise because I was in a rush, but the plushies were pretty cute.

Finally returned to Yaya's after 10+ years and glad to see they are still doing very well. I remember their fun and fruity bubble tea selections as well as their onigiri. We ordered the clean clothes and a Large spicy crawfish onigiri to share. The tea with 50% sweetness was quite plain in my opinion, but still unique and refreshing. The crawfish onigiri was very flavorful and tasty, drizzled with a spicy mayo. The seaweed salad added a nice freshness to the snack. I would highly recommend and would return again just to try more of their onigiris.

Cannot recommend this place enough. We stopped for a snack because my friend had never had a rice ball and I loved them. We came back not even 30 minutes later for a second because they were SO DELICIOUS. Service was quick and nice; you can order on a machine or at the counter.

Taste: 4/5
Price: 3/5

first time here so I asked the cashier what the best selling onigiri  were and she said the yaya chicken (seasoned chicken, seaweed) and Japanese (egg, crab meat, seaweed) so of course I went with those. I ordered a small spicy mayo as well which was a bit overpriced, 50 cents for a tiny bit of mayo. Total came out to be around $8. My favorite was the Japanese, and I highly recommend eating it with the spicy mayo (it added a hot kick to it). The Yaya chicken was alright, i barely had any chicken so I didn't get to fully experience it to make a final judgement. ALSO There is a specific way to open these -- pull the red tab!!!!

Yaya Tea, known for its delightful array of beverages and Japanese-inspired snacks, has long been a popular spot for food enthusiasts seeking a fusion of flavors. However, my recent encounter with their chicken onigiri left much to be desired. This Yelp review aims to shed light on my experience, highlighting the shortcomings of this particular dish and expressing my disappointment with Yaya Tea's offering.

1. Presentation:
Upon receiving the chicken onigiri at Yaya Tea, I couldn't help but feel underwhelmed by its lackluster presentation. The onigiri, a traditional Japanese rice ball, should be visually enticing and appetizing. However, the one I received appeared rather plain and uninviting. Its shape seemed inconsistent, lacking the customary neat and tightly formed appearance expected from an authentic onigiri.

2. Texture:
As I took my first bite, I noticed an immediate issue with the texture. The rice was disappointingly dry and lacked the necessary stickiness and cohesion that is characteristic of a well-prepared onigiri. This flaw greatly diminished the overall enjoyment of the dish, making it feel like a lackluster culinary experience.

3. Flavor:
One of the most essential aspects of any dish is its flavor profile. Unfortunately, the chicken filling in the onigiri was remarkably bland. It lacked seasoning and failed to deliver any notable taste beyond the plainness of the rice. The absence of complementary flavors or spices made the overall dish monotonous and unexciting. Given Yaya Tea's reputation for flavor experimentation, this lack of creativity was especially disappointing.

4. Ingredient Quality:
Another aspect worth mentioning is the quality of the ingredients used. The chicken in the onigiri was subpar, lacking the tenderness and succulence that would have elevated the overall experience. It appeared as if the chicken had been prepared without any marination or additional flavoring, resulting in a dish that felt devoid of any culinary expertise or attention to detail.

5. Price and Value:
Considering the price I paid for the chicken onigiri at Yaya Tea, the lack of quality and flavor made it a poor value for money. I expected a more satisfying and enjoyable experience given the establishment's reputation and the prices they charge for their offerings. Unfortunately, this particular dish fell short of meeting those expectations, leaving me feeling unsatisfied and disheartened.

In conclusion, my experience with Yaya Tea's chicken onigiri was disappointing, to say the least. From its unimpressive presentation and dry texture to its lackluster flavor and subpar ingredient quality, this dish failed to meet the standards one would expect from a reputable eatery. While Yaya Tea's beverage selection remains noteworthy, their execution of the chicken onigiri leaves much to be desired. As a customer seeking an enjoyable culinary adventure, I hope Yaya Tea takes this feedback constructively and works to improve the quality and taste of their food offerings, ensuring a more satisfying experience for all patrons.

- yakisoba is the best dish here hands down. Very flavorful
- the best riceballs are the Yaya chicken and the Japanese rice balls
- really enjoy the bubble tea options. I usually get the lychee tree, first love, and boyfriend. Very fruity and sweet drinks. Has nice toppings as well

It'd so clean in here, but I think they mopped the floor with dirty mop water. It STINKS in here badly. I don't even want the food. Made this trip for nothing. I don't even smell food cooking. Guess I'll have the pork buns from a few doors down at Tao's bakery

This shop had pretty average milk tea overall. I had the passion fruit green tea, which tasted just like others I had at other tea shops. There's an overwhelming variety of drinks to choose from, so it's possible I just haven't found my specific flavor combination.

Drink (4/5): I heard that the milk tea is no good, but we got the fruit tea and it was reasonably well flavored and refreshing.

Venue (4/5): There aren't really any seating areas as they've been replaced with a shop and decorations, however the the decorations do appear really nice and give a nice vibe to the place.

Service (4/5): Came with a large group from work and everyone was able to efficiently and quickly get their orders.

I got the takoyaki onigiri as a little afternoon snack and it was great! I really liked the size and it was so warm. I also loved how flavorful the spicy mayo was. The actual takoyaki was really good in flavor but the octopus was a bit tough. I would definitely come back for the chicken one!
They have delicious rice balls. I highly recommend the Japanese rice ball or the shrimp tempura rice ball. The Japanese has crabmeat, egg and seedweed salad. Perfect as a snack.

Great little spot to grab bubble tea and onigiri. No inside seating but friendly, efficient service and a lot of yummy looking options. The plum onigiri and matcha tea are seriously delicious! Can't wait to try more!

I'm hoping when I do come back that they can do a bit better. I got the Boyfriend, which was a mango and lychee white tea, which I thought was descent in taste. I tried my sister's drink "Sunrise," which was a strawberry and mango white tea, which had a aftertaste I did not like. I think what made me give them a 3 instead of a 4 star is because the girl helping us had so much attitude. We could definitely tell she didn't want to be there and disliked our presence even more.

I've ordered from this location a few times now and I enjoy the food and drink for a quick snack but twice they've forgotten to add boba to my drink. The 83 cents for boba is not enough for me to go back and ask them to remake a drink but it's just kind of annoying

I remember coming here in my middle school days. It was just THE place to hang out for youngsters to socialize and grab a bite/drink. They're good for their tea-infused/non-bubble tea-based drinks, as well as their onigiris which are triangular shaped rice balls wrapped in dry seaweed, with a variety of fillings you can choose from.

I ordered a typical milk bubble tea and a yaya onigiri, because to be honest, the last time I came here was when I was in middle school. The onigiri had way more rice than filling (chicken and seaweed), very different from the past. Wish there was a better ratio because it felt like I was just eating rice + dry seaweed. Figuring out how to unwrap the plastic from the rice ball was a definitely a throwback.

I would recommend this place if you haven't tried onirigis before or an alternative to bubble tea. They also sell a lot of unique Japanese snacks and cool merch.

I started coming here in high school so this yaya's location has a special place in my heart. I came again recently post renovations (I know I'm p late) and everything was just as nostalgic, with a modern twist in decorations. I got two onigiris, the chicken and shrimp tempura, and a large boyfriend with lychee jelly. I got 50% sugar for the drink. Normally, I get 0 or 30% sugar for fruit drinks, but this was actually a bit watery for me. For the rice balls, they definitely have a larger rice to filling ratio now, but overall, still pretty enjoyable and flavorful. I also recommend getting the small size as opposed to a large Bc the large is really just more rice.
Tasty food and the bubble teas are amazing! You can customize your tea with or without tapioca balls and the rice balls are a personal fav

My friends constantly rave about their rice balls and it was definitely one of the better ones I've had. My favorite was the Ginger Chicken, my boyfriend's favorite was the Yaya shrimp. Each has a lot of mayo and are budget friendly at $2.50-$3 a rice ball. My advice is to eat them when they're fresh!

What we ordered:
Yaya Chicken rice ball ($3)
Yaya Shrimp rice ball ($3.65)
Ginger Chicken rice ball ($3.50)
Tuna rice ball ($3.00)
Shrimp with Crab riceball ($3.65)
Crab Meat riceball ($2.75)
Salmon riceball ($3.00)

Our Favorites
Shrimp
Ginger Chicken
Crab Meat
⁣

After getting chicken over rice at the sensational Wah Fung, I wanted to pair it with a drink. Yaya was only a block away so I decided to try it. It is located on the edge of Chinatown near Sara D Roosevelt park. I believe that Yaya is a popular chain here in New York City.

This boba shop is just not that good. Period. Their milk tastes really watery and powdery. You could tell the tea leaves aren't very good quality. Tapioca pearls are whatever, bland and feel stale. The location is a bit inconvenient for tourists as it is a bit of a walk away from the nearest subway station. However, they do have an interesting selection of snacks inside the store which I thought was cool.

Pros: service, price is cheaper compared to other nyc places, no lines
The kids and I like to stop in any chance we get.  With their various locations there is always one nearby.  You won't be disappointed!

Came here for the first time in about almost a decade! It used to be my go to spot for after school hangout and great snack before heading home. This location no longer offers indoor dining which is understandable, given the whole COVID situation, but on top of that, the drink quality seems to have also dropped significantly. The drinks just taste like straight up sugar diluted with a bit of water poured into a well branded cup, sealed, and served. The rice balls seem to have gotten smaller while the price went way up, but it still makes for a pretty good snack, I have to admit. After this recent experience, I can't say I don't miss the days when Yaya Tea Garden was the bomb dot com, always busy, with lines out the door. I don't think I'll be coming back any time soon for drinks, but I might stop by again soon for a rice ball if I'm out of choices for a snack in Chinatown.

yaya tea is one of my favourite spots to stop at when I'm in the city! i ordered a boba milk tea, spam onigiri, and chicken onigiri, and all was delicious. there was a small area to sit, but only two tables. service was quick and efficient.

They opened a new location in Brooklyn- Which is the one I went to! The interior is super cute (: I got the shrimp tempura rice ball and a green milk tea with boba and they were both delicious! If you decide to order online for pick up I would def recommend paying (because it's not required). if you order online for pickup and it's busy you might still have to wait to pay for your food.
Cheap, delicious, and my favorite tea spot! There takoyaki balls are the best and the rice balls are delicious!

Shrimp tempura and yaya chicken onigiri are a must try!
Also try the  boyfriend drink, very delish!

In the continuation of my enamored interest with onigiri I ventured to Yaya Tea's other location in Chinatown, Lower East Side to obtain more rice balls and boba tea.  This location is small and conveniently accessible by subway near East Broadway's F train.  The rice balls comes in small and large sizes at various prices.  I purchased two small plums, two Yaya small shrimps rice balls and my default peach green tea bubble tea with my favorite grass jelly topping.  The small rice balls were plentiful, delicious, and enjoyable for any meal at any time of the day.  Unfortunately, like their Grand Street location soy sauce also was not provided in my onigiri order as I had to use my own soy sauce from home.  My food order for rice balls, thankfully, did not take an eternity to be fulfilled.  Yaya Tea practices sweetness percentage distribution for intake as 25% is the lowest which is a small pump.  Former NYC Mayor Bloomberg would have been proud of Yaya Teas's controlling sales distribution and my consumption intake of sugary drinks.  While I do not like excessive sugary drinks I do like a tad small percentage of sweetness.  The bubble tea mirrors exactly as their mirror Grand Street counterpart for the ice melted and the coldness dissolved the grass jelly, disappointingly became mediocre room temperature thus four stars.  I became utterly dispirited.  I wanted a cold refreshing drink as relief from summer's blazing heat and humidity.  Orders are called by first customers' names.

This Chinatown, LES location has a Yelp mobile check-in offer and a loyalty card, and a takeout menu.  The takeout menu is very detailed with descriptions of various teas and the types of tea (green teas, oolong teas, black teas, herbal teas), and a "how to open an onigiri."

The tea here is not the best, as it is not a strong tea flavor and is often overly sweet. The food however! Their Onigiri is freshly made to order and is always so warm and soft and crispy and flavorful when eaten! I always get the yaya shrimp tempura Onigiri and it's soooo good! Highly recommend.

It has been a long time since I last visited this place. Since then, they have renovated the place and it looks more spacious. Aside from the food and bubble teas, they also sell Japanese snacks and merchandise.
