The lady running the cart was very nice. Since they cook it right in front of you, it takes a couple minutes to get the skewers. I basically got everything on the menu, but my favorites were the squid and chicken heart. I spent $15 for 8 skewers (something like that) and it was amazing!

This is a popular food cart that sells BBQ'ed meats at the food of the Manhattan Bridge on Forsythe Street. What makes this place popular is that you can get different skewers of meat for a extremely low price of $1 each. Every time I visit, I walk away with 5 or so different skewers. My personal favorite would be the chicken, lamb, beef, fish tofu and chicken wing skewers. The meats are juicy and succulent and you'll definitely be wanting more. A sprinkle of red cumin powder adds a little zing to the meat. Definitely do check out this cart whenever you're in the area. You can smell the BBQ aroma of charcoal and meats from blocks away!

I always search for this when I am in chinatown in New York.

Its seriously so much better on the carts than they are at restaurants. I can eat like twenty of these things... And they're only like 1-2 a stick.

Now I want more..

I loooove this cart!
So good, so cheap.  Fast and easy.  If you're drinking by the area this is the spot, lol. After I was shown this place with $1.50 skewers I go every time I'm in the area. They're always in the same corner of Grand Street and Chrystie Street.
They have chicken, lamb, pork, beef, and other options like corn and eggplants *never seen anybody getting any of that though, and I think those are $2.50 and up*

I love coming here every once in a while to snag a grilled skewer stick. My favorites are the chicken, beef and lamb. The seasoning is pretty spicy so be prepared with a bottle of water. I usually grab herbal tea before or after I stop here, just to detox from such a smokey snack.

The meats are all pretty tender and flavorful, the lamb has 50/50 fat and meat though. Prices went up and they're not $1.25 each instead of 1.

Worth checking out.

So I got the buy 10 get 1 free. Got 3 lamb 3 beef 1 fishball 2 hotdogs and 2 squid. Lamb was delicious!!! But the beef was very hard a little over cook. The fishball was very spicy it literally burn my tongue. The hotdogs was decent but the squid ‍ dried, hard and burnt. It wasn't the best squid ever. But the cart lady was very nice. Spend about $15. I would recommend the lamb the most!!!!

Look along the Manhattan Bridge and you will see the charcoal smoke piping up from the little food cart- and sure enough, you have found Young's Xinjiang BBQ Cart (similar to the one out in Flushing).

For $1 - ONE DOLLAR- you get a delicious, grilled skewer: chicken, lamb, beef, hotdog. The lamb is juicy and perfectly charred to perfection. They also offer corn and sweet potato wrapped up in some foil. Be SURE to ask for the killer spice powder- it truly makes everything here special.

Combine this little cart with a trip to Prosperity Dumpling (5/$1 dumplings) and you have yourself a $2-3 lunch.. and a mini Chinatown Adventure.

Look for the smoke (or Google Maps says it's approximately at 16 Forsyth St), Young Xinjiang BBQ Cart brings traditional Xianjiang BBQ to Chinatown. The wait can be a while, and you might have some difficultly without Mandarin -- but like Phoebe says, get it spicy. I would also stick to the lamb, but saw many other people ordering other items (chicken wings, hot dogs, SQUID).

I prefer the one in Flushing (yelp.com/biz/xinjiang-bb…) but this one is way closer (though not as tasty).

$1 Beef, lamb, Chicken & more per skewer! Talk about recession! I think this is better than a protein shake because it is pure protein grilled on a stick!

I just tried it the first time this past weekend and it was so GOOODD!!!!

We came upon one somewhere near this location and I was beyond ecstatic.  I can read the Chinese characters and know we have to try at least one skewer.  Any only skewer is $1 each.  Each skewer is skillfully grilled over coal.  You'll be asked if you want it spicy - the cook will then sprinkle spices on the skewer - the end result is super tender and tasty lamb.  If we haven't tried 4 other places that afternoon, I would have 1-2 each of everything.

LOVE every bite - I'm beyond jealous of all these fabulous food carts...

Yitiao Yangrou Chuarrr!

Just like on the streets of Beijing, a skewer of lamb here is yi kuai.  But unlike Beijing, yi kuai here = $1 whereas it is only 1/7 of a dollar over there.

I've only tried the lamb here, as that's what I usually stick to in Beijing.  The lamb here is subpar and rubbery.  For good yangrou, hit the streets of Flushing, Kissena Blvd to be exact.

I am glad that there is a BBQ skewer cart in Manhattan Chinatown but I have to say the ones in Flushing are much better.  The prices are roughly the same but the real difference is in the lamb skewer.  This one a 3:1 ratio of lean meat to fat chunks whereas Flushing's had all lean meat which deducts a star even though it is on the more "authentic" side.

I also got the chicken gizzard and chicken heart skewers - nom nom nom!

The thing about these carts is that they're *sometimes* never there when you go. But thank you meat stick man for being there!

The meat is so amazing because it takes in the smoky flavor of the charcoal under it. My favorite is the lamb, fish ball (with sauce), and fish tofu (with sauce). And add the spice on it! It isn't TOO spicy and well worth it.

Like most places in Chinatown, it is cash only. After getting your fill, walk along the bridge to buy some cheap groceries and different types of ginger for cheap :o

After trying the Xinjiang BBQ Cart in Flushing and falling in love, I wanted to find if Manhattan had something similar. I was vacationing in NYC and was staying in Manhattan, I didn't want to go so far to Flushing but I wanted skewers!! So I looked on yelp to see if there was one in Manhattan and there was!!

I went on an adventure to find this cart. It was a little hard to find at first because it was already dark outside and I was unfamiliar with the area. But when I did find it, it was this lonely cart near the corner of the street with an older gentlemen watching the cart.

Unfortunately, his English isn't that great but if you point to the menu on which item you want and how many, he'll get them right away. I got 4-5 lamb skewers and he was very friendly, even offered to wrap it up in foil for me to go. I ended up taking it back and waiting for my boyfriend to come back to try it. I also tried a skewer but it wasn't as great as the one in Flushing but that could be because it was wrapped in foil right after it was done cooking so it became well done ...

So my boyfriend and I tried the cart again a day or two later. But this time, there was a woman at the cart instead of the older gentlemen. Once again, we got the lamb skewers. They were delicious when eaten fresh but the meat quality, I feel, wasn't as great as the Flushing cart. There was a lot of fat in the meat ..oof. Though, still yummy and nicely seasoned with the cumin, salt, and spice.

However, beware! On a more recent NYC trip, I wanted to get skewers again because I can't seem to find anything close to it at home...and I couldn't find the cart. So I'm not sure which days they have off or what not.

But if you can find the cart and have some cash on you, give it a try. It is delicious :D

$1 lamb kebabs $2 chicken wings

Lamb was rubbery but with a good amount of fat but were just meh
The big chicken wings, on the other hand, were tasty - hot, crispy, salty and a little sweet. good stuff.

I stumbled upon this cart while running some errands on the far side of Chinatown. Haha, I gotta say, she knows how to hide her cart well. I'm actually half a XinJiang native; my mom was born and raised there, so I do know what authenticity tastes like!

  I got a skewer of lamb for $1. To be honest, I thought for that small skewer, $1 was quite a steep price. Having said that, even though the meat wasn't exactly quality, there was a taste of some authentic XinJiang flavor with the mix of spices. The whole 3 seconds that it took me to eat did bring me slightly down memory lane, back to my carefree XinJiang vacation days.

 If you got an extra buck on you and are in the area, why not?

Probably not the healthiest or cleanest, but this is street food done right. Take a risk and you have my word that I've never had a stomach bug from eating here.

Pros: The spice rub, a blend of cumin and chili powder, is so legit. The skewers are grilled over an open charcoal grill and I swear it tastes just like the ones in China.
-My favorite is the lamb, which can be greasy with chunks of fat, and the chicken, which is always a safe choice.
-Spice levels can also be adjusted.

Cons: I'm not fond of the sweet brown sauce that they sometimes glaze on, but you can ask to have it without the sauce.
-It may help to know Chinese, but holding out your money is pretty universal. There's a sign with English on the side of the cart, so you're good to go.
-The skewers are a bit on the small side, but when it's this cheap, you can always eat to your heart's content.

Great Chinese BBQ cart. Taking one point for their location. I just ran into them and liked their bbq so much that decided to come back the day after that for more. However I walked around for few miles, tried both locations that people mentioned here but nothing!!!! I wish they're more technology literate and be able to update their location here or at least create a facebook page. It'd be great for us and their business as well. But sadly that's not the reality :(
This was a pit stop during Wing's dumpling tour, but I know a winner of a kebab when I taste one...or two...or three...

This is a great spot for families. I brought three little girls here and we hit the jackpot! The girls were at first a little hesitant at first but ended up loving it and we ordered several rounds of skewers, they were that good. We tried chicken, tofu, tofu-fishball and lamb. Everything was delicious, though the favorites were the chicken and tofu. One of the two cooks did not speak english but luckily the menu was bilingual so we could just point to what we wanted on the menu. By the way right next door to the cart there are fruit vendors so you can top off your meal with some fresh fruit!

Doesn't matter if I'm not hungry, I can't resist a lamb kebab for a buck every time I walk by.  That and the deep fried tofu kebab are my favorites.  In fact, one of my favorite meals are a couple kebabs then a stop at a dumpling shop.

The secret appears to be the marinade and seasoning applied in multiple steps before and after bring grilled over charcoal.

This place is great because it's simple, cheap, and delicious. A random cart in Fuzhounese part of Chinatown Manhattan that serves up coal roasted meats. For about a dollar a stick you get flavorful meats seasoned with spices like cumin and chili pepper.

For me I always get the fishballs and beef on a sticks, the chunks of beef they use while small are fat and flavorful. A+ everytime.

This seems to be the only Xinjiang BBQ meat stick option in Manhattan, which automatically gives it 3 stars, because sometimes I just need my fix and this hits the spot.

A skewer of beef, lamb or chicken is $1. However, the meat does not taste as good (the lamb is chewy and dry) and the cart does not feel as clean as the ones in Flushing. Overall, it's not too bad. Would be OK when desperate for a Xinjiang kebab without the time or energy to head to Flushing, but it's just not as good as the carts in Queens.
Good, authentic chinese street bbq. The meat was nice and juicy and had the small portions of fat that I love. Price is cheap too.

For all you bike commuters from the BK, that smell of grilled meat you smell coming over division street is from this charcoal burning machine.  The meats are awesome but the chicken and lamb with extra spice is to die for.  On cold days i buy a sweet potato and throw it in my pocket for later and its like having a built in heater.  Nothing beats a few skewers before heading back over the bridge.  The lamb kebabs have just the right amount of fat.  Cant believe there are so few reviews

Wow, wow, wow!  Had the lamb skewers - fantastic!!  Wish I had ordered more.  Definitely get the spicy powder at the end. Great heat and spice.  The meat was tender with just the right amount of excess fat and a great smokey flavor.  Totally reminded me of the ones I've had in China.  Plan to go back and try the other stuff there as well.
Price went up from 1 to 1.25. Still totally worth it. Remember to ask for your food "spicy" first if that's how you like it. Yum.

i first discovered this cart through a friend when he brought it to me. i love the beef on stick without spice. its sooo immensely flavorful and when the meat is half fatty (not all fat) its sooo good. it almost melts in your mouth instantly. i'm taking off one star though because i've also had experiences where the meat was dry and tough to eat. not to mention its budget friendly!

$1 for any skewer you want. Grilled fresh over charcoal and sometimes even catches on fire. One of the best street snacks you can get anywhere (what would take it to the next level is a peanut sauce like satay or a sour-spicy Viet/Thai style sauce.) YUMM!

I have to say that I'm a fan of this cart.  My friend took me into Chinatown to pick up something and to stop here.  We had a lamb, beef, and squid skewer each.  Lamb and beef skewers were $1.00, the squid was $2.00.  You have the option to add hot spices to your skewer which we did.  The squid is skewered in a long strip and then scored so it is very easy to take bites of of the chewy cephalopod without it all pulling off the skewer.  It is also brushed with a very good lime and lemon-grass mixture.  My friend had to duck into a store to buy a water due to the squid's spiciness.  The lamb and beef were satisfying for the price and spicy.   I will definitely be back.
Pretty good, not as good as the ones in flushing.  The meat is a bit too fatty and doesn't have enough cumin flavor.  Works in a pinch though.
it's ok. nothing really compaline about as it is a food chart and the price is ok. take off one star, just because it is not easy to find.....

This little food cart is well worth the trip to the depths of Chinatown. After wandering down Forsyth Street towards the Manhattan Bridge, I found this little gem that I had heard so much about on various food blogs and websites. A yellow sign presents the simple yet delicious choices of lamb, chicken, or beef....on a stick.....for $1. I got 2 chicken and 2 lamb, totaling probably close to half a pound of meat for $4. Be sure to ask for the spicy seasoning. You will not be disappointed.

There's more to Manhattan's Chinatown than Cantonese and Shanghainese food: in the dark, ghetto district that borders LES, you will find arguably the only area outside of China with authentic food from Fuzhou.

Note that this area is still relatively unexplored by "outsiders," which means:
- no menus in English
- no English-speaking waiters/waitresses
- limited heat/air-conditioning
- CHEAP
- DIRTY
- SMOKING(!!!!!!!!)

After reading up on these restaurants in a Chowhound thread (chowhound.chow.com/topic…), I was intrigued, so tricked my non-foodie friends into this adventure.  Our group of five first tried Best Fuzhou Restaurant on 71A Eldridge, but left due to the massive amount of smoke.

We treked around the corner to Ying Qian Fuzhou Restaurant instead, and were met by a confused waitress in her jacket (confused because we obviously weren't locals, jacket because the restaurant was FREEZING) and a completely empty restaurant.

I tried ordering the xiao chi I heard was good: xiao long bao (unlike the Shanghainese style, Fuzhou xiao long baos are actually mini buns, not soupy dumplings) and fried taro cake.  The waitress explained that they only serve these snack foods during lunch.  Doh.

We settled on:
- Lychee pork, which is somewhat of a misnomer.  This is actually pork that is cut in a way that resembles lychee, but contains no lychee itself, mixed with veggies, and sauteed in a sweetish-sour sauce.  I liked this very much, and it is a Fuzhou specialty.
- Oyster-egg pancake.  I expected o-ah-jian, the Taiwanese oyster pancake, but this was actually just a giant scrambled egg with scallions, onions, and oyster.  I poked at the oysters suspiciously, but they proved to be fresh and tasty.  Good dish, if you like eggs.
- Fish balls.  Another Fuzhou specialty: soft, pillowy fish paste balls that have been poached in a light broth.  I'm generally not a fan of these, but they're worth trying at under $4 for a dozen (something like that).
- Tong cai.  This is also known as kong xin cai.  Good and yummy, very garlicky.
- Salt and pepper fried frogs.  Though I've had frog before, I never liked it much.  However, it was delicious here!  Lightly fried, well-seasoned, very fresh and tender...  Yum.
- Some kind of strange fish dish.  I wasn't a fan of this.

I wanted to try the casseroles (crab, seafood, or intestines), but my dining party didn't seem to be as excited about trying new things than I was.  As we were eating, quite a few laborers came in and ordered simple and cheap noodle dishes that looked super tasty!  We were lucky to enjoy the restaurant to ourselves for most of our meal though, since some of them ended up smoking as well, despite the HUGE "No Smoking" sign in the restaurant =P

The meal came out to about $13 per person.  FYI, the noodle dishes are all around $5.  Next time I will try to come during lunch over the weekend so I can order the snack items, and I will be sure to report back on the noodles here vs. Lan Zhou Hand Pull Noodle.

This is one of my go-to's in Chinatown when I want a cheap, quick, delicious meal.

A bit under the radar, this place has been here a while and seems more like a local joint vs a stop for tourists. They have excellent Fuzhou classics like peanut wheat noodle, dumplings, and fish ball soup - all at extremely reasonable prices (if you look through the reviews, you'll see they've only raised prices minimally over the past few years, which is incredible).

With down-the-street Shu Jiao Fu Zhou often times overrun now given the secret on that place is out, Yi Zhang Fishball offers a very similar menu without having to fight crowds and lines.

Hope people out there can support this local business and keep them afloat!

The restaurant is so good value!!! Food is cheap, and very generous portion. Food itself is average, you get what you paid for, I mean you can't expect top notch delicacy with such low prices right! And in this case you're probably getting more than what you paid for!

~ Pan fried dumplings 煎包 (3.5/5) ~
For only $4 you get 5 buns!! And these are not mini size, but normal size!! These pan fried dumplings are not the typical shanghai pan fried pork buns with soup inside (生煎包). They are normal steamed buns that are pan fried, and not topped with sesame seeds. Nonetheless, the bun is soft and fluffy, you can taste the wheat with a mildly sweet undernote. The juicy filling is enough for you to get the pork almost every bite. The bottom is not crispy, as they most likely pan fry it after steaming. Overall, it's a good average bun, and it is so good value!

~ Wheat Noodle w/ Peanut Butter sauce (3/5) ~
Can you believe this noodle only cost $3?? And the portion is pretty decent as well! The wheat noodle is on the softer side (would have liked it to be more al dente), and the peanut butter sauce is too runny and not very flavourful. Would have tasted much better if they can thicken up the sauce, adding more peanut butter, and perhaps even mixing real peanuts/nuts to add some crunch to it. But as I said, for the price of $3, you can't ask for more, and it tasted good enough to fill my stomach.

Will I be back? Yes
The food here are so cheap, and tasted good enough for this price. This is definitely where I will go if I just want a cheap and quick meal in the neighbourhood.

Guys, Yi Zhang is your life saver if you are a broke grad student like me. It is a hole in the wall where you can find cheap, quick and filling bites from $3. Their extremely affordable pricing is totally unheard of nowadays in such an inflated city.

＊ Pan Fried Dumplings 煎包 ($4)
A simple pan fried pork bun with 5 servings. The marinated minced pork was incredibly juicy, wrapped in a fluffy bao dough. The portion of fillings was decent even they only charge a fairly low price. Different from Shanghai pan fried pork bun (sheng jian bao生煎包), the bottom of their buns wasn't very crispy, and they didn't garnish the buns with toasted sesame seeds and chopped green onions.   They literally just pan-fried the steamed buns, but it was delicious enough to fill your hungry stomach.

＊ Wheat Noodle w/ Peanut Butter Sauce 拌面 ($3)
The noodle was slightly overcooked but perfect for those who love softer noodle. The peanut butter sauce was quite bland and watery, unlike the thicken one used in Taiwanese sesame noodle or dan dan noodle. The sauce clang to every wide noodle after they were mixed well. It will be more flavourful if they sprinkle some sesame, and mix with minced garlic and sesame oil. But concerning the shockingly low price, we just couldn't ask for more.

Worth Returning ? Yes

I discovered this place inadvertently while seeking a snack from next door Ka Wah Bakery, which happened to be closed. My daughter had been chanting, "Snack! Snack! Snack!" I saw a few people hunched over eating at Yi Zhang and, in desperation, thought I would stop by to grab a quick appetizer for my daughter before heading home for dinner.

Given the name of the establishment, I figured that the fish ball soup would be a safe bet. Made in the Fuzhou style with pork inside the fish paste, the savory fish balls in the tart clear broth were indeed delicious. We got about 10 large fish balls in our soup ($4), which was a very good deal. This was definitely a light but filling snack for the night of us.

As others have noted, this is truly a hole-in-the-wall, but one that is well appreciated by locals in the know. Although the menu is fairly limited to core set of Fujianese classics, I definitely look forward to returning for a full meal.
Best place in Chinatown for dumplings and baos! I like them better than Shujiao Fu Zhou.
One of the best, authentic Fujianese food in Chinatown. The prices are super low for great portions. I love their peanut noodles, dumplings, and pan fried dumplings!

FOOD: This place has one of the better peanut butter noodles in Chinatown and the BEST Fujianese meatball soup in NYC. Their meatball soup is authentic and made just right and happens to be the main reason that keeps me coming back again and again. Their xiao long bao is blah because its filling is way too light and there is way too much dough...so doesn't really look like xiao long bao...more like a medium bao. Their wonton soup is neutral in my opinion. Their fishball is also one of the best in the city...it's so delicious.

SPACE: It's a hole in the wall so cleanliness is always questionable. The tables are two long counters facing the wall. They use styrofoam plates and polypropylene containers for soups and noodles along with plastic spoons.

SERVICE: The staff here seem to have a more relaxed demeanor compared to other like places like Shui Mei Cafe. You go in and tell the cashier what you want. He/she will then call your order to the kitchen and they will make the food and bring it to your seat. When you finish, go up to the cashier to pay.

Cash only. No tips required.

I came to Yi Zhang when my go to noodle and dumpling place (Zeng Xing Fu Zhou) a few doors away closed their kitchen and became a frozen buns & dumplings takeout only place. Yi Zhang is a hole-in-the-wall restaurant where you eat at a counter along the wall. One crucial difference from many of the other small places - THEY HAVE AN AIR CONDITIONER that works!

On my first visit, I tried the rice noodles with peanut sauce and was disappointed that the noodles were a bit overcooked. On my second visit I tried the wheat noodles with peanut sauce (pa mien). The noodles were cooked just right and although they were a little skimpy with the peanut sauce, it was flavorful and not overly salty as a some of the other places. I also tried the boiled dumplings which were quite average in flavor and the sheng jian bao. Unlike in Flushing, where they are filled with the same filling as dumplings, here they are filled with small pieces of meat in sauce. As a matter of taste, I prefer the ones at Corner 28, Tian Bao Restaurant and Nan Xiang Xiao Long Bao in Flushing, Queens. I surmise that the ones in Manhattan are Fu Zhou style and the ones in Flushing are Shanghai style.

If you are learning Chinese, this is a great place to practice because much of the help does not speak English but they are friendly and try to be accommodating.

So overall a 3.5 but rounded up because of their very affordable prices ($2 for noodles, $2 for small order of boiled dumplings, $2 for there sheng jian bao), air conditioning and friendly staff!

This little dive has a short menu, appears to be quite popular with the kids getting out of school and must have the most aromatic peanut sauce ever. The name attracted me to it..who names a restaurant after fishballs? Interestingly enough there are more meat items than fish balls on menu. I had the fishball soup as a light snack ; add the peanut sauce noodles, as everyone in there but me seemed to be eating, and you get a tasty meal. Place is clean and service is Quick and friendly.  Will be back to try the peanut sauce!

Oh nothing on the menu is over$5 and most items are $3. Fish ball soup and noodles equals meal for $5. Great if you are on the run. The kids like to est and linger! Two long counters for dining all face the wall.
Found my new place for dumplings!  Their dumplings come in a set of 8 for $2 and it's sooo good.  The skin is thin yet smooth and the filling is packed full of flavor.

Ventured into the depths of Chinatown for the best $5 meal - wheat noodles with peanut sauce and a large order of dumplings. Let those suckers soak in the sauces (you get both -mild and spicy, which is not burning hot) and enjoy authentic dining on the cheap.

This our go to spot in the outskirts of Chinatown proper for tasty soups. It doesn't get much cheaper than these prices. Their clientele is mainly Fujian chinese so order by pointing at the pictures on the wall.  My favorite is meatball soup with noodles for $4. The wontons they make are also very delicate and not the large dumpling like things you get in Cantonese restaurants.

The large order of dumplings for $3 is hard to beat for the value and could suffice as a meal unto themselves.  I suppose one could argue that $3 is a lot compared with Lam Zhou or Prosperity's $2 plate, but I'll concede the $1 difference and say these were quite good.  Generously filled with pork and scallions and cooked to just the right level of tender chewiness -- I will happily seek these out again.  I'm at a loss as to the popularity of the peanut butter wheat noodles.  They were only $2, so perhaps I shouldn't have expected too much, but they literally tasted like a bowl of overcooked store bought noodles slicked with heated Skippy peanut butter.  Even some basic inexpensive touch ups like chopped peanuts on top would have gone a long way to vary the mouthfeel.  The server included a very simple, but tasty cup of soup with the order of dumplings, which was a pleasant surprise and greatly appreciated.  I would like to go back and try more from this simple, yet homey Chinatown hole-in-the-wall.

I enjoyed the food so much that I didn't even have time to take a picture. Lovely people. Very caring and not rude at all. They deserve all the customers in the world. May they be blessed with continuous business. They've been in NY for 10 years. That says something. If you're a tourist or just anyone confused on which place to hit when you're in Chinatown I definitely would give this place a try. Nice menu ranging from your simple chicken dishes to traditional Chinese staples. The tea was amazing as well. Great flavor and very open area to eat. Nice bathrooms too so you know they keep clean! This is on my bookmarks!

Looove this place so so much!! Their lobster is delicious and their walnut shrimp is my favorite. All their food is super fresh and huge portions. Conveniently located and staff is really nice, 10/10 recommend!
Quick, authentic Fujianese breakfast. Definitely add clams to your "dian mian coon" and get the fried taro cake

Such an OG spot for Fuzhounese food. There are two parts to the restaurant: one is above ground and more fancy dining, the other is below ground and you walk down the stairs. I would definitely recommend walking down to the basement one.

You can probably try to order in Mandarin or English, but ordering in the Fuzhounese dialect is definitely the way to go. Both sides of my family are from Fuzhou, so when we come my mother orders in the Fuzhou dialect.

I've been coming here since I was a child and my mother for probably far longer. It's been over a decade and yet the food quality has remained the same, impeccable as always. They truly sell authentic Fuzhou food and it's simply so good.

Some dishes off the top of my head that I love from here include the bian rou ban mian (basically, wonton soup and peanut butter noodles), the fried circle thing, the fried triangle taro thing, their mei fen, ho fun soup, etc.

Every time we come to Chinatown, we order from here. Both the food to go and the food to dine in is the same and absolutely delicious. Prices are cheap as well...this place is just simply to rave for. Maybe the only concern is sanitary, but I've never gotten sick eating food from here. The chefs know their stuff and it's a joy to eat from here.

Traditional fuzhou cuisine. Not my favorite, as we usually go to Fu Zhou Wei Zhong Wei Jia Xiang Fei Wei, but they closed down for COVID.

We got their Oyster, Clam, and Jumbo Clam Foo Chow Ho Fun Soup. Also had their peanut noodles, fried taro cake, and oyster cake to pair with it.

The Ho Fun Soups are really good and fresh, but it wasn't hot enough when it came out for some reason. I liked the Jumbo Clam one the most but it's up to personal preference. Their peanut noodles are a bit bland. It needs some more sauce and salt. The taro cake was average and the oyster cake didn't really have any oyster pieces and was too greasy. I would only go here again for Ho Fun.

Wow! This place is still here. It's been open since the late 80s. I rememeber first coming here when I was a kid. The restaurant looked smaller back then and seems to have been renovated in the past years.

This is of course that standard typical fujianese cuisine. Bowls of noodle soup, pan fried noodle and dishes over rice.

Their peanut butter noodle dish is pretty good and they also have fried taro where most fujianese places don't.

This is a cash only spot.

This place is the amazing. They specialize in Fuzhou Dishes and their portions and prices are both absolutely incredible. We paid roughly 20 dollars for a pretty full meal and it was for 3 people!

The spareribs with special sauce and the egg noodles with peanut sauce was really good. Honestly, I've been to a number of Chinese restaurants in Manhattan's Chinatown and this truly a gem.

The service is good as they actually refill the tea and best of all, they don't charge a stupid tea fee.

Will be back for sure.

It's the place my mom always bring me to for fujianese food. So I would always come here when I'm at Chinatown during when I crave fj food. The place is a little hard to spot if esp if you don't really know you way around so look for numbers on the door. The entrance is next to a bigger restaurant and it's at the basement. But it's a pretty popular place so the flow of people will give you a good hint I guess lol.

The house special Ho Fun soup is like must try fj food item and what I always get along with some fried stuff like the long dough (which I like to dip in soy sauce or the soup), taro cake or oyster cake. Another classic fj combo is foo chow wonton soup with plain noodle with peanut butter. I don't get it as often because i personally don't like it that much and I tend to crave the Ho Fun soup more.

If you don't mind that it's at the basement and he sanitation is somewhat questionable this place offers pretty legit fj food at a pretty cheap price and no tips lol.

A great place to come for traditional Fujianese food. The fried taro is nice, fragrant, and crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. It is deep fried but tastes pretty light and not overly oily. The hot and sour soup is AMAZING! It's not as spicy as I would prefer it to be but still tastes great. There are a lot of toppings in the soup itself, but the overall taste is a bit sweet, which is quite strange.

This place is excellent. Food was delicious and service was very good and friendly. Very reasonably priced too. We sat in the upper part of the restaurant. Place is nice and clean with reasonably good ambience

Disgusting food, I ordered a seafood crispy noodle and a tofu fish fillet bowl to go. Both taste terrible. I also saw them chopping up a whole roasted duck on a plate to put in a microwave to heat, and it the plate didn't fit so the manger was like oh wells, the he proceeded to take the plate to a table of non Asians. I felt bad for that table too.

A Fujianese Fuzhou restaurant, reflecting the local East Broadway neighborhood. Live a little and avoid the American-Chinese and even Cantonese dishes.

Go to basement for the Fuzhou small eats - basically choose from the front of the small menu.

I recommend the fish balls in soup, stir fried rice noodles (meifun), noodle soups and the oyster cakes (deep fried with chives and oyster filling).  For dessert, try the rice balls (tong yuen) stuffed with red bean or nuts. Will be back to try more.

Ehh.. not so much.

- My chicken was not tender at all & broccoli wasn't so good
- I tried my mom's Seafood Noodles, very gingery and kinda greasy
- Table cloths were that weird fabric on the understand/plastic on the top
- Tea wasn't very good
- Had a big screen TV showing a bad kung fu movie, complete with gore which wasn't fun to watch while we were eating.

Only upsides were that were in a hurry and it was very quick and the waitstaff was nice. For the seafood noodles and my chicken & broccoli the total bill w/ tax was $20.
Oh my god! This is the worst restaurant that I eat in my life! Very oily ,no salt ,gross. I never made comments like this, but this restaurant really really let me feel sick of it!

This is one of those authentic restaurants in the non-touristy side of Chinatown. Every time I go, I'm the only non-Asian there. Gotta love that!

The menu's got a bit of everything- from your boring American-Chinese staples for people like Liz M. to strange dishes you should try (if you're adventurous).

I go for things like duck blood, pork intestines, duck feet... and there are many others.

I think the food is very tasty (granted, I have not tried pork intestines anywhere else) and the service is just fine. This is a no-frills place, though. Don't expect much, just real (or so I like to think) Chinese food served hot, fast and yummy.

Servers speak very little English, of course. Just another layer of authenticity.

Do not come here if you are a tourist looking for suggestions. I came here by accident and food is oily as some other reviews suggested. This is probably 1.5 stars but I could not give half star so round down.
traditional Fuzhou eats!  tasty small eats bring me back to my childhood. overall clean, quick service.

was staying in Chinatown when I went out looking for an "edible" Chinese restaurant. I was looking for something somewhat "authentic" but without the shock that many authentic dishes come with (like jellyfish, fish heads, pig intestine, duck tongues, etc.) I know of a few good restaurants on the Mott Street side of Chinatown (Wo Hop for one), but the East Broadway side is much more adventurous, mainly because there is almost no English spoken or written here. The first restaurant I walked into was Yung Sun, drawn in by their take-out menus printed in English (most restaurants on East Broadway DO NOT offer English menus.) I'm glad I chose Yung Sun, because it turned out to be so good, I ate here 4 nights in a row. Almost all of the dishes I ordered were delicious. Some were a little oily, but nothing unexpected. Only the Foo Chow wonton soup was inedible; the broth was salty and tasteless, the wontons are not the ones you're used to either. Not very good. But, the lychee pork, black pepper chicken with mixed vegetables, pork with Chinese vegetables, chicken & baby shrimp with mixed vegetables, taro cake, and hot & sour soup were all superb. In fact, the H&S soup was the best I have ever tasted. Other dishes that were sampled; chicken and eggplant in garlic sauce, beef chow fun (too much gravy), salt & pepper squid, orange flavor beef, chicken & vegetables in garlic sauce, and pork dumplings. I found that the dishes served "Chinese style" (over rice) were an awesome deal (albeit with less choices than the rest of the menu) at about $4.50 each dish. The taro cake is a must (and it's only $.70.) The reason I didn't give Yung Sun a rating of 5 is because the people working here have no personality and speak NO English. I originally tried to phone in my order, only to be told "no speak English." Even in the restaurant, I had to circle numbers on the menu, no other interaction. And, you would think after giving them business for four nights in a row they would become somewhat friendly. Not these folks. The restaurant itself is very clean for Chinatown. Prices are excellent, and the food is superb. I want to tell them how good their food is, but they wouldn't understand! I can't wait to go back, even if it's just for a taro cake and a pint of hot & sour soup.

The Chinese down here in the wonderful lively financial district is pretty slim pickins past 6pm.  I once feared the days in winter where I didn't want to go outside, the indian place in Tribeca wasn't delivering and my chinese food roulette delivered what can best be described as chicken in "goop" with rice.

yea, its bad.

then along comes Yi Hao - I wasn't expecting PF Chang's to show up at my door but instead i got a solid chicken and broccoli dinner special for 7.95 and a good egg roll.  The hot and sour soup was good and spicy.  To top it all off, the delivery is super fast.

This place deserves a better rating, and they have not disappointed the four times i've gotten food there.

Not the worst service in the city, but vying for it. My order took 2.5 hours to get delivered, I called them after the 1st hour and they said that it was out for delivery, until I called them again an hour later, to be informed of the same and hung up on. They're literally a 20 min walk from my flat, and a 5 min bike ride.

Food on the other hand was standard fare, nothing to write home about.

Incredibly quick delivery service, I was surprised at them actually getting it to me in 15-20 mins.  

The Orange beef had orange peel slivers in it, adding to the flavor of the sauce, though I found the dish to be a bit soggy upon arrival.  Even though it was supposedly a 'red pepper icon' spicy item I detected no heat or spicyness whatsoever, a shame.  The free rice was above average though!

Next time I order, and I will be forced one starving exhausted evening to reorder, I think I will try the $7.95 Dinner Specials which come with:

-fried rice / brown rice / or white rice
-egg roll / soda / water / or soup (egg drop, wonton, hot & sour)
-one of 19 entrees

Free Delivery with an $8.00 min.  
They accept Mastercard and Visa credit cards.

I have ordered two times from YI Hao and after the first time I was ecstatically praising them with Yee- Has!

Oh, but the second time, the dreaded.second.time. My wife opened her delivery container and took one bite and saw the sauteed Blatella. Yes, that crunchy cockroach was embedded into the noodle dish, but at least it was dead.

I sincerely debated trying to go ahead and finish my meal because it was simply delicious, but that meat suddenly turned from beef to rat in my mind and I just couldn't get my game on. It's quite the shame because this is the second chinese restaurant that we have ordered from that we have found additional protein in our meals.

To their credit, they issued a refund to us without even checking the food. Hmmm.

This place is a cute spot to get a quick cheap bite in the heart of Chinatown. The spot is well know for their delicious riceballs and my go to are the shrimp tempura and Japanese riceball.

YOU MUST get the spicy mayo! It pairs so well with them and gotta have it with every bite. I got the kawaii smile which is a refreshing mango and lychee tea. Yayas has quick and easy service and definitely a spot to check out :)

Onigiri.  Excellent.  Love that they have the seaweed separate so you can assemble it when you're ready to eat.  That way the seaweed stays crispy.  

Service is a little slow.  They had staff or maybe friends just hanging out.  Still, no complaints.  Food came out fast enough.  

Ambience is weird as it's half cafe, half retail.  You can buy their merch as well as snacks and trinkets.

I usually get the Boyfriend Drink which is Mango + Lychee White Tea or Mango Black Tea w/o ice and 50% sugar when I'm around Nolita. Decided to try something different today.  

WRONG MOVE!!!  Should've stuck with my usual drink choices!  Upset that I'd wasted money on this drink called Second Chance (Strawberry & Peach White Tea) which certainly doesn't deserve a 2nd or Nth # of chances. I asked for large, no ice, w/ aloe vera & 75% (regular) sugar level.

But when I took the first sip, I immediately regretted ever picking this drink in the first place. Looked so pretty with the orangey color & strawberry pulp floating around at the bottom. BUT...Didn't taste the tea, no strawberry or peach flavors, wasn't sweet at all despite the 75% sugar added to the drink, and even the aloe vera couldn't save/help it. The texture of their aloe vera wasn't like the ones I was used to that were chewy and sweet. This one had a mushy texture that I dislike a lot. Felt like I'd gotten ripped off!!!  

I am so much better off drinking iced tap water from Starbucks and that's free!  I'm not sure who decided to put this drink on the menu but I'll not be ordering it ever again!!!  The color didn't match the flavors. SUPER disappointed w/ it.

The staff was welcoming and polite though, greeting you with a smile when you walked in. Fast service too, not much of a wait.

Lesson of the Day: Stick with the drinks you already know, otherwise you would be very disappointed & upset like me.

P.S I'll probably return to try the food on the menu. But definitely no more Second Chance...

As someone with social anxiety, I appreciate the fact that they offer kiosk ordering in addition to the regular kind. They also churn out orders rather quickly. A large onigiri, large taro milk tea, and large blueberry tea (both w/ pearls) ran us about $24 w/ tip. I appreciate all the drink customizations, including multiple non-dairy milks. Both drinks turned out very good, and the large vegan kung pao onigiri packed umami flavor. Could've used more soy(?) protein and seaweed filling, though.

I just wish the seating was a little less cramped.

Yaya is a reliable chain for quick and delicious onigiris! My go-tos are the Yaya shrimp rice ball (tempura + seaweed salad) and the tuna rice ball. I also like the small onigiris better than the larger ones - the larger ones have too much rice and fall apart easier.

There are multiple locations in the city and this one was the most disorganized/messy one I've been to. There were a lot of stacked boxes on the ground, full of extra straws/packaging. There are a few bar and counter seats but it didn't seem like anyone was making sure they were clean - there were lots of little pieces of rice/sauce on the tables when I was waiting to pick up my order on a busy weekend afternoon.

My go to place for boba and delicious onigri! The staffs are friendly and reminded me to get my straw for the boba (because I forgot). I ordered via the Snackpass app or there's two kiosks located in the store you can use. There's seating near the window and a table with stools to eat in the store.

Would highly recommend coming here to grab a bite or you can buy for snacks for your next hiking trip!

A good place for some refreshing boba tea with seating, although the seating can be limited/surrounded by boxes. AC is a little weak so was sweating in the place for a while. Self serve kiosks to order as well which is nice. Tea itself was good and kept be refreshed!

This location has bad stool seating and tables which is great . Still a very casual spot . The bubble tea was pretty great and lots of  onigiri options even vegan ones . The staff could be a bit friendlier. But thankfully I was in good company so didn't let it bother us .
Boba is cold (I expected it to be warm or hot!) and the store is very messy. The ordering process was smooth. But I won't return here.

I stayed at a hotel nearby and was so thankful to have this spot to go to for my afternoon onigiri. I have tried their crawfish and the Japanese one. I loved that the crawfish one had a bit of a kick with the spicy mayo. My feedback on the Japanese one...the picture showed an omelet-style egg but the one I got had chopped up hard-boiled egg. I would've liked it omelet-style better. I want to try the plum and spam one, next time, and come back for the teas! This place is conveniently located in Little Italy, right across Ferrara. You can order on the kiosk or at the counter, and service was fast. It's a quick order spot, not really for hanging out, but it's casual and efficient.

Came in during the early morning- kiosk on the side for easy order and pickup. Got a Taro milk tea with a Chicken Onigiri. Got my order fairly quickly and liked Taro tea a lot- with just the right sweetness. My Onigiri was okay- the rice fell apart as soon as I put it in my mouth. This location is clean and has enough space for a fast sit down bite.

I've seen suggestions of this place online several times so I decided to come with a friend here so we can try, since we both like exploring different foods from different countries, we chose this place, we ordered Chicken Onigiri (Riceball) and Dumplings and a tea, there are stations where you can order by yourself which we did, the service was quick, took around 5-10 minutes which was totally worth waiting, the Onigiri was very much full of flavor and I really enjoyed it. The mood here makes you feel relaxed, it's a nice place to have a quick snack to go or eat. I came here a week later with my family and they absolutely loved it. I will totally come back to this place several times whenever I have the time to do so.

Their rice balls are so simple in flavor yet filling. My personal favorite is still the Japanese one. The Yaya chicken is a close second. It's pretty affordable and eating 1-2 onigiris will fill you up. They also keep well in the fridge for 2-3 days (I'd recommend reheating them in the microwave or panfrying them).

I got a Boyfriend and it just tasted like fruit tea to me. The cup was 70% ice which was disappointing so I probably wouldn't get it again.

Yaya Tea is always a reliable spot for affordable eats, great place for a quick bite in Chinatown!!

Yaya Tea has multiple locations throughout the city. Yaya Tea on a corner of Grand Street is a bit smaller than other locations, especially in terms of seating. However, still perfect for grab-and-go if you're craving milk/fruit teas and onigiri! This location also offers self-service via Snackpass, which was super helpful in customizing our orders.

My friends and I all ordered their signature Boyfriend drink (mango and lychee white tea) as well as their chicken riceball with spicy mayo. I ordered my drink with 50% sugar and with lychee jelly, and the drink turned out having a fairly strong tea flavor. It was less sweet than I expected, so I would probably increase it to 75% sugar next time. The lychee jelly was the perfect texture and had a satisfying snap. Their chicken riceball had a balanced ratio of rice to filling. The rice could have been seasoned more thoroughly--some of the rice was a bit mushy and lacked a crisp vinegary taste. I ordered the riceball in its small size, and it was still pretty filling! The spicy mayo, though definitely had a kick to it, was cold compared to the warm riceball, and I found this a bit off-putting. This order was still pretty cheap though, and service was relatively quick.

Yaya Tea has been a nostalgic staple of mine for years and will continue to be. Though the food is not necessarily outstanding, it's still a pretty yummy bargain in Chinatown!
Loved the drink the tapioca was especially good!! The service was good too and the overall feeling of the inside was cozy! Thanks a bunch

***ABSOLUTE MUST***
This place wags soo good better than what I expected in a good way. The tea was nice but the real star was the rice ball. I just got plain and used soy sauce and it was so tasty. Great for an on-the-go snack but they also had some seating inside. Definitely going back for more.

This is my favorite stop in Chinatown. I'll try and come here every time!! my favorites are the shrimp, tempura, rice balls. I also love the boyfriend tea with tapioca pearls there taro milk tea is also very delicious. I recommend getting at 75% sweet.

Dropped by this place for a quick bite and was pretty satisfied. The riceballs are good, nothing incredibly special but they taste pretty much how I would expect. The packaging is pretty cool--it prevents the seaweed from getting soggy before you eat, which is neat. The boba was serviceable but not amazing, overall a nice place for a quick pick me up in Chinatown.
I love yaya team. I usually get fruit tea with aloe and  shrimp tempura rice balls. This is my go to for onigiris it's so delicous

I've been here a couple times and I like their drinks. They're also pretty reasonably priced (in my opinion) because I know boba can get pretty expensive at some places.

This place has kiosks which you can order on and my friend liked their onigiri. I'd definitely come back here.

One of the original Boba shops in Chinatown, except that this is a location, then the one near Popeyes. They are still expanding. And they just recently opened a new location in Brooklyn around DeKalb Avenue.

I really like their bubble tea because they have kept it consistent. I like that their flavors are still the same from way back when and that their drinks are still good. They also have good rice balls. They offer stamp cards for buy 10 drinks receive a free drink purchase. Their prices are still lower than many Boba shops at around 5 dollars compared to the typical 7 to 8 dollars at other Boba stores.

Yaya will always be full of good memories for me as I've visited since I was in high school. I love their boyfriend, first love, and lychee tea drink!

We ordered a large Lychee Tree and a small salmon rice ball for $10. The rice ball took a bit of time, but the decor and merchandise were fun to pass the time. Good, but nothing too special about the food. Great for snacking.

I make a stop here every time I eat at Nyonya right across the street. I'm usually more of a milk tea person, but I'm always impressed by the fruit tea here. It's strongly tea-forward (I get less sweet every time), which is definitely what I always want in any boba drink. I like the I Love Yaya and I often make my own tea with a white tea base and tea jelly or aloe, less sweet. I'm usually too full from Nyonya so I haven't tried any of the food here, but it looks delicious and popular, and the staff is always kind! This place singlehandedly changed my mind about rarely ordering fruit teas!

It's Lunar New Year!  Happy Lunar New Year!

I was hungry and needed food that was portable since there is no dining in right now.  
Decided on a small salmon rice ball.  This was perfect.  With so many people around, I ended up eating this later in the afternoon at home.

Great drinks but with a fear of no bathroom availability with so many people, I opted out of getting a drink this time.

Stop by and check it out.

Not much to complain. Chill spot for kids. Drinks are great. Service is fast, you order on the kiosk and they get it out within 20 minutes. The onigiri is good too. Yaya chicken isn't the best but other than that I got shrimp tempura which was good. 4.2/5.0 star experience

This spot is awesome! It's rare to find onigiri in NYC, especially with such a variety of fillings. I'm a vegetarian so I really appreciate that there are vegan options. The spring roll variation is also really yummy.

It's also so reasonably priced. I find onigiri to be really filling, so I'll get 3 in the small size and I'm usually stuffed after (shout out to carbs). This comes out to around $10 which is a great price for a filling and delicious meal.

The boba is great - pretty standard as far as boba goes - I get the fruit teas every now and again with my favorite being Clean Clothes (kiwi). I prefer less sweet so I usually get 50% sugar and sometimes I'll add lychee jelly for fun + another texture.

WARNING -- DANGEROUS
i came in this past sunday around 6pm and both me and my friend got a bubble tea. first off extremely bland and just tasted like sour water. weird because the two of us usually like yaya's bubble tea but anyways we left with our drinks and at one point after i took a sip i started to choke really bad and couldnt seem to dislodge whatever it was. after a while i had to stick a finger down my throat just to find it was some sort of piece of thin metal all tangled up (almost like a staple or something?) it literally pierced the skin by my throat and two days later it's still swollen and painful.

extremely dangerous and negligent. i understand it was a BIT busy at the time but this potentially could have been much worse had it been a child or a elderly drinking it.

Still frequent this spot often to get rice balls and drinks for myself and the kiddies. Today I ordered via DoorDash on my way out so I thought I wouldn't have to wait too long. My order wasn't suppose to take as long as it did but I ordered hot drinks instead of cold. When I told them I mistakenly ordered it hot, they willingly remade my drinks and asked if the app confused me so they can improve. That is really great customer service- I was ready to pay for my mistake but I was not charged. Drinks were great and rice balls were as good as they normally are. Anyway- will be back as frequently as I normally would come!

The food is good. I had tried boba for the first time in there and I am in love. The flavors were good and I am definitely going again. The service is nice, they have nice workers which treat u with respect. The place is nice filled with different varieties like onigiri, boba, plushies etc. There is a large variety of things to eat/drink.

Riceballs with all your favorite fillings such as crabmeat, spam or shrimp tempura. Plus a great and delicious selection of fruity teas that are pre-set or you can mix and match your own flavors with tea choice. Always an awesome spot for a quick bite and to quench your thirst.

Cute tapioca spot.

We tried their Blue Blood Tea with 25% sugar and tapioca and got 1 chicken onigiri. The drink was fair,  sweetened to my liking, however the tapioca pearls were tough.

The chicken onigiri was tasty though! The chicken was flavorful, and it was the perfect on-the-go snack.

Dine-in currently not allowed.
Very good vegetarian options. Just a few seats. Loved the mango boba teas. Rice bowls are very Nice for snacks. Would go again.

Friendly and quick service. Drinks and food left a lot to be desired. Tried the fried chicken and tuna onigiri, both were disappointing. Fried chicken was dry and overly salty and the rice was not seasoned well and way too wet that it was a ball of mush. Similar issue for the tuna and the tuna itself was very fishy. The oolong milk tea had no tea flavor and did not taste like oolong. Tapioca was lovely with a perfect chewiness and sweetness.

So many options to choose from! Highly recommend looking at their full drink menu because some of their drink names are pretty funny, definitely really creative. If you're not getting multiple rice balls, upgrade to the large because you'll want another for sure! Another tip is to pay a bit extra for the spicy mayo on the side and pour it on the riceball. If you've never opened a onigiri packaging before, no worries because the plastic wrap has instructions on it for newbies.

- Japanese Rice Ball (seaweed salad, hard boiled egg, imitation crab meat) - this is one of my go to rice balls. The ingredients are so simple, but go perfectly together!

- Chicken Rice Ball - it was pretty salty compared to usual this time, but overall great flavor!

- Green Panda (green apple and mango tea) - if you're into sugary drinks, this is for you since they use flavored syrups for all their drinks. Make sure to check your drink for the taped message for an added bonus to make your day!

Went by because I was craving bubble tea snd this is one of the locations that I love the most. I went in and there was no line. There were people waiting for orders but that wasn't an issue. I ordered 5 large drinks which came to about $30. The staff member was nice and recommened to get Better Life as I was undure of which drink to get. Once the drinks were resdy I did notice that they missed the toppings for one of the drinks. I let them know and they quickly fixed my drink which I very much appreciated it. Overall i will likely return again as I forgot to get myself an onigiri from there. 4.5/5
Yaya is perfect place to go for a variety of tea. Refreshing and a classic spot to go in the heart of Chinatown. This is a grab and go.

Believe it or not, I'd never tried boba tea and was always a bit suspicious of it and afraid of the pearls. It was so tasty! We also got rice balls and those things are a very addictive snack. Ordering is easy through the tablets. Service is quick and nice.
Yaya is my go to spot for bubble tea and rice balls! Been a loyal customer for years and all their locations are great

This is such an adorable boba shop! The tea is delicious and you can either choose from their menu or customize your own drink. The prices are reasonable and the staff are friendly. I will definitely be visiting again.

The first time I came here, I ordered the Boyfriend which is a mango and lychee white tea. Even though I asked for 10% sweet, it was very sweet. Not sure if they forgot or if the regular drinks are supposed to be extremely sweet. I couldn't taste any mango; the lychee flavor was overpowering but since I love lychee, I didn't mind. The second time I came here, I got a salmon onigiri (riceball) -- this was delicious! I got a size small one and it was bigger than I expected. It was sufficient for a light lunch. If I'm hungrier, I'd try a size large or maybe get 2 or 3 size small to try. I'm interested in coming back to try other onigiri, and maybe I'll try their teas again. If so, I'll probably try a hot milk tea.

I love yayas! They have the best fruit teas and the best rice balls! Rice balls come in a small or large size. My favorite is the yaya chicken and the salmon one! They also have appetizers here like spring roll, takoyaki, shumai, and gyoza. My favorite drink is the boyfriend with lychee jelly. The credit card minimum is $5 and they have a rewards card too! There's also a spacious open area inside to sit

Yaya is a tea, rice ball, and snack shop. There isn't any outdoor seating for COVID. Also note there's a 10$ min for credit cards.

For their fruit teas,  I think the fruit syrup is equivalent to sugar level, so if you have less sugar, you get less fruit. Fairly run of the mill. Would get again.

They have snacks I don't normally see in American and even Asian stores. We lemon lime hichews and the Japanese equivalent of lemon warheads.

Strawberry mang passion fruit oolong tea - good oolong taste, strong passion fruit.
Lichee green tea - lichee strong, good balance with the green tea
Tempura rice ball - really cute sticker, the seaweed was easy to apply. I think if it had tempura sauce it be great, ofc that might not be "authentic"

Ordered a strawberry green tea with boba and my drink tasted like water, no green tea flavor and no strawberry. Pearls weren't soft enough for me. My friend ordered the Boyfriend and felt the same sentiment. Go to Truedan instead right next door!

Service was great, not pushy. They make the order right although the interior is a mess if it is a real sit down place. The depth of taro milk tea is just okay for my taste 7/10 and think they use powder taro. Yifang Taiwan Fruit is still my favorite although it is much more expensive

Yaya's has always been my go to for a casual, affordable meal. Yes, they are a bubble tea shop, but for me, their selling point is their Onigiri. They have so many different flavors and each come in small and large. My favorites are the Japanese (seaweed, crab meat & egg) and the shrimp tempura. The filling to rice ratio is ideal, and I love that they season the rice so no part of the Onigiri is bland. I've also had their takoyaki as well. They make them just as good as a Japanese izakaya!

They have a lot of different teas, with unique flavors like lychee, kiwi, and passionfruit. You can even customize your own tea drink.

As an added bonus, they also sell cute merch, like plushes, earrings, hoodies, tshirts, and bubble tea kits. Sadly, due to Covid, there is no dine-in or outdoors option, but I can see this being a great spot to hang out and grab some snacks in better times.

Yaya's please keep doing what you do best :)

Cute spot with cute merch. Got the jasmine honey milk tea. It had a creamy taste. Service was meh. Waited twenty minutes for drinks when it wasn't that crowded. Have friends who love this place though!

A place I always have to go to when I visit NYC. Nice location with seating areas to chill with friends and just hangout. The staffs are super friendly as well.

I always order the Japanese rice ball for myself and or the Yaya with shrimp for my friend. It is a good price as well. I believe the Japanese rice ball is $2.75 and the yaya with shrimp is $3.25. For the drinks, I always enjoyed "First Love" and "Boyfriend". I like "first love" and "boyfriend" because it has my favorite flavor in them. Those two have great combinations of flavors. I ordered the jasmine milk tea this time with 50% sugar.

Will come back again the next time i visit the city and try something different.

Solid riceballs. The Japanese Riceball is still my fave, but I really miss the Spicy Tea Egg Riceball. Please bring it back. God, I need a fix of that asap :/

I don't come here as often as I'd like to, primarily because I don't live in Manhattan anymore, but the prices are decent and reasonable. Service varies but pretty quick for the most part.

Yaya is a solid boba and onigiri spot. Although there's a steady line, most people do take out so there are seats available.

Yaya is cute, though it might not be the most aesthetic café in the area. The prices are reasonable though.

They have cute messages on the cups and they also sell Japanese and other Asian snacks.

I'd recommend Yaya!

Their drinks were good quality and not too sweet. We also ordered the shrimp tempura and salmon onigiri. We preferred the shrimp tempura. The prices are affordable and the onigiri will definitely fill you up. This is a great place to go for some snacks and drinks. The only down side is that they didn't have indoor or outdoor seating, but it may be because the place is small.

This is actually a hidden gem to me. I do archery nearby and have become a regular here.

Perfect to go with a friend or two. It's got a small mom and pop vibe to it. And even if you're solo, they have a bar off to the side you can sit at.

When I'm in a rush, I'll stop by and order a jian bing. I've tried the beef and fish ones and have loved them so far. Particularly the fish.

They've got nutritious, homey tasting noodles like the wonton or pork belly noodle soup for when I'm not feeling well. If I had to pick between the two it'd be pork belly. Well portioned pork belly slices.

We never exchange many words but the simple friendly hellos are always appreciated especially here in Chinatown

the jianbing is just alright but damn that chongqing noodle was so good lol i cannot wait to come back and just get that spicy noodle one more time because i was drooling off the earth.

the bathroom is tucked in some really weird corner and you have to ask the person at the front to help get the key. They speak mandarin and cantonese. 3.5% extra for a credit card.

No tips needed, it's a fast casual place but i left one anyways because they gave me back extra change.

would totally come back again

I'd rate this a 4.5, rounding up cause I just had their noodles today and it was satisfying.

Noodles flavors are consistently tasty and not too oily (unless it's supposed to be), place is no-nonsense but uncrowded, the lady there is super nice. Price is not cheap but reasonable (it's post pandemic inflation, I have to keep reminding myself nothing's gonna be cheap like the old days TT_TT).

Favorites are the sour & spicy noodle and chongqing noodle if you're looking for flavor bomb, lanzhou beef (great when you're craving warm, comforting but clean clear broth). Zhajiangmian aint bad either if you're looking for a dry  brothless noodle.

Solid neighborhood joint that locals like me keep coming back to.

So delicious. My friend and I went for a very late breakfast. I had the beef jian bing, she tried the pork belly jian bing. We both absolutely loved it.

The portion was very generous and the price was very reasonable. We both left with happy bellies lol.

Everyone in there was very friendly. The inside is tiny but very clean.

It was seriously delicious. I've never tried jian bing before and I definitely want to again.

Yiwanmen is one of my favorite casual noodle restaurants in all of Manhattan Chinatown. Specializing in Sichuan cuisine, its noodles are consistently delicious, with fresh ingredients and vibrant flavors. The establishment is relatively small with a few tables, but clean and large enough to accommodate my daughter in her large stroller when we visited Yiwanmen on a Saturday around noon.

Whether for dining in or delivery, my favorite dishes are the fish noodle soup with mala sauce and their signature Chongqing red oil noodle. The noodles are perfectly chewy, broth savory, and  portions generously sized. Although their jian bing was very good, I was disappointed to find that the "sausage" was really just hot dog. While hot dogs are ubiquitous as a street snack in China, I was hoping for something less...processed and more akin to Chinese sausage. Even so, Yiwanmen is a staple for us in the noodle genre in Chinatown, especially given the quality and affordability.

I order 2 pork belly bao, the bao are nice and soft, come with sliced cucumbers in them . It taste quite refreshing but the sauce I did not like it. I wished the pork belly was warm . The place is very small and has a few tables and chair, not good for big groups. I think the most it can fit is a group of 4 . They have a $15 minimum for credit card . So make sure you bring cash and no public restroom.

I discovered Jian Bing watching street food videos on internet and had to have one! A google search surprised me with options all over town. I've had some great ones and so so great. Yiwanmen is a great option and they offer 7 different kinds. I go for the pork belly. A jian bing is a crêpe with fillings and sauce, but there's also a crispy cracker in the middle that's a fun texture in your mouth! Was it down with a chilled  herbal tea.

Solid Chinese noodle place! Very small shop with 3-4 benches as seating and a semi private seating area in the back. The shop was quite clean and brightly lit, and when I went on a Tuesday night at 6:30 there weren't many people there.

I ordered the chongqing noodles (spicy oil, lettuce, preserved mustard, and pork) for $9, which was really worth it! The noodles had good texture, broth was very flavorful but not too spicy, and a good serving of toppings. I would come back to try the jianbing for sure!

Yiwanmen (translates to one bowl of noodles in English) is a small family-owned restaurant in Chinatown. The storefront is tiny and only have 4 tables and some window seating. You order by the front then grab a table. The lady in the front who you order with will also bring you your food. Menu is not that elaborate -- about 8 noodle options and some buns / pancake selections. I couldn't decide whether to order the Chongqing noodles or the hot & spicy intestines noodles, but ultimately decided to try the Chongqing noodles since it seemed to be their signature. We also ordered the hot braised beef noodle. Our order didn't take long to arrive. First sip of broth and was disappointed by the lack of spiciness for both bowls of noodles even though it's supposed to be spicy noodles. We added some chili oil, which is on every table for use, but that didn't really do much for knocking up the spice level. Overall, while I was disappointed about the level of spice, I did enjoy the flavor of the broth and noodles. It was a delicious and affordable lunch for under $10/bowl of noodles -- which is what I love about Chinatown, especially during a time of inflation and rising food costs.

I do recommend this noodle shop to those who want to enjoy a bowl of noodles without the spicy kick. If you're a spice lover, look somewhere else.

After walking by this spot several times, I finally came in for a try. Their menu is simple - noodles, and some sides. Prices are pretty low, but portions aren't crazy big (definitely still sufficient for a meal though).

Everything was pretty yummy. The soup was savory, and I really like the Jian Bing. The mango basil tea was sooo good. Their Meng Meng tea was super sweet - I wouldn't recommend unless you love SWEET drinks.

The duck bao was good, but I've had better baos.
Overall, nice spot! Some seating indoors - good for SMALL groups.

I stopped by recently over the weekend for a quick lunch. The place is small - a few tables and some counter seating. It feels like a small mom-and-pop shop. I had the Pork Floss Jian Bing, which was good, but not the best one I've had. I think it could've been a bit more substantial. My partner had the Pork Belly Bao and the Pork and Chive Dumplings. The dumplings might've been the most solid dish out of the 3. I think this is a good spot for a quick bite while in the Little Italy/Chinatown area.

My girlfriend and I saw this place while walking and went inside on a whim. It's a very cozy spot with Mandopop playing in the background.

We only got their jianbing with crispy fritters (the classic way it's made) and the lady behind the counter was nice enough to split it in half for us.

The jianbing was delicious with nice crunch from the fritters and pickled veggies, and when you add their chili oil thats available on the tables, the spicyness takes it to the next level.

Next time I would definitely go back for their noodles which look delicious as well.

What a delicious and warm little pocket of yumminess that you can carry in your hands!

My sister and I had the beef slice (B5) jian bing. It was so tasty! The egg wrap had the perfect thickness. I feel like sometimes when it's too thick it becomes too much egg. The Hoisin sauce wasn't overpowering either. I also really liked the crispy fritter thing stuffed in the middle. Of course, the rest of the filling was the perfect complement, too. I am interested in trying some other flavors.

I know the restaurant was mainly known for their noodles, but I think their jian bing are now getting some hype. Stop by for a little snack!

Visited this shop after craving some good ole Asian food and I will say this shop definitely satisfied! It's a cute lil shop with VERY affordable prices (bowl of noodles was $9) in the NY area. Overall the noodles were good but i would say the flavor can be a little richer for the beef noodle.

They also charge a 3.5% credit card fee for any transactions Where you pay with CC so bring some cash :)

This place is DANKKKKK get the n1 or n2 for some authentic beef noodle soup!! GET THE NOODLE SOUP THIS IS A NOODLE SOUP PLACE!! The owners are also super nice and the service is great. Definitely recommend checking out this small restaurant! I would recommend no groups larger than six unless you don't mind sitting apart. These are the kinds of restaurants that make Chinatown great!!

Delicious snack you can pick up and eat! I ordered the B5 / sliced beef jian bing. The flavors were immaculate and the ingredients tasted fresh.
It was smaller than I expected, but it was the perfect amount of food to hold my hunger down. I was able to walk and eat it with ease.  
It also took some time to prepare, but you can definitely call to order ahead! I noticed a lot of people coming in to pick up their called in orders.
They seemed to have a lot of options on their menu with indoor seating!

I was wondering around looking for something to eat and decided to come here for jiang bing.  I had one with duck before but it wasn't on the menu so I asked. They said they could make it so I ordered two. I was shocked when she said it was $29. I had to ask a few times because the others ones were $6-9. I paid cash since card would be charged another 3.5%. I ate mine as soon as it was ready. It was delicious. Light sauce with lots of fresh veggies, some duck and crispy chip-like thing wrapped in a warm crepe-y outer layer. My friend ate his later but still crunchy and good. Because of the price, I'm not sure how often I would order this but it was delicious.

On a Chinatown jaunt we popped in
The front of the house person (I assume owner) was very pleasant, friendly and kind
We tried the pork belly crepe
A very interesting an nice change of pace
A pleasant flavor and texture as well
I'd recommend you check one out
She also recommended the beef noodle and I would certainly return to check that out
Pretty good Jianbing - haven't had the other items, but saw others eating noodle soups. Very cute mom and pop shop, some seating inside, low prices. What's not to like?

Friendly staff. Limited seating inside. I ordered the jian bing and it was very yummy, albeit smaller than I was expecting for the price.

The pork floss one is delicious and the perfect snack, or meal if you have a very small appetite. I'd eat it again, but $8 for the pork floss one seems a bit steep to me.

Wanted to introduce a friend to a traditional jian bing experience and stopped by Yiwanmen. Tiny interior but friendly, fast service and delicious food! The perfect on the go snack/lunch. Would happily return.

My friend insisted we try an authentic Jianbing while in NY which led us to Yiwanmen. We were greeted warmly with an elegant storefront and friendly service. The staff were welcoming and patient while we figured out our order. Once we ordered, we enjoyed a quick chat while they prepared our order fresh. Within minutes, we had freshly made breakfast ready for a great price. Now, arguably the most important part: how did it taste? The answer is simple, absolutely delicious. By far one of the BEST breakfast items I've had. Flavorful barely begins to describe it. There is an excellent blend of texture and flavor that is perfect for a crisp morning in NY. I would highly recommend everyone to give this restaurant a shot as I know the Jianbing was just scratching the surface. There's much more on that menu that's worth a try, I'll definitely be back!

Listen up, folks! I stumbled upon this joint in Chinatown, and let me tell you, it's a hidden gem. This place serves jian bing - a Chinese breakfast delicacy that's hard to find outside of Flushing. And while it's not the best I've ever had (a little too mushy for my taste), it definitely hits the spot when you're in the mood for something different.

But wait, there's more! This small restaurant is a staple in the neighborhood and is known for their noodles - I haven't tried them yet, but I've heard they're pretty darn good. Plus, the vibe is perfect for grabbing food to go or for a quick solo or friend-date.

Speaking of the neighborhood, Chinatown is not to be missed. It's a cultural hub that's bursting with life, history, and, of course, delicious food. From the colorful storefronts to the bustling streets, there's so much to see and explore. So next time you're in the area, swing by this spot for a quick bite and soak up all the magic that Chinatown has to offer.

Delicious ramen, baos and crepes, and also the best deal in town where you can get a meal for $10. Not for those who dislike tight spaces: it's a tiny spot, and you'll likely be sharing a table with another couple. I thought the waitress (who also cooks)  was nice, and  she even translated everything from Chinese to English for us. Totally recommend if you're in the area .

I love love jian bings! They're my favorite street food to eat. This beef jian bing was no different. The beef wasn't  sliced like I thought it would be but minced. I thought the beef was a bit salty but it was still juicy and delicious. I noticed they added lettuce - I don't think I've had a jian bing with lettuce before but I love it! I would come back here and try their other flavors.

They have outdoor seating as well. They have indoor but they prefer customers to sit in the designated outdoor seating.

A delicious noodle spot in the border of chinatown and little Italy. The place is small with three big tables and two bar tables, but there are a lot of seats. Noodles are chewy and served in a delicious broth. I had the wonton noodle soup and those wontons were stuffed, the broth was very clear and it felt like soup for the soul. We also had the spicy braised beef noodle soup, the broth was intense and rich in flavor. We ordered at the counter and our food was ready less than ten minutes later. I don't think you can go wrong with a place like this. I'll be back to try the jianbings and their fruit teas.

If you see my BMI shooting up to the roof, look no further at the crispy Jianbing ($6) from Yiwanmen.

Your diet is going to thank you very much mhmmm.
煎饼果 was very good. Spicy pork was  my picture is of the 肉松! It is also a very good price.

Great experience overall. The owners were extremely nice, the noodles were very good and the price was only $9... it's been a while since a good hot lunch in the area cost less that $10.

I ordered the N1. Chong Qing Red Oil Noodle. It was delicious and look forward to trying the N2. Hot braised beef noodle on my next visit.

Tip: Go with cash so you avoid a CC fee.
Fantastic and truly authentic spot for some good noodle soup. The broth was very warm and yummy, and the wontons were tasty. The interior was also very calming to eat at.
