Yoshida-san has a reputation among high-end sushi chefs in New York for serving the best tuna, often featuring Oma and Aomori hon-maguro during the meal.

On my first visit in February 2022, I loved the chef's ankimo preparation along with the sawara, chiaigishi, and otoro nigiri, the bafun uni gunkan maki, miso soup, and Sous Chef Gang's Basque cheesecake. This week's highlights included the ankimo and nodoguro egg yolk rice otsumami. The ko-aji and akami nigiri, miso soup, and uni torotaku handroll were also exceptional. For dessert, the white chocolate gelato was a standout. Across the visits, Chef Yoshida's ankimo has been stellar - creamy, luscious, rich, and slightly sweet. And this week's lightly grilled nodoguro exploded with liquid fat and flavor that coats your tongue and mouth. The finish was long, lingering for minutes afterward.

Yoshino successfully captures the 'New York Style' dinner theater experience, a concept pioneered by Sushi Noz in 2018. From the hikarimono and tuna display to the sabazushi searing ceremony, Yoshida-san and Sous Chef Gang grab and hold the diners' attention.

At times, Yoshino suffers from a lack of harmony. On my first visit, I was underwhelmed by the heavily French-influenced otsumami; one that still bothers me was a plastic bag filled with clams and tasteless shaved truffle. While the otsumami were significantly better on my second visit, the shiro amadai, kaki, kegani appetizer missed the mark even if the culinary techniques and presentation were high-class. Despite the hype, his signature dishes such as the saba pressed roll and karasumi mochi are not more delicious than his other offerings. In fact, the mochi was tasteless and slightly burnt with poor distribution of karasumi inside.

For aficionados and completionists, Yoshino is worth a visit. However, even at Yoshino, you will not find perfection. If perfection doesn't exist, then maybe we should look for something else. While Yoshino is undoubtedly a top-tier sushi restaurant in NYC, it falls short of becoming my personal favorite, and I don't foresee frequent return visits.

Best Omakase - chef and staff were amazing. Great conversations with everyone.  Goes without saying the food was outstanding but the service is really also top notch.  For example, Chef was explaining in detail the fish and even the ingredients.  

Beware when you ask for tea though, i wasn't paying attention and got the really expensive tea (it was worth it but shocked at the price).  That said, this isn't the place to nickel and dime yourself, enjoy the experience.

Exceptional.  Truly a master. Very intimate to be able to watch the chef so closely.  
We were celebrating our engagement and felt very special. They were so warm and inviting.

This was my first visit to Yoshino. I recommend not reading too many reviews, especially the New York Times one, beforehand, and let yourself be the judge of your own experience. As someone on the NYC omakase circuit, I found Yoshino to execute extremely well on the classics. The omakase falls short on the creative side, but that's okay, because you'll leave without regrets - it really is one of the best.

Yoshino is a hidden gem that captured my heart! From the moment I stepped in, I was warmly welcomed, creating a comfortable and inviting atmosphere. The menu presented a delightful selection of traditional Japanese dishes with a contemporary twist, each dish thoughtfully presented like a work of art, a true testament to the chef's exceptional talent and creativity. The staff's friendliness and attentiveness made the entire experience even more enjoyable, and I wholeheartedly recommend Yoshino for an unforgettable dining adventure that will leave you eager to return for more!

Writing a review for Yoshino New York feels a bit silly, as they hardly need more buzz. Even if they did, words seem inadequate. A part of me feels the need to try, if only to thank the team for the special night my wife and I had.

Chef Yoshida is a true master, and we are lucky that he has taken his talents to America. Rather than an intimidating journey however, Mr. Yoshida puts everyone at ease with his outgoing personality and never lets you take it all too seriously. What took it to another level was the authentic enthusiasm and warmth that everyone on the team exhibited. My closest USA comparison to the vibe would be Alinea in Chicago, another culinary destination that will knock your socks off but can still take a joke.

The omakase is simply on another level compared to any other in America. Every dish on the menu is outstanding, but if I were forced to pick a few favorites it would be the oysters and tilefish in hairy crab broth, the golden eye snapper with crispy skin, horse mackerel nigiri, the three tuna preparations, and the most ridiculously delicious handroll with tuna and uni.

Special commendation to Ms. Kobayashi, the GM and sommelier. The sake pairing perfectly complimented every dish, and she expertly guided the room throughout the night. Her mastery helped turn terrific into transcendent time and time again.

Wow !!! Just WOW! Words cannot even come close to BEGIN describing how incredible, unique, and talented Chef Yoshida is!!!

The cuisine presented to you here, is pure, authentic Japanese sushi. It is in a class of it's own! At this rate, chef stands to take the #1 spot for BEST SUSHI CHEF in the entire nation! [& may possibly, beat out my favorite sushi chef, by far... ] I will not names - but for the few of you who know, you know!!!]

This 1 year anniversary dinner, which my boyfriend and I attended last night, was absolutely spectacular & superb!!!

Might I add.. we left feeling full to our heart's content, but not painfully full.. which can happen sometimes. I can imagine that as a chef, it is difficult to create an Omakase that satisfies all; while leaving you full to the point of not needing to eat the rest of your night, but not being SO full to where you can't sleep hehe.. again, iykyk :)!

Onto the meal! We started out with 6 delectable courses prior to 12 pcs of sushi. Each and every bite was phenomenal.

When it comes to serving up an Omakase, I believe the true magic lays within the chef's creative ability to not only deliver an outstanding, quality meal, but to also be able to captivate his guests and interact with us all - setting an ambiance to experience the art of food and culture, with the person(s) you are with, and surrounded by.

Chef Yoshida not only delivers, but SETS THE STANDARD for what a 3 Michelin star restaurant looks and feels like. The experience crafted by chef and his team goes above and beyond! He is on par with all [5] - 3 Michelin star restaurants in NYC, and better than at least one of those. [[The one I'm referring to is NOT Japanese cuisine, rather French - but comes off as more of a Mediterranean fusion, which isn't anything to die for - and probably should be a 2 star. Anyway, that's neither here nor there - ]]

As far as the overall delicacy served at Yoshino and the experience delivered, is is definitely worth  a try!

***That goes for anyone that is a fan of true, Japanese cuisine and culture. For westerners that simply enjoy sushi - I'm not quite sure you'll experience it in the same way; you must understand, to really enjoy. I write this comment for anyone that reads a review in the future that sounds out of touch with my review - or differs from my opinion - some yelpers criticize price, etc. if you are a true foodie - this isn't going to be your concern and you'll prepare to visit ahead of time. Nor will that be a reason for you to write a negative review, bc I doubt anyone will experience a negative time when visiting Yoshino.***

Chef Yoshida is a true artist. Yoshino is the epitome of excellence at its finest! Enjoy :) !!!

Pete Wells is the Ebenezer Scrooge of the restaurant scene, so when he gave Yoshino Four Stars in the New York Times I knew it had to be amazing. And it is! Sushi Master Tadashi Yoshida is the first sushi master to actually move to the United States. In the past it has been only protégés of a sushi master that have moved to the US, but at the age of 50 Yoshida decided to close his Nagoya restaurant and set up shop in New York. Having been to Japan many times in the last thirty years, I must say that this was one of the most amazing sushi I have ever had and one of the top 10 meals of my life. It was a delight from beginning to end. The menu changes constantly so you will always be eating seafood that is in season and what is available to the chef from Japan. Mayumi Kobayashi, the general manager and sommelier, is an experienced restaurateur with an outsized and welcoming personality. The staff is excellent as well. Truly a wonderful experience.

Yoshino is definitely brings some new vibe n trend in already crowded n high quality Japanese cuisine standards in nyc.
I love each bite of the dish.
Personally, I love it better than MASA. N I look forward Yoshino getting 3 stars

I booked Yoshino 3 months in advance for my fiancé's birthday. I had high expectations after hearing that the chef of this restaurant owned a sushi restaurant in Japan that was rated in the top 3 of Japan on Tabelog (Japan's extremely selective version of Yelp.)

This place was so Japanese that I felt like I was in Japan. Sushi or fish that I had not eaten since my last trip were on the menu. Everything was fresh and delicious.

There were a few dishes on the menu like shirako (cod milt) and the mochi with karasumi in it that I felt were difficult to serve to an American audience. I wondered the chef would eventually have to adjust these menu items to fit an American palate. That being said I had the best version of shirako that I have ever had here. I could appreciate the quality even though it is a dish I typically don't care for.

Yoshino-san was also very funny and hospitable. My fiancé was impressed that they noticed he was left handed and set the table so it was easier for him to eat.

My fiancé loved his experience and thought it was one of the best dining experiences he had ever had. This experience reminded me very much of my time in Japan. It is a bit too expensive to go back regularly (you could buy an economy ticket to Japan the price of this meal, alcohol, and tip) but I would highly recommend this place for a special occasion dinner.

Love it here. Chef Yoshida is lovely and so are all the staff. Really love the vibe inside it's bright but not too bright. Warm yet clean and minimal too. The hinoki wood is stunning. A friend reserved the whole place for a big birthday dinner.

I thought the appetizer portion was excellent not super traditional and more inventive. You can definitely see the French influence. The sushi was the star as expected with perfect rice and perfect temperature fish. I really enjoyed the whole experience. Highly recommend.

I really want to love this restaurant, especially after seeing chef Yoshida's passion and determination to serve sushi for international audiences and hearing his story behind his relocation to NYC. However, being the most expensive sushi (and meals) I had had at $515 net, I expected nothing less than the best sushi in my life, and unfortunately it didn't deliver, by quite a large margin. There were things that I was impressed and a few things that let me down. Let me elaborate:

Things that impressed me: the technique and the texture - in my opinion, chef Yoshida's technique is number one. His nigiri was pressed into perfection. The amount of pressure he put onto the rice, making it firm to the touch, but still melt once it touches your tongue. The balance of topping and rice is impeccable. You might have had this experience where some chef did not get the amount of shari correctly, and you ended up chewing fish at the end of the piece while the rice already disappeared. Here, the rice and the fish were gone at the exact same time. And he managed to do this every single piece. This is truly a master at work.

Another point that really impressed me is the texture. Every piece is on point. The ankimo is cooked to perfection and melted in your mouth like a piece of Foie Gras. And I have never had a fried kinmedai as good as I had here.

However, here comes some minor disappointments. The fish, for some reason, did not quite show its flavor that day. The ebi was not quite as sweet as other places. The kohada, although was pickled really well, didn't taste very umami. The grilled saba, which was supposed to be the highlight of the night, did not have that lovely fattiness like when I had it at sushi Nakamura in Tokyo or Sushi Yoshizumi in San Meteo. The bafun uni was only average, although that's more about the luck of the draw rather than the skill of the chef.

Here comes the major disappointment: appetizer. To summarize, I think chef Yoshida tried to make appetizers that gear towards American audiences. I appreciate the effort, but the flavor combination just did not work well, and most of the time was more of a distraction from the ingredient itself. For instance, the fried kinmedai that was cooked to perfection, was drenched in a ginger scallion sweet soy sauce 'Chinese style'. I would be more satisfied if it was served only with a pinch of salt, grated wasabi or daikon, and a wedge of sudachi, which will certainly highlight the excellent cooking of the fish. The hotaru ika was smoked with some kind of wood (apple I believe) that did not go quite well with the ika, and furthermore it was seasoned heavily with white miso dressing which completely hid the flavor of the squid itself. I'd be completely satisfy if this was grilled lightly on binchotan charcoal with salt and served to me on a skewer. The worst dish of the night is certainly the salmon, which is covered in onion cream which taste like salad cream. It was sad that I didn't taste any salmon in that dish.

I didn't want to end this review in a bad note, so let me say that this is overall still an excellent meal. But if I take the price and the hype around it into account, I have to say it was quite a let down.

$400/ per, in terms of experience and food quality, it's definitely 10/10.
The chef yoshida and assistant chef gang are cutest chefs in New York. Their way of presenting their food is memorable, bring up lots of laughters, especially after a long day of work, some gentle laughter is needed.
The fishes are great, nothing to complain, but one thing can be improved is the mochi, it's just not my cup of tea, I wished it can be sweetened.
Other than that, I love to come back.

My first meal here was incredibly phenomenally amazing, but my second meal here was absolutely spectacularly unbelievable. ONE Michelin star? Should be TWO! EASILY surpasses my meals at Daniel & Kreuther & Saga.

AN ABSOLUTE DELIGHT. My husband stumbled on Eater's feature on Chef Yoshida and booked an 8:30pm reservation on a Monday night.

Chef Yoshida and the entire staff at Yoshino are incredible - the amount of effort, detail, finesse, and pure mastery of skill were fully on display during our 2.5 hour dining experience. What I especially loved about dining here was that even though you may experience waves of serious realization that you are eating food served by a true master chef --- Chef Yoshida and the talented staff at Yoshino (shoutout to Yuki & Chef Gang Lin!) are so personable, down to earth, and love engaging in some great & fun conversation, with everyone helping out to translate between Japanese and English!

The ambience is minimalist but you'll appreciate the intention from a design aspect given all the high quality materials and beautiful art on display. The tableware is beautiful - the plates, bowls, cutlery were aesthetically such a treat to experience! Also, I 100% appreciate that counter seating isn't at bar level for shorter people like me, and this doesn't sacrifice your ability to observe what's going on behind the counter.

The FOOD was just incredible. 21 courses of pure delight. Honestly everything was amazing, but the key highlights included house-made mochi stuffed with Karasumi, Japanese Tilefish cooked with clams in a broth with flavors as deep as the sea, Spanish Mackerel, Hand Roll, and the Basque Cheesecake!

Yes, the price is high, but this omakase experience will last in your memories as a truly unique fine dining experience!!

While we were in Hawaii, we were recommended this establishment from Sushi Sho's Nakazawa-San. Let me simply say, this meal was amazing and ethereal at times.

Yoshida-San is very friendly and will do his best to communicate with you in English. The menu had some nice touches with different techniques outside of the classic Edomae sushi courses. The initial appetizer was firefly squid with cauliflower purée and caviar. The sweet miso sauce binded all components of the dish and it was a luxurious, flavorful start to our omakase. Two of the appetizers were very similar to what we had at Sushi Sho (squid stuffed rice and ankimo) and were executed very well. We were served a very unique baby anago (noresore) in "noodle" form with a savory soup and tiny morsels of fried inari, which was quite delicious and different. We were also served a savory mochi (karasumi) which was stuffed with an in-house aged roe seared over charcoal; a very interesting texture (chewy like a thick mozzarella cheese with a stiffer gel-like texture from the air-aged roe) and very different from what we have ever had at an omakase establishment. The amadai (tilefish) dish was prepared inside a plastic bag encapsulating the aromatic fish and clam broth. Instead of being overpowered with salinity, the broth provided an intense flavor but light mouthfeel which was extracted from the two types of protein. The New Zealand king salmon dish with peeled cherry tomatoes was an excellent and unique dish as well. The tomatoes burst with their sweet juices while the salmon provided the familiar firm texture and fattiness as your bite progressed through the inside of your mouth.

The shari rice is made with 3 different types of vinegar and aggressively seasoned, just how I personally enjoy the shari when combined with the neta. The personal standout nigiri for me was the iwashi (sardine). The neta was scored incredibly intricately and had the perfect balance of flavor (slight sweetness from the fat), texture of the flesh, flavor of the shari, and the disbursement of the rice grains as the nigiri is pressed against the roof of your mouth with the initial bite. The bluefin tuna was top grade and two different types of otoro procured from Toyosu market that was first auction of best quality while the akami was from Boston. The two types of toro, kamashita and otoro had the familiar more firm texture of a wild bluefin tuna but finished with a nice melting of the fat which enveloped your tongue as you finished the bite. We were served a very unique lightly fried fugu milt (sperm sac) which continued the same velvety theme as the ankimo that was served earlier in the omakase. The Hokkaido uni used was of the very best premium quality as each gonad sliver was of the exact uniform color and size. Yoshida-San seemed most proud of his giant saba roll which was seared with a very hot charcoal grate. Again, very delicious.

The meal is very expensive (party of 2 was over $1,000 with tip, no alcohol) but if you have the money to burn, it is worth at least one try. You will encounter rare and unique items paired with elite technique while served with a smile and positive attitude. Enjoy!

Booked the reservation roughly 2 months in advance. I thought it would be the perfect place to celebrate an 11th year anniversary. Sadly, it was memorable in all the wrong ways. Maybe it was bad luck but luck shouldn't matter for a restaurant of this caliber.

Arrived at the restaurant 15 minutes early and waited with a few other guests in a small foyer. We were soon greeted by the host and shown to our seats. We sat at the far end. The interior is what one would expect. Gorgeous counter, tasteful decor, and spacious yet intimate. We were promptly presented with the menu and beverage options. The waiter also pointed out the cloth napkin ("a gift") that the chef designed himself. It was thoughtful and the design was unique but the fabric was far from ideal for napkin use (nit-picky). Regardless, we were excited for the food to come.

Then, things got ... interesting? Apparently, the day before was the chef's birthday and all the guests (expect me, my wife, and one other guest sitting next to me) were friends with the chef and sous chef. They came with gifts and champagne and desserts to celebrate. We didn't think much of it at first, in fact we enjoyed the celebratory vibe, or so we thought. But then the sous chef came out and the experience went south. The best way I can describe it is a king (chef) and a court jester (sous chef). As the chef was unwrapping his birthday gifts, the sous chef provided completely unnecessary comic relief. Photo bombing pictures, sarcastically demanding gifts, complimenting and comparing the value of the gifts, etc. This charade would continue the entire night. I understand that chef didn't speak Chinese and having a trilingual sous chef is invaluable. But rather than simply being the translator, the entire night was just gossip and small talk between the sous chef and the party guests. Even the chef at times stood there looking clueless as to what the conversation is about.

Let's talk about the food. There were 8 appetizers followed by 14 sushi. Most of the appetizer were misses for me and mostly for the same reasons. The preparations either did not let the ingredient shine or poorly composed. There was either an overshadowing sauce, a random overpowering ingredient or simply too much going on. The hairy crab, with caviar and uni, all delectable ingredients, ruined by half a green grape. The ikameshi was ok, very standard. The chawanmushi was loose and watery, bit on the salty side and served in the tubular cup with a thick wooden spoon. The ankimo was cold, fishy and had a denser texture than I'm use to. The hotaruika and miso sauce was fine, but the garnish pepper leaf was a too much. The karasumi was the best appetizer. It was creative, but yet simple. The kinmedai preparation did not do it justice. It could've been any snapper and it would've tasted the same. And lastly, the salmon, drenched in a white sauce that tasted like bottled salad dressing.

During most of the appetizer course, which was prepared 90% by the sous chef, the chef paced behind him with a glass of wine, occasionally peeking over his shoulder. I've been to my fair share of high end omakase and usually the chef handles most of the food presentation . Also, if the restaurant staff is reading this, word of advice, it is very off-putting the way the appetizers are assembled from cling wrap-covered plastic tubs from the under-counter refrigerators in front of the guests. It honestly feels like layering scoops of leftover, which could've been easily avoid by doing it in the kitchen.

On to the sushi course. There's not too much to say, it's exactly what I expected. Starting with the oily-er fish, mackerel and gizzard shad. Both well salted and marinaded. The shad, maybe a touch too long in the vinegar, but still delicious. The striped jack and spanish mackerel paired beautifully with the seasoned rice. Temperature of the fish and rice were spot on. The hairy crab was good but I would have preferred not repeating it from the appetizer. Then followed the lean, medium and fatty tuna, which were all amazing. The nodoguro was a pleasant surprise and tasty. The remaining items were decent too. The meal ended with a Japanese musk melon, which was ok but clearly overrippened. Two of the diners brought cakes and were gracious to share with all the diners.

The night ended strangely as we asked for the check, paid and exited while the guests and chefs continued their festivities. Overall the dining "experience" I give it a 1/5. It might have been very different if we dined some other night or with a different crowd, but again, when diners are paying $500+, this is not acceptable. If this review was solely based on the sushi course, I would give it a 4/5 (-1 for the quantity and variety). But this dinner was suppose to be so much more and it completely missed the mark.

A magnificent moment when I was able to visit Yoshino. Eating at Chef Tadashi Yoshidas counter was truly the very best sushi experience I had in my life.
Every bite I had was delicious. The signature sabazushi was exceptional. Loved karasumi mochi by chef gang. To end such great meal the basque cheesecake was cherry on the top.
Can't wait for my 2nd visit
The best Omakase place in New York. If you can get a reservation, don't hesitate and just go for it.

I booked the reservation one month ago for my anniversary.  The restaurant sent me the confirmation email one day before the reservation. I confirmed with restaurant and I was expect to attend. However I waked up in the morning and was shocked because the manger cancelled my reservation at middle night , the day of my reservation ,my anniversary !  last minute the manger cancelled my reservation. I waited for their call, they didn't even give me a call! So I wrote a email to them ask the reason. They just say they define my credit card as scalper's ( that's their explanation which is absolutely insult, I can simply give them other credit card if they doubt, second how they still took my deposit actually two full meal fee 1000$+200$ service+tax  if they doubt my credit card ? but without any apology and without communicating with me!!! ( what is funny is , they charge the deposit already ! I don't know whether other people's reservation had been cancelled without refund like this ?  whole morning Totally no contact , no detail explanation . They didn't even give a call to explain. In the email , they asked me to contact with  Tock, but funny is Tock don't know anything, they check the system they don't the why they cancelled my reservation. Tock asked me to call the restaurant , but I called them. None picked phone at all. Moreover they already deposited with my credit! Tock said the deposit already transferred to restaurant! ( that's so wired , what 's  their behavior ) . Around 1 pm afternoon already ( you know you suffered from this disgusting thing, you won't have mood to plan other thing). the first email they just said my credit card is scalper but without mentioning any refund, Yoshino asked me to contact Tock and didn't mention any refund. They are really susceptive. Until I said your restaurant sent the confirmation email ahead and cancelled my reservation after my confirming, and Tock don't know why your restaurant cancelled my reservation! ( luckily I contacted with Tock first , I could stop them using any excuses ) then they sent me second email promise me will refund it. But  how can they charge with my credit card already. They deposited already. Back step , They should cancel at least 3 days ahead. They knew the rules that if cancelled within 3 days , no refund. This is seriously problem. If they cancelled my reservation at least one week ahead , I wouldn't be so angry. In addition , I could have enough time to book other restaurant. This restaurant ruined my anniversary totally.  Make me feel disgusting. I feel huge depression , sadness. I think none met this situation like me. Anniversary cancelled by a restaurant and didn't receive any apology. The explanation email I only could tell how much rudeness and arrogant  of them, there is no single word of apology. Never meet this kind of restaurant before. The popularity is based on their fame from Nagoya ,they chose New York instead of Tokyo. Tokyo is more competitive. We travel to Japan always , my Japanese traveling argent helped us book many local Japanese restaurants. They are so polite never broke the agreement. This restaurant is no thing about food , they thought they are top star , and they are so popular and never lack of costumers.  So Disgusting. Moreover if you are regular or send gifts to them , you can book directly from them. So shame on this restaurant. Make me feel nausea, so disgusting!

Certainly one of the best omakase experiences I've ever had. Every course was amazing and the chefs and staff were fantastic. I cannot in good conscience encourage anyone spend this amount of money on a dinner, but if you love sushi and have the means this place should be top of your list.

I used to "frequent" a sushi bar in California called "Sushi Yoshizumi" where the chef would mention he plans to visit Yoshino when it opens. Now I know why after trying this place.

Everything was impeccable at this place, and I mean not just the food. The atmosphere, the service, the small details, the bathroom, the conversations with other patrons were all excellent. Great sake selection as well.

It's an experience.

Friends that knew I went asked me what was my favorite from the meal. The only answer I could honestly give (and this is not coming from laziness) was "every single thing"

One of the best sushi chefs in Japan, Tadashi Yoshida san, is now in NYC.

At $400 (gratuity not included), it's the second most expensive sushi omakase in NYC after Masa.

Is it worth it? YES! He's using the most expensive ooma maguro (akami, chutoro, and otoro), the most expensive uni, white truffles from Alba, nodoguro, kegani, caviar, etc.

Good luck trying to make a reservation, prepaid on Tock. All booked already for October and November.

Service - wonderful

Highest recommendation

In my Top 3 sushi omakase in NYC.

: 10 calenders

Excellent addition to NYC. I think Yoshino reserved a Michelin star soon. Everything was delicious and innovative, I wish there were some seasonal edomae sushi for his price point otherwise, I highly recommend this place. Only regret is his edomae sushi lacks seasonal sushi/higher quality fish/signature. Kohada wasn't as good. I had much better kohada in the past.

Food: 5
Service: 5
Interior: 4.5
Price: 3.5-4

Overall: 4.5

Oishi~ Had to try Yoshino as everyone is raving about it and enjoyed the perfect omakase from Yoshida san and sous chef Gang. Amazing food, perfect presentation, great service, and cozy ambiance. I'll be back (when I can find a reservation

Where can I start?!?!?! So I have followed chef Edowan since his career in Japan I have never had the opportunity to dine with him until recently. I was in NYC last week and was able to make a reservation beforehand to dine here. There is a very long wait list to dine here but it is totally worth it. I sat for the 8 pm seating. The restaurant itself is amazing and everything has a story behind it. The wood used for the sushi bar is wood that is over 300 years old and is also wood that was used in one of the palaces in Japan. All of the plates used in the serving are hand made and painted and well let me tell you that the ambiance inside is insanely superb and chic. The quality of the product used to make the entree and the appetizers is better than the best. The rice used is superb. Chef Edowan is extremely charismatic and charming and makes the whole dinner experience extremely enjoyable. The pictures do not do this dinning expletive Justice as you have to truly appreciate the real deal. Trust me you will not be disappointed once you are treated to probably one of the best dining experiences of your life!!!!!
One of the Best OMAKASE in NYC! Must try !Will come back often to try the new menu , they change menu every month!
I'm in miserable pain from food poisoning today, after dining at Yoshino last night. Didn't expect it for such a high end restaurant.

There are innovative chefs, and then there's culinary geniuses. Risk takers vs. trailblazing visionaries. Somewhere in between lies a grey area that challenges you to forget about everything you thought you knew about food.  Chef Yoshida-san not only shares his imagination, but also inspires you to open your mind over and over again. Nothing will compare to the mind-blowing experience emerging within Yoshino's walls.  Picture prom night but with two dates.  From the specific origin of each ingredient to the history of the Hinoki counter, every detail serves a greater purpose that ultimately redefines the meaning of beauty, balance, and art.  Special thanks to my close friends, Jerry & Jessie, for finessing the opening weekend reservation.  Covid or not, this intimate dinner together was so special to me & Margie.

Stepping into Yoshino felt more like stepping off the metro in downtown Tokyo.  With this type of ambiance, it's only fitting that I indulge in rare sake til I start to feel pleasantly jetlagged.  But rest assured, every bite will awaken your senses.  The intro to the omakase was uni/caviar/hairy crab.  Meticulously constructed in multiple layers, this masterpiece essentially builds anticipation. As the appetizers continued to ignite my taste buds, our Chef spoke with such emotion and excitement while grinding the wasabi root; it barely scratched the surface of what he had up his sleeve.

Needless to say, the entire 20-course omakase menu was presented with the utmost craftsmanship.  But more importantly, each serving has its own special story intertwined with brilliant cooking techniques.  My favorite highlight was the saba-bozushi aka mackerel.  There are no words to describe the transformation.  You have to see it for yourself.  Let's just say it reminds me of the time I was granted access to Kobe's pregame warmup.  I didn't fully appreciate greatness until I witnessed Black Mamba's preparation up close and personal.  Like the ticket stub, I subconsciously took home the menu as a souvenir.

Make no mistake.  This was a 3-hour symphony, not a movie. But my review would be incomplete if I didn't reference the oma blue fin trilogy: 3 suspenseful presentations of the top rated tuna in all of Japan. I couldn't help but overhear someone sarcastically complaining about how they'll never look at tuna the same.  To be fair, at one point I began to wonder if I'll ever enjoy holding chopsticks again.  In the end, dessert kept me salivating thru GWB traffic, the entire staff treated us like family, and I couldn't resist taking a pic of the bathroom.

p.s. I'm still undecided about posting my pictures (for the same reason I haven't publicly shared videos of my first Jay-Z concert). The sentimental value means more to me than a million likes.

Some of the best Shari and tomago I've ever had. I loved the French twists on the appetizers. Everything was masterfully executed. The ingredients for the nigiri were truly amazing which made this meal perfect from beginning to end. The chef was very attentive and gave us details about the ingredients which I love. And the tuna was out of this world. Looking forward to coming back soon.
Undoubtedly the best sushi I've ever had anywhere in the world. Perfect atmosphere, great service and spectacular food. Worth every penny.
Was in a local grocery store and saw that the water they charged $12 per bottle was actually $3 per bottle. obscene

Impeccable food and service. The sushi was hands down the best in NYC. Appetizers tho are definitely under the influence of NYC, evidenced by chef's enthusiasm of incorporating truffles in his dishes. The chef also designed the napkins for guests to take home as a gift.
Amazing quality sushi for an amazing price! the lady who works there is so sweet too :) shrimp tempura roll rocks

Their lunch special is a fantastic deal for Manhattan -- two rolls and a soup or salad (or soda or water) for $11! The delivery was right in the desired window estimate and fresh tasting. Would absolutely order this again. Let's dive in...

Salad (3/5): The only item lacking a bit in this meal, the salad doesn't do anything original with this standard at most Japanese restaurants. The iceberg lettuce was still wet making it hard for the dressing to adhere well to the lettuce and carrot shavings. The dressing flavor was the usual carrot-ginger combo.

Bean Curd Avocado Roll (3/5): This is my first time trying this roll. Overall the roll flavor is a bit like a sweet-salty bread (the bean curd) and the avocado is fatty and creamy, so it's a lot of soft textures. I would consider it again but only with crunchy ingredients added (e.g., cucumber).

Mango Avocado Roll (Add Jalapeño) (4/5): Glad jalapeño was added to this. This checks the box for the most part as vegetarian rolls go. The mango was sweet enough for not being in season right now.

Shrimp Mango Avocado Roll (4/5): Very nice to have a 3-ingredient roll on a lunch special menu! I would personally like more equal proportions of shrimp and mango compared to the big hunk of avocado (but I'm nit picky so take this comment as you please). Otherwise this is a nice combo of flavor.

Alaska Roll (5/5): Again, 3-ingredient rolls included in a lunch special makes the value-seeker in me giddy! The salmon is quite fresh and the ingredient proportions are well balanced.

Value (5/5): As mentioned above, two rolls and a salad are a steal in NYC!

TL;DR: Would recommend to anyone who works local or has the option for delivery.

I walk past this little sushi place everyday and finally DoorDashed it for pickup one day. After reading through the reviews I'm suprised so many people had a bad experience because I only have great things to say! This small kitchen is only operating for to-go service (not sure if it's due to COVID or construction) but it's easy to overlook - almost like a ghost kitchen. My food was ready so fast and the food was really affordable for quality sushi. This will be my go to takeout sushi in the future

I got a Toro roll. Presentation was nice, rice was perfectly cooked, and the quality of fish was ok. I don't think this is the best toro i've tasted (i've tasted a lot from many different places). My favorite thing about this place was that they were open late so I was able to order a roll at 1230am. I also had their clear broth soup which was perfectly flavored. I don't see myself going back by choice.

Leaving my first review ever because this place was much better than the reviews give credit for! Experienced sushi consumer and very happy with the freshness and taste -- I got the 18 piece sashimi dinner deluxe and slices were very thick! My partner says the sweet heart roll is his new favorite roll ever too. Ignore the old rating and get your takeout here!!
Vegetable Tempura has 5 slice of different types of veggies, pretty nice for a small appetizer.

Really yummy sushi for a great price point in my neighborhood. I'm always grateful for local small businesses that serve quality food for reasonable prices, especially in Manhattan where things can get very pricey! Came here for the lunch special and got 3 rolls for $15 with a salad (or soup).

If there were 0 stars for this restaurant, I would honestly give it a 0. I ordered from them via grubhub and I immediately asked them to cancel it due to the fact that a coupon was not applied. However, they told me they can't do it. Next thing you know, my food is late and I ordered a sashimi platter for 2 along with other dishes and there ends up to be absolutely no soy sauce in the platter. I called them back and they promised to deliver the soy sauce, and that took about an hour after I had to call them 4 times. I wrote them a poor review on grubhub due to their service and the food wasn't even good.

Here's the thing, the next day Yo sushi calls me back and told me "I didn't give you the soy sauce in a rush because we assumed you wanted more soy sauce and you didn't really need it." They asked me to take down my review in exchange for a 20% coupon, I rejected it because I honestly wasn't fond of their food and the service was horrible. The owner of the restaurant texted me after we hung up the call, and told me that I'm going to get bad karma for giving them a bad review and called me an 80 year old woman with bad memories, and tried to threaten me. It is ridiculous how a business just tries to call and amend things through offering coupons when they need to recognize that their service is horrible. Also texting customers and yelling at them is definitely not the way to go either.

I'm so shocked by the negative reviews. I just randomly ordered take out from here. And I have to say it's on my top list of sushi places And I've eaten a lot of sushi in my life! The dancing Tuna roll and yellowtail jalapeño are incredible!

If i could describe this place in one word it would be "Yuck"! .

This place should not call itself a sushi restaurant as their food barely has any resemblance of what sushi should taste like.

The sushi was swimming in a pool of wet soup.

The Salmon teriyaki was dry and hard like the bottom of a old shoe.  

The pork dumplings tasted very questionable.

One of my fav. regular sushi places... All their rolls are solidly done... The toro roll is melt in your mouth great... No idea what is up with the previous poor reviews other than maybe they were targeted towards the wrong location?    Whatever the case may be, as of today they definitely deserve a good review!

***Quick service, Mediocre quality, Friendly staff***

I was looking for a quick to-go option and stepped into this restaurant. It was empty, which should have been a dead giveaway but I was in a rush. The sushi is decent and nothing that great about it. They somehow got my order wrong and had to take my order back to fix, which I'm unsure how that was possible since I was the only person they were serving. I wouldn't recommend this place, to be honest.

I ordered and shared sushi for lunch with a friend! This place was solid. It wasn't crazy good, but it was pretty good, cheap, and had fast delivery.

We ordered a miso soup, very typical. Nothing special. And we got a seaweed salad, that tasted surprisingly fresh.

We got a green salad with house dressing and miso soup as part of our meal with the sushi we ordered. Then, we got the tuna roll alongside the triple fish trio. Salmon, tuna, and yellowtail were really good. The tuna roll itself with seaweed on the outside had nice big cuts of fish. Really good!

The sake we ordered was alright. A little more dry than I would have liked, but they strangely listed no options. So we just went with a 10 oz mystery sake and got what we got haha.

Overall it was a solid lunch! I liked it and would eat it again.

If I could give negative stars I would. This place is disgusting, I will never order or eat from here again. Extremely rude service and there are plenty more sushi restaurants in Manhattan, no one cares about this stupid hole in the wall, they act like they're Tao. They're incredibly mean and the food is below the threshold of edible.

Ordered some sushi rolls and I was pretty upset that I paid extra for spicy mayo but they forgot to give it to me. I had to eat it with nasty soy sauce. I always hated soy sauce because it tastes superrrrr salty and it burns my lips. Sorry but I just couldn't enjoy the food. They did call me after I'd given up on my food to apologize and offer to refund my $1. I told them it's ok...its not the $1 I care about.

Spicy crunchy tuna was neither spicy nor crunchy and eel avocado roll was like 1 part eel to 9 part avocado.

Delivery dude was kinda rude too. Closed my own door on me while I thanked him lol.

Portions are big.

This place isn't closed, they're only open for dinner.

I've been passing this place for the last 2 years or so and deciding to finally try them tonight.

The food came very fast, it arrived in about 10-15 minutes. The price was on the low end.

I ordered the sashimi dinner which came with miso soup, salad, rice, and 24 pieces of sashimi. The description didn't say how many pieces were included so I was pretty shocked when I found 24 pieces.

The soup and salad were pretty basic. The rice was a nice freebie considering I ordered sashimi, not chirashi.

The fish were pretty big except it was inconsistent. Some pieces were good but most weren't - many pieces were mushy or tasted like they came out of the freezer and were just thawed today (extremely cold and abnormally firm)

I would give them 1 star but the price was very low and food arrived fast but i wouldn't order from here again.

Dont go here, especially dont go here for the soup. This a Chinese-run sushi place where they have little concern for or sense of Japanese food. The tempura udon shrimp had way way too much breading and was fried to the consistency of a brick -- with dipping sauce! When the idea is that you will put it in the soup, and only on the side so it stays crispy. Aside from the udon noodles, there were only two small pieces of broccoli in the soup, for $12 that is really pathetic.  They were pleasant, hence the 2 stars. Only one star for the food.
I'm always looking for super cheap sushi places with vegetarian/vegan rolls and this one is so great. Take out or sit down, I love it. Cheap beer, good avocado in their rolls, I'm into it.

I logged onto Yelp just to write this because I was stunned. Haven't been on here in years. Read this whole damned thing for I only speak the truth.

I ordered last night b/c family ate Thanksgiving meal at 3 and I'm hungry again at 10:30. Called to make sure they were open, which they were. Very polite on the phone - tells me it's 30 minutes for my order that costs $12.95 on the menu.

Delivery man is prompt! 35 minutes later, he's here.

As I open the door to greet him, he's all "happy holidays"two or three times, and I greet him in kind. Hand him a 20, and his face lights up as he begins thanking me profusely. I'm now dreading that I'm going to have to ask for change, but I'm not exactly rich, and he's crazy if he thinks he's getting a ~75% tip. The bill comes to $14.10 with tax, so I figure a $3.90 tip, amounting to +30% is pretty nice for 10 minutes work.

I ask for 2 dollars back, and to sum up, he moans, groans, pretends not to understand my request, makes me repeat myself 3 times, and FINALLY when he takes out his wallet (do they not give delivery people cash?), he has the AUDACITY to hand me ONE FUCKING DOLLAR and go "ok?" like we're fucking bartering in the stairwell, like I just visited his garage sale at 11 PM on a Thursday and decided to haggle for food.

I was dumbfounded. In my stunned silence, he then changes his mind, I think , and starts waving towards the dollar in my hand as though asking for it back, or maybe he wanted to increase it to $2, but I thought it would indeed be a bit much for me to shake this guy down for change when I'm fairly certain I am better off than he is...but I'll be DAMNED AS A SATANIC HERETICAL ARSONIST if I ever order from that place again.

The food was decent. No soy sauce though, wtf? Luckily condiments last forever for some reason. The chicken, however, was gamey and not choice. Rice was good (thank fuck for that).

TL;DR
If you order delivery from this place, make sure you either pay and tip online, or have exact cash, because their delivery personnel are flat-out rude.

The quality of the food could be much better the concept is amazing the customer service was so so overall decent spot to meet up with friends and try to enjoy some seafood choose wisely before making final decision on seafood . My decision to recommend this spot is still up in the air.

Very decent sushi at a great price. Also received 20% off via Seamless Web. Delivery was fast (about 15 mins) and the food was pretty good.

Everything was fresh and tasty, however a few of the rolls were not perfectly constructed, so the seaweed came apart slightly.

I'd probably give the place another shot.

We took out from this place last night and it was a big disappointment. The chicken hibachi was mediocre, not bad but it tasted nothing like real hibachi. The fried rice was alright, but almost tasted like the McDonald's version of fried rice. The miso soup was honestly pretty gross...and I thought of all things the least likely to get screwed up would be the miso soup. The ginger dressing for the salad tasted good at first but ended up being super watery once mixed into the salad.

Believe it or not all of that was eatable...until we got to the sashimi bento box. The california role it came with was probably one of the worse sushi roles I have ever had, and the sashimi was absolutely terrible. My boyfriend took one bite and that was it for him. It just tasted old, dry and too soft. One of the kinds was so fishy we could not even eat it. The shumai was actually good, I'll give them that. But all in all it was probably the worst Japanese food I have ever had.

Ordered through seamless and this was the worst food we ever ate. I got the nabe yakisoba and a tofu skin sushi (forgot the name) while my boyfriend got beef negimaki. Delivery was taking longer than usual (got a notification like 5 minutes after we order ((7:20pm)) that said delivery should arrive 7:45-7:50.) so we called around 7:55pm or so to check on the order. They sounded like they forgot to place the order and said it was coming soon. Food finally arrives around 8:10ish and we were SO disappointed.
1) the nabe yakisoba was SOGGY. Like if you leave package instant ramen in the soup for an hour soggy. The  egg looked beautiful but was WAY overcooked for an sunny side up egg. The shrimp tempura was heavy battered and it was like eating a corn dog. Shrimp was also ehh.
2) boyfriend was disappointed by his beef negimaki to which he describe it as eating rubber instead of beef.
3) tofu skin sushi was eh. Skin still had a lot of it water.

Never will I order again without doing any research. We end up throwing almost everything away cause it was so bad. Should've yelped this place and saved me $30.

Great quality, super quick service, nice people! Green river roll is delish.

They also have gluten free soy sauce!

Awful customer service, menu on Uber eats had typos and did not state the correct ingredients in menu items. With this, I accidentally ordered something with eel even though I am highly allergic and didn't know there was eel in the roll. When calling the restaurant to explain what happened they told me they can't do anything about that and the menu was correct. I'm very disappointed and will never be ordering from here again. If ordering from Uber eats, you will see their menu is not accurate. Clearly this is a healthy threat and issue to me and I'm sure many others.

Discovered this place on Seamless Web and thank goodness I did! This place is my go-to for delivery sushi. Everything I've ever gotten here has been fresh and tasty. My favorite of which is the Calamari Tempura rolls. The sauce was yummy and the calamari was perfectly cooked, not tough and chewy.

The delivery service is pretty fast considering my office is a bit far from the restaurant, so I'm very impressed that my miso soup was still hot by the time my food came.

I will definitely order from here again!!

Very disappointed that I spent 7.50$ on a chicken katsu salad and it consisted of one piece of soggy chicken and iceberg lettuce....
Like, seriously? Not even a tomato??

Ordered delivery.

Food was bland, cleanliness dubious, and service unprofessional. The delivery boy first asked to come into our apartment to see the rooms (??!!!), then requested more tip in cash even though it has been included in the order.

Don order from here.

Ew-uhhhhhhh

Chicken teriyaki came swimming in watery teriyaki sauce. The onions weren't sauteed well enough and tasted absolutely raw.

I ordered a chicken tempura roll and they gave me a shrimp tempura roll and I'm highly allergic to shrimp I'm very disappointed  I called the place to complain and they hung up on me, never ordering again! Plus they were a hour and a half late with my order, bad customer service
Fast delivery, but they don't give you any sauces or condiments with your order. Which sucks if all you get is everything that would be better with soy sauce ... like sushi ... deal breaker.

My friends and I put in a large order through seamless and it took TWO HOURS to arrive.  During that time they peppered our phone conversations with lies ("Your order is already on its way"), run-arounds ("What is your seamless web order number?") and stall tactics ("Look outside your window and tell me if you can see the delivery man!").  We should have realized it was a bad scene when we were put on hold and incidentally overheard them giving a gushing apology to another customer.

When the "sushi" finally arrived it was virtually inedible.  It was, without a doubt, the worst sushi I've had in New York City.  The fish was brown, oxidized, crusty.  The rolls were falling apart.  Fried things were soggy and undercooked.  The best part of the meal was that sh!tty Japanese restaurant salad you get with the orange ginger dressing.  One nice slice of cucumber and a single, insultingly small cherry tomato.  I would rather have eaten sushi from a stinky midtown bodega.

Thanks, Yo Sushi!  Your quality establishment is a great reminder that my immune system is still functioning properly.

Eek! Methinks not.

My food hasn't even come yet, and I can already confidently give this place 1 star. Their quoted 30-45 minute delivery time is currently at an hour and ten minutes. When I called them, I got a disconnect sound. I called them again, and got a busy signal. I called a third time, and this unfriendly thing picked up. I told her my food was late, and she said "It's on its way" just to hang up on me. B!tch.

Yo, Sushi... I hope you lose customers. You deserve to.

P.S. Guys, put your reviews on SEAMLESS too! This place is  the highest rated Japanese place in Midtown, which is why so many people order from it.

In my world there are two kinds of sushi, exquisite and pedestrian.  I've had the pleasure of exquisite sushi in Tokyo, Osaka, Los Angeles and here in NYC, but being a New Yorker I have to admit to eating more pedestrian sushi than I could even remember.

This is a pedestrian sushi joint.  It's a good pedestrian sushi joint, though.  I would never have walked into this place had my buddy Jim not recommended it.  He said it was completely good and a remarkable value.  Value sushi doesn't have a very good ring to it, but I trust Jim's taste - he's been all around the world and has eaten everything - he knows good food, and being a fellow artist type he also has a strong respect for value.  He was right in his assessment of Yo Sushi.  

A $9 dollar sashimi lunch special proved to be way more of a pleasure than that amount of money ought to provide as far as raw fish goes.  It was good.  Two delicious pieces of white tuna, two slices of halibut, three of salmon, three of tuna (the least special of the assortment) and a couple pieces of crab (or crab substitute) that may as well have been as much of a garnish as the shisho leaf and grated daikon came with a typically lousy iceberg salad, good miso soup and a bowl of rice.  The fish was not top quality, but it was fresh, and while we were eating more fresh fish was delivered to the restaurant for the dinner crowd.  In a place like this you're looking for freshness, because you know you're not getting the best fish.  Less than the best is still tasty when it's fresh, and that's what you get here.

Six of us had lunch here with too much sake and a couple beers.  The bill was $115.  That's six people eating raw fish and drinking for $115!  Maybe I'm out of the loop, but I didn't think that was still possible.  I got so used to "value sushi" being a disappointment that I'd pretty much stopped bothering with it.  

Yo Sushi surprised the hell out of me.  It was an OK (not great) sushi joint that happens to be priced like it was ten years ago.  In fact, it's exactly like walking into a pedestrian sushi joint ten years ago, which is not a terrible thing.

Three stars for the food, plus one for the value.  If you don't care about value or pedestrian sushi knock a star or two off this review.  If you want some good fish on the cheap consider Yo Sushi.

Today after work I was on a personal mission to arm myself with a massive amount of sushi and watch movies all evening.  I turned to Yo Sushi as my accomplice as I figured this place might be a good compromise between quality and quantity.

I ordered the large chirashi, one of their signature rolls, a seaweed salad, and one piece of uni.  It was definitely a lot of food, and they included a miso soup.

I placed the order on seamless, and they called to tell me they were out of uni. I asked them to just take it off the bill and I was a bit worried they wouldn't refund the charge to my credit card.  I am happy to report that it looks like they did issue the refund.

The sushi was okay.  The tuna in the chirashi had a bit of a course texture.  The miso soup was lacking flavor.  The roll was good, but I did think the eel on top was sliced a unfortunately thin. Also, shrimp was one of the ingredients in the roll, but there was so little of it that it was hard to find. I would, however, recommend rolls from this restaurant over individual sushi pieces as the exact quality of the fish is less important in a roll.

I did not expect the sushi from this restaurant to be top notch, so felt fine about what I got for the sake of saving.  After the meal though, I compared the prices from Yo with a higher quality sushi place in the neighborhood and I was disappointed to see that the prices are identical for most items.  So in end I learned that it would have cost me exactly the same amount of money to order higher grade sushi from another area restaurant.

But I did take advantage of the 20% off deal on Seamless, so that represents a good savings I couldn't have found elsewhere.  I can't say I would recommend this place though and I probably won't be going back when I can get better sushi for the same price closer to home.

Oredered delivery from Seamless web. It was quite prompt.

Got 3 roll lunch special: Philadelphia Roll, Tuna Mango Roll, and Eel Avocado Roll. Comes with standard soup and salad.

It was ok. I hate Philadelphia rolls and don't know why I ordered one (maybe because I'm from Philly and feel guilty). The tuna mango roll had this bIzarre effect: I didn't realize mango was in the picture until late in the roll. I just thought it was tuna. How is that possible? Stealth mango. Eel avocado, as always, is good.

Price is reasonable! Would order again.

I recently started getting into the more elaborate sushi rolls, but my wallet certainly doesn't enjoy them. Luckily, Yo Sushi's prices are not that bad, my total was $15.66.

1. Alaska Roll - Salmon, Avocado, & Cucumber - Inside Out with Sesame Seed.
2. Philadelphia Roll - Smoked Salmon, Cream Cheese, Avocado, Cucumber, Tempura Batter & Scallion - Inside Out with Sesame Seed.
3. Shrimp Tempura Roll.

Okay, so maybe the rolls I ordered aren't the most complicated ones, but even the ones that were were not that expensive either. I should also add that I ordered delivery from them and my food arrived in a timely fashion. Gotta love online delivery.

I also had the option for some of the rolls to have them in a hand (cone) roll. The rolls all tasted fresh, and did not come apart. My tempura roll was HUGE, and I asked for the philadelphia roll in a hand roll. Everything was good, their assortment is vast. I will probably be ordering from them again soon.

Overall 3.5 stars.

Decor: 4/5
-Looks very organized and clean but that's cause we were the only diners tonight

Service: 3.5/5
-Good service, they gave us some soup on the house which was generous of them

Sushi: 3.5/5
-Super white tuna with avocado: large cuts of tuna and avocado. I wasn't a fan of the sushi rice though. It was a bit on the hard side.
-Alaskan Roll: i've had better..but it's decent.
yelp.com/biz_photos/PD0O…
-These rolls were priced on average ($4 to $4.50)

If you want AMAZING sushi, go to Sushi Yasuda.
yelp.com/biz/sushi-yasud…

3 stars - spicy mayo; 2 stars for service; 2 stars for ambiance; and 2.5 stars for the sushi.  

This place is usually empty because a large portion of it's business is derived from takeout orders.  Most people choose to takeout because this place is, well, kind of sad (especially if you're dining alone after work). The sushi itself is okay; the salad and Ginger dressing was okay; the spicy mayo was okay--basically, this is a safe bet for a quick bite, but I won't be thinking about this place once I leave.

I had the spicy yellowtail roll, which had an okay taste, but was VERY mushy and poorly rolled (spicy fish mixture coming out of roll) and the specialty spicy salmon roll which was better than the first roll, but also double the price.  

Bottom line:  you can walk (not run) to this place, but if you happen to walk past another sushi joint that looks good, maybe you should try that one instead.

Horrible delivery. Container was open with raw fish inside. Soup was spilled in separate bag.

Horrible sushi. Cheap wasabi was gritty when blended in soy sauce, fish was un-fresh, miso soup flavorless.

I will never eat from here again. Much better place like East on 3rd ave.

Ordered a few different rolls for some variety. I do not know if it was an intentional act of "aging" gone wrong or a mistake but the food tasted old. Also, I was not sure if I was drinking the rice off of the sushi or eating it as it was as soggy as porridge.

(Note: this is a rating based SOLELY on the quality of the food which is pathetic at best)

I've only ever done delivery from here, but have always been completely satisfied. This is definitely my go to delivery sushi place for four primary reasons.
1) The sushi is always fresh.
2) Delivery is usually prompt.
3) I can order on Seamlessweb.
4) It is inexpensive for good quality.

I'm a bit of a purist when it comes to sushi and my order mainly consists of sashmi; however I do appreciate interesting rolls. Plus sashmi itself never really fills me up on its own. My favorite special rolls are Dynamite Roll (spicy white tuna, cucumber, tobiko topped with avocado) and Snow Roll (spicy tuna and avocado topped with lobster salad). Would recommend to anyone.

This is not a gourmet place, but if you want something easy delivered to work, then this is the place for you. The lunch specials are the best. Their Katsu is tasty and during lunch comes with shumai, a cali roll, rice, soup, and salad? For $9? Please and thank you!

I will be the first to admit I've had better sushi but at this price, it's totally worth ordering. Just be forewarned that delivery time runs a little long.

This place was alright.  We went right before closing and they still let us in to eat, but they sure did make us feel guilty about it.  They shut off half of the lights while we were eating.

I have had fresher fish, I have had better prices, but I have also had worse.  3 stars

The search for good delivery sushi continues in midtown, the land of mediocre delivery sushi. I realize that delivery sushi is never transcendent or anything, but cmon. I wanna feel like I'm enjoying my lunch instead of slogging through it.

For the record, I got the 3 roll lunch special, which came out to $12 with tax and tip with the seamless web discount. Got salmon skin, eel avocado, and yellowtail scallion. None of these were outstanding and the nori wrappers were really, really, really chewy. Almost like gum.

The miso soup was hot and yummy. The salad... was a pile of iceberg lettuce with the saddest tomato piece I have ever seen. It was almost white and not in that good heirloom way.

Take a pass.

Don't be afraid if the dining room isn't full, this place is AMAZING. My roommate just turned me on to it and I'm planning on making it my sushi haunt.

I LOVE the tuna, so fresh. They have great specialty rolls but their ala carte sushi is so much cheaper and not at all plain.

I really dig the traditional atmosphere so I plan to dine in soon, even if it is a little creepy quiet. put some music on!

Totally love this place

Ordered the 3-roll sushi lunch special and it was alright. I like that Yo Sushi has a variety of rolls and comes with soup and salad - I was full after eating half my meal. It's a decent price and delivery was relatively fast. The sushi seemed fresh - I just wasn't wowed by it.

The main reason I ordered from Yo Sushi was because it would:
a) fulfill my sushi craving
b) was within my office's delivery range and
c) gave me the most bang for my buck (out of all the sushi delivery places)

Was it the best sushi I've ever had? No - but it was a lot of food for what I spent - and that's all that really matters at the moment.
Sooo, I keep going back to get a few rolls for dinner, and still love this place.  Their may be sushi that's a little tastier, but for overall price and value, I still love Yo Sushi

Enjoyed this food for the most part. I'd give it a 3.5 for effort.

Decently fresh and tasty sushi box "lunch special". If it were up to me I'd call it more of a "lunch mundane" than a lunch special...but it was a solid mundane at that and my co-workers seemed please with it too overall.  

Well priced for the worth. My meal came with soup (corn egg drop -- yum!) and left me feeling a positive vibe toward Yo Sushi.

Man I wonder how places like that stay open... I came here pissed off but after reading all the other negative reviews, I feel almost bad for them. But I mean don't open a restaurant if you do not know the buisness. So very true that they don't give soy sauce blah blah but what bothers me is the inconsistency. Some time the sushis are good and normal sized but sometimes they're only half the size of the usual. When I called last night to tell them about it, a poor non english speaking girl answered the phone. I'm not lying. She didn't understand a word I was saying. Not even the word : manager ? I had to start speaking japanese even though I'm french so WTF. How many languages do you have to freaking speak in this city ? If you live in the US speak freaking english man or don't put these people in a position where they have to deal with the phone, I mean... It's such a nonsense its almost fun... Will order from there again coz its the only place open around 3am but I'll always pay in cash and check the order at the door. From now on if I'm not satisfied with what I see, I'll just send the guy back. I dont give a fuck. Bye

和牛 is the best Amazing 刺身 and 手握り
福寿 is the most popular sake here and we totally love it.
Definitely gonna come back next time. Pricey but worth it.

Recently came here for a date night. Different location but I expected the same quality of food. We ordered an assortment of small dishes and nothing really stood out for me. The wagyu rice dish was was too seasoned and seeing the chunks of fat rather than marbled in texture made me question if it was real wagyu. The squid and squid paste was a bit fishy, the pork belly hot pot was pretty bland. And the grilled rice balls tasted stale. Not sure if I would recommend or go back, especially considering the price point .

Came here randomly. Made a reservation 2 hours before. The food was good and the ambiance is nice. Service was good. And food was excellent. Besides the plain squid. Everything was great. The dessert was okay. We ordered the mochi ice cream and the macaron hojicha thing. Will definitely come back here. But expect the bill to be pricey.
The chicken meatball is meh. Based on reviews I expected it to be great. But other wise everything else was great.

Wasn't sure whether I wanted to give this place 3 or 4 stars but I rounded up because of the service and ambiance. It is a bit pricey but overall had a good experience. My favorites were the grilled squid and the 5 kinds of tempura. I ordered the fish hot pot for myself as the entree but wish it came with some sort of rice or that the portion was a bit bigger. My friends got the house chirashi and it was great. The fish was fresh. We ordered a bottle of sake for the table to share and the cost came out to almost $100 per person. Pricey but overall a good experience!

My experience eating at Yopparai was quite pleasant. We were immediately seated at 7:15pm with a reservation for 7:30pm and were instructed to take off our shoes so that we could sit at the dining area.

We ordered the Tsukune (Homemade Chicken Meatball Topped with Raw Egg Yolk), Hotate Butter (Grilled Scallop in Soy based butter sauce), and the Ika Ichiyazuke (Grilled Whole Marined Squid) for the appetizers. They were all around $16-$18 each, which is honestly not too bad for the quality of the food that was received. We also ordered the 10 piece chef's choice sushi for $85.

The Chicken Meatball was really delicious. On the perimeter of the dish was this chopped radish-textured formation that was coated beautifully in this soy-based sauce. It was the perfect amounts of sour and savory. We had to mix in the raw egg yolk with the meatball and it tasted absolutely amazing.

I could not stop eating the Hotata Butter scallops, the butter mixture was so rich and flavorful, and the added lemon juice complemented the scallops and the sauce perfectly. The scallops were also extremely tender and flavorful, and they even put salt on the side to add an extra zing. The grilled squid was also extremely appetizing and delicious, and they gave an extremely generous amount of squid that was addicting to eat.

Lastly was the omakase-styled sushi part of the dinner. They gave us generous amounts of fish ranging from salmon roe, botan ebi, yellowtail, tuna, chutoro, salmon, fluke, and uni. Each piece was curated beautifully and was an absolute pleasure to eat.

Overall my experience was great and my stomach was pleasantly satisfied at the end. We also got the Yopparai Partfait at the very end, which was $12 for vanilla ice cream, a ton of whipped cream, sliced bananas, strawberries, and cereal. It was a perfect way to end the dinner and the night.

Good food, small portions, EXPENSIVE pricing.

Food was good! We got an assortment of dishes (portions are on the smaller side for sure), but the two winners were the miso black cod and the tuna (toro) roll... Also enjoyed the wagyu roll as well but definitely wasn't worth $25

The ambiance of the restaurant was very nice though. It was an intimate space with limited seating. I appreciated that - the noise level never got overbearing like so many other restaurants. Recommend counter seating - we got to sit next to each other but also interact with the chef on the other side. Expect to spend ~$50 - 75 per person all together.

have been in search of a fire izakaya spot so decided to check this place out. will say that right off the bat, great hospitality! we had a table reserved outdoors in the kotatsu but it ended up being a lot colder than we expected so they were able to seat us indoors.

we got a variety of dishes and the flavors were all very traditional. top pics were the tsukune, tempura, and kakuni. rice balls were a bit overcooked and some of the flavors were a bit too mild, especially id you are pairing with alcohol.

as far as what i want in a go-to izakaya spot i'm not sure it checks all the boxes as there aren't a ton of options on the menu. however, the hardest thing to stomach is the price. you will inevitably hit the 150$ mark for two and you may not leave with a completely full stomach. i would say this is more of a spot to come to focus on drinking and share a few appetizers while youre there rather than have a full meal.

Came for a friend's birthday, ordered a variety of dishes since nothing on the menu was of substantial size. All their dishes are small-medium, not for sharing amongst 5 people. Their raw fish selections were fresh and sweet. The quality was on par with the price tag but some dishes were decent, not sure I would pay a premium. The service there was nice, often came to refill the water and checked in on us. I would recommend this for an intimate couple's evening out, but not for a party or big group. Although, I appreciated the quality of the fishes I still walked away hungry and the total bill came out to be about $400.

First time at Yopparai and wow, the sashimi are so unique. Hubby really love the New York Trout and their other fish as well. And can we talk about the exceptional service here? We were greeted by a nice man named Mr. Yuki. Very kind and friendly. And our server, Mr. Pat, was amazing!!! Very attentive, kind, informative and very professional. We also want to thank Mr. Kevin as well. Came over to our table to greet us and ask us how we are doing. Amazing staff!!! Thank you for making our dining experience so memorable. We will definitely be back. Mr. Pat did say come on Thursdsys because Kopparai get fresh fish on Wednesdays. We are looking forward to it! Thank you for the hospitality. Xoxo

The best sushi in NYC hands down. That is all.
I have nothing further to say their entire menus is delicious. The service is amongst the best I've ever gotten.

Yopparai is the place to go if you're looking for a top tier lux izakaya experience. They have a broad menu of sushi, sashimi, hotpot, noodles, etc. When our party of four arrived, we were seated indoors in a traditional Japanese zashiki. Our waiter was very helpful and explained all the items on the menu. We ended up ordering...

Shrimp tempura - 4/5 Loved how it came with a lot of shrimp

Pork belly hot pot - 3/5 Not my personal favorite. Flavor only really came from the soy sauce

Tempura $32 set - 5/5 probably my second favorite! The shrimp tempuras were huge! Definitely recommend if you want to try different seafood tempuras other than shrimp

Miso black cod - 4/5 the fish was very flaky and soft. Paired well with the pickled radishes and carrots

Grilled squid - 3/5 squid was nice and tender but was lacking in the sauce department

6 type sashimi - 5/5 highlight of the night! My absolute favorite piece was the scallop!

Overall, Yappori is a great place to try if you're willing to spend a little extra on Japanese food. If you're not sure what to get, I'd say get their noodle dishes, tempura or the sashimi!

Are a reservation for two for the streetside outdoor seating with the kotatsu table to keep warm. It was definitely cozy with the kotatsu but a bit awkward with people walking by and having to take shoes on/off and go into the restaurant to use the restroom. Definitely a cool experience though.

We ordered:
- two types of sake (unsure which unfortunately)
- nukazuke
- karaage
- agedashi tofu
- kakuni (pork belly)
- hotate butter scallops
- 6 pieces sashimi
- 6 pieces veggie tempura

Our favorite item was definitely the kakuni -- we wished we'd ordered another serving of those instead of the sashimi. The karaage was incredible -- such delicious meat and the breading was so light. Probably the best agedashi tofu I've had and that's one of my favorites to order at Japanese restaurants. The scallops were delicious but the portion was a bit disappointing -- the total amount maybe equalled two whole small scallops, sliced up. Veggie tempura was definitely good but not groundbreaking. Sashimi was good quality but nothing better than what I've had at other quality sushi joints.

This was definitely a fun (and pricey) experience. No regrets (except not ordering more pork belly) I'd maybe return if they changed up the menu significantly, otherwise there are plenty of other izakaya to check out -- the food here is good but expensive so you may get equal bang for your buck elsewhere.

I'm in between a 3.5 and a 4 for the restaurant for a few reasons. We came here for a late birthday celebration with a group of around 12 people. My friend had made reservations ahead of time, which should be done as it's a smaller restaurant.
I would've liked if the tables were connected rather than in two separate booths back to back, as it felt like we came as two separate parties. Or if there was an option of opening up a window in the sectional, it would've helped too, but completely not their fault. So if you do come as a larger party, be mindful of the seating arrangements.
Another thing, in the booths, you do take off your shoes to be seated.
On to the food, my date and I ordered a sashimi deluxe, the black cod and the assortment of tempura to share.
The sashimi was pretty fresh. I only wished they had one more shrimp as there's only 1 piece while the others were either 2 or 3 pieces.
The black cod was way smaller than expected but overall a nice flavor. There isn't too strong of a miso taste as I can't recall it.
The tempura was alright... not much about it.
I also tried my friends Chirashi which was slightly lacking in flavor, or it's my friends fault for not mixing well.
We also ordered these sparkling sake drinks, the yuzu was pretty nice, along with the yakult, but do not get the plum. It's literally a pickled plum that you're supposed to break apart or ask them to do it.. it just did not taste very pleasant. The waitress was very nice to replace the drink though.
All the staff were very kind and helped us take group photos inside and again outside. I'd come again just for service.

Service was excellent and attentive. Ordered the $130 omakase. First course had various small bites. Scallops and the dried roe was very salty. Felt like we needed some rice to balance the salt. The chawanmushi was served with salmon roe had good in texture and flavor. However, I liked it better in other places where they added shrimp or some other seafood to the dish. 2nd course served various sashimi. Red snapper with torched skin and the ebi sashimi stood out. Chirasi and  Unagi don were both good. Desserts consisted of green tea ice cream, red bean paste, and fresh strawberries sandwich between Japanese crackers.
Indoor seating is basically tatami, except for a few bar seats! Yopparai is for yakitori, so please make a reservation and try it!

Awesome izakaya! The food is really awesome. Highly recommend the uni flight (if it's available, dunno might be seasonal), wagyu,  and pretty much anything on the special menu.

Outdoor seating was nice too. Enclosed tatami "booths". In the summer, it can be pretty stuffy though.

Reservations recommended. Intimate private seating booths. Traditional style food and service. Expensive prices suited for a special occasion. Food are art pieces to discover and enjoy. Most portions are small, gives room for their dessert. Food reminded me of omakase appetizers and platters.

Would recommend the washi beef tataki if you like raw beef, sushi is decent, hotpot is an interesting experience. Lots of things to try. Beautiful seating areas.

Portions are small for the hot dishes which is expected for izakaya. But, every bit I had was delicious. Seems like you can walk in to sit at the bar easily. Tatami table was a great vibe. Sapporo pitcher was a decent value for $35. My favorite dish was the Inari! The Sushi set was also fantastic and included a tamago with a super cut stamp.
I would definitely come back here! My friend and I loved the ambiance and food. Our favorite was the roll in the special - so yum!!

Terrible. The edamame was way over salted and looked and tasted like it had been reboiled multiple times. I sent it back. The special chirashi was only slightly better than supermarket chirashi at four times the price. It featured rice with a thin confetti topping of fish shopped into small pieces. Impossible to taste anything. Probably what was left over from sushi cuts. Topping this mish mash with bit's of gold leaf was an offensive attempt to justify the price. Avoid.

We sat outside in one of their adorable dining booths. It was nice and toasty and we didn't feel cold at all. Now, on to the most important part.
