Our incredible waiter Pat really made our night special. He had amazing recommendations with Saki pairings and the best plum wine for dessert. Everything was top notch beginning to end. I can't wait to come back and I'm dreaming of that amazing pork belly hot pot and salted toro that melted in my mouth.

Service is about as unfriendly as I have experienced. Not rude but just unfriendly. We walked in with a sunny disposition and said hello and were greeted with serious faces. Chef koichi (who is the only visible member of the food preparation staff, since he is standing behind the counter preparing all sushi/sashimi orders) looked mad and didn't respond at all. Wow. It seems he was having a bad day and was showing it to the majority of his customers. He said not one word nor responded to any friendly questions asked of him. He made what should have been a fun outing into an uncomfortable one. What a poor environment. Really dampened the mood of our large party. Sadly the owner is not present as much as before so I guess his employees do as they please now.

Food comes out quickly and hot. Taste is not remarkable. More on the bland side. For an eaters crowd figure about $120 per person. At that mark there are plenty of other better Japanese offerings in the city. A hard pass for me.

A nice cozy izakaya/restaurant. Reservation was easy to make online.

Service was great too but our server forgot our second order for toro... which was ok.

Food were great too, but the portions are a bit too small. But oh well, it is in New York.

Everything was amazing, from the food to the service.

Made a reservation for the booth, with Zashiki seating (there's an opening under the table for anyone who wants to put their legs underneath)

Food:

Miso soup was a little bland, the shrimp head miso was very flavorful, strong taste for seafood fanatics.

8 piece sushi platter had a wonderful spread, on a bed of ice to preserve the fresh taste. Tuna was exceptionally tender.

Wagyu roll was a fun thing to try, with the cucumber cutting through the savory meat.

Had a great dinner here! Staff is super friendly and attentive, I love the private Japanese booths where we take off our shoes.  I recommend getting the special fish collar, wagyu beef, shrimp tempura and chicken meatball , scallops, the black cod sushi pieces were amazing as well! They have such a great selection to choose from! Sashimi is super fresh too, I can't wait to go back and try the omakase next time!

I had a great dining experience at Yopparai. They definitely deserve 5 stars! All servers were very informative and attentive. I also loved the atmosphere. I recently had two late night dinners there and I loved dining in the booth tables. It made me feel like I was in Japan! I also dined at the bar and liked how their bar chairs are set up to store your bags and other belongings. Again, this reminded me of Japan - They would totally do this at izakayas/bars there. Most importantly, every dish I had tasted awesome. I also like that they serve coffee jelly here, not a very common dessert and I was so happy to find it here!

Love Yopparai! Great atmosphere & cozy for couples & groups (4max) This is definitely a new favorite spot.
The service is attentive & food amazing and nicely presented. The environment is understated and intimate. They have recessed table seating, or sushi bar (equally nice) . I do think that the sushi prices are a little high, so I mainly go here for the small plates ,  special's & izakaya type fare. Good sake menu as wel

Nice cozy spot.
Came for little night cap after dinner, intensive sake list!

Also got some small bites -

House Smoked Cod Roe - just like regular cod roe not smoked... meh.

Cod Milt - interesting to have it in NY, pretty delicious!

Botan Shrimp - pretty good usually my favorite sushi/sashimi piece.

It's a bit difficult to find Yopparai but I did it! Yes, you need to walk up the stairs of the restaurant sign. Don't look left or right at the other restaurants. It looks like you're going up the stairs of an apartment building but ring the doorbell on the right hand side. Go in and then someone will open the sliding door on the right.

I went as a group of three but it's definitely a date night kind of spot. There are so many options on the menu but the washu beef and kakuni were my favorites. Both were amazing in their own ways as the washu beef was raw, marinated well and super tender. The kakuni is basically a really soft and fall apart in your mouth pork belly. It was so good - I had to order another one.

There were other good ones too such as the kaisen sunomono and ika no uni ae. Both the chicken with meatball (too salty) and grilled eel (no flavor) fell flat for me. The other dish that really surprised me was the beef tongue due to the texture.

As for price, it's definitely one of the more expensive izakayas I've been to. But I left satisfied with the food and service!

Great food, great hospitality.  Thanks Kaito san for being a great server during my dinner there.

I like how they put thought after with each and every dishes, simple yet delicious.  Unlike other izakaya, this one is actually quite child-friendly to my surprise.

My favorite dish is actually the cooked rice with salmon and salmon roe, along with ebi shinjo. Its different than the other Ebi Shinjo that I had at Kyoya but its still good.  

Scallop butter is good for the show but I guess I would skip it next time.

A great dating spot!
Love this little spot near home. Fresh sushi and very cute little hotpot. I will come back for sure.

4.5 stars for food and 5 stars for service. Had a reservation for Friday night which was a good call since this place is small and was packed at 6. The front door is locked and you need to ring the doorbell to get in. This confused me at first but then I realized it leads to an apartment building so that made sense.

We ordered the crab rice, cod and shrimp dumpling in Dashi, duck breast on hot plate, tripe stew, and the grilled pike fish. The crab rice was delicious and they did not skimp in crab at all. The duck breast, tripe stew and the fish were delicious as well but was a bit on the small side for the price. My least favorite was the cod and shrimp dumpling which had a weird texture and was underseasoned.

Service was impeccable, they refilled my waters without me asking at all, were very attentive and friendly and took their time to explain the dishes.

Although the prices are a bit high for the portions the food is good and fresh. Would definitely come back to try other items on the menu! Definitely make sure to make a reservation before coming here.

Very nice, very authentic Japanese place. Nothing that really made me jump out of my bar seat but good ambiance and good food. Small portions which could've been expected but still wanted more.

The highlight was the chicken sausage without a doubt. Should've just gotten 5 of them :)

Washu beef was solid - bear in mind it's cold though.

Beef tongue was good. Usually not a fan but was quality here.

Anagram (eel) was very bland. Wouldn't recommend.

Stew was minuscule but cute. Wouldn't go crazy ordering it tho kind of useless.

Miso black cod was great. Always a go to for me and didn't disappoint here.

Got a few more things but forgot. Sake was good too and presentation of it was very unique. Service was also good and waitress was very nice. Overall, Michelin Star place so had to try but not crazy about it. Quality for sure but nothing too exciting.
Fantastic Japanese spot. I've always found their sushi selection to be fresh. My husband loves their karaage and the chicken meatball is a MUST for the table. おいしいだ！

Love this izakaya! They have an extensive sake selection and you can always ask for recommendations from their staff. The one we had was Oze and it was on point. Love the yuzu cocktail also.

Really warm and welcoming and great date night vibe.

Very cute restaurant with no more than 25-30 seats, half of which at the bar. I made a reservation well in advance for my wife's birthday and, considering the high reviews, was very excited to pay a visit. Although we had a good time, I don't think I'd go back, and here's why.

Kakuni (Berkshire pork belly): this is a must. It was so perfect we ended up ordering another one at end of our meal (yes... as a dessert).

Karaage (fried chicken): unusual and tasty. Very tender.

Chawanmushi (savory egg custard with chicken and crab): a mistake. I was expect something completely different. Don't order this, as it's a waste our your stomach space (and money).

Yakitori (Japanese bbq): butakushi (pork belly), gyutan (beef tongue), kamouaki (duck breast): although not particularly memorable, they were quite good. If you don't like searing your own meat, don't order the duck.

Miso black cod: very delicate and quite tasty.

Rice with sea eel: not your usual eel over rice. The eel is braised to the point that it shrunk to barely anything, and tastes overcooked; the rice looked amazing, but didn't have much taste.

We skipped dessert, mostly because 1) the list was uninspiring, and 2) my wife couldn't order the only interesting option - their $20 green tea tiramisu - because she's temporarily on a non-dairy diet.

Their seats are creative, with a clean space for your belongings (probably to hide them from the smell of the kitchen... yeah, your clothes will be smelling like food for days), but the design is cheap, because you're sharing a 2-inch back pad with the person behind you, which can be quite annoying when you get an idiot who can't stop pushing toward you (like I did... a woman who pushed me several times and then went ballistic when I finally pushed her back...once).

Overall, although the food was 4-stars worth, we felt that the service was rushed. Our waitress - initially helpful and polite - kept pushing us to order more items together, which is not what you want to do knowing that they would all come at the same time (and get cold). On one occasion she even opened the menu in front of us while we were eating, asking us to make another order right away. I mean... r u kidding me? Could she just let us savor what she had just brought us? I politely told her that we would rather enjoy that dish first, and she left mumbling something that didn't sound very friendly... I get that you want people out as soon as possible, but if you treat your customers this way, don't count on me to ever return to your establishment.

I came here tonight to celebrate my friend's pre-birthday dinner along with her peeps. The restaurant is conveniently near the Delancey Street station less than a 5 mins walk if you got long legs like moi lol

How awesome that the restaurant is located inside an apartment building. I pulled and pushed the door then I realized it was a sliding door...duh haha! A few people greeted me and I told one of them my friend's name for the reservation. She pointed towards the back which I saw seats by the counter...phewww luckily a table for 8 to my left. Space is quite tight as we were seated by the kitchen so the food is piping hot when it gets to our table.

Our server was just a bit too fast in clearing the dishes for the next course. At the corner of our table, there was plenty of space for our server to stack bowls and plates for all our dishes.

Drinks:

The birthday girl ordered their only cocktail on the menu...Yopparai Cocktail (2)

Kokuryu "Black Dragon", Fukui region 6oz (1)

Shiragiku "White Chrysanthemum" Nigori, Okayama region. 12oz (1)

Note: For sake, our server came over with a basket of sake glasses for you to pick.

Food *sharing is caring*

Oden - Assortment of 5 items (1)...I really like the Mochi Kinchaku mmm ::sad face:: I wasn't done eating it and my bowl was taken away from me

Today's Specials - Washu Gyu Tataki (1)...I thought my friend didn't eat hers yet so I placed one on her plate and now she can have two...I didn't try it because the beef looked too red for moi

Homemade Yudoufu (2)...mmm this dish was very unique which came in a wooden box while the flame underneath was heating the tofu and the sauce to pour onto these delicious mouthwatering tofu man

Otoro - super fatty tuna (2)...my friend ate mine because mama don't like raw food

Today's Specials - Sanma Shioyaki (1)...I tried a little bit of the grilled mackerel but way too many bones for me

Karaage (2)...the first order had only 5 pieces then the second order was more...definitely one of thee yummiest fried chicken mmmm

Kakuni (1)...woah baby thick pieces of the pork belly...mama love meat...come into my belly haha

Miso Black Cod (1)...I am not a fan of seafood but this dish was really yummy and the crispy skin mmmm

Jidori (1)...I prefer gizzards over liver anytime so everyone can try more pieces since I am not putting that in my mouth

Butakushi (2)...Oooo mama love pork belly especially the fatty part...I was engaging in everyone's conversation than in one second I noticed the fatty part of the pork belly was taken away from me...oh no miss don't mess with me...I snatched that baby from my plate and ate it

Gyutan (1)...No way am I eating beef tongue

Hotate Butter (2)...beautiful presentation and it was quite yummy as I am not a fan of scallop as well

Kurobuta Tamago Toji (1)...it was yummy and our third dish with pork belly hehe

Yaki Onigiri - sea urchin (2)...my first experience with sea urchin...thank god it was that slimy texture that everyone loves...mmm I do like rice cake and these babies were very crunchy

Yaki Onigiri - spicy marinated cod roe (1)...definitely has a kick to your palate...spicy but tasty mmm

Today's Specials - Smoked Duck (1)...another yummy dish

Lastly Inaniwa Udon ***seasonal item*** (1)...a little sweet for me but it was good

Overall it was a yummy experience for authentic Japanese small bites. I definitely came here with an emptied stomach lol

Note: Please don't clear the dishes so fast just ask if we are done since it happened twice to me.

Yopparai is a tiny Japanese sake bar and restaurant in the LES.
They are famous for their Oden (traditional Japanese foods simmered in dashi). Their food is very good to excellent and the service was great! The ambience is calm and demurred (we were the loudest ones there).

K and I were here for a friend's birthday. The six of us sat at the largest table in the back (table for 8). We ordered the following.

Nigori sake (unfiltered sake) 12 oz- this was great because it was smooth, had a silky-milk mouth feel and packed a punch without tasting like a higher alcohol content.

Otoro- the fatty tuna slices were satisfying and rich. It was delicious and pretty. The chef topped each slice with gold flakes, making this dish even more decadent.

Smoked duck- this was perfectly tender, had a fatty duck skin layer and delicate smoked flavor.

Yudoufu (Hot homemade tofu cooked with negi and shiitake in a wooden box)- I loved the presentation and taste of this dish! The tofu was placed in a wooden box with a fire in the lower compartment. The view of the tofu, Japanese leek, and broth was not beautiful but the combination had such a depth of umami flavors. Everything was perfectly cooked: the silky housemade tofu, the crisp sweet leeks and the savory broth. It was one of my favorite dishes.

Gyu-Tataki (Lightly roasted Washu beef with ponzu dressing)- this was like tender beef sashimi. The beef was seared ever-so-lightly so you could barely see the cooked outer ring. The ponzu sauce was a citrusy slightly sour soy sauce.

Oden Mori of 5 items- Egg, daikon, bean curd, mushroom and taro cake simmered in dashi broth. This was excellent. It looked ugly but
I loved the soul warming rich flavors from the dashi. Everything was perfectly cooked. My favorite was the daikon and gelatinous taro jelly cake.

Karaage (Japanese fried chicken for $12)- this was such high quality fried chicken. It was so light, perfectly seasoned and the chicken was very juicy. It was a thousand times better than the karaage I had at a restaurant in St Mark's (and costs $3 more).

Hotate Butter (scallops cooked in butter)- the scallops were fresh, briny and buttery. One piece was little overcooked but the flavors were just right.

Butakushi (Kurobuta fatty pork belly roasted)- fatty roasted pork belly. This was so good that we reordered it.

Gindara (Black Miso Cod)- this was seared so it had a crunch and was so tender. The miso added so much delicate rich flavors. I wished I had one to myself.

Kakuni (Berkshire pork belly simmered in sweet dashi broth)- This was ok. The flavors were great but some pieces were tough. The best pieces were the ones with a chunk of fat.

Kurobuta Tamago Toji (Kurobuta pork belly simmered in dashi broth with soft scrambled egg)- this was delicious steamed egg with ground pork belly with a dashi broth. It was savory, slightly fatty and very tasty.

Jidori Liver (roasted chicken livers)- flavorful and tender. Good if you like liver.

Gyutan (thick-cut Washu beef tongue prepared in Sendai style)- This was cooked medium rare. I liked the tender beefy crunchy beef tongue but some cuts were tough. I also like beef tongue well done. The medium rare beef after taste was not so good.

Inaniwa Udon- udon in chilled savory sauce topped with tiny tofu and shiitake. This was savory and delicious. The tofu was silky, the udon was perfectly cooked. The udon also helped round out the meal so we all left full.

Sanma Shioyaki (grilled mackerel)- this was flavorful and perfectly grilled.

Onigiri  (Crunchy grilled rice cake) topped with soy sauce - this was rice seared so it forms a delicious crunchy layer.

Onigiri  (Crunchy grilled rice cake) topped with roe- this was the better of the two onigiris. The salmon roe offered a tiny vesicular crunch compared to the crunchiness and stickiness of eating a seared layer of rice.

It was a delicious fun meal! You could taste the high quality ingredients and the care the cooks took to make each dish. I would order the onigiri with salmon roe, the tofu, beef tongue, oden, and pork belly yakitori again.

instagram.com/snackchatn…
This place is super cool and authentic. The food was excellent and the the service was too notch. Nice selection of sake!

I would give zero stars if I could.

Service is as unenthusiastic as it could get. While no one was rude or anything, I can tell that they are not doing anything to win more tips.

Food is terrible. For the same price, I could get much more tasty food with arguably better ingredients in other izakayas in Manhattan. The miso black cod carries neither the flavor of the miso nor the cod.

For $80 per person, Yopparai could have done better.

+.5 for service

I was very close to giving this place 5-stars. However, I had to take away the star due to the washroom being not clean at all when I used it.

With that aside...

I really like places this small and ambient, as the chef would not be overworked and would put a larger effort on your food. Sure enough this was exactly what myself and my aunt got while dining here.

The following is what we ordered:

Washu Gyu Tataki - Delicious. Nuff said. Loved the ponzu sauce they used.

Take Sashimi - Definitely one of the best sashimis I've had, though it's hard to do bad with sashimi in places like this. I didn't weigh sashimi really high for this review.

Karaage - How is the batter so light??? And yet so juicy at the same time! Probably my favourite dish, and I've had a lot of chicken karaages in my life.

Kurobuta Tamago Toji - Another great dish, and decent size too. The kurobuta pork was simmered beautifully and, again, it was juicy as well. Comes with a side of rice.

Butakushi - Also delicious, though at this point we figure we ordered too many pork dishes. Will probably pass on it next time.

Gyutan - When they mean thick cut, they mean thick cut. Yet it was extremely chewy and not tough at all. Another well done dish.

Ika Ichiyazuke - One of the best I've had, and I'm a crazy ika yaki eater.

Service was excellent, and everything aside from the washroom was 5-stars. Definitely an amazing place that deserves a Michelin star.

Although I enjoyed the dishes we tried, I wasn't blown away by anything--3 stars for the food, 4 stars for the ambiance.

As expected of an izakaya, all the dishes were small, tapas-sized and we shared the following dishes among the four of us:

Kakuni ($9): Berkshire pork belly simmered in sweet dashi broth. A good start to our meal but not particularly memorable.

Agedashi-mochi ($8): As someone who really likes agedashi tofu and mochi, this was too intriguing to pass up on. Sadly, it didn't really work for me--the mochi was very soggy and didn't hold its shape. The mushroomy broth was nice though!

Seiro Meshi topped with salmon flakes and roe: This was a yummy filler to go with all the other things we ordered which were gone after one bite each. The sticky rice had a nice flavor but the roe (I believe that was the culprit) was quite salty. I found myself picking at every last kernel of rice in the wooden seiro box to make sure none went to waste!

Chicken meatball with egg yolk: I forget the name that was on the menu. This was tasty but had me craving a bowl of white rice to go with it.

We also ordered a whole fish that was a daily special--the waiter recommended it saying the flesh was unusually sweet. It was interesting because it was simultaneously sweet and also very bitter.

I wanted to try the sea eel but they were sadly out. Nothing was bad, but nothing stood out either--I don't foresee myself itching to revisit.

I would give them 6 stars if I could. It's one of the finest Japanese restaurants in NYC or in the entire world. It is so fresh & delicious. The service, ambiance. & staff. Excellent selections of sake.  Beer. Daily specials. The authenticity. It reminded me of the delicious meals I had during my visit to Kyoto some years ago. Top notch. If I were living in  LES, I would go there every night! Kudos to the restaurant's management team. Must try .
Good sushi in the East village that doesn't break the bank. Quiet spot that seemed more popular for takeout.

Seriously a gem. Unique in every way from presentation to taste.

We had, from order of my fave to least fave (tho all good!): sendai gyu tan, karaage chicken, oden, smoked cod roe, miso tripe stew, hotate butter, uni & squid.

Other people's food also looked super good and it's a great date spot at the bar.

Highly highly recommended and can't wait to go back to try more!

Surroundings:
This is a small restaurant on the second floor. The entrance is to the right of the staircase (I went to open the wrong door). There are only two 4-seater tables, three 2-seater booths and the rest of it is bar space. I would recommend coming here for an intimate date or with one or two friends. If you have anymore in your group you won't fit. The plus side of being so small is that it doesn't get noisy. We went around 8pm on a weekday.

Food:
- Kurobuta Tamago Toji (really small, could be an appetiser)
- Salmon Flakes and Roe in a Seiro dish (really amazing, a little salty when you're halfway through, but only enough to fill a petite 5ft girl)  

A friend recommended this place to me and we each spent about $40 after tips and tax.

Pros:
1. Small and intimate
2. Friendly Service
3. Good selection of food and drinks

Cons:
1. Sake is more pricey than other places
2. A couple of the dishes we ordered were disappointing

What we ordered:
1. Sashimi (5 kinds) - B+ (Good, but had better elsewhere)
2. Karaage - A+ (Juicy and succulent)
3. Daikon Salad - B (a little too bitter)
4. Tsukune - A
6. Gyu-Tan - B (cut too thick, hard to chew)
7. Anago Seiro Meshi - A
8. Saba Shioyaki - A-
9. Matcha Shaved Ice - B+

Came back here last night with my date after a while. Still one of the best authentic izakaya in NYC.

Service and vibe was great. Love they played jazz in the background. Like most higher end bars in Tokyo do.

Most hot dish we ordered were excellent. The only pet peeve was that food got cold quickly and was not as appetizing. Wish they can keep it warm. Our
favorite was def the sea eels simmered in dashi broth with scrambled eggs. Savory and sweet. The eel was delicate and flavorful. The pork belly version was good too tho the sweet miso was not the texture I like; the dressing was a tad too thick.

We also got the nukazuke. Note to newbies, typical Japanese meal starts with pickles. So get this.

The oden was my must-order every time I came here. Was good as usual. So was the shiokara (salted squid in squid gut). Another must-order of mine. Tho I think Shigure gets the best shiokara in the city.

The smoked duck breast prob was my less favorite. Flavor was good but a tad too dry to my liking ; I prefer the French version. And better with wine not sake.

Lastly, understood was busy night but they forgot the chicken gizzards yakitori my date ordered. And my hair smelled like fried chicken when I walk out there :(

Being said that, will be back!

This place was tiny and cute. Eight of us came here for a birthday celebration. we shared a several dishes. Food was amazing here. My favorite was the shishito peppers. The egg custard was great as well. I wished that I had space for having more dessert. The shaved ice was awesome. The service was very good.

Pretty good restaurant!
The service was good and we loved their oden! Definitely on the top notch in terms of seasoning their food.
The miso appetizer was good, with the two rice dishes being my favorite. The dimmer dishes were also tasty with chicken and eel marinated in eggs and a slightly sweet broth. Karaage was fine and the chicken meat (one of their special) got some unique taste to it that worth a try.
My only complaint might be that the portion was pretty small in general. Food was yummy!

My sister and I came here a little after the store's opening hours. They sell little tofu skin pockets with rice and fillings. Some of the flavors we tried were:
*beef bulgogi
*mushroom bulgogi flavor
*avocado
*salmon
*spicy tuna mayo
*crab meat

They were all pretty good and reasonably priced. This spot would be a pretty solid option for a quick bite.

This place offers Korean inari sushi which unlike the Japanese ones, they are topped with a filling. After seeing online, it was a must try and a friend spoke highly of their seared salmon flavor. After all of this hype, I decided to come try it and we got seared salmon and the myungrang mayo. The mayo one was very disappointing as the texture just felt like eating a spoonful of mayo. On the other hand, the seared salmon had no sauce and was too dry. I felt like they should've combined both flavors because one was too wet and the other one was too dry. On top of that, you can't taste anything from the salmon because there is no sauce and it didn't seem marinated, and it was torched too much. Other than the filling, the rice itself was not good, since it had the texture of over cooked rice. Additionally, it was around $4/piece and I feel like there are other things that you can buy at that price. My friend said that that seared salmon was not as good as she remembered it (but she did try it at the soho location). Overall, we were just really confused by what we were eating since the flavors and textures did not complement each other.

Besides the food, it's supposed to be a takeout restaurant so the service was quick and easy! It was a small area so if there was a lot of people, prepared to be waiting a little bit. There is outdoor seating which is nice! They did give us a little lollipop with our order which was sweet!

(Overall: 69% | D) - Overall, the concept of stuffed tofu pockets is one that has endless possibilities. However, I found the technical errors at Yubu to be critically hindering of the original appeal that should be addressed.

(Beef Bulgogi: 57.5% | F) - You can see on the beef actually that the fat solidified from being cold despite me eating this relatively quickly after I ordered during rush hour. The flavor is also a bit bland and needs to be more forward.

(Pork Jaeyook: 90% | A) - This one is spicy, but I found the flavor and the combinations to work well overall.

(Crab Meat: 77.5% | C) - The flavors from this imitation crab salad are a bit off... I think it would taste better had it followed a recipe similar to a California roll.

(Salmon: 67.5% | D) - The salmon tastes dull and uninspiring. Some yuzu ponzu would help lift the flavors, but more importantly a higher quality salmon could be used.

(Spicy Tuna: 55% | F) - This one tastes as bad as it looks. The tuna tastes like it came out of a can and overall just does not work in this setting. A raw spicy tuna would work much better.

IG: @amei.eats

I was really excited given the pics here looked so good but I'd say I was underwhelmed. It's good for what it's supposed to do but something is order via delivery and not something I'd walk to go pick up or eat in person.

Best flavor was probably the smoked salmon. NOTE the spicy ones are genuinely a bit spicy!

My experience at Yubu was too traumatizing that I wanted to bury this memory forever. The woman at the counter was quite rude and unwelcoming. Mushy rice, cheap toppings, misleading menu. Nothing comparable to the remarkable Yubu I had in Seoul.

＊ Fish Roe Mayo
The most disgusting piece in our order. We felt like being scammed as it had  "salmon roe" on the menu photo, but it turned out to be a ridiculously tiny portion of "flying fish roe". They literally just plopped a chunk of mayo onto the rice. I seriously want to report them scamming their customers with fake menu photos.

＊ Spicy Tuna Mayo
At this price point, we thought it would be fresh sashimi tuna but we were completely wrong. It was made with cheap, fishy and salty canned tuna. Speechless.

＊ Beef Bulgogi
Their cooked toppings were better but not wow-ed. It's really hard to go wrong with beef bulgogi. I will only reorder this one if I ever come back (maybe never).

＊ Torched Salmon
Another edible piece. Nothing special. A better bang for your buck comparing to the cheap canned tuna and mysterious mayo.

Yubu is a hidden gem of an inari shop in New York that packs a punch in terms of flavor. I tried the salmon, crab, mayo, and spicy chicken inari, and each bite was a burst of deliciousness that left my taste buds dancing.

The shop's small size and quick service make it a great option for a quick bite on the go. However, keep in mind that there's no seating available inside. The portions might be on the smaller side, and the prices a bit steep, but the taste more than makes up for it. The creative combinations of ingredients in the inari wraps deliver a satisfying blend of textures and flavors that's worth savoring.

While the lack of seating might not be ideal for a leisurely meal, Yubu's focus on quality and taste shines through. The inari wraps are prepared with care and attention to detail, resulting in a delightful culinary experience.

The compact size and quick service cater to those on the move, and the inari wraps are a testament to the creativity and skill of the kitchen. If you're looking to treat your taste buds to a unique and flavorful inari experience, Yubu is worth a visit despite the portion size and pricing considerations.

If there was an option for 3.5 stars that would be my real score. Yubu is a pretty cute inari store and yes they are pretty good but nothing super amazing. For $4 per pocket I don't know how worth it is especially when it'll take me at least 6 of them to fill my stomach. Among the ones I got, the bulgolgi and salmon ones were my favorite.

Yubu is a small shop specializing in these delicious Korean "pockets" (I think that's the term for them), which are rice wrapped in tofu skin with various toppings on top. I got a box of 4 with the following toppings: beef bulgogi, spicy chicken cheese, crab meat, and salmon spicy mayo. The bulgogi one had classic delicious bulgogi pieces on top. The spicy chicken cheese was not as cheesy as expected but had some other tasty savory sauce to go with the chicken. The crab meat one was my favorite- not sure if it was real crab meat or imitation crab meat, but the white sauce on it was really delicious. The salmon spicy mayo was also good with salmon sashimi but was quite spicy (spicier than it looks). One of the best parts of this was that it was only $13 for these 4! Granted they are pretty small (maybe a few bites each), but still, I think is a great deal considering the quality.

The main issue with this place is that there is no seating inside, only a small seating area outside by the sidewalk. There was no one else there when I went so there was no wait. The lady working there was average friendliness and the service speed was quick.

Overall, if you are interested in some delicious small and reasonably priced Korean "pockets", then definitely stop by!

We stopped by Yubu on the way to the park to grab a quick snack. The spot is very small and upon walking in, I felt very rushed by the owner asking if we knew what we had wanted. We had not even had a chance to look at the menu. Not sure if it was because we were in a group of 6 and maybe took up too much space.. idk.

While the portion sizes of the Yubu chobap's were huge compared to the standard ones someone might get at the grocery store the prices are on the higher end. In terms of your options you can choose different toppings and mix and match essentially making your own variety pack. we opted for the tuna mayo, torched salmon (favorite!!), spicy pork and bulgogi.

The presentation is very nice too making it a very instagramable food. They do also come with high quality chopsticks to withhold the weight of these yubu chobaps and a chupa chup lollipop!!! They also serve a variety of bubble teas which we got the strawberry matcha and it was so delicious! A nice balance of the strawberry and matcha with the creamy milk taste!

They don't have seating inside as I mentioned, it's a small spot but they did have an outdoor area that is enclosed that customers were allowed to sit at and eat.

These tofu pockets are AMAZING. We only got a box of 4 since we wanted a little snack before dinner but I swear we both could've ate 10. They are super addictive and very fresh.

We got the bulgogi, spicy tuna, crab meat, and salmon. Every one was absolutely tasty especially with the spicy Mayo mixed in. The bulgogi was cooked perfectly. The salmon pieces were fresh but I felt like it lacked a bit of flavor - maybe some eel sauce or soy sauce would've made it even better. Our favorite was the spicy tuna and bulgogi.

We also got a mango ale. The drink was just ok - it was slightly too sweet and had mango pieces on the bottom.

I can't wait to come back here!

The Best Bodega Around

Breakfast Sandwich And Coffee Every Morning I Work, Being as its down the block and the most fair priced deli in the neighborhood that i know. Never Fail To Dissapoint im in there so often they know my order and start making it as soon as they see me walking in, Open 24 Hours a day! The grill is only open until 6pm but you should try there cheese steak, Considering its a deli the cheese steak is moderately good and the best in this neighborhood. Cold Sandwiches Mostly 24 hours as well.

This storefront is so narrow that you could blink once and walk by it.  I used to work on the same block and was a regular customer for coffee and a breakfast sandwich.  Food is good, service is fast and friendly, prices are cheap.  They have a nice selection of pastries if you have a sweet tooth.  Lots cheaper than a McDonalds breakfast.  Takeout only.  Only downer is that the place gets crowded when there are more than a few customers at the counter at the same time.
Good breakfast, cheap, and they ONLY serve turkey bacon (which is awesome).

WOW! What a great find in the Theater District for a pre-show lunch or dinner!

First of all, we had the best server in the history of servers -- Drewski! He was amazing -- knew everything on the menu, offered suggestions where we asked for them (including around drinks), and just could not have been lovelier. The place was pretty busy, and he was great about checking in from time to time to let us know the status of our food.

Speaking of the food -- yowza, that was an amazing lunch! Everyone got something different, and everyone enjoyed what they chose immensely! I got the chicken sandwich with avocado, with pepper jack cheese, which added a great kick. Another person got the sliders, someone got the devil tacos (I think that's what they were called?) and there was a fish dish that I don't pay attention to because I don't eat fish. :) And the winner of our table was the fried chicken with a sweet potato pancake. We all tasted each other's dishes, and shared our fries and sweet potato fries. There wasn't one thing we didn't all rave about.

They also have an amazing list of drinks, both alcoholic and non-alcoholic. I saw someone on the way in who had a beer that was as tall as I am (not saying much, but you get my drift). Drewski, if you're lucky enough to get him, knows his bourbon in particular, so definitely chat him up if you're a bourbon person!

We didn't have room for dessert -- but maybe next time, as we decided as a group to return and eat our way through their menu.

Enjoy!

Fabulous space for dining, it was a bit chilly at first but that was quickly adjusted. Chareese gave the best service and the GM was kind enough to share the history of Yardhouse with us. Fries were ok, but the burger and the sliders were hands down the best I have had all year. Their blend of beef was truly premium and flavorful. Top secret of course. I could really use another right now.

They were also nice enough to share complimentary birthday brookies and ice cream.

love loved everything we ordered and now I have to try their locations in California

mushroom garlic noodles 5/5
wings were cooked perfectly! no complaints we ordered multiple flavors and all were good
5/5 for the jambalaya pasta it tasted even better later as leftovers

the service was fine. the server got some of our orders wrong but we were a large group drinks were 4/5 the flavor wasn't consistent but wasn't the worst.

a good place to stop while being a tourist
Pizza was great while the meat from Jambalaya too was fine. The rest are okay for hungry walkers like us in the street of New York.

I loved this place from florida so I was super excited to see one in NY. I was also pleased for a chia restaurant in the city for the prices to be equal and not surcharged like other franchises have in the city. I was also happy that the quality was the same !!! It's a chill vibe very large space great for small or large groups. If your not a beer drinker which I'm not there are some beers that taste like a spritzer which are the ones I go for !! The server was attentive and great with giving feedback on the menu.
The poke a nacho is perfectly balanced and super flavorful ! It definitely can hold its own as a meal. I sont see it being great to go so I recommend eating it to order. The onions rings are great well fried and made with real onions. The rib eye was large engorge for two maybe 3 people to share depending on appetites. We chose fries for the side !

We loved it so much that of all of the places in New York we chose the Yard House two nights in a row!!!!  It was perfect with fun and caring servers and delicious food!!!! The best non-meat burgers I've ever tasted.  
The beer was cold and glorious.

I've been to this location about 3-4 times & I enjoyed every trip. The food portions & quality are top tier. It can be a bit pricey if you're handling the bill by yourself for other people but i can say it is worth it 100%. The service is excellent & the noise is kept to a minimum. 10/10 will go again.

I've been a fan of Yard House as a chain for years as the one near home is a favorite for happy hours and events. It was fun to see a big one right on Times Square: big open windows, bright colors and lights, and a welcoming calmness away from the hustle and bustle of the street. On our first full day in the city, our group of five headed in and didn't have to wait for a great booth table overlooking the restaurant and street.

Our experience that night was wonderful, we had an amazing server Russell who talked with us, shared our happiness at being together, and was attentive throughout. I love YH for their always large selection of beers - both the big guys and a lot of local ones so I enjoyed a few flights of things all new to me. We ordered a number of appetizers and small entrees to share. As we had a birthday in the group, we even got a song and cake - thank you all for that.

Prices are reasonable for the location and consistent with other locations as is the menu. If you're in a group and not sure where to go, the menu will have something for everyone. It's a fun place and great option in a city filled places to go.

I had a genuinely good time here! The half yard beers are HUGE but definitely good for a photo op if you are into that. The food was decent as I got the Nashville Hot Chicken sandwich that I think could have been a littler spicier but solid nonetheless. The service was fine, and attempted to accommodate my friend with a dairy allergy despite the kitchen messing up with cheese multiple times. The ambiance was fun and gave us the opportunity to watch the football games playing.

Got the Coco Passion, Buffalo and lemon pepper wings, truffle fries, and margarita pizza. The coco passion is sweet and strong with three different types of rum. There's plenty of space since it's a large restaurant in Times Square. They have a tablet to show what the different menu items are. Staff were nice.

As a Californian living in the East Coast, I was pleasantly surprised to find a Yard House in Connecticut! Such a variety of beers, what more can you need?

We came on a Saturday for a very early dinner so it wasn't pack and got seated right away. We were 3 plus a toddler. I noticed a lot of families were there at the same time. I saw a lot of small kids like mine so it's very family friendly.

Our server was really nice and attentive. He even helped us get another high chair since the first one was kinda short. He also let us sample some beers since I was on the fence on which to get. We ordered some cheese curds (must have!), a burger, spicy beef noodles and a steak salad. Honestly, everything was really good. I personally had the noodles and it was delicious. It wasn't spicy, I even let my little one try some of the noodles and veggies. He enjoyed it. The portion was so big, I took the other half home. Definitely would come again.

+.5 for service

I love the location of this Yard House, right by Times Square and it's a huge space too. Never had any issues finding a large table in the three times I was here this past weekend.

I didn't end up having any food here, but had drinks each time. Yes it's a bit pricey, but considering the location of this place you're gonna be paying higher than usual prices. And honestly for the convenience, size, and ambiance it was 100% worth it.

Service was excellent, and they were very accommodating despite our increasingly large group size each time. The best part? This was one of the only places I went to where they split the bill by item, not by an equal share of money (e.g: Splitting a $30 bill by what you ordered, not splitting it 3 ways in where we pay $10 each, regardless of what we ordered). This is standard practice in Canada, and I was shocked by how most places don't do this in the US.

Definitely recommend here for drinks after a stroll in the Theater District, especially if you're with a large group!
My food was delicious. I wish they had a happy hour like other locations. Server was cool. Drinks were good. Busy location in Times Square. Sat downstairs by the bar.

I've been here for a beer or two before my boyfriend's band practice a couple of times now. It's hard to find a good spot to go to in Times Square. This spot does not have any kind of happy hour. It is however a chain across the United States and other locations from what I see on their online site do have happy hours lol. I can't speak for the food and or service really. I've just ordered drinks up at the bar. I do appreciate that they have different sized glasses you can order. Anything from a smaller beer goblet, to a regular pint glass, to a slightly larger pint glass, to a Yard sized glass. I'm personally a fan of the regular pint glasses because prices run steep depending on what you get. Beers range from like $7-14/15. What I am a fan of is that there are close to a hundred beers on tap. Some of which I haven't tried before which is a pleasant surprise. They have beer categorized in their menu by the type of ale: ipas, pilsners, stouts, browns, sours, wheats, etc. They also have their own Yard House brand of brews that are worth checking out. I'd say if you are a huge fan of beer it's a spot worth exploring. Food prices seemed insanely steep for being traditional bar food.

We stopped in as a two for some Thursday Night Football.  Seated right away upstairs. Ibraham took great care of us. He was spot on for drinks (full bar, wine and tons of beer)and food without writing a thing down. We watched football (Giants lost to SF) while dining on burgers and pork chops. Both were cooked perfectly, hot and delicious.  Tableside kiosk can be used to order drinks, summon waitstaff or pay. (Convenient).  No need, Ibrahim was attentive to is and the very lively crowd for a Thursday
Enjoy!

I enjoyed my visit to Yard House Times Sq!   Now listen   depending on your arrival their could be a wait so save time make a reservation!

....there is nothing wrong with a solo date!  Self-care comes many different ways.  I went up stairs and sat at the bar and great service was provided.  My food came very quickly which mad my day!

One of my favs and a go to when eating at any of the yard house (ATL, Palisades Center) locations is listed below.  I would definitely recommend my pick!

Items selected from the menu includes
Food:
- lobster garlic noodles
Drinks:
Sunset Sangria for my day time choice
Midnight Sangria for my night time choice

Why do I recommend:
- all of the location are huge!
- huge Bar menu with mocktail, cocktails, wine and beer (perfect for all age group)
- food menu has a little bit of everything including option for (v, vg and gluten-free diets).  
- music
- great for all kind of reservation ( family, friends, business)
- right off west 41st towards midish block

Tip:
Depending on your time of arrival reservations are a must!  

reminder this is a roof top restaurant.  Which means you need to first enter the hotel.  Stop at the concierge desk check in at which you will be directed to the roof top elevator.

Don't be afraid to ask for suggestions I have realized when you talk the staff at any restaurant they will help you make a great choice!

Stopped in here for a couple of drinks on a hot and muggy Saturday afternoon prior to our matinee at the nearby Nederlander Theater.

The place is fairly huge, but is was quite cool, a respite from the heat.

The bar was packed but we found two seats together.

Huge selection of tap beers and a full bar for mixed drinks as well.

Bartender was attentive.

I started with a Petrus Cherry Chocolate Nitro Quad. I liked it, the chocolate and cherry flavor was there but not overpowering.  

I followed that with a London Pride (two actually). London Pride was my go to beer when I travelled to London some time ago, and if I spy it in America, I always get one or two. Good stuff.

My better half had a Moscow Mule which she found refreshing.

Three stars because the single stall unisex restroom on the first floor had a toilet that didn't flush. Not a pretty picture......

First Visit- Bamboozled

Back in September was my first time dinning at the Times Sq location. A group of friends and I two-stepped over there when we missed our reservation @ another restaurant.

I was familiar with the brand & just thought they were ok. My impression was changed, I actually order an entree and enjoyed it. Previously @ the Ridgehill location I've had drinks and basic wings, nothing overly impressive.

After a 20min wait we were seated upstairs. We all order some starters and drinks. I ordered the Lobster Garlic Noodles (hold the mushrooms) and was pleasantly surprised. So much so I convinced another group of friends to come here after an event a month later (October).

Second Visit- Tour de Armpit Wings

Womp WOMP.... Big Big mistake!

The food was subpar at best and the service was by far severely unprofessional, at times giving disorganizing and very much rude.

We were immediately taken to a table on the ground floor. Our server, Elijah, was pleasant. However his enthusiasm shifted by the time the check was requested.

Everyone order simple appetizers, or dessert and I order an entree as well. My starter was wings, which came out first. I watched as a server/busser carried the wings all over the dining room under her arm as she attempted to figure out what table ordered them. We literally watched her go to every table except for ours. Then I witnessed her holding the plate of wings under her armpit while clearing & cleaning another table, that was the end of it. When she finally made it to our table the wings were sauce-less and cold to the touch. I immediately sent them back. It took another 15/20 minutes for the girl to bring out the sauce and to notice we sent the wings back.

I also ordered the Lobster Garlic Noodles (hold the mushrooms) again. When this dish came out, it was also cold and had to be sent back. There was no apology/ concern or care from any staff member (no manger came but we didn't ask). Not even our server and by no means did we think he was at fault.

The rest of the table ordered poké nachos, wine and dessert. Everything else was just ok. The service severely began to slack after the "tour de armpit wings" and noticeable got worse towards the end when asking for water and waiting for the server to return with minor things like napkins and lemons.

We watched as he had a full conversation with the table next to us but failed to check-in with what we asked for or when we needed assistance. Then when we received the bill the "tour de armpit wings" was still on the bill.

I can understand slight service struggles when busy, but they were busier the first time than the second. While I thought they presently surprised me the first time I was wrong! The service and food quality doesn't justify the price or calories.

I highly doubt there will be any additional visits for me, especially not a third visit @ this location.

Just A Note:

First visit was a party of 5, we sat upstairs and second visit was a party of 4, we a at downstairs. If that makes any difference. Idt service and quality should be contingent on where you sit.

I went to Yard House last night. I love Yard House and I try to go when I'm in the city. Katie was my waiter. She was exceptional. She walked me through the whole menu in a way no other server had at Yard House before. She suggested beer for me I had never tried and brought me samples so I would be able to taste it before I bought it. Then I spilled my beer (my first beer I wasn't drunk just clumsy) and she cleaned it up for me and brought me a new beer, free of charge. She didn't even make me feel bad. I always come to yard house because it's the best, but from now on I'll be requesting Katie.

Great service and excellent beers but really want to watch the NFL playoffs. While they have the games on the TV's the music is loud inside and they are not going to put the game audio on. Looking for a sports bars and not so trendy.

BBQ bacon Burger - 5 Stars perfectly cooked and seasoned.

Had dinner with a group of friends here. Service was good. I wanted spicy so i got the Korean chili garlic wings. They weren't bad but not spicy. Everyone enjoyed their food and it was a good time. Watch your phone here because there is a phone thief working here. Friends phone disappeared. The waitress or the guy bussing our table didn't seem concerned, but told us not to worry they'll find it. It took us talking about tracking it from the iPad to them suddenly finding it. They knew the hostess had it. She took pictures with friends phone and didn't delete them. Smart.

I came here the other night with some foodie friends. We were in the area after an event nearby and we were starving. I figured it would take forever to get a table, especially being in Times Square but we were immediately taken to a table on the ground floor. Our server, Elijah, was very nice. He smiled the entire time he served us, despite there being a few hiccups.

We ordered some drinks and a couple of starters. I had the poké nachos and another person had an order of traditional wings. For whatever reason, the wings came out first...well, sort of. A server/busser carried the wings all over the dining room under her arm because she was unsure which table ordered them. We watched her go to every table except for our. When my dining companion witnessed her holding the appetizer under her arm while cleaning another table, that was the end of it. She finally made her way to our table and dropped off the wings without any sauce. They were cold. My gf immediately sent them back. It took another 15 minutes for the girl to bring out the sauce and notice we sent the wings back.

Luckily for me, Antwan brought my poké nachos straight to the table. They were OK. I've never had that big of an issue with them in the past at the YH in my area so I decided to stick with what I know. They just didn't poké enough for me and could have used more tuna. The rest of the table ordered the lobster noodles, some dessert and vino. Everything else was ok. The service began to slack a little towards the end when asking for water and waiting for the server to return. He was having a full ocnvo with the table next to us and failed to check in when we needed assistance.
Lastly, we had to make sure that we weren't charged for the item we sent back.

Whenever I've gone to YH, we usually sit at the bar. It's just easier for better service and even then you might find yourself in Diner Hunger Games, when trying to get your bartender's attention. When they're busy, service goes down, bad. IMO the food isn't all it's cracked up to be. The quality and flavor don't justify the kcals.

It's safe to say that barring desparation, I likely won't be back to this loc, especially having to dodge their guarding derelicts. It's crazy out in Times Square these days.

This is a regular spot for me and my Bestie.  We come to sit at the bar, catch up, drink and eat.  It's always very relaxing and conveniently located to both Port Authority and Penn Station so when we're ready to leave we can make our train and bus. I ordered a Mule I believe but I tasted NO alcohol and no ginger beer. Usually I at least taste the ginger beer. The drink was a fail for me but the food was still good to me.
I ordered sweet potato fries and the Garlic Lobster Noodles. Both were very tasty

We came here on a Friday night and it was packed.  We stumbled onto this place while walking around Times Square and they were able to accommodate us at the bar without a reservation.  We sat a the bar on the second floor and our bartender name was amazing.  We are not big beer drinkers but he gave a lot of good recommendations and we ended on Cider.  

We ordered Chicken Nachos and Burgers that were really good and juicy.  They had the game and sports on every channel.  It was not an intimate setting but a sports bar setting so just be mindful.

I had a great time here and will definitely come back here if I am in the area.

I must say I love this place!
Very busy place considering it is in Times Square. I was super surprised by the hospitality. Our server was amazing and we received our food pretty quickly.
Noise level is decent and the food was great.

I ordered a nice burger with sweet potato fries and my friend got the shrimp taco which she loved!!!
I also ordered takeout to go for my boyfriend and he enjoyed the meal.
We ended up paying $48 each. I must say that's a great deal for apps+ drinks+ entree.

If you're in the area consider stopping by.

Ahhh NYC Times Square

I've been to the one in DC and decided to try it again. This time I was looking for healthy options and a good drink - a happy medium so to speak.

My experience was really great here. I've only ever sat a the bar. I'm sad I did not take pictures of my October fest flight and chicken lettuce wrap. This is very much a tourist location where people from all over the world come in or locals. It's what makes NYC a great place. The waiters I had were cool. Shared stories and were attentive. Their knowledge of drinks and the extensive tap was mild blowing. I've never seen so many taps.

Pro - location, Times Square by all major trains, Port Authority, and a few blocks from Penn station. Staff are pleasant. Bar staff are golden. Food is good with healthy options and not extremely pricey. It is a huge place with two floors and an elevator. It's disability friendly. The bar has a lower section. I sat near someone with had devices to assist her with standing and walking. There's one bathroom at the bottom floor.

Tip - this is a very busy place. If you have a large group inquire about a reservation to avoid wait times or get on the waitlist. Every time I go it's not always easy to find 1 seat let along 2 at the large downstairs bar but people frequent in and out.

For a busy place I appreciate the staff being so pleasant! It's definitely helped my mood and brightened my day.

Cons -

It's a chain yet it gives restaurant experience feels - the staff was friendly and accomodating.  The layout and decor is modern and spacey.  Music plays in the background, you may tap a toe or wiggle in seat at best, the volume is controlled... to avoid outbursts of turnin' up, I'm sure :-)

Notes on the Grub-

- Mac and Cheese was tasty.  I love the truffle addition, adds savor.  I will say they went a lil hard on the amount of mushrooms.  Bring the mushrooms down a notch and it's totally a go.

-Filet Mignon.  Soft, juicy, look petite on the plate but every satisfying.  The side mash and veggies were too a flavorful hit.

-Truffle Fries... these were almost great in my book.  2 things, both times I've had they're fried a bit too hard and the Thyme ( I get it we all wanna add our lil twist) throws the flavor off.  I expect my truffle to have that "good stank"  (iykyk) and the thyme adds an unwanted mint flavor on the back end.

-Sips... now this is where the chain part comes in.  I know they mean well yet the drinks didn't pack enough punch for me - even in asking for my own mix.

-California Roll Stack (I don't remember the name)
This was flavor galore.  Just imagine an extra large California Roll, yum.  Ease up on the Mayo and I'll repeat buy.  Was slightly too "wet" for me.

This is the type of place where you pick your fav dish and then treat yourself to it ever so often.  I wouldn't make this my entire evening out, this is a dinner date, family/friends outing or have a productive meeting w/ a client eat spot.
Really really good! I was skeptical about getting but boy did it change my mind that is my new favorite dish until I find another
Service and food were both great. Nashville hot chicken with sweet potato pancakes was on point as usual. Yet another Yard House that I'll happily eat at anytime.

Nice service & drinks. Big sports bar, touristy vibe.
Just tried their Onion rings tower which is not so great.
It comes with a lot of onion rings & tasty chipotle ranch, but the texture is oily & soggy. It needs to be crispy!!

Hope they nail it next time!

Went in and had just 30 minutes before a show..  We had Russ whom was amazing.  We had drinks and food and was able to enjoy before we left. We didn't eat much of the nachos and asked if he would hold them until our show was finished.  We came back after the show and asked for Russ again. We ordered more drinks and Russ had a fresh order of nachos for us . We was an amazing server and unique personality.  I could not recommend Russ enough!

The shrimp noodle seemed like the chef just threw veggies and herbs on the plate without really taking the time to remove the stems and cutting sizable pieces but overall there wasn't complaints about flavor. Pizza fries and burger all delicious. Atmosphere was calm with great music. The waiter was great. The service was on point with no complaints whatsoever. Very kid friendly with games and coloring paper/menu for the kids to enjoy while eating. I've been here twice and would come again.

I've been to Yard house before in the west.  I was greatful we decided to stop here while in Times Square.  Really wanted the cheesesteak, but really didn't want the bread, too heavy late night.  So I decided to tell them to put everything from the sandwhich on top of the fries.  BEST. DECISION.EVER!!!   Why have I not through of this before???  

Our waiter Joey went to break just a few moments before our meals were delivered.  He came back over hoping to see how it looked.  Glad I had taken the picture because after not eating for 10 hours I want about to wait around for him to be back..so all that was left were a few of the fries.  

Ya never know what dish you may discover if you just ask them to leave out the bread.  The rib eye was tender chunks of deliciousness, much more than I expected.  The steaksauce and garlic Aoli added a lot of flavor espically to the fries.  I was really happy with this decision.

Came here with hubby after a late concert in NYC, they stay open pretty late which is a plus. We got drinks (coco passion and a lemon drop) which where good. We both ordered the lobster garlic noodles which we thought was yummy, but on the verge of being too salty;still good tho. We ordered the steak to go. Overall good experience
I had the truffle cheese burger which was pretty good. The queso dip was also pretty solid. Service was  good as well.

I came here afterwork with some friends for a get together.  The food was really good and the drinks standard as all bars In restaurants.  The ambiance is a nice vibe and energy was good.  It was packed but I guess it's the holidays.  As all my reviews I only give 4's on the first try but a second round will determine my next rating.  Give it a try

This place was has been a pleasant surprise, twice. Yeah, I know, it is right smack in the middle of Times Square, and despite of what you are thinking, the food was excellent for the price. Yes, I am also well aware that this is a chain, but we were very surprised how prompt and quick they were with the food, both times, we had to ask if they had a huge kitchen, they do.
We ordered the chicken wings and they were one of the best chicken wings we've ever had. They also have a very large beer selection. Ambience and music is always on point.

Prices are really reasonable for times square. Staff are really good and friendly too. Give this place a go in you are in NYC area.

This was fine. It's convenient to Times Square. The beer list, while expansive, wasn't overly unique or impressive. Our waiter was great, but they also have the on table iPad ordering, so it was a bit confusing. The large Bavarian pretzel was a hit. Everything else was just standard fare.
Very poor service. Asked for a water that was never delivered. The waiters don't care about the customers asks. Would never recommend a customer to attend this bar.

Yardhouse always hits me with nostalgia - used to be one of my go-to spots in college for apps and drinks during happy hour. Half price drinks and apps, sign me up. Dropped by for a quick snack and drink while in Times Square and it definitely brought me back. The poke nachos were just as good as I remembered. Deep friend wonton chips, topped with ahi tuna, and drenched in sauces. Got the dragon fruit cosmo to wash it down. Sweet and easy to drink. Wasn't made well per-say (ice still in the drink) but it was enjoyable nonetheless. Special shoutout to the waiter for being such a sweetheart - definitely bumped up the rating.

Came here a few weeks ago, food was good. I only ordered one dish but I'm giving this place a good review because our server was really cool. Would give 5 stars but it was packed so my family had to wait a bit. We were told our waiting time to be seated would be 15 minutes but we had to wait way more than that. Other than that, the atmosphere was really chill. There were a ton of people but it wasn't overly loud.

I came here for the first time after seeing a play. It's a big restaurant with two floors and they have an elevator. Nothing special about the ambiance just a bar/restaurant. I ordered the chicken tortilla soup which was more like a chowder, it was thick and creamy but tasty. I had the chicken Cobb salad that was ok, the ranch dressing was bland but the vinaigrette was good. My waitress was very good and attentive sorry I didn't get her name.

I brought my wife here for her birthday in August last year, and the service was outstanding. The staff made her feel like the queen she is for her birthday. Thank you for being a wonderful place to dine. By the way I also ran into my nephews that same evening.

I've been to several YHs before and was familiar with the menu, which is why we came here for a late dinner on a Thursday evening. We were seated right away but it took a bit to get our orders taken. Our server was friendly and hustling, but they had a lot of large tables to cover. Food was fine but the espresso martini (for being listed as a speciality) was pretty bland from what I am used to. It tasted mostly of espresso vodka and nothing else. What really made this a miss, however, was the music. And it wasn't too loud except the bass was either horribly out of tune or the speakers broken as every time a bass line played it rattled and blasted the room rather than provided an upbeat ambience.

One fine Thursday evening in midtown and come across this wonderful bar with positive vibes. Enjoyed match between Arkansas and Gonzaga with my Lavender Drop cocktail and then a good Lager beer! Enjoyed having conversation with a gentleman visiting from England. Had a good discussion on Indian food, English premier league and Cricket.

Thank you for the wonderful hospitality.

Visiting soon in the future.

Cheers,
Amey

I was so glad to see a big Yardhouse open around Times Square! Yes it's a chain, but it's a cool chain. It seems worth spending the money for excellent food and lots of craft beer choices. They have a good selection of food items and a lot of their dishes have a bit of a twist to them. For example, I had the Korean BBQ cheesesteak which had a lot of meat tossed in yummy sauces. There's a whole wall full of draft beer, the menu organizes it by style. I like that they also have a whole bunch of house beers (in different styles) that were created in partnership with a few different breweries.
I visited around 6 PM on a Tuesday and it was pretty crowded, most of the tables were full and I got one of the last seats at the bar. Apparently they also have a second level but that wasn't open..

I'm giving a lower rating because I feel like there were too few bartenders. One seemed to be focusing solely on drink orders from the wait staff for their tables. And the other 2 were hard to flag down, especially from the end of the bar. It's not that they were bad, it's more that they were understaffed.

Beers are cold and refreshing.
Servers are very accommodating .
Place is clean and big.

I will recommend this place to a friend or coworkers. We went at YH Tuesday 4PM and we got a table as soon as we entered. Also a lot of table to choose at that time. Easy peasy ! Will definitely comeback!

I've never been to a Yard House, but I most certainly will return. We had just finished off a couple of those .99 pizza slices you can find around Times Square, and were looking for a place to sit and warm up a little while enjoying a brew.

I knew immediately we were going to enjoy our visit. The two bartenders (Aaron and Rose) were Jonny on the Spot with our drinks, were quick to help us understand how the Subway works, and were a fount of knowledge about all things related to the Big Apple. The entire counter top bar was completely full. They were super busy with customers, but they were so efficient, not one customer had to wait more than a minute to be served. All the while, they took time to help us non-natives to get a game plan for how to navigate the city.

Really can't thank them enough, but I will try the next time I pop in for a quick refreshing brew.

#todaysdiscovery

Great time at the Yard House tonight. It's a Thursday night and there is a 20 minute wait  but the hostess is super friendly. However, after 5 minutes we find 2 seats at the bar, so we cancel our table reservation.
At the bar Jasmine is so friendly with a great smile. We ordered  are drinks and two appetizers; Fire Cracker Shrimp & Buffalo Tenders.
The Fire Cracker shrimps were very tasty and came with what I would call hash browns on the bottom of the shrimp.
The Buffalo Tenders were just too hot for me but made with good chicken.
I also ordered a Grilled Chicken Creaser Salad which was delicious.
Overall, great service... good food, I'd come back.
If you like an amazing selection of beers, you are in for a treat.

Pages and pages of drinks to choose from in the menu.  But they also make it easier by having the kiosk at your table to browse and order by category drinks, apps, and desserts.  It also makes it easy to spend a lot of money as you can add another item and it's another $15 easily.  The allagash curieax was a high alcoholic content but didn't taste it until the aftertaste and was pretty good.  Chicken tenders were rather small, especially being double breaded, there really wasn't much meat.  But the sweet potato fries were pretty good.  Admittedly, we didn't try the main dishes so can't really rate the food, but there were lots of options, and service was fast and friendly, with plenty of seats on multiple floors.

Food 9/10
We ordered the Busan pancakes, the tteokboki, beef brisket, fresh and marinated ribs. The ribs were sooo tender and nicely cooked, the way they were cut brought out the flavor perfectly. Honestly one of the best cuts of kbbq i've had in the city. The tteokboki was mixed in with SO MUCH seafood, it was super worth. The pancakes were less memorable, but they still tasted great nevertheless. Banchan were solid too.

Atmosphere 9/10
Vibey interior, it's giving elevated korean bbq experience, but doesn't feel tacky. Dim lighting and large spacious tables. Quite loud inside.

Service 9/10
Friendly and fast service. Cooked everything so well.

My girlfriend said that this is her favorite kbbq spot in the city, and I can understand why! Been here 3 times and it has always been a great experience. Servers were attentive, and the meats were cooked really well.

The beef quality is outstanding (got fresh shortrib and dry aged ribeye all 3 times), and the 3 ssamjang that was given all adds a unique flavor to the ssam. I love the fact that they'll quickly bring sesame oil and salt if we ask for them as well.

I also love all the appetizers that I've tried, but the biggest highlights would be the crispy potato pancakes and the mul yookhwe (assuming you are open to trying raw beef).

Came here on a weekend night. Reservations are definitely recommended, but it doesn't seem too difficult for now. The restaurant smells incredible and is clean and modern.

We ordered the marinated and non marinated combo. The mean quality here seems pretty good and looks fresh. I think my experience here would've been much better had the server done a better job at cooking the meats. While some pieces were good, the marinated meats ended up soggy and steamed/boiled in the marinade, which made the meat tough.

For the price point this restaurant is charging, the servers should be trained better at cooking the orders correctly.

Overall, flavor was good, ambiance was nice, but execution was a bit poor. Many other options to try in this area!

This is stylish and swanky Korean restaurant in the heart of Koreatown.   They have a big menu, including Korean BBQ (which we didn't do), and the menu prices can vary widely depending on your selections.  Each of us in our party of 4 ordered entrees that ended up being generous and reasonably priced actually, especially for Manhattan.  They were also all flavorful and delicious entrees.  They have two floors of dimly lit dining space and with full bars and fancy drinks on both floors.  It's a cozy romantic date-night sort of place, though that wasn't necessarily what we were looking for.

So, we ordered the following and also got a traditional serving of delectable banchan.

- Uni mentaiko rice, $32
- Galbi patty, $24
- Grilled mackerel, $24  (wife's)
- Spicy pork bibimbop, $23 (mine)

We ended up eating upstairs and service was attentive.  The wife in particular got a huge amount of mackerel.  Our friend, who is an uni lover, really enjoyed her uni dish.  It was a great dinner choice for our one night in NYC on this trip.

Our group got the prime/mari package, and the meat was very high quality. We're all small eaters and wanted to save some room for dessert, so the package was the perfect amount for the 4 of us.

Service was great - they cooked the meat for us while constantly refilling our water and banchan. Ambiance was nice and classy, perfect for celebrations. We didn't feel gross nor smoky after.

Note that menu is only available on weekdays. Dinner menu all day on weekend. Lunch reservation was easy - I made a reservation the day of (Sat) a few hours before. No cancellation fee which I appreciated. All in all, I'd recommend coming here if money isn't an issue. It's expensive but you get what you pay for.

This is our FAVORITE restaurant in NYC!!!  I don't know how you can come and give anything but 5 stars as your rating.  Small intimate restaurant (reservations high recommend).  Each table basically has its own server with other helpers to make sure you are taken care of and enjoying your meal.  As far as the food goes...WOW, come
Hungry my friends!  For appetizer we had the Galbi dumplings (pan fried).  This was the least favorite thing we ordered.  For meats we did the fresh short rib and marinated short rib.  Their meat is amazing.  They cook it for you at the table and it just melts in your mouth!  My favorite dish is the octopus over rice.  It comes in a hot
Stone bowl and is super spicy but has an amazing flavor.  For dessert we had the pear sorbet and it was very refreshing and not your typical ice cream.  Wish this place was in Seattle so we could come more often.

Sept 2023.  Sorry but meat quality is AYCE level.
Service and Ambiance both 4 stars and standard for K-BBQ.  All of the meats were over cooked so that didn't help but the overall quality was not good.

Came here before a concert at MSG (just a few blocks away!) and had a great cocktail and a delicious dinner. We sat upstairs at one of the tables set up for Korean BBQ, but the entire space was so beautiful.

I started with the Angry Tangerine cocktail, mezcal, Campari, tangerine foam. It was SO good!! Loved the smokiness mixed with the fruitiness.

We also got an appetizer of the fried dumplings and for dinner, me and my cousin split the Uni Mentaiko Rice & one of the bbq entrees. The Korean BBQ (I cannot remember which one we got) came with lots of little sides like kimchi and fresh veggies. Between the two of us, it was the perfect amount of food.

If you find yourselves in midtown looking for some good food and a nice space, this would be a good find.

My friend and I came here with reservations on a Thursday night. The place is very beautifully decorated inside. We were lead upstairs to our table. We decided to get the package with a mix of marinated and unmarinated meats.  Our waitress told us they are known for their unmarinated meats.
We started off with the unmarinated meats first which was super delicious ! Great cuts of sirloin and short ribs. The salt provided for seasoning was great  and completed the meats very well.
The marinated meats were good too but I think me and my friend both agree the unmarinated meats were way better!
Service was very good. They cooked our meats and let us know when they were ready. The side dishes were super tiny but we were able to get refills. Overall a great dining experience! I do wish the meats came with rice as well but that's my personal preference. We left full and happy :)

One of the best Korean bbq places I've been to. The Yuzu ade was very refreshing. As an appetizer, we ordered the Mul Yookhwe, which is any icy steak tartare in a broth. This was one of the most unique dishes I've ever had. The texture is unreal with the ice crystals, soft beef tartare, refreshing flavorful broth, and a myriad of veggie slivers. We were told that this delicious dish is seasonal, so it will be taken off the menu soon. We also ordered the Marinated Short Ribs and Wagyu Short ribs. Both were delicious! Top quality and great marinate. More soy-forward than other places I've tried. I enjoyed the side dishes, as well. For dessert, we had the Asian Pear Sorbet, which was magical. It comes with a sweet cinnamon flavored broth that's poured over it. The sorbet leans refreshing and light, which is always my favorite type of dessert. If you like ultra-sweet desserts, this may not be for you. The texture of the sorbet was almost like a shaved ice. I absolutely loved it and our entire meal. Service was amazing. The restaurant has a serene high-end feel, that's not stuffy. We will definitely be back!

Yoon does Korean BBQ right! We came here with a group of 4 and received excellent service even though it was crowded. The food was delicious and you get a lot for what you pay for. It's always fun seeing it prepared and cooked in front of you and being able to share with friends. Worth a visit!

Had some fantastic delivery during the pandemic so I was excited to sit down in person for a birthday.  Mildly disappointed but still solid.  

During the pandemic, the spicy tteokbokki was my jam.  It was perhaps a bit too spicy for me but the texture and overall flavors were addictive so I'd happily eat it anyway.  The rice cakes were crispy on the outside and delightfully chewy, and the dish itself was filled with legit seafood.

Sitting down in person, the meats were about par.  A fatty looking plate of brisket rendered down and was satisfying.  The fresh short rib was the best, scored on both sides to make it tender.  Sadly, there were some bone shards in the meat.  The wagyu short rib was the worst dish, somehow flavorless and chewy.  The dry aged ribeye was a joy, especially after the disappointing wagyu.

Personally, I like unmarinated meats at kbbq but here they don't give you much to doctor up your bites, offering just salt.  I tend to shy away from marinated meats because they end up being too sweet but if I return I will go with a marinated package instead of the unmarinated prime.  

My one cocktail was fine but we did enjoy the soju seltzer.

Strangely, our original server started the night well but someone must have pissed her off right before our last meat dish.  Aggressive and sloppy.  Bewildering.  Service from other staff members were fine.
