Unfortunately less discerning palates and those who did not finance the ill-fated venture had already begun to eat. The two orders will not adequately feed two people.

No one answers the phone when you call. The voice mail has not been set up.

I feel like I was scammed.

I haven't been in years because the reviews were so mid, but glad I stopped in on a random Monday. The sushi was great and fresh. Honestly, it's the only sushi worthwhile in Harlem, so thankful they're still open, and they deserve more business. I highly encourage stopping because sushi is one of those foods that don't do well with any travel. I will say, if it is busy, it can get slow.

The food is decent but overpriced. We order takeout from here sometimes as a treat but will now take our business elsewhere. The staff is racist against Black customers, which is unacceptable anywhere but especially on Malcolm X Blvd in Harlem. We will find another spot that actually respects the community it profits from.

Yuzu is an small, but inviting restaurant with a neighborhood vibe in Harlem. It seems like a place that is frequented by folks who live in the neighborhood.

I visited Yuzu on an early Friday evening, and the place was not crowded. The staff was very friendly and helpful, but my waitress seemed a bit distracted with another table. I think the folks at the other table were regulars, and the waitress was familiar with them.

Unfortunately, I will say that the food prices are above average for what you get. I take that back. The appetizers were reasonably priced, but the main dishes seemed to be a bit overpriced. Perhaps, Yuzu uses better/higher quality fish compared to other Japanese restaurants in the area. Honestly, I was not wowed with my selections to justify the price. Don't me wrong, the food was good but it was not that good for the price (especially in Harlem). I will say that I was very pleased with my black sesame seed ice cream.

Wow! The fish was extremely fresh, tender and delicious. I also liked the hiziki appetizer, which was different (and better) than most other hiziki served in the U.S.

Extremely reasonably priced for the high quality. We were the only eat-in customers on a Tuesday night. They gave us a free appetizer of a new dish they were trying!

The wait staff was attentive but not hovering over us.

Very convenient to 2 and 3 subway lines. Glad my friend suggested it and that we tried it - I will definitely go back. Highly recommend.
We ordered online for delivery got the assorted seasonal fish meal, lotus root, hamachi collar. So, so good. Like a little omakase to your front door. Extremely high quality fish, super tasty.

This is the only sushi spot in central Harlem worth patronizing except Inoue but you can't go to Sushi Inoue every day.  I have been here in person several times and just ordered delivery for the first time for dinner. My order came in 20 minutes.
The chirashi and karaage were as good delivered as they are at the restaurant. Can't wait to dine in again which I should have done tonight since delivery, tip and tax totalled about 1/3 of the bill! Note the default on seamless for the driver's tip was 25%!   You can definitely customize.
Nice atmosphere and great food.  Good service too!  Whether Indoor or outdoor  not too loud

So, I normally like this spot.  But they charge $2 for extra ginger. For me, It's like the feeling you get when a fast food joint charges you for condiments. This type of charge turns me off, so I'm not coming back.  The worst part is she charged my card without telling me until after she gave me my receipt.

If you want to know about the food - The sushi is relatively good, and I'd give it 3.5 stars for the sushi.

Spontaneously wanting some sushi, we decided to get Yuzu sushi delivered to us! We ordered the shrimp tempura roll, Negi-Hamachi roll (Yellowtail & Scallion), and the Black Dragon roll (crabmeat and shrimp on the inside; eel and avocado on top of the rolls). The bill came out to around $44, which is somewhat expensive for our tastes, but we found an online coupon giving us $10 off our bill! :)

The Negi-Hamachi roll was pretty light, which was great because we had a total of 3 rolls to finish, so it didn't leave us feeling heavy from eating too much. The rolls were pretty small, but I would have been filled with 6 or 8 pieces of it.

The shrimp tempura roll was probably the most average of the rolls. Similar to many other restaurants' shrimp tempura rolls, it's heavily compacted with rice and vegetables, leaving a small cube of shrimp in the middle of most of the rolls. Only the end pieces really had a good amount of shrimp in them.

The Black Dragon roll was my favorite roll out of our sushi trio! The eel was very savory, while the avocado was both creamy and helped neutralize the eel on the top. It was a bit difficult to taste the crab and shrimp with the strong tastes of the eel and avocado though. Nevertheless, this was an amazing roll!

I was shocked to see how small the rolls looked when we first opened the box, but between 2 people, the rolls were a perfect size for our shared dinner! I'm so glad there is a wonderful sushi restaurant such as Yuzu near us in Harlem!

I went to Yuzu last night with my sushi buddy -- the only person in my circle who crazes sushi and sashimi from time to time. This was our first time there and so we didn't know what to expect. Waiting for my friend to arrive I ordered a Chinese stout -- delicious. When she arrived we ordered an Echigo stout for her as well and an Hijiki Sweet Salad to share-- quite different from most hijiki we've had and just sweet enough. We were brought an unusual new appetizer they were testing 'on the house', then ordered a regular sashimi set of 11 pieces, and later individual pieces of sushi. The fish was super-fresh, and the lean and fatty tunas melted in the mouth. This is really superior sushi/sashimi, undoubtedly the best in Harlem and one of the best in the city. Highly recommended.

I've been here multiple times since yuzu first opened.
there isn't a lot on the menu besides traditional sushi so be aware (my gf hates raw fish)
i believe the pieces of fish are way too small
the price point does not really fit Harlem
why does the omakase which costs 85$ and up only come with 7 pieces of sushi.
if you get a sushi and sashimi combo- the sashimi is TINY.
you can spend quite a bit and leave very hungry so be aware.
however the food has always been great an the decor is very trendy.
the staff has always been friendly.
Very small spot but extremely nice staff and delicious food! I got the sushi set, which was perfect since I didn't know exactly what I wanted and the set provided a nice sampler.

Wish I could give this place 3.5 stars. I ordered the sushi sashimi set for delivery on a Sunday night. It came in 30 min, 10 min earlier than the predicted time, which I appreciated. However, for the price ($38 after tax!) it was not worth it. You get 6 pieces of nigiri, 6 pieces of sashimi, a crab avo roll (really??), and a small miso soup. Needless to say, I was not full afterwards.  

Fish quality: ok, most important part right? I will say the salmon, yellowtail, and scallop were very good. They were fresh and flavorful, and the fish-to-rice ratio was perfect. The quality of the tuna was subpar. It was mushy and the texture had lost all integrity, as if it had been in the freezer for way too long. Everything else was just as you'd expect, nothing spectacular.

As I alluded earlier, I was very disappointed that the roll they included was a crab stick avocado roll. For the price I would've hoped for something better. Maybe an eel avocado roll would've been more fitting.

I've had comparably good sushi and fish quality at AYCE places. I would expect a non-AYCE sushi restaurant to have higher standards.

Anyways, with everything considered, especially with the lack of sushi options in central Harlem, I would probably go back but definitely order something different.

Amazing food. Horrendous services.

I was contemplating whether or not to write this review because we really liked the food. But I realized that these issued must be addressed. So here goes. This is my second time here but things weren't what we expected. See, we  went there around 8.00 pm on last week with my girlfriend and had to stand outside for 15 minute behind the all these clustered delivery drivers on the front door. It kind of pissed us off because they are very incompetent when it comes to managing the outdoor situation. After the long wait , the skinny male staff with black bowl cut hair sat us down, then he immediately left us without saying a word and provided us with nothing (not even menus or water) and then took him another roughly 15 minutes. But thankfully the female staff noticed us and provided us with all the necessities. Then after we went over the menu and was ready to order, the said male waitstaff came over to us and we later learned that his name was "john" trying to help us but his English is not the best but that's okay, nothing wrong with that except the fact that he remains muted and never answer our question about the food and just nodded every time we asked question is really infuriating.  Why hired someone who clearly can't communicate well enough to be in the front of the house. Last time we came, we were helped by another guy with long brown/copper hair. LOVE that guy. He was funny and really helpful in guiding and explaining the food. Sadly, he wasn't there the day we came in. Anyways, lets talk about food. We ordered plethora of things and it was amazing.  Although not amazing enough to triumph the horrible services we've had.

Went there on 6/25. Sat on the sidewalk terrace. Liked the $5 happy hour drinks. Overall the food was very good. My only issue was with the seaweed salad, it came on top of a bed of what looked like kelp. I have seen some places do that to make the serving appear bigger. I hope that was not the case. The service and ambiance was very good.

Ordered the following for delivery:

- Sakedon
- Chirashi Don
- Toro Sushi
- Karrage
- Shrimp Gyoza

My raw items (sakedon, chirashidon, toro) all arrived cooked as they were packed on top of (instead of underneath - HEAT RISES) the other hot items (karrage, gyoza) AND packed on top of warm rice. I understand that donburi is generally served over warm rice, by science says you put cold meat on top of something warm and it WILL start cooking. I called the restaurant to provide my feedback. I was told that this was "so weird" and that "it's never happened before" and that "the rice is supposed to be warm". Sure. Send me warm rice. Separate the raw fish and place it in a separate container so that it does not COOK. I was basically laughed at and and told that this never happens so they don't know what to say. How about sorry. Will never order from here again.

Food quality is good to great. Rolls are slightly better than average but fish quality for sashimi is definitely worth the price.

Recommend the bentos (portion kind of small) and the chefs choice sashimi.

I was on the fence about coming here after reading all the inconsistent Yelp reviews, but decided to give this place a go anyway. Stopped by for lunch on a weekday with my friends and got seated right away. We ordered chirashi bowls and were pleasantly surprised by the variety of fish they included and how fresh everything was. Portion sizes were also perfect and reasonable for the price ($15 each). The servers were pretty attentive and nice as well. Service was a bit slow though; took them a while to bring out the food and give us the check despite there being only two other tables at the time. All in all, a solid experience.

Final thoughts. Would not recommend coming here if you're expecting some mind-blowing sushi, cause this is not the place for that. But do come if you're in Harlem, craving Japanese food, and looking for a convenient spot to grab food that is both reasonably priced + decent tasting.

Unfortunately a lot more expensive than what it's worth. The timing was great especially with the poor weather BUT the sushi pieces were very tiny and didn't taste fresh at all. The tomago looked old and didn't taste like tomago should. Normally it's a brighter yellow color with a sweet but eggy taste, but the tamago tasted stale with almost no flavor. Very disappointed.

Went to grab a bite for lunch during happy hour. They had a variety of items to chose from the menu for during this time. I chose the teriyaki salmon Beto box which came with California sushi rolls, gyoza, salad, and miso soup. The salmon was fresh with a tasteful amount of teriyaki sauce. My favorite addition to this meal was the miso soup.

I appreciated the waitress warning me that the bento boxes took time to make versus if you just ordered the 2 or 3 different types of sushi rolls.

Bottom line, I will be coming back here again during my lunch break.

This was a delicious place for a sushi meal. Located on a busy Lenox ave.

Ordered the dish that gave us a sample of all the best pieces of sushi. All the pieces tasted fresh and well crafted. The starters are surprising good. The roots tasted great. The miso soup had some veggies in it which gave it good bite.

Service was quick and responsive. The ambiance was a dimmed lit "let's get to know each other" type vibe.

Overall: will return if I'm ever in Harlem looking for some sushi.

Sushi made by Japanese chef with great price!  I went there with my husband. My husband is really obsessed with Japanese food. I ordered Yuzu set. My husband ordered otoro nigiri and king sermon nigiri a la carte. My Yuzu set was great. They will ask you if you have anything you can't eat so I told them the fish I don't like. My husband's Itoro nigiri was good but I think it wasn't  good as the price. We were very in hurry so we didn't have time to try their deserts but I would love to try some next time.

I enjoyed my sushi takeout and though everything was fresh and well prepared! Seems like a great spot to have in Central Harlem, pricing isn't prohibitive and I look forward to ordering from them again! Both the Shrimp Tempura Roll and the double shrimp roll were great.

I got Lunch Salmon teriyaki. The salmon wasn't cooked at all. Completely row.
I will never order from this place.

Placed an order at 7:35. Got to the restaurant at 8:15. Order still was not ready. Waited until 8:41 for the food in the cold.

On top of that I couldn't eat one of the rolls because it came as Tempura, but wasn't listed as such on the menu (black dragon roll). I checked all iterations of the menu to be sure.

So now I'm cold, late, and can't eat something I paid for. I've had a decent experience here before but this was pretty bad.

Saving grace was the nice waitstaff. Happy to give it another go, but I think I'll only do sit down instead of carry out.

First time visiting, we were pleasantly surprised to find an authentic Japanese restaurant!

We ordered sushi & sashimi combo, eel avocado, grilled hamachi and ended of with green tea ice-cream.  We loved all the food: fresh, good quality, & lovely presentation.  The grilled fish took a while but it was worth the wait.  

We will be back, hungry for more!

Yeah Yuzu! This is officially my favorite Sushi bar in Harlem.  
To be honest I haven't been to Sushi Inoue because the hostess has informed me that they are closed on 2 of my 3 attempts to visit although there were customers sitting at the bar at the time and their Sushi chef was back in Japan having his visa renewed on my 3rd attempt to visit. I haven't been to Charlie's either but these are reasons Yuzu is my favorite Harlem Sushi Bar:
1.) Great customer service. The staff is courteous ,  unpretentious and knowledgeable.

2.) Fast service. I have never had to wait more than 13 minutes to get my meal. I've visited Yuzu 4 times.

3.) The Sushi is scrumptious. I know you're really not supposed to do this, but I love hotate and I really love spicy hotate rolls. I sometimes will ask for this roll even if it's not on a menu. I feel bad about it, but sometimes the  palate wants what it wants and you know what? The Sushi chef at Yuzu graciously accomedates my palate. His spicy hotate hand rolls are delicious. I don't know what he does to his Sushi, but I can taste the difference and his Sushi is a cut above. One of the today's specials was Sayori (needlefish) and it was sublime.

4.) The atmosphere is inviting. It's cozy with soft lighting and illuminated Japanese woodcuts decorating the wall above the Sushi bar prep area.

My server on this visit was Kwon. I believe she's the proprietor.  We talked Sushi for a while. She said she can taste the difference between Sushi made by different chefs too. Kwon explained that the secret is in how each chef dresses, or marinates their fish. The Sushi chef at Yuzu is a 3rd generation Sushi chef which may account for his exceptional skill in his craft. Although they don't have it on the menu, their Sushi chef is certified to prepare fugu so you know he has skills.

I passed by this cute sushi place several times until one day, I was really craving sushi! love the decor of this place. It's also very clean. Service is quick and attentive. I really enjoyed the vegetable roll.

Very good. Good tasty sushi rolls. The wine was excellent and the service was amicable. The decor is nice and calming and the presentation of the meals was also appealing. Very friendly staff and good food, what more can u ask for.

Having been at various different sushi spots here in NYC and Boston, I have to say, even the basic California roll had a nice flavor and the black dragon roll was delicious.

I order a cucumber and rice wrap without sesame and seaweed

They told me that they cant make it anymore for me.   Some of the food prepared did not wear gloves.. be careful  They are working with raw fish

got takeout last night and really wasn't a good experience.

The sushi was a bit warm and not even fully cut into individual pieces - which I have never seen before.

The rolls themselves looked like they were just quickly thrown together. Too bad this is one of the only decent spots in this area for sushi :/

I ordered the Red Dragon Roll to go. The restaurant was empty but about 3 people came in for take out. The Red Dragon Roll was $17.96 for 8 rolls. It was good. I would go back but for a more cheaper option

Very good place for sushi in Harlem.  It is a bit pricey but everything is fresh and tastes good.  We had the beef bowl and sushi.  We came here for dinner on a Saturday and it was about half full.  The decor is simple and clean.  The sushi we had was the California roll and tempura sweet potato.  This is a solid choice for sushi!

I've never explored much with Sushi, but as of lately I've been wanting to give it more of a try. This day I came to Yuzu, I did just that. I tried things that I thought I wouldn't have liked and turned out loving it. This place has given me a new found love for Sushi. Our waitress was nice. The place is very clean. Overall I had a pleasant experience and I surely will be back. Highly recommended place.

I use to love this place - great sushi for the most part but things are changing.

Prices have increased, I'm sure trump has something to do with that (ok I'm just being a hater I know).....

I asked for extra ginger, never charged before now they do.  Not mad at a change policy but that's like when a company charges you for extra ketchup. Not a good look.

Also, not a huge deal but you leave there smelling like you were helping the chef fry up the tempura.

I will only go there if I have no other options given they are skimping and over charging on sushi essentials.
I took my girlfriend here since heard good things. The chef was wonderful and fun. Food was excellent. I enjoyed the time there.

Unfortunately revising my review because of an ongoing and repeated problem when ordering delivery and experience. While this sushi is good, they continually cancel my order. It says on their seamless place (and it attached photo) no delivery minimum. I placed an order tonight for 14 dollars (subtotal) and over 20 dollars (with delivery fee and tip) and they canceled by having seamless call me. I called them to ask what their not listed minimum was? 15 dollars. Not only do I consistently order but I live 2 blocks away. If they want to maintain a minimum I understand that, but post it so the site doesn't let people order, and don't sort change people for a dollar on your mistake.

I've had a lot of great sushi in NYC and it has all been mostly very expensive (I don't trust the sushi buffets tbh) but Yuzu had decent prices for the quality of sushi they served. It exceeded all expectations when I originally looked them up searching for dinner in Harlem. They even had an option forOmakase if you're feeling adventurous. I had the Red Dragon Roll (14 dollars ish)and the Avocado Eel Roll (7.50 I think). The rolls were delicious and the setting pleasant. Upscale to the other sushi places I've walked in and right out of in Harlem. My final advice to one looking for cheaper end sushi in Harlem is to never go to a restaurant for fish that doesn't look impeccably clean, and in turn, give Yuzu a chance.
My favorite rolls include spicy tuna, salmon avocado, and yellowtail scallion. Their sushi is always super fresh. Can really speak to their other items

Finally tried this spot! I did take out. Hostesses were very friendly, my order was made fairly fast, and the two sushi rolls were tasty. (They were a little stingy with the wasabi -- it was a packet, and the soy sauce)
It seems like a nice place to eat "in", there was even live music!

We had a good dinner at Yuzu last night. We enjoyed the hamachi kama (super tender and nicely grilled), the sushi set dinner, some kapa maki, hot tea, sake,  and wine. The waiter was friendly, and even asked the chef to include ikura in my sushi set (not usually included). The nigiri sushi was good (not the best cuts ever, but fresh and the rice was well cooked). Their green tea has a nice toasted rice scent and flavor. The atmosphere is welcoming and "neighborly," with couples and families who had clearly been there previously. They made us feel the same, even though we were visitors from out of town and not regulars.

I came here for a private event that provided frozen margaritas, wine and shareable apps. The spot has a cozy feel with cool African masks and art hanging on the walls. It seems to be a neighborhood spot with regulars and the service is pretty friendly. Our drinks were strong and the food came out hot and fresh. I only took away a star because the bathroom smelled pretty bad.

We came here on a Friday evening. Initially, there were 4 of us but we were expecting some additional family members to join us. The waiter was nice enough to allow us to sit at a larger table that would accommodate our total party. He was very nice and personable. He gave us some good menu suggestions and checked on us often. The food and drinks were spot on. Everything was great except for people walking past asking for money, asking to taste our food etc. Unfortunately, the restaurant can't manage people walking past, but it makes for an uncomfortable dining experience. Next time we go, we'll avoid the outdoor seating closer to the street or just dine indoors.

A very nice atmosphere, great food and well-made drinks (I had the frozen pina colada and the frozen margarita...both were so good but the margarita was my favorite if I had to pick one to order all night...$6 each for happy hour). Our server was wonderful and always came back to us with a smile. She even gave us suggestions when we were torn between which dish to order. My friend decided on one of the specials of the day. Crab cakes with spinach, wild rice and quinoa. She really enjoyed the crab cakes and told me to try some. They were delicious. She said she didn't really care for the spinach, wild rice and quinoa mix. She said the dish could've been seasoned better. She said she would get the crab cakes again but with a different side dish. I ordered the homemade nachos. It was a large, super filling portion and really good (although I would have rather it come with black beans instead of pinto beans). The nachos were fully loaded with grilled chicken, pinto beans, guacamole, sour cream, pico de gallo, cheddar and monterey jack cheese.

So many options to choose from here and we plan to return to try them. It's also worth mentioning that they have a daily Happy Hour until 8pm, a rarity these days considering most happy hours end at 6 or 7 pm.

I've been coming to Yatenga for years but haven't been back for the last two years I moved out of the city. Now that I'm back Yatenga was one of my first places I had to go. One of my first apartments was above Yatenga so I remember the delicious happy hour specials and truffle fries. As life goes things change and so did the fries but not the customer service.

My sister and I came here on a Wednesday right when they opened at 4pm. We still practice socially distancing as much as possible so we decided to sit outside in their heated patio. The tables are spaced out enough and the heaters definitely are needed as it gets cooler here in the city. Tom, the bartender was incredibly kind and shared their dinner specials.

We ordered the Madame Yatenga salad with added shrimp and salmon, Yatenga drink, and fries to start. Food was incredible as it was the first time but I do wish they had their old large truffle fries because they were better than the fries we got this time but were still delicious. We ended up staying for two hours talking to the other kind neighborhood folks and received invites for future events. Yatenga is one of my favorites and it continues to be.

Also we ended up switching ti their happy hour which is $5 house red and wine but they also have frozen pina colada's and margaritas.

We had the Shepherds pie and the mussels. Very rustic theme. Service staff was friendly and helpful. We had a late arrival to our party. It was no problem. No need for reservations on a Sunday evening.

Food was so good! Went to a retirement party and I felt bad for the staff. They were running all over the place and they still maintained service that was stellar. This is a place to check out. Not a crazy drink selection but the food makes up for that. Give it a try. I don't think you will be disappointed.

Stopped at this place on a Saturday night without a reservation. It was the two of us so we figured we'd chance it. Great call because we were seated as soon as we entered the building. We were greeted by the waiter who had on his mask. And was able to take a seat at almost anywhere in the restaurant. there was not too many other people there which was great for us. as soon as we sat down the waiter brought us water and gave us a menu. The other waiter came in and let us know what the specials while we ordered our drinks. I had originally ordered a prosecco but then when I took a second look at the menu I saw a cocktail called Montego Bay and I had to have it. Great call on my end! That drink was super delicious; so much so I had to have one more before I left the restaurant. For an appetizer the waiter suggested a shrimp appetizer. it was a shrimp with a reduction of white wine sauce with garlic and red pepper flakes and it came with toasted bread. It was really delicious we almost finished up all the sauce. The waiter provided the specials for the night which was a paella and a rack of lambs and that's exactly what we ordered. We did not regret it at all. Both dishes were absolutely delicious. The rack of lamb was cooked really well and the paella was delicious without being too overdone. I believe towards the end of our meal the chef had came out and asked us how it was and we had to give him his praises.

if you're in the area and looking for somewhere to eat, definitely stop by this place.  the ambiance was really interesting with a whole lot of statues which seem to be African statues all on the walls. Very retro artsy decor. The staff was great service was really well done. And again do not go without trying the Montego Bay cocktail. I may just come back just for that cocktail. Yes it was that good.
I love Yatenga! The chef gambas is my go to dish. I highly recommend for either drinks or food!

Came here for brunch with friends and I was not disappointed. The food tasted amazing and the drinks were strong and on point. The music was also really nice and made the experience even better. We didn't feel rushed by the staff which is also a major plus. I had the a la vodka with chicken but the burgers looked so good so I'm going back just for that

I ordered using UberEats. I pulled everything from the bag then started with the French Onion Soup which was absolutely tasty. The cheese, bread and onions were really a great start! The A La Vodka Penne was also good on it's own however the grilled chicken helped to set it off! I was sad that the cheesecake slice wasnt caramelized like I had been sold to believe on UberEats. But let me go taste it while you all figure out what you're going to order

This place is just a vibe. The food is rich and delicious and the drinks  are strong and delicious. Everything was reasonably priced and the staff is super attentive and sweet. Try the Mac and cheese and the French onion soup.
Food was very good. Had a shrimp dish that was very tasty and we also had macaroni and cheese.  Delicious as well. The drinks are great!  Only negative was the service.

Cute restaurant in Harlem! 

Breaking down the review as follows:

Ambiance: I love the ambiance of this place. The decor has a very nice African influence. Very warm and inviting!

Service: Our server was good. She was attentive and chill. Filled up our water very diligently and asked if we needed anything throughout the meal.

Food:

I had Shrimp Gambas and it was delish!!! Their large plates are just that... large so you could almost share unless you're really hungry!

Drinks: I had the lemon drop martini and it was very good.

I would recommend this place and could easily my go-to place in this neighborhood.
Love Yatenga they have the best drinks and the good is delicious.  Chef Sanchez makes everything DELICIOUS
If your ever in Harlem , you must stop and try everything . Food was delicious . Ambiance was great Customer service was amazing . I would differently coming back .

On my quest to keep exploring Harlem, hit up this place for brunch.

The spot has nice outdoor seating and interesting decor. The decor is not for everyone, but I liked it and found it interesting. They had regular tables inside and one large communal table. The communal table is annoying because the only way out on the side against the wall is for people to get up and let you out.

The food is regular brunch fare, didnt find anything special. We had some salmon eggs benedict and french toast.

The service is all over the place, extremely disorganized. We ordered coffee which ended up coming after the food and only after we asked for it 3 times. To pay at the end of our meal took about 10 min, just too slow.

If this place was a little more organized it would  e a great regular brunch spot.

The food was good.  The leg of lamb was flavorful and perfectly cooked.  We also had the mussels with frites.  The sauce was delicious!  The calamari was also yummy.  

The one gripe I have is that the crowd was super rowdy that night and the waitress dropped my fork onto my dress and stained it.  She did not really do much about it.  Wouldn't you generally comp a drink or a small appetizer or *something* for that blunder?  I thought it was a bit rude.  

Nevertheless, the food was good and the decor was innovative.
Yummy food and drinks. Great staff that is friendly and attentive. The place could use an upgrade though. However, I love it so much that I will continue to go because Black-owned

Been coming here for the past year and I like the place.  The menu is a little interesting but the food is good. I usually only order 1 thing off of the menu because of how it's set up ... I wish I could explain it better.  Any who I usually order the Mac and cheese  
But my absolute favorite thing about this place is the happy hour margaritas! They are cheap in pricing but very delicious 1 or 2 usually does the job for me lol
Food is amazing one of my favorite places they have great bartender by the name of tom you have to know him he is great the good is amazing French food

I did write that I'd be back right?  Well I went back to Yatenga, I believe LESS than a week than my last visit.

This time I ate and I had the Yatenga and it was as delicious as it looks.  It was cooked to perfection and not to mention, I was surprised at the fact that it had avocado on it which made it all the more better (because obviously I didn't read the description all the way through lol)

Tiffany, was once again, my bartender and she absolutely fantastic.  She makes some amazing drinks and her outgoing, fun, high energy vibe is WONDERFUL for being behind the bar.

Next time I go will most likely be on the weekend so I can take advantage of their Bottomless/Unlimited Brunch.
Ran into this place yesterday. Drinks were really good and the food was delicious. Service was eh but it wasn't bad.

Loved. The brunch options. Hubby
Was happy and we share all food- he had the steak and eggs for $19 I had Mac and cheese with mushrooms for $12. Mac and
Cheese gave us leftovers - love the spot and Ray was awesome! You will love it!

This black-owned Harlem eatery hit the spot like oh like whoa.  I did an impromptu drop in for dinner.  I was walking past and decided that the woman was hungry so I needed to get it taken care of like asap.  I ended up enjoying the French Onion soup, the Chef Special Gambas and the sweet tooth was the chocolate soufflé.  The soup was good but not amazing.  The Gambas was the all-start.  I loved, loved, loved the balance of this dish.  It was macaroni and cheese styled but it had shrimp and spinach and mushrooms.  I loved the balance of the meat and the veggies and the carbs.  Amazing and tasty as all get out.  I ate half and enjoyed the rest the next night.  I did have a drink but I cannot recall what it was.  The chocolate souflee was excellent! The entire meal was excellent from start to finish.  The food is a solid, unequivocal 5 stars.  I will say the service from my waitress was lacking from start to finish.  I had to flag her down for a seat even though she had made eye contact several times.  I get that you may be the only one but a simple verbal acknowledgement is welcomed.  I just felt like I had to flag her down for everything- to order, to get more water, the check, everything.  I wish she could have improved but she did not.  I cannot even say it was perfunctory.  I mean my food always came out hot and fresh but then again I believe that was the runner who was on it. All in all, the place is good food with good music and good drinks.  I definitely look forward to going back and trying more of the menu, whether breakfast or dinner in hopes that the service will push this to a 5 star overall rating. They are right next door to Shrine so I look forward to moseying over afterwards.  

Highly recommended.

Very nice restaurant in central Harlem.
Good French/african food.
The staff is friendly, good service.
The majority of the plates taste really good.
Their chocolat find his also amazing.
Nice spot for a date.
They're connected to the bar next door, Shrine, which has good live music every night.
I would recommend this place if you're in central Harlem

This review is coming a little late, but it is definitely deserved! I visited Yatenga for the first time when I booked it as the location for my job's staff thanksgiving dinner in November. Sivan, the owner, was so accommodating and prepared to deal with our last minute request - we needed a space, menu, and drink specials for 40 people within a 3 day notice! Sivan and the Yatenga staff pulled through, even letting us set up the space how we needed it. Our staff loved the food, drinks and ambiance. The restaurant manager Donat (sorry if that's misspelled!) was also so attentive, asking if everything was to our liking, offering to lower the volume for our staff's speeches, and overall being so friendly.

Thank you Sivan and the Yatenga staff for making our night special!! We will definitely be returning and forever recommending this restaurant .

I really hate to write this review but have to provide feedback. Yatenga used to be our favorite neighborhood place for drinks or food or both. We went all the time.  We have went twice since the chef has changed and it's gone drastically downhill.  Some of the best food items like the chicken milanese are off the menu, and others like the steak sandwich  have changed for the worse and lost their flavor. the french fries used to be to die for and perfectly cooked and now they are small cut and over cooked every time we order.  Some of the fancier menu items like the leg of lamb are very good, but we liked this place for it's more "everyday" food like the chicken milanese and even the enchiladas which were totally amazing and are now gone!

I understand menus are updated time to time, but the overall quality of food has gone way down and the prices have gone up.  The staff all seem depressed and the place has lost it's luster and I've overheard other regulars complaining about the menu changes as well.  With some adjustments I hope Yatenga can get it's groove back!

The Chef Special Gambas was delicious (mac n' cheese with mushrooms & spinach with shrimp on top). Enough to split between 2 people. My friend and I didn't order anything else, just drank ice water & we were very satisfied. Spent a total of $36 tax & tip included. Server was helpful, super friendly and attentive. Love the casual vibe and dim lighting. Also, just learned that they play live music next door every night.

Been here a couple of times.  This a great place!

They don't have a ton of beers on tap, but it is a interesting mix.

The food is really good.  The prices might seem a bit steep, but the portions are very generous.

The decor is fascinating.  I'm not sure how to describe it; a bit of African and European.

If you find yourself in Central Harlem -- and you should sometime -- this is a great place for brunch, lunch, dinner, or just drinks and apps.
I really enjoy the "Gambas" with shrimp. So delicious with the addition of spinach & mushrooms. Service was slow with only one server and dessert menu was limited  but cest la vie

They never disappoint. Have the Montego Bay cocktail, it will definitely take you there... LOL
I usually go there for brunch. I am a creature of habit and usually have the eggs Benedict. Most recently I had the croque monsieur. It was perfect. The toast was buttery with the perfect texture. It had a perfect layer of cheese. I had mine with salmon, but they also have it with turkey, or ham. The side of vegetables have the perfect amount of vinaigrette, and the home fries were done just right and served warm. I couldn't h been happier. They need to comp me a cocktail for this review....lol I kid. I kid.

Meh.

The good. The atmosphere is great, the open atmosphere with all the windows open is great. Our waitress was really nice.

Between my group we had the French onion soup - which was good. The burger and fries which were great, and the tuna tartar, which left a lot to be desired. The tuna just didn't taste like sushi grade tuna.

The ugly. The napkin on my table felt chunky. I opened it up to find someone's gum - staff didn't remove all the used napkins when turning over the table. There was also a gain on my cousins plate with his hamburger and fries. Left me weary.

Glad to see that Yatenga is still going strong in COVID times! They have changed their menu - I assume to accommodate mainly delivery orders and food availability better but the mainstays are still there - the Chef's Special Gambas, Steak Sandwich and the Salade Niçoise are as delicious as ever. Their take on French bistro cuisine is hearty, with a bit of spice that's made Yatenga a neighborhood staple for years.

Great atmosphere, good food, design is unique and very welcoming place. We ordered Mac and cheese which was off the hook, delicious! The fries are perfectly done, hot and fresh, not saggy or overlook. Also ordered enchiladas, were great however the combination with onions over salad and then the enchiladas not so great but flavor was amazing overall
Will definitely come back

I think I'm too old for this place.

Sunday night open mic jazz was inspiring, but the drink and food service lacked inspiration. Sorely.

No menu substitutions here. It's not that type of a place. Maybe (Absolutely) I'm also too fussy for this place.

Zero stars please, worst meal in 15 years, what a mess of a place.  First time I left less than 10% tip.  Took forever to get our order taken, when the food arrived one entree was totally wrong, everyone ate, the missed entree took over 20 minutes to come. When it did it was crap.  I hate to be so hard on this joint that I wanted to like, but nothing went right.

Burger undersized and overpriced, very pedestrian, fries greasy poorly prepared. Mac and Cheese was ok, nothing special though. When the steak came to the table it reminded me of a dish in a school cafeteria, such poor execution of a simple dish.

When we first sat down the table was sticky, should have walked away at that moment, when I asked the waitress to wipe it down please, she was offended and never came back to clean it.  I really wanted to like this place.  The bus boy finally wiped it down, it was his first day, coincidentally it was the chef's first day as well.  I'm done even though I could go on and on.  One good thing did happen though, I found parking just a few doors down, highlight of the evening.

So let me get this straight, I pay full price for substandard food and service, and you think that is ok, because your staff is new???? Are you serious?????

So my sister in law frequents this Resturant often and while my daughter was staying with her this week, they got the Gambas. My daughter is a foodie and a little eccentric in her taste like me and insisted on me trying it. Well let me say this, my taste buds were happy!! It's not a cheap dish ($25!) but I'd have to say worth it.

We got it to go, which wasn't too long of a wait. The ambiance was relatively eclectic. Nice art, wooden statues and the old school (although revivied) amber light bulbs gave the place a chill vibe. My daughter & her friend felt the place was empty compared to their two prior visits during the week where they say it was PACKED. It was 8pm on a Saturday. I would highly recommend the Gambas all in, (shrimp, ham, spinach? Etc) which is their version of adult MAc & cheese it won't disappoint!! I'll have to go back to try other menu items, but i know the wait staff recommend the fish. I'm a fan of whole fish stewed and they had one that smelled incredible. until next time... i'll fondly remember the Gambas...

First time at Yatenga even tho I've passed by it like a million times. No regrets! I was here on a Wednesday around 6pm..there was no wait and it was happy hour which is always a good idea. Got the half-chicken, roasted salmon, and Mac & cheese with ham + frozen margarita & frozen pina colada. All for about $70. Everything was really good, nothing to complain about. The ambiance is very relaxed and seems like a perfect after work spot/ date-night spot. All the service was really fast and I would deff come back! Good for groups, kids, etc.

Favorite place in Harlem!  We come for the delicious food, I always get the salmon which was so good last visit.  Big portion over tomato ratatouilles. My friend always orders the steak and fries, which she loves.  It's our go-to place.  The bartenders and the folks at the bar are super friendly and the vibe is always positive.  Waitress last night was very attentive and personable.  
Best part is that you can walk next door to hear live music which is always fun and a varied.

Cute little spot in Harlem with simple food. Assuming all their ingredients are fresh since the menu is limited for brunch lunch and dinner, so much so that they didn't have desert options for brunch time :( Love the venu and historical artifacts of African American history. It's a very special, warm and cozy spot. The waitress we had was kind of rude. Probably not deliberately but made it obvious she didn't want to interact, and hadn't checked up at my table frequently enough.
Went there for brunch yesterday, it was very nice. My eggs benedict were perfect ($14) and the place has a nice and relaxed atmosphere. I'll definitely go again for brunch. :)

Came here for brunch and it was wonderful, the service was great a little slow coming out of the kitchen.

The food is amazing, very well seasoned and fresh. I don't have a lot to say about specifics because I never found the bottom of my mimosa ;) but it was a great experience and if you a someone looking for a great place to do brunch, Yatenga is a MUST.
Love this spot. The service was amazing. Cocktails are delicious and different. We had a great meal and such a fun night!

Service ..
Terrible no way to welcome a person who's sitting by himself . Make me want to spend money!! Don't drop my food without silverware and then tell me 'it's coming. Then why not check if I need something ? I said I wanted the menu still but you waited 10 minutes to ask how was everything . You need training and the owners should be upset they lost money. I was hungry and wanted my usual, peppercorn steak and lamb shank Togo !
Not today I'm asking for the check and not even finishing this appetizer or beer. Goodbye Yatenga
Get your staff and your element together ! Don't depend on tourist to save you. We,that live here matter too.

Who would I thought this place is a gem? The front of the restaurant does it no justice. The food, service and ambiance was perfect. This place is very very chill. This is one of my favorite place in harlem.
Amazing brunch place and right next door to an even great place to catch drinks or a live performance

Ordered the Chicken Milanese. The grilled vegetables were good but the rest was meh.
The bathroom has issues. All the toilet paper is wet; the toilet itself doesn't stop running so it doesn't flush; the handle of the toilet is upside down and backwards. Sure restaurant bathrooms are high traffic and hard to maintain; old NYC pipes are half the battle. But seriously these are small but important fixes for the sake of hygiene and efficiency: invest in a basic toilet paper holder and a new toilet, ya'll. In other words small fixes to avoid nightmare scenarios on busy nights .... just sayin'...

I want to simplify this review badly but it's fucking impossible.

Everything here made me fall in love again, not only with food...but with people.

I had this place bookmarked quite some time and decided to treat my college friend, who lives close by, to dinner. I had to wait for her tardy ass though so I took my impatient ass to the bar.

Upon entry I didn't think anything special of the restaurant. It looked pretty ordinary from the outside and once I stepped inside I had the same reaction. It took about 10 seconds of standing there and having the waitress ask me "Will it be just you tonight?", to really soak in the beautiful African feat. French, decor. I told the waitress I'm waiting for someone but I'll head to the bar. A lot of regulars come here and honestly I love that about ANY restaurant because it shows loyalty. No matter what goes on outside the restaurant ppl. still love it so much they make sure they always come back, and that's a compliment within itself. I wanted to be 27 and not 21 so I did wine all night. I met an older gentleman who gave me grandfather vibes (my grandparents all left me before 21 and I was bestfriends with my granddad so I appreciated this so much) and we chatted quite some time. His name was Gerry and he treated me to a drink, and idk but I felt a connection (not a lover type connection you creeps). In the midst of waiting for my very late friend, I ordered calamari. I can't even go into details about the food here cause it is LITERALLY some amazing food boasting with flavors that touch not only your stomach but warms your got damn soul and I'm NOT exaggerating. Needless to say, the squid was perfectly seasoned and accompanied with the perfect dipping sauce I ate it all...even the spinach beneath it.

My friend finally arrived and we sat ourselves to a nice corner seat. Ordered the Mac and Cheese, the lamb, the goat, and the salmon because I was paying and the bitch thought I was Santa.

It's intimate and I had a wonderful server. She was Colombian and just as excited as we were to try out this place for our first time. The food came out quickly, which I was surprised to experience...seeming that the food was so good I thought it would take forever to get it.

Love! Everything about this place is LOVE! The food had love in its ingredients, the people had love in their soul, the restaurant itself had love in its foundation...everything about this place had LOVE in it and that's what made me fall in love. I don't visit Harlem often but each time I do I feel so beautifully and unapologetically BLACK. So happy to just be here. So authentic and so raw. I was told they own a bar next door that also serves as a lounge/dance club and I would love to try it.

If I didn't live in Brooklyn I'd be spreading my loyalty too. Luckily, I have enough friends within the area so I'll just pretend that I want to visit them often just so I can keep making it back to this spot! *inserts purple heart emoji here*

Oh! They have great Happy Hour specials too.

Went here for the first time on Sunday for brunch. It has a great atmosphere with many pieces of traditional African art, which I really loved. The food wasn't bad but definitely not amazing and the service was lackluster. They were very slow to take our order and bring our check. Overall I rate this restaurant three stars for average food and service. Though I did hear that drinks are good here. May be worth coming back for happy hour.

Very nice spot for date night! The waitress was amazing and attentive as she patiently waited for us (me) to finish the last bite of their yummy Mac-n-cheese! I had the scallops over purple potatoes, they were perfectly seasoned. My friend had the chicken which he devoured! The drinks were yummy... I'll definitely come back for brunch next time!

FRAUDS!!! FRAUDS FRAUDS!!!

3RD TIME I PAID $12 for A smoothie.
***** keep in mind , they are only deli open during Lockdown
  So, greedy,  they charge you for all the ingredients,  all the NECCESSARY ingredients on UBER EATS.

They just put water & the fruit in a blender. That's it. I was so mad, I wasted  my money

Pretty decent food but the portion was large enough for me to make two meals of it, which was great for the very affordable meal price. I ordered the shrimp egg foo young and the pieces were well seasoned and not overly crispy. They gave the sauce on the side which I appreciated so I could control the flavor and avoid making each omelette fritter soggy. Quick service as well!

Really a 2.5 star rating.

I ordered spare rib tips (with bbq sauce and hot sauce), fried rice, a shrimp egg roll, and selzter water. It came up to $15.60. I felt this was a bit overpriced, given the type of food I ordered but hey at least I'd get to try this place. (If you catch the lunch special though, I believe it would be just under $10. I came after the lunch special time--which ends at 3pm).

Service was fairly quick and the lady seemed nice who took my order.

Spare rib tips were tender but tasted like jerky meat (very salty and no flavor). Fried rice didn't really taste/remind me of the usual fried rice one would get at a Chinese food spot. Egg roll tasted like fish.

Was kind of disappointed as I rarely eat Chinese food, but when I do--I look forward to this treat. I don't feel it passed the flavor check. Hopefully this was just an "off" day for them.

I'd give this spot a 2.5 star rating.

food is just ok. nothing crazy. lo mein is pretty good. I just hate they close at 10. wish it was little later. yes the woman is loud but she's not mean I just think that's how she is. there's a man who does orders late night who's really nice. I LOVE THAT THEY ACCEPT CARD!.

Average Chinese takeout place near Mount Sinai. Lunch specials comes with soda. Yes, the lady that takes the order is loud so it seems like she is shouting all the time, but I don't think that she is doing it to be rude. There are three tables to eat the food at.

I had chicken lo mein which was ok. The chicken isn't as velvety as most Chinese take out restaurants. I find it weird that they have chicken chow mein on the menu but then proceeds to tell me that chow mein is vegetables only when I try to order it. I also had the same experience with a different Chinese takeout restaurant in the area. *shrugs*
Classic Chinese food restaurant, food was tasty and sauce for broccoli and chicken wasn't too overwhelming and oily. Fast delivery & lunch special comes with can of soda.
I luv this place but not the general tso chicken

Chinese restaurant located directly across from Mount Sinai Hospital. I've been coming here for about 15 years. They do a lot of take out because of the hospital so their ingredients are always fresh. Food is tasty and very good all around

If you're ready to make some questionable health decisions and potentially lose some of your hearing this is the place to go. When you walk inside it's honestly a pretty nasty restaurant and the main lady that works there always yells orders VERY loudly. But if you get past that then you have the opportunity to try their sesame chicken. Honestly I was very surprised by how flavorful this dish was and how the nuggets were actually good quality (not that gross filler you find in Panda Express orange chicken).

Great portion of chicken and rice, and you can get an extra soda at lunch I believe.

I have stopped going there recently to eat more healthily and because they got a C health rating, but honestly for the price and flavor, I still feel I can't go lower than a 4.
Comfort food on a budget from an old school Americanized Chinese food restaurant. The decor is a time capsule.
It is a hole in the wall.. but, it's quick.. great portion, inexpensive.. everything take away Chinese food... it's nothing fancy just straight forward food

First off, the disclaimer that there is not much in terms of food options around this neighborhood, but not terrible either!

This place might look kinda shabby ( and B rating) but honestly, if this place was so awful as some of the other reviews suggest, then why were there sooooooo many people taking up the tables and waiting for take-out? Not just when I am there, but also when I pass this place pretty much every day, I can see it always has business from the window.

For a 6$ dollar lunch deal with typical Chinese (Americanized) options, the food is really not all that bad and meets the needs of the Chinese take-out I have been craving on this rainy, humid day.

I don't understand all these bad reviews. This place has your typical Chinese take out food. Why people are expecting this to be some fancy, authentic Sichuan joint is beyond me.  The ingredients are fresh, the egg roll was actually hot and crispy. The hot and spicy chicken had a generous serving of chicken. Not just vegetables. At $8 for rice, chicken and an egg roll I think it's a good deal.

I would highly recommend for quick delicious take out around Sinai.

Hey I ordered General Tso's not General Montezuma's!

I must agree with my fellow Yelpers, not so good. Not the worst Chinese food I have ever eaten, but for NY City, it was bad. My meal was a lovely ballet of blazing hot out of the wok and ice cold salmonella breeding ground. 24 hours later and I am still not sick; feel like I dodged a digestive bullet. Where do Chinese restuarants get that weird chicken anyhow?

Sorry Yoan Ming, no stars for you.

It's been a while since I've visited.  Used to go once a week when I worked in that area.  Chicken Chowfun was one of my goto dishes and it's still pretty good.  It's not greasy or salty but has a nice subtle flavor.  I used to dump hot sauce all over it back in the day, but I ate it sans sauce this time and still hit the spot.   I would probably give that dish 4 stars but the restaurant gets a bit less.

This is the definition of a regular Chinese food spot from the ghetto. The lady in charge screams out every order even if the restaurant is silent. They are pretty fast and usual Chinese food flavors, nothing great.

As soon as I walked In there was a funky smell and it wasn't nice  I can't comment on the food i ordered a small white rice which I felt was overpriced at a dollar sixty because of the smell I wouldn't buy anything else

There are not too many affordable options in this part of the city, but Yoan Ming Garden is one of them. If you are looking for quick cheap decent Chinese food Yoan Ming is perfect. I have had the General Tso's chicken with brown rice after many late nights of studying.

The lady who takes your order comes off as abrasive and the place itself is a little bit dingy. But if you're hungry, looking for something quick and easy, Yoan Ming gets the job done!
Yoan Ming Garden's, Crispy Garlic Chicken With Vegetable Fried Rice With Garlic Sauce On The Rice Is My Favorite. Definitely Check Out When In The Neighborhood.
abousolutely far away from what Chinese food means, the mapo tofu is full of beans, mushroom, not even spicy. Pure American style food.

Now has a c rating. Such a shame because a great location. Gone there on two occasions (never with a c ratting) and it was fine. Sesame chicken and white rice which was fine, but better at other locations. Definitely need to get their cleanliness and hygiene in order and will probably be better

I ordered my delivery via seamless at 11:45am. At 1pm I called and lady said I should be receiving it "any minute now" At 1:20pm I called the 2nd time asking where it is. She tells me maybe another 20 minutes. How did it go from receiving it any minute to.... another 20 minutes, ....20 minutes later... ... how about I have work and gotta leave by 230pm? So I told her no one will be home and it needed to be cancelled. Long story short she refused to cancel and funniest part was that she kept saying it HASNT EVEN been AN HOUR since my order. does she know it's 120pm and I ordered AT 11:45am as it says on my seamless receipt????? Are you retarded?? I am bad at math but I ain't THAT bad. I had to call seamless to request a cancellation. Hoping that they cancel it cuz Screw this place.
Excellent General Tsos chicken for a great price. Lunch special has the best prices. Super fast order, usually takes less than 10 minutes to make everything. Highly recommend the lo mein
Very fresh and delicious (and fast) Chinese food. Also wonderful service and unbeatable prices. Highly recommended!

I went to high school a couple of blocks away from this place. Maybe that's why I love it so much. I'll start by saying, it is oily. Whatever you order, it's oily. And you're probably not gonna feel great after eating it. But man, is it good!

This place has the best hot and sour soup ever! I've yet to find any place that makes a hot and sour soup as flavorful as they make it here.

You can also get a styrofoam takeout container full of greasy, oily fries with watery ketchup for like $2. Yum!

I like the sweet and sour chicken as well. Their red dipping sauce is really flavorful, like their hot and sour soup.

And when you order something, the lady SCREAMS your order to the cooks in the back in Chinese. Somehow I feel like the loud scream translates into more flavor.

As far as Chinese takeout, this place is hands down my favorite.

I assume the other reviewers aren't from NYC. They think "gluten" is the devil, and Brooklyn is the Mecca to everything. Here's the deal: they're fast, they yell orders out and their food is GOOD. I have YET to find a better fast Chinese place in the city and I've been here 28 years. Then again, we all think ours is better, right? This place has been around forever, that's gotta stand for something, amirite?

This place is great for several reasons.

1.  They are fast, efficient and friendly.
2.  It may be one of the grubbiest little restaurants in New York, but it still manages to have an A health rating.  
4.  Dishes are made to order. (I ask for very little oil and they actually do it!)
5.  Portions are huge and the food is very inexpensive.  One $6 meal over there is easily two meals.
5.  Hot and sour soup is excellent.  The chicken rice soup broth has excellent flavor.
6.  Not the greatest in taste, but its fast food, what do you expect?  

For quick, cheap, Chinese takeout, Yoan Ming Garden certainly deserves 3 stars. 3 stars for taste, and 4 stars for convenience, efficiency and price.  It's pretty entertaining to watch the woman up front work the register during busy hours.  She's like some sort of super woman,  answering the phone, taking down orders, while simultaneously  packing up the delivery orders, dealing with the people picking up orders,  trying to place orders and at the same time, working the register and screaming orders back to the kitchen.  I'm not even sure how the cooks manage to keep up with everything, but the system that they have, weird as it may be seems to work!

Was overcharged right off the bat. Ordered a lunch special with an egg roll and soda. I was charged an extra $2. When I asked what the breakdown was, the cashier repeated my order rudely. At this point I was unwilling to stay

This place has decent Chinese food. Had the orange chicken once, and the curry chicken another time. The curry chicken was so weird, and was spiced oddly. The place is a hole in the wall, and the woman at the counter does indeed yell your order to the cooks behind her. This place is a good standby, especially with a $5.95 lunch special, but I've had far better Chinese food in NYC.

Yoan Ming is your down and dirty neighborhood takeout Chinese place. You know, the kind you go to if you're in a pinch or sick of everything else but is never your first option. The kind that makes you feel slightly sick by the time you finish your meal (versus the hungry a half hour later feeling from other Chinese places) It's also one of the few places in my neighborhood open until 11.

Consistency of food can range from okay to just plain gross, based on what you get, and when. As with many similar places a lot of the curries are made from the same basic recipe just mildly spiced differently or with different veggies, and are pretty tasteless. Things on the menu that are tolerable: General Tso's Chicken (pretty standard mix of dark and white meat, deep fried with a couple pieces of broccoli on the side), Chicken and Broccoli (we've all seen it, pretty hard to screw up), their fried rice and lo mein, Chicken or Beef Teriyaki (but it's a little salty), Spring rolls,  As I've learned, it's best to go in off-peak hours since they may actually make your order fresh and not en masse food they make and have sitting around during busier times. But if you go during peak lunch, you get a free soup or soda with your food, so there's that.

Servicewise, the middle-aged Chinese woman yells at you for your order and then screams it to the cooks in the back, and I wouldn't have it any other way. Thankfully, you have a full view of the kitchen behind the register so you know there's nothing odd going on with your food. The space is pretty tiny and shabby, and there are a few seats in the front, but it's primarily a takeout place. All said, Yoan Ming is tolerable in small, rare doses, and if you're a sleep-deprived grad student strapped for time (like yours truly), this does the job, albeit it does the job not too well.
Refused to give me a cup of water with my purchase because they want to sell you a bottle. Places that refuse to give you a cup of water with your meal shouldn't be taking up NYC storefront space.

It's good... It'll get ya by. Friendly staff and they're always quick about getting the food too you.

If you're in the neighborhood. It's the one you want!

Disgusting. Period.
There are other Chinese restaurants you can try but definitely not this one. This is one of the worst.

The food is good for the great prices, but WHY does the woman always SCREAM at me?! I'm the most polite customer anyone could ever wish for and I place my orders very efficiently, spoken clearly. But somehow, the woman who answers the phone is always mad at me. :(

If you're eating at Yoan Ming Garden, you're doing so out of necessity, not choice.  It's not a place that you choose to go; simply put, it's open late, and it's cheap.  If you're hungry, it will fill you up.  But that's about all it does.  

The food is your typical bad Chinese that you can find in thousands of restaurants across the country; chances are, they get their ingredients and preparations from a central supplier.  If you've eaten at one of these pseudo-chains, you know what type of food to expect.  Yoan Ming's menu, however, promises much more than is available.  On several occasions, I've tried to order items listed on the extensive take-out menu, only to be told that they don't make them.  Instead, the focus at Yoan Ming seems to be fried chicken with french fries, which is what you see the majority of customers ordering.  Maybe it's good, but why is a Chinese restaurant specializing in fried chicken?  For some reason, it makes more sense if they specialize in, you know, CHINESE FOOD.  Their Chinese food is wildly variable in quality.  Dishes come heartrendingly understocked with meat and laden with oil; the food is so greasy that you can actually see a standing layer of oil at the bottom of your dish.  And for the MSG intolerant, let's just say that walking by Yoan Ming should be enough to give you a headache.

The atmosphere is another contributor to my first one-star review.  The woman at the register has made an art of being unfriendly.  The restaurant itself feels dirty - the walls are stained and covered in very optimistic pictures of Yoan Ming's food.  The tables are messy, and everything seems cluttered and unclean.  I actually worry that eating here is a genuine health hazard - salmonella is a real possibility, and I wouldn't be surprised if someone reported getting E. coli from the food.  However, (shameless plug), if you do get sick, walk a block down the street to Mount Sinai for excellent care!

One star.  Again, you eat here out of necessity, not choice.  The food is greasy, uninspired, and routine, and the space itself is not conducive to anything but bacterial growth.  If you're getting Chinese for dinner, go somewhere else, but if you're craving some hot and sour soup at 10:30 PM, you know who has your fix.

The worst Chinese food ever!! I ordered sesame chicken with fried rice and broccoli 3 days ago and I got so sick! I was throwing up! I barely made it home to have everything coming out of both ends!!  I threw up the entire meal and I had the worst diarrhea ever! I will never eat here again.

This area is a relative wasteland of food.

I go here when I get out of work late and I'm too tired to cook + don't feel like eating pizza, subway, mediocre sandwiches etc. This place is strictly a take-out joint in my book, but there are a couple seats that I see people eating in from time to time. The food quality is probably slightly below your average hole-in-the-wall americanized chinese food establishment. There is an A rating outside the door so at least you know they are clean.

Extra star for everything being CHEAP.

Go only if you are craving greasy, unhealthy chinese food and you have no other options for other greasy, unhealthy chinese food.
Good deal, decent typical chinese food.

The only positive thing I can say about this joint is how amusing the sheer abrasiveness of the lady behind the counter can be. But that little freakshow can in no way make up for the utter mediocrity of their food, the mopped-dungeon level of hygiene on exhibit or the misleading bait and switch of their lunch "specials". Plus free indigestion!!!
Very good, fast and cheap food.  The staff is loud (you'll see) but friendly.  One of my favorite OES lunch spots.

This place is disgusting. I've been there 2-3 times and I should have made up my mind after the first time I ate from here. I ordered General Tso's chicken and truly wonder what this meat was... I honestly don't think it was chicken. It tasted old as did the veggies. Whenever i'm craving chinese I walk the extra mile to Chinatown East on 92nd and 3rd which tastes MUCH better. However, I've yet to find a chinese joint in Manhattan that tops my "holy grail" chinese restaurant in NJ.

If you ever have to be at Mt. Sinai or in that area of Central Park and are looking for lunch Yoan Ming Garden is a decent option for Chinese food.

Standard cuisine. You can eat your meal there or take it to go. Small sitting area.

I went to this restaurant today to purchase Chicken wings and French fries. I though ordering chicken wings and fries you cannot go wrong, the wings were fried very well however the chicken wings had NO taste and too much hair on them for my liking. That bother me because I paid $5.72 for my order. I could not eat the wings because all that hair on them. I think that they should do better because Mount Sinai hospital is across the street from them.

Greasy Chinese food, and not all that great. I have only ordered from here once and they were nice enough to randomly throw in a soda when I picked it up, but I probably won't be returning. Pick Up Stix on 91st and Lex is better in my opinion.

This place is good for lunch time but the food  has a lot of oil in it and the women behind the desk is the loudest women in the free world. Even though there is a lot of oil  in the food  the price isn't  bad. The only thing I do not like is that they charge you tax even if you pay with cash that's just un American
Soooooooo cheap! The food is great, the service is fast. Everything about this place is too good to be true BUT it's true. It's really true!!!!
Typical chinese fast food . Oily but it removes my hunger. A lot of rice and food for lunch special. I will come back if im in the area.

I wouldn't be surprised if the chicken is not actual chicken. It neither tastes like actual chicken nor does it look like it. This place is so bad, I wish I could give it a 0 star rating since this is the first time I've eaten bad chinese food. The place overprices you on something that probably takes 5 cents to make considering the quality of the meat and it charges taxes on food. While I may not be well-versed in tax laws over food, no other resturant/deli does this. What I got from was also considerably less than what I could've gotten if I had gone to another place. Other places usually provide the same sized meals for less and most of them provide a free drink of choice.
Good food, especially hot n sour soup made w meat. Usually very quick

Everything tasted weird. I ordered the most basic dish - beef and broccoli (only because they didn't have pan fried noodles...seriously though, HOW DO YOU NOT HAVE PAN FRIED NOODLES?!). The beef tasted old and the duck sauce and hot sauce was gross.  If you were to compare this place this to any decent restaurant in Chinatown or Flushing, this wouldnt even make the list. They're lucky it's practically the only one in the area and that it feeds hungry, on-the-go Mount Sinai employees. The one star is for the broccoli coated in sauce.

The woman running this place is ruuuuuuuuuuuude! I tried ordering take out a couple of weeks ago and all I asked her was what brown sauce has in it. I've never had brown sauce before and instead of taking a moment to explain this she just hung up on me. So I called back to ask her why she did that, and she abruptly said, "I don't have time to explain what brown sauce has in it, are you gonna order or not!" and I said yes I will be ordering. Then she said she would call me back and hung up on me again. So I was hung up on twice. Now at this point I would've just let it go and moved onto another place but I was determined to order from here because I previously good experience with them so I decided to give her one more chance. I called again and I told her that I was ready to place my order. I was ordering over $25 worth of food and so she took my order and my address and concluded the order. Then 5 minutes later she calls me back to tell me that they don't deliver to my address. At this point I was fed up and let it be and I moved on to another place. It's so disappointing when a place like this, with what I considered to be good food would carelessly fend off a customer in that way. It just makes no sense to me. I understand that people have off days and they can become overwhelmed with too many demanding and uptight customers but I was nice, polite and patient with her and she still behaved unwarrantedly rude. So for that I will never ever eat from there again and I give 1 star. Done.

looooooooove the michelada here. savoury, salty, spicy. just the right amount of mix to beer ratio that i'll likely be back for soon.

caprinhas were enjoyed by my group, and is actually the strongest drink on the happy hour menu.

margs taste like juice! although i warn the passion fruit marg is pretty skewed on the sour side.

great service on a quieter sunday evening. we were able to be table seated because it wasn't on a busy day.

super vibe. cool, upbeat, and just a great way to take the edge off the weekend.

An impromptu dinner search found us here. My group and I indulged in a bunch apps and couldn't find one we didn't like.

We tried their arepas, calamari, all tacos, shrimp ceviche and pinchos. If I had to pick the best it would be the arepas. They're executed really well.

It was also happy hour so we all had rounds of frozen margs, regular margs, caipirinhas and mojitos.

Fantastic...

The food is great drinks are good but upsetting when you come to dine for a party of 2 and want to have a drink and a app while you wait and they don't want to seat you. I would totally understand if the place was busy but they have plenty of open seating. Then when seated they take a long time to arrive to take your order after you been told the seating is only for 1hr and 30mins again totally fine if the place was packed but it's not. Really left a bad taste in my mouth.
Not only is it horrible when the "hostess" is trying to turn you down and then ends up. Ring the waitress your table when you then have to tell her that it will be a table for 1 just to get attended.

Horrible system

This place was made for the East Village, with their incredible happy hour specials, vaguely Latin American menu, and blaring loud music. Forget about trying to get a table here on a summer night, because the East Village crowd will beat you to it, and who can blame them. Unlike many of the other similar eateries along this stretch of Alphabet City, the food at Yuca Bar is actually quite strong.

Dining at Yuca Bar is more for the party than it is to enjoy a quiet meal among friends, but what a bonus it is to actually like the food. The namesake yuca fries are fresh and come with delicious sauces, but it was the yuca salmon that actually surprised me most. The salmon had a yuca crust and was served with veggies in a tomato chipotle sauce that was equal parts smoky and umami filled. I paired this with a delicious coconut mojito, which was on the sweeter side but gave me a nice buzz, which is all I cared for.

We were sat outside on a hot night but the cocktails and overhead fans kept us cool, and our server was really sweet and helpful with our order. I can see why Yuca Bar has been crowded on most nights since they opened almost two decades ago.

Pablo Kleber (Bar)
Pedrito (server)

Drinks were subpar/watered down but besides that ... They definitely stepped things up from my last post

That shrimp ceviche was flawless.

Cute Spanish restaurant in the east village. There's different nationalities all on one menu which is pretty different.
Food was good, but all the dishes needed a lil salt.
We started w the empanadas which were tasty. They came with 2 sauces. One  chimichurri and the other was a spicy sauce.
I ordered the steak which was okay. Was a little over cooked and needed salt. The rice was good. We also ordered the chipotle chicken dish which was flavorful.
The drinks were good we ordered the mule and the mojito. Restaurant wasn't too busy so the service was pretty good.

ADORABLE RESTAURANT. GREAT SERVICE . AMAZING FLAVORs

Was able to enjoy this little cute restaurant in New York!
The service was great and honestly the moment you walk in to when you leave. I wish I had a plus one for this meal because the options all looked wonderful.

I went with the churrasquino it was amazing! The flavor and tenderness of each bite was perfect!

The flan was a share size even though it looked tiny. Bold and just the right sweetness!

Thank you!
Ciao!

Yuca bar is a versatile restaurant that I believe turns into a club at night. How else would you explain the long lines of super young people on a Friday or Saturday night?

I've come twice unintentionally. The margaritas were good. The tacos were very average though.

I'm not sure if the Yuca bar is a place I'll go out of my way to get tacos but I can see myself stopping by for another drink and maybe trying something else on the menu.
I love this place! I love the pulled pork sandwich and the yuca fries. The staff is so nice and helpful. The music is always good and the place has a really fun vibe!

Came with a group of friends for dinner, we were seated immediately despite the restaurant being super packed and loud! The service was quick and attentive along with friendly. The food was okay, I didn't try anything other than the Cuban sandwich so I can speak for anything other than that! I've had better Cuban sandwiches, but it was still good. The drinks were watered down as well.
One thing I'd like to note was how one of my friends left their bookbag, we realized half an hour later and called them to ask if they've seen it. The waitress who took our orders put the bookbag to the side once she realized my friend Marco left it, we really appreciated that.

It really is just not that good.
The paella was very mid. Thr tacos were also mid. The octopus was among the worst I have had. It was not prepared well. Everything was just very normal and nothing good or bad ( other than the octopus).
I can not emphasize this enough: Do not order rhe octupos. It is flavorles. Tastes like fish. And the sauce tastes like straight up sugar. It is also extremely dry.

The tacos were very very standard. Do yourself a favor and get cheaper better tacos elsewhere.

The paella was probably the worst or the second worst Paella I have ever had. To be fair tho, I have really like pther Paellas that I have had before and this was not too bad. I just did not enjoy it as much. There was no crispy rice in the buttom. It was a mess and all the flscors kind of bleed into each other. It was also very watery.
