There was this lady right outside the kitchen who had her mask down the whole time while receiving the plates, passing them down to the waiters, packing up delivery orders, picking up the phone, touching surfaces, etc. No mask, no gloves, totally careless. Indoor dining has just restarted, and we were thrilled to come and support this restaurant. But it didn't feel right, we couldn't feel comfortable, explained it to the manager and we left before ordering. The situation is difficult enough, show some respect and care for your customers especially indoors !
Sorry Yelp, but this restaurant is not doing its best in Covid times

To be perfectly honest, I wish Greek restaurants would start to be a little bit more adventurous and that way things would be a lot more memorable. I'm struggling to even remember our meal here.

But my notes seem to think this place was pretty good so I'll go with it. Those very same notes say that the chicken was excellent and the Mousaka was really good. In terms of small plates, the octopus was very good (but pricey and small) and the zucchini croquettes may be the overall star.

What I do remember pretty well was the fig-based, Moscow "mule". That's one tasty drink. Otherwise it's up to you if you're going to trust my notes...

I went this past Saturday at 8:15PM. Restaurant was half empty, and my service was blazingly fast. I'm talking, receiving food 4 minutes after placing a large first order fast.

The fish itself was good. This is not a particularly high quality fish place, but  the hand rolls were adequately made and stuffed to the brim with fish, and giant slices of avocado. I was impressed. I placed a second order and got it just as fast the first.

Some fancier rolls have a $1 surcharge per roll, like my favorite, the Dragon Roll, which is the only large negative for them. I tried some of the other fancy rolls which are included and they were great.  

The bill was $33.70 after tax for one person, which is a steal for ayce anything, let alone sushi these days. I've been to other places that deliberately slow down delivery of food to limit you. I didn't see that here at all. I'd gladly come back again if I was in the area.

Back again!!!! I can't seem to stay away from this AYCE gem. I said it once, and I will say it again. This is by far the best deal in New York.

Every piece of sushi is super fresh and made to order. Just too bad i live not so close or would be here more often.

Relax setting and staff is super attentive. Always service with a smile.

Been coming here for 22 years. There have been some negative reviews and a few changes in ownership. Recently went on Tuesday at 6pm. Didn't get the rush like other reviews have stated. Also our favorite is the salmon skin hand rolls and it was loaded with salmon skin and not a lot of rice. Also had a lot of salmon and tuna tataki and the rice was not big (see photos) like others have experienced. I guess you can make your own judgement based on the pictures. We probably will go back on a Friday or Saturday so we will see if we get the rush when it's busy. Still our favorite AYCE sushi buffet for $30.

Came back 3 days later. Rice amount was still the same. If anything they should have put more rice based on the amount we ate. We are eaters. Service was a bit slower but it was Friday this time rather than Tuesday.

All you can eat at a Chinese run sushi place must have good value right?

The moment we walked in and saw tables and tables of large guys, we knew it was a bad choice but we got seated quickly by two overwhelmed waitresses. They were trying to serve 15 tables, a sushi bar and manage all the take out orders on a Friday night. Throughout the night, the lines of big guys were accumulating and they were trying to shoo existing customers away by keep coming back to ask if you are paying by cash or credit card (I'm still eating miss -  why would you keep asking me that?!)

Anyway, to the food. As expected, very limited choices. Have to pay up for anything semi decent. For 31$ a person, you do get all you can eat RICE. Every roll or sushi comes with reams of rice so they try to fill you up.  Picture attached on how creative they got.  They also deploy the wait them out strategy, the longer the customers wait for their 2nd order, the fuller they will get. We waited for 45 min until our 2nd plate of 15 pieces (for 3 ppl!). Were we full? No but we were full of disgust and left. A combination of being hurried (even though the order took 45 min, if they wanted us to leave to seat the next table, try serving it earlier) and 75% of customers salivating for the unlimited rice, we figured it's best we jet before we become the meal.

We opted for all you can eat, and their special rolls were very good. The restaurant is a casual dine in no need for reservations. My favorites were East and Rainbow roll. It was so so good. The rice is too sticky and too much, in my opinion. They charge for peices that are left and if you leave too much rice. They don't do all you can eat sashimi either. It fixes a quick itch for sushi. The service was quick and good. For the price, it isn't horrible. There's only a few appetizers that's available. The gyoza pork is my favorite. I feel like presentation could be better, too.

I'm giving them 5 stars to counteract the reviewers who gave them 1 star. Workers are friendly and efficient. I got the AYCE ($30.95 + tax + tip). I'm very phobic toward AYCE because usually AYCE gets a mega bad rap for either low quality and giving a lot of rice to fill people up fast. Basically coming in, you should expect that it's a more quantity vs quality. The typical qualities are in for an AYCE on a budget: no sashimi, heavy rice on the nigiri and sushi, too much vinegar in the sushi rice, rice temperature is overcooked as the rice is crumbly. Out of all the nigiri I would say the salmon was the best out of what I ordered compared to yellowtail and tuna.  It's not bad, but really is dependent on if you are looking for quality vs quantity. The only biggest issue is that people who eat here associate this with legit Japanese food and real Japanese food is 100 times way better due to quality and execution of the food.

THE WAITRESS WAS SPITTING UP 6 TIMES RIGHT NEXT TO OUR TABLE!!! EWWWWWWW.
!! DON'T COME HERE !!

The waitress was spitting up 6 times right next to our table while we were eating. It was gross. We stopped eating All You Can Eat and left the restaurant. Bad experience. Never comeback.

(We visited at 3pm on Wednesday.)

"all you can eat"
Bullshit.
Service was not good.
Ambiance is terrible dark, and the waiter who served us was talking really complicated to make us order food incorrectly!

The food used to be incredibly amazing here but the management is changed twice and all the sushi is still good. The portions are smaller, and when I got the salmon teriyaki, my mother and I returned it look like it was the right cut. It used to also be a wonderful sizzling hot tray with vegetables. Now I was just sort of a plate and very disappointing. It's sad because I've been going there for years. I may not go back there which is hard to say for a loyal customer. They should review their menu and staff. It was always a little hole in the wall but great food and fun people no more unless it changes again, but this summer.
Best deal for AYCE sushi. The seared tuna and salmon rolls are perfection. Seated quickly, service is quick and servers are always nice.

Amazing AYCE place! The quality of the fish is fantastic, worth the $30 pp in my opinion. The interior of the restaurant itself is small, but the orders come out quickly and the service is good! My favorite would have to be the eel, salmon, and sweet potato nigiri/rolls :)
The amount of rice they serve with each piece of fish for the all you can eat special is a joke. This place was good 10 years ago and have fallen off a cliff since.

Came across this place a few years ago after another AYCE establishment went strictly to a delivery option.

The restaurant has gone significantly downhill and is simply not worth the trouble.

Here are a few things to consider:

- the ambiance is horrendous; place looks like a high school cafeteria that is unkept.

- there is an obnoxious patron that frequents almost daily and completely ruins the vibe. He talks on his phone incredibly loud and is simply annoying lacking self awareness entirely.

- the price may seem like good value but it's gone up several times within the last two years and it's a known thing that they give more rice than fish so that "value" is a bit of a misnomer.

- the server Annie is outstanding; she may be dismissive but it's just because she deals with a lot from this unruly customer and the chefs who allegedly are divas.

I do not recommend the AYCE there was way too much rice.

The service was good. The staff was very attentive. At one point I overheard that a table nearby didn't get one of the rolls they had ordered and the waitress made sure to get it to them very quickly.

We went here strictly for the All You Can Eat sushi and it was meh...

Food: the quality was ok. The cuts of fish were generally thick and tasty. The downside is, there really isn't many options. At least, not as much as you would see at other all you can eat sushi restaurants. The hot foods are fried chicken wings, chicken karaage, spring rolls, and vegetable or pork gyoza. The rest are sushi or rolls. Even the sushi/roll options are a bit limited and just extended to the basics. The special rolls are $1 more each.

Service: the staff was friendly, greeting you in and out. They are very attentive and helpful with questions.

Vibe: the restaurant itself needs a lot of work. The tables are sticky, the room is dark and poorly lit, the curtains are frayed at the bottom and overall, it looks like it hasn't been renovated or updated in the past 10 years. Unfortunately, the restaurant is next to some pretty, newly renovated restaurants, so it sticks out in a bad way.

As far as all you can eat sushi restaurants go, I wouldn't come back. I think it might be the only one in the UES so locals won't have many options but I think it'd be worth it to take the 4/5/6 train down to the East Village for some good sushi.

All you Can Eat :
Fat Rice makes you full easily. You shouldn't Order many Sushi at once..... you get Full Right away. I recommend to order Hand rolls /miso soup as well.
You can Try Plum it's hard to get from Many Sushi restaurant!

Inside of the Restaurant is Dark and Old. I'm not sure many ppl will Like it.

Must try: Sushi Sashimi for 2!

Why: Solid sushi and sashimi for a great price! 4 piece sushi, 17 piece sashimi, and a California roll for $28. Salmon, Yellowtail and Eel were fresh and were my favorite. The Tuna and the Shrimp sushi were not as fresh, but good. The 6 piece California roll were pretty large and packed with avocado. I also added the Avocado Salad for $3 and appreciate the many slices of avocado. Yes, I love avocado! I would order both of these again because it was filling, delicious, and affordable.

Notes: I ordered takeout and they were very quick (less than 15 mins during lunch hours on a Sunday) to assemble my combo. I appreciate the presentation for the takeout order. They also have AYCE for only $26! Looking forward to coming back to dine in.
Very dark inside for no reason, there was no music playing the entire time & very MID room temperature sushi  Definitely not worth AYCE

This place was great! Average sushi - perfect if you're not a sushi snob. It's AYCE after all! Of course, you don't HAVE to opt for the all you can eat dining. They also have a regular menu. Service was very fast.

We both arrived at around 5:50 pm on a Saturday and there were maybe two other tables of people. By 6:30 pm the place was fully packed. If you're planning on a weekend dinner, maybe come slightly earlier or plan to wait. When we left, we saw groups of people waiting outside. They setup a little heated area for them.

No free bevs, mochi or sashimi at this place, like I've had at places in Nj, but oh well!

Good prices, really good sushi, comes really fast, great that most rolls have more meat than rice, also, a huge menu selection with a great 13$ lunch bento box, main issue is the service the chef is great but the waitress constant just walks around and never comes to your table, and she sometimes just ignores u, but she is kind and still a good server , overall a hidden gem in the upper east side

I remember coming here every week for years when I used to work around the corner.  It was always our fav AYCE sushi place for over 20 years. We haven't been back for over 2 years and we were hoping they are still just as good as we have always remember. Most are the same but a few things are even better now.  Improvements:  (1) fish portion on top of sushi is bigger now.  (2) the eel rolls have improved and they are really delicious  (3) service has improved
Disappointments: salmon tataki used to be more fatty and smoother
Overall: The sushi and rolls are amazing. We will be back regularly from now on as we were extremely happy.   We both stuffed our faces but I weighed myself the next day and I somehow lost weight!!! Still confused how this happened as I thought that I gained 5 lbs.
Fav cut rolls: spider roll ($2.50 extra), East roll, rainbow, Alaska rolls, and crab salad (hand rolls) .
Everything was super fresh and our orders came out really quick.

I love this restaurant. My boyfriend and I always go here and the service and food never disappoint. The staff is friendly and are quick to take our order. The all you can eat sushi deal is great quality. Their sweet potato roll is great. The salmon and spicy salmon and spicy tuna rolls are also a favorite.
The sushi is delicious! I've ordered takeout through Yelp several times and each time it's come within a half hour!! Highly recommend.

The only reason I can think of to explain Yuka's current 3.5 star rating is unreasonable expectations by some people.  I'm not Mr. Fancy Pants, but I have eaten at plenty of high-end sushi restaurants in NYC (Sushisay (RIP), Sushi Yasuda, Nobu (RIP), Next Door Nobu (RIP), Nobu 57... you get the idea), and the last time I checked Yuka was charging a fraction of those prices but delivering a lot better than a fraction of the quality.  So, ummm...  what's the problem?  One suggestion: temper your expectations and you will have a very enjoyable meal.
I have ordered from Yuka many times, and I've had the AYCE twice (soon to be more than twice).  Not only have I never had a problem with the food, but I would encourage any and all of you slobs out there like me to try the AYCE option.  I was expecting a scam but it was well worth the money.  The one piece of advice I would give you is to limit the amount of rolls you order (unless you really enjoy filling up on rice).  There is a perfectly reasonable amount of rice with the sushi pieces, but it is admittedly a little heavy on the rolls.  Also, if you are not a big eater perhaps you should go a la carte and call it a day.  If you are looking for quality sushi at a reasonable price then look no further.  I don't know any other place in Manhattan that will give you 30+ pieces of sushi for around $30.  
ProTip: if you go primetime on a Fri or Sat then expect to wait a lot longer and/or be rushed when you are eating.  Maybe don't go primetime and enjoy your meal?

Solid AYCE sushi! The sushi isn't as good as a la carte sushi places imo, but for $26 weekday dinner, it totally totally hits the spot. Didn't have to wait for a table of 2 on a Friday night, and the food came out very fast. Probably good to come with at least two people so you get to try more rolls.

Food was amazing and super fast especially for all you can eat sushi!  There are a few hot appetizers you can get included in the all you can eat sushi.  Only 4 stars because we basically didn't have a waiter.  It was fine and worth it but we it was difficult to even get a refill of water.  I would say totally worth it tho!

This is my first and likely only ever Yelp review. I have never felt compelled to post a Yelp review until now. I wish I could give 0 stars. The tuna tasted like spoiled butter. Truly rancid. I usually eat a lot at all you can eat sushi places, but I was so disgusted that I could not bring myself to order any more food. Terrible experience.

I am still recovering from the food poisoning I got on April 22, 2022 and it is two days later. I ordered the clam sushi and the octopus sushi which they don't sell too much of or maybe it was a supply chain problem. We have been going to this place for 2 decades and this never happened before. BTY it is a Japanese restaurant where everyone in Chinese. So long Yuka.

They've changed the ayce menu after many years of being away. But it's still a good selection now with hot appetizers along with sushi!! Recommend going with friends as it's hard to eat ayce by yourself. And it's way more fun to share food and company so enjoy!!!

Service: Great
Quantity: Good
Food: All you can eat sushi
Price: Around $34 after taxes

I haven't dined in since Covid. It has been a while. 2nd Ave upper East has changed a lot, many new restaurants, but many didn't survive through Covid. I am happy Yuka survived.

Yuka has been around for a long time, and they keep their quality. Sometimes rice can be a bit more, but most of the time they are good compared to others AYCE restaurants.
Fresh fish, clean and friendly service. I added $1 to get the Yuka hand roll (cucumber, salmon & salmon roe). Special rolls/hand rolls cost $1 more which is so worth it.

If you are a sushi eater with a big appetite, this is a great restaurant for you.
Take care my Yelp friends and stay safe!

WARNING!!!!
The worse service ever!
Waitress who was supposed to be hospitable and greeting  as everyone in the restaurant business was absolutely rude and not welcoming, she has completely ignored my request to order food.
Also it's place supposedly all you can eat and they don't want to give you extra if  they see you eating more .
Please stay away from this place.
Food is not even good neither!
The owner should fire this waitress immediately.
i will also promote this place to whole public eye on upper east side!
Ugh what a bad experience!
AVOID THIS PLACE!

The reviews at this place were overall great but occasionally had some bad ones sprinkled in so i was excited but cautious... but i really liked it!

A few of my friends and I did outdoor dining AYCE for dinner
outdoor seating area has a cover in case it rains. and the tables are about 6 feet apart.

Food: delicious! fish was fresh and tasty. my favorite was the Manhattan Roll (lots of diff pieces of fish in the roll). they spicy tuna / salmon was great too.   get the miso soup too.
Only issue was with the eel, which was kinda mushy (not sure how to describe the texture).   I wish they also had sashimi for AYCE but oh well.

Price: w/ tax and tip, came out to about $34 per person.

Service: quick and responsive but almost too quick. really felt like the waitress was trying to get us out asap.

Overall: recommend! if you want good sushi and a lot, check this place out.

Especially during covid times, only place I know to have this kind of price for AYCE sushi. The specialty rolls get me every time. Kira is my fave . Sake deal is hard to beat- 3$ with AYCE special. I'm glad to see they've adapted to covid regulations and have been inventive with the winter weather- nice tent with good heating! They're very attentive to you when there's a big line- hard workers, nice service & delicious sushi keeps us coming back!
We had to wait a bit for a table but we went during peak time on a Friday night. Worth the wait. AMAZING ALL YOU CAN EAT SUSHI!!

So disappointing!

Other than the attentive service, our AYCE sushi dinner was horrible. I hate to write this review around the pandemic, but I'm almost certain we were served raw menu items left over from a previous day (or before the pandemic a few months ago). The sushi was sour, left a horrible aftertaste and was left unfinished.

Ice cream was served towards the end of the meal, but was old and rock hard. Both my partner and I left with unruly, aching stomachs. Luckily, no food poisoning symptoms occured later in the evening.

I think it's safe to assume we came on the wrong day, but will NOT be giving Yuka a second chance.

For the best AYCE sushi in the city, try Kikoo Sushi near Columbia!

I never used to be a big sushi fan, but when my friend introduced me to this place, it was a stepping stone in converting me. Quality AYCE places tend to do that. I've dined here so often that I can claim Regular Reserve status. No Regular Preferred or basic Regular for me. The service is very friendly and the waiters never rush me, even close to closing time.

For nigiri, the salmon is my top choice. It's consistently fresh and tasty. The squid and surf clams are a bit more inconsistent, but I still always order them, along with eel and flying fish roe. I also love the crab salad hand roll. Yes, it's imitation crab meat and mayo, but it's deliciously addictive.

The process is simple: fill out your order sheet with the number of nigiri/rolls you want next to each option, then hand it to the waiter. If they forget something or you want to order more, just grab another sheet. I do 3-4 rounds on each visit because I don't want to order everything on the first round. I've learned that I can't let my stomach take control at AYCE places because I end up full of food I didn't want and regret I can't shake. I usually end with a round of just the salmon nigiri and crab salad hand roll.

Skip the gyoza, miso soup, and all those other subpar frills... they take up space that should be saved for yummy sushi.

This is undoubtedly the worst sushi I've ever had. Granted I'm visiting from out of town, the sushi was mediocre at best. I mentioned to my friend that the local grocery store serves better sushi for this price ($29.95 AYCE). Aesthetically speaking, preparation of the sushi was not appetizing at all. The fish tasted old/unfresh. They had a special posted that we requested. The waitress abruptly stated it was not available, and just left the special posted on the board. To top everything off, our waitress blew her nose and did not wash her hands. The restaurant itself was dark, gloomy, and not very welcoming. I would not recommend eating here. Overall grade D.

For the value of all you can eat, the ingredients are fair but the sushi is fugly. Yes. Fugly.
Still, dinner for around $30/person, cannot complain. :)

I ordered delivery from this place. The fish was not fresh and tasted off. It made my stomach hurt as well. I also found a short black hair in my sushi rice. I ended up throwing away my spicy tuna roll and rainbow roll.

I ordered all hand rolls and was there to witness Ali and her mom making a scene and having a Karen moment. Oh and they didn't even pay for what they ate either. All the hand rolls have thick cuts of fish stuffed inside and the normal amount of rice that all sushi places would usually make. Service have always been great everytime I would come in and they didn't let bad customers get in the way of giving other customers great service.

I am so disappointed with my delivery order, but not for quality.
1.  Seaweed salad.  They should have included a magnifying glass to find it.  In store quantity is fine.
2.  Asked for extra dressing.  Did they bother to read my request. NO!!!
3.  Asked for fresh mustard for goyza.   Not there.

Fish is always good.  Tis why i patronize them.  May have to rethink and find alternatives.
They have a great all you can eat.  Much too much rice.  And price goes up each week.  Sad, but i can see why.
Well, the food was standard sushi, but there was the issue of my first bite of a my roll tonight had a staple in it.

My favorite all you can eat sushi places in NYC. The price is beyond reasonable and the quality of fish is extraordinary. Highly recommend to anyone here. In fact, I take anyone who visits me in the city here.

One of the better deals you can get in NYC. The AYCE Sushi is $24.95/person pre-tax and tip. It comes with a selection of sushi, rolls, hand rolls, and appetizers. Beware that some of them have extra costs associated with them - luckily these are pretty clearly outlined on the order sheets you fill out.

I've seen more variety elsewhere, but the options for the price is worth it if you can find some favorites. For the sushi, I am a fan of the eel, tataki, octopus, and squid; the baby octopus and surf clam are also worth a try. I was disappointed with their regular salmon, however, the tataki is definitely the way to go! For the rolls, I am a fan of the East and New York; for more classic/basic rolls, I am a fan of the Rainbow and Alaska. I would steer clear of the salmon skin - extremely dry and scratchy.

You get to end your meal with a choice of ice cream - the best way to end anything AYCE! It comes in a small styrofoam cup with the options of chocolate, vanilla, strawberry, and coffee - but clearly chocolate is the way to go.

For AYCE we paid $70 including tips. The sushi was alright, but I do not taste very fresh. The waitress seemed preoccupied all the time. I felt like I had something stuck in my throat from the middle of dinner and onwards. I came home and found a bone lodged near my throat and had to get tweezers to pull it out. I wouldn't recommend coming here.

I rarely go to a place twice in NYC--heck 6+ times and counting.

I go just for their sushi buffet. It's great. I have friends from Jersey who go into the city and venture up to UES just for Yuka. For a a buffet for 24.95 in the city, it's a great deal for decent quality cut fish.

If you're from jersey and you have sushi palace...or from Boston with Yamato's...the menu assortment is definitely underwhelming but for the area their fish cuts and the price is worth the visit if you're craving AYCE.

I mostly get the nigiri (you know...get more fish and less rice...bang for your buck). Their appetizers and the fried chicken is good! Their yellowtail and salmon and tamago are my go-tos. My boyfriend likes their spicy crunchy tuna and the peanut roll (surprisingly good!).

Remember to ask for your complimentary ice cream cup.

Was looking for an all-you-can-eat sushi place in NYC and this came up so we decided to try it out. It was around $30 per person, which is a great price for AYCE. The sushi itself was really good-super fresh and tasty and it came out very fast. I was thoroughly pleased with it! There were many options on the AYCE menu but they were mostly typical sushi rolls-nothing fancy. There was the option to order special sushi rolls for $1 more. You can order as many rolls, hand rolls, or appetizers as you like from their AYCE menu but make sure you finish everything or they will charge you extra for the wasted food. The service was super! They were very nice and accommodating to our requests. My only problem with this place was it was not very clean-we decided to sit outside because the interior was stuffy, dark, and dirty. But the outside was not very clean either and the tables were uneven so I was scared the food would get knocked off anytime one of us moved. I wish they would put a little more effort into the appearance and decoration of the restaurant because it is a little off-putting when you first arrive. And I expect a little more cleanliness from a place that's going to service me raw fish!

I highly recommend this restaurant: the service is swift and attentive, the fish is fresh, and the price is very competitive.

This sushi joint in the Upper East Side offers great value: for 24.95$, you can order all you can eat sushi all day long. We were greeted and seated as soon as we set foot in the establishment. The AYCE option comes with miso soup and Hershey's ice cream.

Requesting what you want is as simple as filling out an order sheet with an array of handrolls, maki rolls, nigiri (ex: tuna, yellowtail, salmon, eel, mackerel, etc.), and hot items such as gyoza.

Everything we ordered came without much delay. The portions of fish are generous and there is not too much rice (unlike many other sushi joints).

Minus one star because we never received the miso soups we ordered as well as some gyoza. However, the abundance of sushi we ordered was satiating enough, so we ultimately decided not to remind the staff.

Overall, it was a great experience and we left extremely satisfied. It would be hard to find better value in NYC.

DISGUSTING
Worst sushi I ever had
The seafood soup also tastes like ocean water and the seafood was disgusting
I would have rather payed 5$ for McDonald's
Me and my family did all you can eat sushi and it is 36$ for each person
Please don't come to this place

I'm back yet again to review another mid low dinning experience. Yuka is one of those restaurants you want to go to once a month because of how much you stuff into your mouth. The AYCE option is a must because if you're like me, you like to eat without financial limits. Now let's get to the sushi. The nigiri is quality when it comes to fish to rice ratio. The fish is good for being in New York and truly taste like a fresh slab of fish. Being from San Diego i'm used to fish straight out of the ocean, but Yuka is up there with the big dogs. The rolls are very good and simple. What i've learned over my years of dinning is that it's not all about the flashy, stunt food. It's all about the basics and making sure what you're serving is top tier, and Yuka has this mastered. The Gyoza Is so good it makes me want to fly home to San Diego and slap my momma. I recommend Yuka. Peace out mofos

York Deli has become my go to on the Upper East Side. It's a neighborhood deli in every sense of the word.

Angel, the owner, is friendly and cheerful. He greets regulars with banter, jokes, and occasional nicknames. There's usually Spanish music or pop playing, and it always feels like a spontaneous party is dangerously close to breaking out, especially on Saturday mornings.

And the food is solid. I tend towards a BEC and always appreciate that it's made to order and with real eggs. Also--if you tip after receiving your breakfast order, Angel rings a bell and cheer. It's fun.

So many of the newer delis popping up feel corporate and anesthetized, but York Deli is a throwback. It's welcoming and warm and really makes this UES corner feel like a community.

All four of us had the same response to our meals: "it was OK". I asked for rye bread for my pastrami sandwich but just got some bland toast. Coleslaw and grilled cheese was meh. Hamburger the same. Next time I'll pay a little more for something much better.

I was in the mood for a BEC and figured that a local deli like this one would be the perfect place to go! York deli definitely serves a classic bacon egg and cheese sandwich on a roll; nothing fancy but you know exactly what you're getting when you order it. The only thing that could have improved was the bread; it was pretty bland tasting and the bread can sometimes make or break a sandwich. Other than that, I would come back to try a different sandwich at lunch time to see how it compares

Hello,
Worst food I ever ate! I had to throw it all away. Wasn't even good enough for my dog! A must to avoid place. They have some nerve passing that off as edible. Assholes!

I found myself walking thru the upper east side and decided to step inside the York deli. The guy behind the counter was very helpful and I ended getting a pastrami sandwich. The sandwich was great and a really good size. Prices are super reasonable. The menu here will satisfy anybody who is looking for a deli type breakfast or lunch.

Came here in January '16 and the cashier was very nasty to me and the people I was with. He falsely accused one of us of having a fake ID when trying to purchase alcohol and was incredibly disrespectful. I'm never coming back here again.

FIRST!

Right, but only because I'm reviewing my corner bodega, which I know is super-lame, but I totally dig this place.  I come here for three reasons:

1) Vitamin Water/Snapple White Teas
2) My-Friend-Will-Arrive-in-Ten-Minutes Beer
3) Entemann's Glazed Pop-Ems, my #1 source of saturated fat

These things are always fresh and always in stock.  The guy behind the counter remembers me now and kinda smiles at the fact that I'm always buying the same thing.

I also suspect he might think I'm a total man-whore, but that's neither here nor there.

But the REAL reason I'm writing this review is to confess that they had this cat that I hated, and one time when nobody was watching I scared it and threw a bag of chips at it and then it ran away from me when I was leaving.  It went out the door and around the corner, and I haven't seen it since.  So it's probably dead because of me.

UPDATE: The cat has returned!  I saw it walking around outside yesterday.  It even sorta walked up to me, so either it's forgiven me or it's gaining my trust as it plans its revenge.

They got rid of all their chip selection aside from deep river brand.  There are so many similar places to get a Turkey sandwich that the fact that I cannot pair said sandwich with doritos or fritos means that I will be finding a new bodega-deli.

I had high hopes based on the positive reviews & after paying nearly $10 for a reuben sandwich, but was disappointed how little meat was included (maybe 4 razor-thin slices of pastrami). The guys there were nice, but unlikely I'd go back.

I love this place. I live just around the corner and go here all the time. They have really good sandwiches with the standard Boar's Head. The breakfast sandwiches are also really good.

The guys who work here are awesome as well. They really try and get to know their customers. My only problem with it, is they charge extra for lettuce, tomato and mayo on the sandwiches. Come on guys!!!

Very sad this old time deli, with the old time deli aroma and sign is no more. The only thing remaining is the sign. Sad because the old guys always delivered what you ordered and knew how to make a sandwich. New guys cannot get a delivery order right, EVER. It's not rocket science. Its wrong EVERYTIME. Pretty sad because Super-Del is now closed who was opened 24 hours on the same block. Anyway eff this modern world, and get off my lawn.
I live around the corner and indulge on a York Deli sandwich a couple times a week. Quality sandwiches, friendly service and close to home. I would definitely recommend.

I go here to get York Deli Sandwich and coffees. I just went here for a Sausage and egg on a bagel and it was fantastic. The best one I've had in this area as of late. It's good every time. Make sure you hold your spot in the line because people come in and everyone tries to pay all at the same time. So, the guy who gets the paper wants to go ahead of the other guy who ordered a sandwich and then that's what happens. Prices are decent. If it was a little cheaper I'd go here every time.

My neighborhood go-to.

They have just about everything I need. Great egg sandwiches. They carry Boars Head cold cuts - (need I say more) and make a kick-ass turkey sandwich.

They are open until 4 or 4:30am...Staff is always friendly. There aren't many neighborhood establishments that have survived this long.

I feel way better purchasing small goods here than Duane Reade across the street.
Support the little guy!

$1.25 for delicious deli style coffee - YEAH!  
Definitely not burned like Starbucks.  Go for it!
Good small deli. It's right around my place so it's super convenient. They have some hot foods prepared but I mostly go for breakfast sandwiches. Definitely a thumbs up.

What do you want from what's pretty much a bodega?
When I want a simple egg white / ham / cheese, I come here.
My draft was three stars, but if that's the case, then why am I here all the time?
Four stars.
Nothing fancy, but I like it. Probably because it's one of the least pretentious places in the neighborhood.

I totally like York Deli better than the other "it's-so-similar-I-sometimes-forget-which-one-I'm-at" bodega that is two storefronts down.

And I'll be honest - it is because of two things, and two things only:
1. York plays better music.
2. The guys behind the counter don't creep me out quite as much.

Otherwise, this is your standard deli. Boar's Head meat sandwiches, $4 breakfast "specials", nasty slop buffet-type food, overpriced convenience-size staples (chips, candy, soda, bread, condiments, etc). They've also got your morning papers, your daily fruit and your muffins. And for the less-virtuous: cigarettes, beer and scratch tickets.

Get er' done.

Ordered: Toasted cinnamon raisin bagel with butter & an iced tea
Received: chewy cinnamon raisin bagel with cream cheese & THEY DO NOT SERVE ICED TEA?

So while I like stopping in here to get sodas and snacks when convenient, I wouldn't recommend stopping here in the morning for breakfast on the go...

Fast Delivery, good food and friendly personal service.

Cons: expensive. Would not include my free small coffee with my breakfast sandwich because "I didn't get meat on the sandwich" (I got an extra egg instead).
4.00 for an egg sandwich on a roll even by NYC standards, it should definitely have came with a free coffee, especial because I am a repeat customer.
I ended up agreeing to pay for the coffee, and he charged me a dollar for it.

Aside from this incident, this place is definitely a 4 star deli, and worth using for anyone in the area.

Great deli with hot entrees that you don't have to take from a shared buffet. (Those are disgusting.) I can get restaurant-quality roast chicken and mashed potatoes, and it doesn't cost restaurant prices. I can even get a large or small! Grab a couple beers, and I'm set for the night in less than 5 minutes.

And Victor's review? Yelp really needs a negative feedback option. Cheese is a premium item everywhere. Accusing them of stealing by "sneaking" charges onto the bill is a disgusting accusation, and he gives a neighborhood business an undeserved 1-star review.
Great prices, perfect spot to get breakfast delivered on a Saturday morning.  Decent beer selection as well.!

If there is one thing I hear New Yorkers are fond of- it is their local bodega - So it should come as no surprise I love everyone at York deli. All of the people who work there are super nice. Things to note: They have great iced coffee. I especially like their roasted potatoes which they have all of the time. Also, their sausage and peppers sandwiches are VERY yummy (no need to go to little Italy). But most notable are the chocolate chocolate chip muffins which are highly addictive- so purchase at your own risk. Other delis / restaurants in the area have muffins. However, york deli have the best one's by far. pick one up on your next trip.

This place has everything you need.  2 liter of soda at 2 AM, check.  Turkey and cheese on wheat at 4 AM, check.  A 40 of OE to start the morning, check.  That's the true definition of a convenience store.
Great chicken and rice.Ok prices.Pretty nice.Good food.They have a lot of good snacks.
Terrific corner deli.  The grilled chicken breast is terrific.  The sausage and pepper lunch special is solid.
I love York Deli! Whether it is 4pm or 4am it, it is always the same guy with the ponytail behind the counter.  The breakfast special platter is awesome. 100% guaranteed hangover cure.

Absolutely loved the mix fish rice bowl.  I am rather familiar with what should be expected from a dish like this, as my wife is Hawaiian and we eat more poke than most people. Furthermore, we lived in Japan and experienced the art of subtle flavor.  
Nevertheless, the dish checked off all the boxes: fresh fish, well cooked rice, and fresh vegetables, the fish was beautifully seasoned.  I will definitely be back.

A decent spot for a quick bite when I'm craving rice. Mostly rice bowls and bentos, though they seems to have a variety of menu items.

Pork Chop Rice Bowl was probably the best and will be my go-to going forward. I'm not a big poke eater, but I found the Salmon Rice Bowl to be a bit disappointing. The portion of fish was a bit small for the amount of rice I got and it seemed smaller than what I can see in other reviewers' photos.

I would avoid the Shrimp Tempura Rice Bowl. The shrimp tempura they use is a frozen product. I suppose there's nothing wrong with that, but it just felt like I was eating fried tempura batter with rice.

Basic ingredients. Filling. Nothing too special. Short-answering staff. They're not rude, just to the point.

The mixed fish rice bowl with brown rice was good but it lacked spice or real flavor. All good ingredients but nothing out of this world. Also a little expensive for such an underground thing.

This poke place is located in the shops at the Columbus circle station. It was open later than a lot of other restaurants which was nice. I got the mix fish rice bowl with sushi rice which was very yummy. The fish was fresh and the sushi rice was seasoned really well and was sweet with the vinegar.

It was pretty filling and did the job I needed it to do! The food came out really quickly. There's seating inside as well. $15 for the bowl.

Solid!

I can't tell if they are a Taiwanese place or a sushi place. I do not know about the poke.

But the Crispy Fried Chicken over rice is really tasty. Freshly made, crispy, dark meat, not too heavily battered. Served with rice with a small amount of pickled veg on top, with half a hard boiled egg...takes me back to my Filipino-Chinese childhood.

Would go back in a heartbeat.

P.S. I heard a man ordering Lu Rou Fan in Mandarin so I suspect they're Taiwanese not Japanese, and if the Lu Rou Fan is good enough for the Chinese customer then it's good enough for me!

Nothing special...no specific taste, actually no taste at all for $16.  I could have made it with store bought chicken stock and a basic noodle pack under $5.  $2 instant ramen would taste better. Noodle seemed undercooked, tasted like flour dough.

This place is pretty simple, some sushi (didn't try it) and some bento boxes. I didn't go in expecting much, but it was honestly pretty good. It's in the underground market strip near the south end and looks a little bit run down but for the quality of the food and the price, it's a steal.
I got the fried chicken over rice and I'd say it was solid. Kinda crispy, with a sweetish, soy saucish, sauce on it. Over pickled mustard greens and half a tea egg. Nothing crazy special but for a quick meal I was impressed and it hit the spot.

Keepin it real out here near K Town
Place is located in a convenient location, easy to get to for a quick bite. The darker popcorn chicken color scared me a little not going to lie, but the taste is still decent. Takoyaki balls were packaged so nicely (in to go box), looked like cheap fish balls but the taste is pretty decent.
Probably won't visit any time soon again

The Pork Chop Bento Box was a delicious assortment of food, and the miso soup was an amazing compliment to the meal that really hit the spot. The staff here is also very kind and helpful. They have a variety of Asian drinks on the side that you can choose from. It was great that there was space to sit and eat inside as the space in the Turnstyle Underground was a bit crowded.
Careful ordering through grubhub or any other online service. They mess up your order ridiculously and don't even apologize or offer a refund...

Yong Kang Street was a pretty simple experience overall.

Ordering my food was quick and easy. The restaurant is small but very attractive and there were a good number of seats to accommodate patrons. They also had some interesting beverage choices available, but I stuck with the conventional Coca Cola. I ordered a white meat chicken rice bowl which came up to $17.40 with the drink and tax, which I feel is a decent price for the amount of food that's included in the bowl.

I'm not exactly familiar with every ingredient included in the bowl, but as a whole it has its distinct features. The chicken was a bit mundane: nothing wild about its seasonings or texture, but it certainly served its purpose in the bowl. The various greens brought a variety of different sensations to compliment the meat, but I feel the soy sauce(?) was a bit much for the bowl. The sauce made the avocado slices a bit soggy. A smaller portion of sauce may have changed the eating experience overall. However, the rice served as the highlight of the meal: it was as soft as rice is meant to be and the sesame seeds included were a very nice detail to the meal. The texture as well as the background flavor supported the meal for sure.

Overall, I'd recommend eating here since they've got the principles down but maybe try a different rice bowl.

I know this is microwave fast food but it's still so healthy and tasty! My favorite one is the eel rice bowl with delicious eel meat white rice, Japanese egg omelet, seaweed salad, and two pieces of pickles. It's simple but the most authentic Asian flavor.
Hidden below street level in train station. Good rice bowl, quick, clean, poke fresh, good assortment of drinks.

Just moved to this area so hopped on Yelp to find our new go-to Chinese spot. I ordered the General Tao Chicken for delivery last night and was pleasantly surprised.

My boyfriend thought the chicken was too chewy but I enjoyed it. Wish they gave more broccoli instead of a side of rice but overall was a nice average meal :-)

Good, quick and friendly service (gentleman at counter was efficient and friendly)
Cold weirdly flavored food.
I had the chicken teriyaki bento box- I couldn't get myself to finish it. I hate wasting food, (and so does my student income) but it tasted off in a way I didn't want to risk.
The chicken was plain, cold and dry- it tasted like they peeled the white meat off of a rotisserie chicken and drizzled teriyaki sauce on top.
I requested vegetarian gyoza instead of pork, they were nice enough to accommodate my request. The vegetarian gyoza tasted like it was filled with an indian, spicy chick pea curry  - very unexpectedly.
The miso soup was delicious.
The salad the bento box came with was just lettuce and spicy mayo- kind of gross- but the wakame (seaweed salad) on top was very yummy and fresh.
California roll was mediocre at best.

I really wanted to like this place, but it really felt like a waste of $$ and left me still hungry
bland noodles, floppy fried pork, broth tastes like sweat. fine enough service, but not worth it

delicious food and fair prices.

free miso soup included.

fun to people watch people walk by in the underground market

recommended by me!

The Motto of this place is "Positive Eating", and that's exactly what it is. This poke bowl truly lifted up my spirits on the cold rainy day Tuesday was. I got the spicy tuna poke bowl and it was truly delicious! Everything was fresh and made to perfection. The only thing I will say I wasn't a fan of was their poke sauce, it didn't do anything for me but the rest was so good. The customer service was great, the man and woman who worked there were very friendly. Portions were generous enough that this literally kept me full for hours. You will take a nap after eating this, and it's okay because it's for a good cause.

I think this new place is ok. I tried their Taiwanese noodles and some dumplings. Everything was a bit salty for me and I was very thirsty after eating everything. The beef noodle soup was very mediocre so I'll probably try something else next time. Their dumplings are pretty decent so I would probably order them again. The service was very fast and all the food was done in less than 10 mins! Very convenient location.

Second time down the turnstyle food market court (before ballet at Lincoln Center). This place was pretty decent for a quick poke bowl. And I do mean quick. Took literally one minute! They have everything ready to prepare fresh which was nice. I'd check it out again in a pinch if I'm that way again.

I ordered a dish of Roasted Duck and Pork over rice. I then watched as the cashier/chef took a pre-arranged bowl out of a fridge and put it into a microwave (!). My jaw dropped. I was being served leftovers. Oh, the Duck they gave me was completely inedible! It was all just bones! Stay away from this place!

Yong Kang Street offers poke bowls for the MTA traveler passing through Columbus Circle.

The area is clean, colorful and well lit. We shared a poke bowl before going to Lincoln Center Theatre. The cashier was cordial and cook/chef was fast. I liked the vinegar sushi rice. The bowl was filling with crunchy edamame, seaweed, firm avocado, a teeny bit of salmon roe and handful of tuna chunks. Some tuna was sinewy or too soft but others were firm. I was thankful that it was not overrun with mayo sauces.

I just wish there was more tuna and more tuna roe, but this was the lowest priced poke bowl ($10.99). It was filling and tasted decent.

I would recommend if you are running through or don't want to eat at Whole Food's hot food bar.

An Asian fast food business utterly overpriced that sits inside MTA's Columbus Circle 59th Street subway station mezzanine level inside a underground food market called Turnstyle.  There are many options for poke bowls.  Customer service appears non-enthusiastic but robotic stolid.  Ordering line moves moderately.  When glancing another customer's order fulfilled when pickup the poke bowls appears small comprising of small and limited toppings or additives.  It does not entice me to give it the o' college try missing both quantity and quality factors.

I opt for one glass bottle ginger ale drink $2.99 which enable me to re-hydrate during the day.

I have been eyeing this place for quite some time now. When they first opened I got a chance to try a sample of their sushi and remembered that it was fresh so I really wanted to try their pokē bowls. I came very close to trying it twice but changed my mind each time after seeing the price and items.

I finally decided to stop by for a quick bite after work today since I wasn't going to have a chance to eat until 11pm, but only had 20 minutes to eat.

I stopped by the place around 5:45pm ordered a mix fish bowl which the workers started to make right away! The food was ready by the time I signed my credit card receipt and I was able to eat it everything and leave before 6pm! ( I ate quickly but also enjoyed myself).

The pokē bowls were not as small as they looked to my surprise. I think the diameter of the bowl really had me fooled.

The mix fish pokē bowl contained a generous portion of salmon, tuna, and yellowtail mixed with avocados, edamame, masago, and a mild spicy sauce that was balanced out by some crunchy cucumbers that brightened up the flavored.
The shrimp dumplings were also authentic to what it was suppose to taste like as well. The total came out to be around 20 dollars.

Overall I enjoyed coming here. I recommend this place when you are craving quality sushi without having to tip at a restaurant or just want to satisfy a sushi craving quickly!  

** bit off topic but worth mentioning: while looking up the place on Yelp I realize the name of the shop Yong Kang street is actually a street name in Taiwan that (my mother grew up living on is famous for having good food and lots of restaurants.

The roasted duck bowl was pretty good which is why I'm giving two stars. I'm taking off three stars for rude customer service. I showed my COVID vaccine proof to the woman working at the cash register,  so she allowed me to eat inside the restaurant. After I finished eating, I looked around for a trash can inside the restaurant, and didn't find one, so I decided to place the empty food bowl on the metal shelf to the left of the cash register which I did and then began to walk away. Suddenly, the guy who was preparing sushi started to yell at me saying that I should take the food bowl outside and throw it away there. The woman working the register said the same thing in a similarly gruff, accusatory tone and demeanor as if I knew I was doing something wrong and they were calling me out for it. I find the customer service treatment I received there to be totally unacceptable. I understand food service is hard and COVID times can make things especially  tense, but that is no excuse to deliberately try to embarrass me in front of other customers. I will not return here to eat again.

This is a great gem hidden in the underground market in 58 street station.

I came here with a family friend after apartment hunting (god lord) on the upper east and west side and ended up discovering it by accident (in an attempt to find the station). And what a pleasant surprise this cozy place is. It's a grab and go spot with a few small tables.

In terms of food, there is no shortage of places. I ended up ordering the eel bento box and wow! It came with rice and eel (the main section), dumplings, salad (which I switched out for more dumplings) California roll sushi and a miso soup. It cost $13 but was incredibly filling and a good quantity for the amount. My friend ended up ordering the special (duck bowl) which came with duck, rice, Lima beans, and some pickled greens. This was the perfect resting munch after a long day.

This place is located underground in a subway system. Although our GPS said we were right on top of it, we couldn't see it until we filtered through a few yelp reviews.

A lot of people rave about their Poke Bowls, but I don't get it. There isn't a lot of Poke in the bowl, in fact I was disappointed at how little you got. Also, the flavor isn't there, and I don't know if it's because we got the Spicy Tuna Poke Bowl and not one with more flavor like Shouyu? I don't know, I felt like I spent too much for something that wasn't cold and bland.

The people are really nice though and were patient enough with our questions, so I gave a one star for that.

Decided to try this place because I was hungry and remembered seeing sushi burritos on the menu. When I entered, I realized it was only Poke Bowls. I still decided to order something since I was starving and already there. I ordered the Mixed fish poke bowl with brown rice ($11.97 - the most appetizing looking one in the menu). When I got the bowl, not only did it not look appetizing but it was small and barely any fish (mostly cucumber slices and edamames mixed in). As for the taste, the fish was chewy and bland. I couldn't finish my bowl and I left disappointed and hungry. +2stars for the fast service.

I was really impressed with this place. Fast casual and so good! They invited me to eat here and I was hoping the food would be good because I dislike writing bad reviews, and thank goodness it was ! I started off with milk tea boba and let me just say, I'd rate this 10/10 probably my favorite boba in the city thus far--and yes I've had Boba Guys, and yes I'd rate Yong Kang's over BG. I ordered the Taiwanese style beef noodle soup and it was definitely comparable to Momofuku Noodle Bar. Honestly I am really really impressed with the whole place. The service was great, it's a perfect lunch/quick dinner spot, and it's clean! It's always so refreshing to eat at a new restaurant and have them hit all the nails on the head!

Best place for authentic Taiwanese food. This small little place uses not regular rice but sushi rice with stew crushed meat! It was delicious!  They are going through a hard time with this pandemic. The owner said huge loss with the traffic and income! I highly recommend people do pay a visit and help them drive traffic. They have small table for sit in and take out!

Terrible. Roasted deck and barbecue pork.
Hardly Nothing but bones anD fat. Very very very disappointing and all from the deep fryer. Barely any vegetable almost all just rice.
Not fit for human consumption
Yak.

My friends and I truly love Yong Kang Street. It was a remarkable experience. Eel Bento Box was really fantastic, I have tried couple of things here and Eel Bento Box is my favorite without a doubt. Crew is very helpful and can help you with anything. Yong Kang Street - I'll be back, i hope sooner than later.

Such a wonderful cute little Japanese spot! I got the chicken teriyaki bento box. It comes with rice, soup, gyoza, 3 pc California roll, regular salad topped with seaweed salad all for $13.99. A steal. Everything was sooo delicious, I MUST point out that their teriyaki sauce is absolutely amazing and different from most. Please try it! SO GOOD. I also got a Japanese drink that I had trouble opening and the lady behind the counter opened it for me :) really nice people and they really care about getting everything right and making sure your experience is more than wonderful. Coming back here many times again.

Awful and embarrassing. Should be zero stars.

Food: ordered teriyaki bento box. $15 with tax. Awful. Teriyaki sauce is bad, beef is fine, the rice they served was sushi rice and didn't warn of that. Flavors don't match at all. Gyoza are an embarrassment and ingredients are wrong; they are not Asian in any way as they had a spinach skin and contents inside were different vegetables. California rolls were even bad--too much rice, only imitation crab and tiny sliver of cucumber. No balance of ingredients.

I went to Yongkang street last Sunday when I around Central Park. The food was surprisingly delicious for such a small food stall. I had an chicken poke bowl and my friend ordered the eel bento box. Both of them were very tasty and fresh.

Delicious food and tbh they know me well by now. I rave about their sushi to anyone who will listen and for good reason!
I am also a bit of a picky eater and they listen to my special requests every time without getting frustrated or making me feel bad. Ingredients are always fresh and service is quick and to the point- which is great when you're on break and have to get back.
HIGHLY recommend!

I got the fish mix rice bowl (half salmon, half tuna), and though all of the ingredients tasted fresh, it was lacking in flavor. I doused mine in soy sauce, which definitely helped. The portion is tiny for the price ($11.97), but I guess that's expected with poké bowls. The service was rushed even though there was hardly anyone there at 1:30pm on a Wednesday. All in all, alright, but I'd prefer to go somewhere where I can get more bang for my buck!

This cute restaurant is apart of the great Columbus Circle food market (underground, apart of the subway station) and while this place may seem outshone (at first) by the other dozen or so shops, it's definitely worth your time to stop by!

First, the staff was so friendly to my friend and I; she explained to us what Poke bowls were and offered great recommendations based on what we did and did not like. I got the Spicy Tuna poke bowl and my friend got the Salmon poke bowl -- both were $10.99 and delicious! It's RAW meat, though, so if that's not your style, you should probably order something else. I also think $10.99 is a bit overpriced for the amount of food you get, but this is New York City, I suppose.

Personally, I loved the comic book wallpaper, which turned this place from a kind of boring little restaurant into a cute, trendy spot to eat. It's the perfect backdrop to any artsy instagram photos, too, if that's your kinda thing. :)

It was a good experience and I would maybe come here again (but only after I check out all the other great places to eat at this underground market).

Staff/Service: 5 stars
Food quality: 4 stars
Ambiance: 3.5 stars

The restaurant is inside the subway station of Columbus Circle,  not beside the street. The food is delicious and fresh,especially suitable for my chinese stomach. Every dish that I ordered is large amount.I will go there again.

Poke bowls are decent portions and the sushi is also fresh- service is very friendly and the place is very clean.

Would return for the poke bowls!

Only drawback is that they don't have the myriad sauces or extras found at pokeworks- ie crispy lotus root or garlic flakes but still good!

I had their white meat chicken rice bowl and it was delish! ESP with the soy sauce they give. I got the meal for a dollar on the ritual app but it's actually 11.99+ tax which I think is way too much for the portion you get. I don't know if I'd spend that much but honestly the meal is good so maybe one day.

This review is just based off of that one meal***
I come here at least once a month after work and sometimes we order their food on grub hub to the office ... Fresh, clean and delicious!!!! I love this place and you will too!
My friend make an order for delivery today,  never ever order from here again! Not fresh chicken , no taste! I order the teriyaki chicken bento box! The chicken was hard ! Ommgggg so disappointed ！

Super yummy and a good range of options!! If you have gluten issues, you can ask for gluten free soy sauce, and they can make your poke bowl without the special sauce or eel sauce, which they say has gluten ingredients.

They're also fast paced, which I like. Try to have your order and any questions ready before you get to the front of the line. Very New York
Amazing restaurant  the food is delicious and the employees are very friendly . Eva was berry helpful with the menu.

Yong Kang is a Asian spot in the turn style. I had the pork chop bowl and it was actually decent tasting. However it is quite pricey for what you get and their are much better options elsewhere in the city.

I was going to the 1 train to be surprised by the underground mini mall plaza before getting to the MTA. That being stated, I saw this place and decided to try the Spicy Tuna Bowl. The selections and mix was solid (not too overbearing on sauce and the food was fresh). That being stated, it is definitely not a place to go to if you want to be full, or if you want a solid amount of fish in it (felt that it needed a little bit more fish). There is some seating in the place, and you can take the food to-go if needed.

I found about Yong Kang Street through MealPal. I picked up a Shrimp Tempura rice bowl for dinner. The dish came wit 3 shrimp tempuras, edamame, seaweed salad, cucumber and avocados. OMG, it was the most delicious shrimp tempura I've ever had!!! The batter is incredibly light and flaky. The shrimp was extremely fresh and tender. Everything just melts in your mouth. The spicy mayo and teriyaki on top added so much flavor in the dish! I highly recommend eating there so the batter won't go soggy.  Definitely will come back again!!!
Excellente food portion, great ingredients and cool theme. Its a nice place to eat when you are near it. I do not give it 5 stat because its missing that wow factor you rarely find.

My family and I enjoyed a wonderful meal. Our server was exceptional. He accommodates our every need and made excellent suggestions on meals to try. We all agreed it was by far the best  meal we've eaten.

Nothing special, but fine. As expected.

Red curry with chicken had zero coconut milk. Very much lacking aromatic or bright flavors. But my fault for ordering Thai from a Chinese joint.

The dumplings in garlic oil were toothy  but stale. They were no more garlicky than they were sweet and artificially thickened.

If you want REAL Chinese food, do not go here! Really bad American Chinese food. Had the worst tofu I have ever eaten.
As my Chinese husband said "no wonder Americans hate tofu".

Go to Grand Sichuan on the UWS instead.

This is a terrible, terrible restaurant.  It's an inexpensive hole-in-the-wall kind of place, but it doesn't even live up to those low expectations.

It appears that most of the food they serve for delivery has been sitting in their buffet for quite a while.  Tough chicken, dry rice and thick (and pretty disgusting) sauce.  General Tso's, which is normally pretty good regardless of the restaurant, is bad here.  As others have said, the meat they use tends to be the "odd bits" that contain bones or ligaments or whatever.

Delivery guy is a total nightmare.  I tip well, but he was very rude and just looked dirty.  Anyone who lives around the restaurant has seen him speeding up and down the sidewalk on his electric bike, yelling at pedestrians - he's no more pleasant in person.

There are dozens of cheap Chinese places in the neighborhood - this might be the worst.
Oder from them but the food never come. the worst part is that they take no responsibility. Never order from this place!!!! Food is not that great too!!

I have a laundry list of issues with this place, but I don't want my review to sound like a rant but here goes..

Food is sub-par. I have very low expectations of chinese take out, I know they have sauces pre-made and many things are pre-marinated and they just throw it in the wok and send it out the door. That being said, my food was bland, the soy sauce they use is low quality for the amount they charge. They use too much corn starch in the sauce, making it very goopy ( I even had a corn starch ball in the food), the hot and sour soup comes out more like flavored vinegar than anything else.. fixed with some siracha but most of it was thrown out in the end.

Delivery was quick, 45 mins but the delivery guy showed up with one shoe missing..  just thinking about it ruins my appetite. I will not be ordering here again.

I ordered my lunch here from grubhub.com. They took over an hour getting here, and as I was walking downstairs to pick up my order, the delivery guy calls me again - BERATING ME ( !), telling me to hurry up - he's busy. Of course when I got back to my office to open up my bag, my food my order was wrong. I contacted grubhub customer service and they were amazing. I then checked my email, and the restaurant charged me an extra 2 dollars to bring the stuff they forgot the first time around - unreal. It is now 2:30. I ordered my food at 1pm....
The delivery person is disgusting - my advice is eat in! Wish I could give you a review of the food but uh..still waiting for it.

I have ordered from New Asia for years but when I placed my order tonight with New Asia via Seamless, food was delivered from Young Chow:

It has the same address and phone number as New Asia did, so I can only guess there is a new ownership and Seamless has not been updated yet.

On balance, the food was definately below average which was really a disappointment considering the food from New Asia was always above average. Add the fact that they included the wrong kind of rice and failed to include the free can of soda their menu says comes with any order over $10 (our order was $17) and my first impression of this restaurant will be my last impression of this restaurant. There are too many other good Chinese restaurants in the area for me every to order from here again.
Cheap, tasty chinese food. Hits the spot when drunk or just want an americanized chinese dinner. Very fast delivery.

They are seriously LUCKY Yelp MAKES you give at least 1 star. SEAMLESS ( the site i LOVE to hate ) Let me order until 10:45 so i assumed you know its fine to order delivery at 10:30.. Right? WRONG. I then called to add a soda the person i spoke to on the phone was fine with it never said anything about what time they close.
Then the DELIVERY MAN COMES.... DUN DUN DUN.... pounds on my door... its now 11:30... yeah i ordered my food an hour ago but whatever.. I know its late I'm not complaining. I open the door and he starts SCREAMING at me "WHY YOU ORDER SO LATE?!?!?!?! WE CLOSE AT 11:30" then i couldn't understand what else he was saying then he wrapped up with "YOU NEVER ORDER LATE AGAIN!! YOU HEAR ME!!!!???" I was so shocked so i said "DON'T WORRY I'll never order from you AGAIN" and i slammed the door. In the 2 minutes he was screaming at me I told him to lower his voice and my neighbors even came out!! SO EMBARRASSING.

Then to top it off the pineapple juice was fucking everywhere and got all over my floor.
He's lucky i didn't throw the fucking bag at him.
NEVER AGAIN.
Oh and the foods not that good. Order from Pearls Chinese its always the best.
The worst customer service! Super rude and unprofessional! The food sucked, tasted cold and under seasoned. Never ordering from here again.

We ordered from here a few times. The latest order was tasting fine until I found a dead fly halfway through my chicken and broccoli. They promptly sent over a new order, but needless to say, I'm not all that interested anymore. Mediocre food I can deal with....but flies? That's a no-no in my book.

The good news is that they do dinner specials that are basically the same as the awesome deals you can get during the day at most places. Egg roll, rice, and entree for less than $10. Not a whole lot of places on the UWS that can claim that.

The bad news is that the food is mediocre at best. I have ordered delivery here twice. The first time I did the chicken & broccoli. It was pretty standard-- nothing to complain about and satisfied my Chinese food craving. Second time was more of a nightmare. I ordered the Sweet & Sour Chicken which came as fried balls of chicken with flavorless-red colored sauce to pour on. I used the whole thing and it still didn't have much flavor at all. Should have known better for a place like this, since I prefer the not-so-fried version (P.F. Chang anyone?)

Overall, if you want cheap Chinese, order one of the American brown-sauce standards and you'll have an unmemorable, filling dinner.
You get what you pay for.  The sweet and sour chicken is yucky.

The food here is mediocre at best. I ordered delivery using seamlessweb and it took over an hour and half to get to me. Every time I called to ask about the status of my delivery they would tell me the delivery guy is on the way. While there aren't many chinese food places in the UWS, there are definitely ones that are superior to this one.

Updating my review with photos: My whole family's official favorite Yakiniku choice in NYC, and even top 5 in the city. It's a no-frills restaurant that is still well decorated and elegant without the unnecessary fanfare.

The Shimofuri Kalbi - Salt was on par with the meat we eat in Japan and the Scallion Rice was addicting. We also loved the Diamond Cut Karubi. Ending the meal with the Almond Pudding is a must.

Great little find while entertaining some work colleagues. We opted for ala carte rather than the prefix. Everyone loved it. We had a pescatarian with us, and even she had plenty of options. Wine / drink  won't blow you away but we made do with some Silver Oak cab :).

Surprisingly not crowded. Attentive waitstaff. And lots of privacy with plenty of seating options. Oh, and surprisingly, despite the open table cooking, my clothes did not carry the scent out with me.

Only draw back was I thought pricing was a little high given portion sizes, hence knocking off a star. Still, would dine here again!

Great food & service.  We ordered a la carte instead of the set courses. A5 wagyu kalbi was fantastic & only $38 which is a steal. Most places charge $50 for 2 small pieces, here they gave you 6 healthy cuts.  Beef tongue was our next fav, others stuff were good: pork belly, pork neck, regular kalbi, all kinds of veggie appetizers & Goma sesame salad. The least fav was the chicken, wish they have wings or thigh.
See attached video below for better visuals.

youtube.com/shorts/8zJiL…

Beautiful interior ambiance, very slow service, good quality meats for a high price.

We made a reservation for a table of six and were promptly seated after walking in. However, each attempt thereafter to reach a member of the waitstaff--to get water, place orders, or to check on the status of our orders (because they took a while to come out) were ignored on our first attempts, and it took multiple members of our group actively making an effort to reach waitstaff that we were finally addressed. I'm not sure why--it wasn't that busy on the Sunday night that we went, but it will deter me from returning in a city with so many great restaurants.

The quality of the meat itself is good! The marbling is prevalent throughout the meat, and the cuts were tender. In particular, the beef tongue was very tender; it had the juicy, melting quality that good beef tongue has.

I loved this experience and found a way to sample a few dishes without breaking the bank. I reco a business dinner but I wanted my mom to try delicious food near Grand Central (ktown was too far with luggage).

Delicious oxtail soup, tender bbq chicken & beef, and favorite bibimbap with eel. A sparking sake always hits the spot for a celebration and sweet palate.

Amazing ambience, elegant service, complimentary mochi, and no scent.

Not my favorite cuisine. Plenty of work, plenty of waiting. Uncomfortable seating arrangements on cushions on the floor (which are probably sought after but made it hard for me to enjoy myself. Presented a large prized cut of Kobe or Wagyu beef which I appreciated and enjoyed preparing.

Honestly everything here was excellent. The decor is very cool and stylish. They have this thing where a bunch of folks do a little welcome chant as they walk you to your table. It's kind of funny since as I'm waiting for others to arrive at the table I can tell when they're there by the entrance greeting lol.

Something I'm not particularly keen on but I know a lot of places started doing - if youre looking to reserve your spot - it's a $50 hold too - so either cancel your plans the day before or show up. Which if you're looking for something  of a more casual drop in then it might not be for you.

The meat there is incredible! To save yourself a couple of bucks you can opt to get the cheaper cuts of meat since I feel like those cuts were just as good as prime cuts. I'd steer away from the cocktails - they taste fine but I hardly taste ANY alcohol - and for 13-15$ a pop - I expect to taste alcohol otherwise I'm just drinking a very expensive iced tea concoction.

Lastly, they have a timer limit on the tables. Basically 2 hours from your reservation time and then you got to go.  And though I didn't go over time so not entirely sure what they'd say if I did - its kind of one of those things that rubs me the wrong way - similarly to the 50$ hold for reservations.

But overall nice experience - but I do think for the experience the price is a little steep.

The quality of the meat at this place was superb. My favorite was definitely the marinated short rib.  The marinade has a very balanced sweetness and the short rib is fatty and tender. Usually I don't like my bqq meat marinade, but this is one of the best short rib I've had in a while. The tongue was good but not as good as the short rib. I also really enjoyed the pork jaw. Other cuts we had were also good. The side dishes were hit and miss. The tartare was pretty good (although the three of us had a mild stomach flu the morning after). The yukkejang noodle was not great. The soup was a bit one dimensional. The noodle was like an instant noodle - not great also.

Overall the quality of the bbq meat is superb. Other dishes are meh. It's on the expensive side though (around $70pp), but we were pretty full afterwards.

4 stars - recommended

Booked this reservation through Open Table on a Sunday night and thoroughly enjoyed our date night here. We were seated in the area where you take off your shoes and sit on pillows on the floor which was a cool experience!

We ordered 4 meats a la carte which was just the right amount for my boyfriend and I. The pork was a bit too fatty for my liking, so I stuck with the leaner meats which were very tender and deliciously seasoned after grilling. We also ordered the rice ox-tail soup which was light and paired well with the meats.

For our dessert, we enjoyed an almond pudding which was nice and creamy. A great place to splurge on if you are craving yakiniku.

Food was great, presentation is great. Ambiance great.

But they're just meat resellers. That's why Yakiniku is all about service, and the service was HORRIBLE.

They messed up my eel rice. It was HARD. It stuck to my TEETH!
And they didn't replace it right away, they asked me what happened like it was unbelievable, and gave us normal steamed rice replacement afterwards.

We waited for water refill way too long. They filled mine then forgot my girlfriend's... we waited to order way too long.

Toraji was highly recommended by a friend of a friend, so we made plans for 6 of us to dine here on a Friday night. Reservations were made on OpenTable and they even sat us about 15 minutes early since our table was free.

But it kind of went downhill from there. Our groups trickled in by the time our 8pm reservation hit and then we were promptly ignored for a while. We kept trying to flag someone down to take our drink order and food order. No joke, we were not even offered water while we waited for our whole party. Most places would've came by, offered water, and asked if we wanted drinks while we waited.

After making our drink and food order, we had to order water from two separate waiter before they finally brought some. And when they did finally bring water, they were super stingy with the water. They also got our drink order wrong. Then after a while, food starts coming. We all opted to do the Toraji 2022 set. Wagyu sushi was very good, as was the beef tartare. The first round of meats were cooked by our waiter and they were excellent. He was great. The last round of meats were cooked on our own - I'm not sure if that was meant to be the case or if our waiter got distracted by other things? It wasn't made clear to us, so we did it ourselves.

And then we were ignored again for a while, even though a few of us wanted more drinks. We ended up finally getting our dessert - and then being ignored again for another 15-20 minutes. I'm not sure if it was because it was a Friday night and they were understaffed or just too busy? But it was not great being ignored for most of the night. Our entire meal took over 2.5 hours, when it realistically should've taken no more than 1.5 max. The food was great, but honestly it's not enough for me to come back if the service is going to be like this.  The price is also kind of expensive for what you get. You can definitely get better quality at higher quantities for the same cost elsewhere.

Amazing Japanese BBQ with a trendy atmosphere. We walked in on a Friday night with two people and sat at the bar, but it ended up a cozy and intimate setting for BBQ. We ordered the premium boneless rib. The rib was a perfect combination of lean and fat meat, and after cooking for 20 sec on each side, the fat bursted out in my mouth while the lean meat portion was chewy.

One of my favorite dishes was the rice with raw egg yolk and scallion. Don't overlook this dish as a simple combination with fresh ingredient can do the magic.

Definitely expected this place to be one of those over priced bbq places but boy was it worth it.

I only got the standard course but the pacing and order of items made the dining experience way more enjoyable than any other Yakiniku or kbbq place I been too, I felt that the staff was attentive enough to see when we were finishing up our meats and brought the cold noodles just in time to clear our palette and end the hot food portion of our meal on a high note.

The meat quality was exceptional, and the shrimp quality definitely surprised me as I usually don't expect cooked shrimp to taste that fresh and well seasoned.

The almond pudding was also amazing and not too sweet that I was tempted to order one to go.

Overall highly recommend and will definitely be back again to try the wagyu!

Good meat, a bit on the pricier side but nice portions.
