Loved their appetizers and also soup. Tried the beef bone one I think, very good.
Definitely a one of Yakiniku to go place in the city-

Came here with my husband to eat dinner one day. The interior of this restaurant is so beautiful and had a "zaseki" seating area for customers to take their shoes off and sit comfortably, while enjoying the meal.

We decided to order 2 asahi beer first to cheer, then ordered their Toraji course to get the full experience. We started off with the soup, yukke, salad and wagyu beef sushi. They all tasted so good with the beef sushi literally melting in your mouth (cue in the drool). Finally, we started cooking the meat, which we literally finished every single piece in one bite. It was definitely some of the best meat I've ever tasted and would absolutely come here again for a celebratory occasion!

The food was delicious but the service was unacceptable, especially for +$180 per person.

We waited for so long to order and to receive a refill of water. We had to constantly wave for someone to even look at us and the waitress would serve the table next to us and would leave without even glancing towards our table. The eel over rice had rice so hard it go stuck in my teeth and when I called a waitress to change the bowl, she looked at me as if I was speaking nonsense.

Please improve on the service. Very disappointing.

Decided to check this hidden gem. It was super close to the hotel I'm staying. Boy oh boy! It's absolutely delicious! I decided to try their standard course. Meats cuts were great. I was surprised how filling it would be. I was pretty skeptical at first but kept an open mind about it.

Mind you, these pictures are 2 orders of the standard course.

Great ambiance but service is pretty slow. The staff were very friendly and soft spoken.

an underrated yakiniku spot! when i was searching for japanese yakiniku (bbq) places, i stumbled across this one and was very intrigued by the tasting menu. there were not many reviews so i was a bit skeptical, but when i walked in, the atmosphere was very modern and classy.

we opted for 2 toraji 2022 course and 2 premium wagyu course so we could try everything for 4 people.

5/5: EVERY DISH. the beef tartare, the wagyu in soup, the a5 sirloin sushi was so tender, soft, and easily melted in my mouth. everything had a good amount of flavor, and a variety of sauces that paired up with each course. when it came to the meat, the server grilled our meat to our liking and recommended each sauce for each type of meat! there was nothing that wasn't tender or flavorful. each meat was very unique, and there was a good variety.

3/5: service. it was quite difficult waving them down because they would not look our way, and was quite hard to understand because the restaurant was very loud. i had to ask to refill my water a bunch of times but they forget to kept coming back.

the food trumps over the service, and would recommend this place for meat lovers especially those who love wagyu! well worth the $128 /person

From the modern Japanese decor to the superb service to the insanely fresh meat, this spot earned all 5 of its stars!  All of the cuts of meat were delicious, but my favorite had to be the thinly sliced goodness that is the short rib.  The beef tongue was a bit too tough for my tastes, but others may feel differently.  The only minor complaint was that we had to cook everything ourselves...perhaps everything might have tasted even better with an expert cook at the helm.  Regardless, definitely plan to be back with friends soon!
Avaryage food but really bad service! Have to wave many time before anyone looked at us and help. Will never come back again.

5 stars for the service! The server at first told me that we will need to cook the meat ourselves but I guess when she saw that we've never done this before she just cooked it for us which was very sweet she kept coming and making sure if were okay and it just made the night better you know will def come back!

Higher end traditional Japanese BBQ. You pay more to get full but all the products are high which quality which carries the meal. None alcoholic delicious drink that my son enjoys is calipico. They serve two types, carbonated and none carbonated. The draft beer is asishi. A surprise during the meal was how delicious their Japanese bbq sauce paired with the meats. We tried beef tartare with egg. That was the first time my son had tartare and I am glad to say he will go back. The place is small so it can fill up quickly. I can see my self returning again and have no reservation about recommending this to anyone.

We are so excited to know this Japanese bbq is opened. We didn't know we need to reserve the tatami private room when I booked so we are sitting at the main dining area next to the window.

The food is quite good and the menu has many options to choose from. We order the standard course dinner to try.

The standard course comes with salad, pickles rice etc and the marinated Toraji CourseStandard CourseStandard Coursebeef are so tasty!  My boy wants to go back again after he had the first bite of beef tongue!  

It would be better if the service is more attentive.  Anyway, we will be back very soon!

I came here twice and both times did the Toraji 2022 Course - absolutely loved every part of the course. The appetizers were probably my favorite part because each of the dishes were so flavorful and great for pictures. The main courses were also amazing, the cuts were nicely done and tasted amazing. The only thing I wished was for the dessert to have been of slightly larger portion. The restaurant itself is very open and spacious. Generally any sort of bbq leaves you smelling like bbq, but this place had such a good ventilation system you couldn't feel or smell a thing which I greatly appreciated. The service here is also impeccable. Will be coming back for sure.

Great service and value for your meal. We got the 2022 Toraji course meal and left feeling full and satisfied. Waiters were attentive and help you cook the meat to the level you request. Meat was really good quality and melts in your mouth

The food is ok.......But the service is terrible. Especially the waitress named Juri. She doesn't know how to properly serve a table at all! And after we ordered the main course, another waitress asked me what dessert I wanna go with, so I ordered almond pudding. Turns out the special dessert in the main course today is also almond pudding I don't understand how didn't she warn me about that.

Definitely don't wanna come again.

Great food, service needs a lot of work!!

I came to yakiniku Toraji with my friend who had highly recommended the place. This is by far the most delicious and authentic Japanese  bbq place in New York. I thoroughly enjoyed every dish we had and it was one of the best meals I've had in New York in a long time.

My only issue with this place is the service.  We had to ask for water 20 minutes into the meal and they did not refill our water even after we emptied our cup. It seemed like there were a lot of wait staff but I literally had no idea what they were doing because they were just standing around most of the time. We would literally need to call them over to come as they did not check in on us.

Service needs to be adjusted to fit American and New York standards but otherwise this is a great place. I will not dock them for service in this review because they are still in their soft opening.

Highly recommend. I will come back!!

The quality of the meat is really good. Places like Gyu-Kaku is no comparisons to this place.
Service is generally bad. No one greeted us at the door (door lady on the phone for 5 min) before she let others come to us.
The 1st server told us that we only need 30 sec per side for the THICK cut beef tongue... and 2nd server told us 2 minutes per side. And one one attended for waters / teas. We have to ask every single time. Won't repeat.

One of the best Japanese bbq I had. We did the toraji tasting menu. Wagyu beef was amazing. And the beef tongue was the highlight. The host barely speaks any English but he understands us. The whole experience makes us feel we were in Japan

THE. BEST. Yakiniku in New York City!!!

Toraji's menu is a wonderful selection of the highest quality food and drink. The staff does a great job creating a friendly atmosphere while remaining professional. The masters behind kitchen's creations will absolutely impress your tastebuds! conveniently located right near The Empire State and Grand Central.

10/10 highly recommend

Probably one of the worst place I ever been to. They should feel sorry for their meat, selling such nice meat with such bad service is sad.

Got here without a reservation since Opentable have all the time slot available and making reservation need to put down the c.c information and I was feeling lazy for that. So I wasn't expecting the restaurant would be crazy busy which is true, they open at 5PM, for here at 645PM with 5 tables inside, restaurant itself isn't big so 5 tables is almost half of the restaurant. First, there a hostess station in the front but no one is there nor any notice regarding anything. So we stood in the front for a bit hoping someone will come, but some server were standing in the dinning room looking confused even they saw us waiting in the front but I guess there only one server do the sitting job since he was the only person doing so the whole night.

We finally seat down, while we still taking our jacket off, someone came and ask for our drink order, my jacket was literally half off and I haven't even scan the menu yet, like chill. Would be nice if they can give us some water, we got NO WATER during the whole meal. Is funny when you pay for such pricy meat, you will think, I could at least get some water right? Nahhhhh not here.

We order one beer and one coke, and the coke came in a small glass bottle(233ml), but other than coke, I see all the other soft drink come in a can(355ml), all customers  paid the same price but got different quantity of beverage. Why? That shows how unorganized this place is, the lack of caring and management really get to me.

I ordered garlic scallions soup which it suppose to come with beef and daikon. However, when the soup came, it was FULL OF EGGS inside which it was mention on the menu and then I realized it was the wrong soup later on when I double check the menu, which is fine since I was planning on taking it home since I was getting full and the soup itself was huge. But that's the worst part of the night. After we paid, we asked for a to go container to pack the soup to go, the server brought us a container that can't close, top and bottom are different set which I don't know how that happened. From there, we literally asked 3 different servers and one just completely ignored us, he literally knew there no lib for the bottom that they gave us or something, he said "ok" to us and never come back, another one brought us the wrong lid and tried to close it for us on the table.....and said she will look for a lib and never return. What is sad is that they seat us at the bar, so we saw everything and how everyone react including the manager, maybe two of us didn't order the whole kobe beef so they don't care about us, after 15 mins, we need to ask another server and he asked the manager and seems like she knew there no lid for the bottom since the last server also asked her. Is fine to let us know they are out of to go boxes so we can just leave but what is funny is that, at the end, the server brought us a smaller container and asked us to put it there.....at this point, dose it really matter. What is even funnier is that the manager at end come to the door asked what happened, we literally watch her the whole time tell the server to look for the lid and none of them found it and she said "I was busy" so why are you here now trying to asked what happened?

They open at 5 PM, they have so much time to teach the staff and restock the restaurant before opening. What a disappointment. Sigh.

Brand new restaurant. No alcohol license just yet, so be warned.

Soft and extremely delicious beef tongue. Well cooked kalbi style. Reasonable prices for the bibimbap and noodles. Definitely a fancy restaurant look with courteous staff. Very quiet as they get their name out there.

It's not bad. Most of the meat are heavily seasoned so if you are getting the sauced versions, no need for any extra sauces. Korean dishes reinterpreted with slightly Japanese influenced flavors. Thus, it's not for people familiar with Korean BBQ flavors. It's distinctly Japanese influenced across the board. That's not necessarily a bad thing, just comes down to preference. Nothing at the restaurant is simply offered or given, not even water. All things must be requested and are billed. Having said that, there could be friendlier and more accommodating service. This style of BBQ is very familiar to me so I was fine without the extra explanations, but if it was a novel experience most won't really know what to do.

The verdict? I would go if I'm in the area. Portions are small for the price but overall no hassle no smell no crowd type of establishment.
Pricey but worth every dollar, just enjoy! Highly recommend sirloin sushi, must try! And the rice is sooooo different from others, must try!!!!

I had such a great time at this restaurant. I heard from my Japanese co-workers that this is a chain restaurant in Japan.  The wait staff were so friendly and helpful and the quality of the Wagyu beef was excellent. My only complaint is our lobsters were a bit overcooked on the grill.

I noticed a lot of pedestrians passing by the restaurant trying to peek inside because the interior looks so pretty. The restaurant is big and roomy which is perfect for social distancing. They have semi private seating to accommodate larger groups.  

I know that a few people complained about the service but my husband and I had no issues. If we need something we just asked a staff member.

I will definitely come back again and recommend this restaurant to my friend's.

I wanted to give 5 stars but didn't because of a rude waitress, Juri, I believe that was her name as it appeared on the receipt. She had no idea how to serve to make guests feel comfortable.
Food, interior were excellent and other servers are very nice.
The standard course is reasonable and more than enough amount of meat.

I was arrived 10 minutes earlier today but the waitress insets me to wait outside. It is super fucking cold and she says they are having a meeting so she does not allow me to wait in the waiting area. She forced me to out of the restaurant. Wow she is  a piece of work. I have never seems anyone waitress rude like this.
Definitely worth eating here!!! Great quality, nice atmosphere, great experience!!! Marked and will come more often!

If you're midtown and craving Japanese BBQ this place is excellent. The meat is beautifully curated and the bbqs at your table or counter are perfect. Awesome Kimchi, draft beer, super friendly and helpful service navigating the menu. Not that expensive either. Looked like "in the know" crowd food wise too.
Love this place. The meat, dessert, whole menu selections and the decor were fantastic and beautiful. The staffs were incredibly nice and warm. Will definitely come back.
Their bento box was great!!! I had omakase last time and enjoyed as well. I would definitely come back.
Really good quality meat. Great ambiance great place to bring a date.  They place some nice jazz in the background.
Great tasty food and the service is really great as well. Very professional crew and a great place for a quality meal.
Sister restaurant to One of my favorites still left in NYC, Yakiniku Gen, highly recommend,  always fresh meat, confirmed personally this one is just as good as original sister, worthy of Last Supper
Wow, first visit to Japanese Restaurant. The server was helpful with recommendations. The food was clean and flavorful. The wagyo as the best beef ever.
the vibe is very good as a mid-town restaurant. I like the decorations. high quality meat and very authentic! everything was good.

We had the wagyu option, which on this night included shrimp and scallops, as well as a big portion of wagyu beef. The beef was so tender. The server did the grilling, as she explained that the wagyu is more difficult to prepare correctly. The precursors to the main course we're plentiful and delicious. Assorted kimchi, salad, broth with a slice of beef and scallions, a dish of beef tartar with rice and an egg (so good), a piece of beef "sushi. So much food! The price was $98 each, and worth every penny.  The decor is lovely and the staff were very accommodating and attentive. Great new spot in the neighborhood!

Good quality.
Reasonable price.
Good service.
We recommend this yakiniku restaurant.

Got the premium assorted meat, meat tasted good and fatty but not worth $90. Service was just ok, they didn't explain which meat is what. The menu is pretty limited, I prefer Gyu-Kaku because they have more options.
The food was so good! The quality of meat was amazing and the sides were perfect complements!

Food was good. There were preset courses as well as the option to order a la carte. As some of the members of my group are picky, we just ordered a la carte and honestly it was probably a better value as we spent less than we would've spent on the preset courses and got everything we wanted and was full. For the 4 of us, our bill came out to $250 which also included at least two drinks each. The only comment I have is to check your bill in detail. We had ordered our second round of drinks and water came instead so I'm assuming they heard us wrong. Additionally, for some reason we ordered two rounds of our drink but it was put in as two different drinks in each round (the first round was the wrong drink and more expensive than it should've been but I noticed after we paid).

Nice BBQ but small portions -the food is very good, however, the cheaper portions are small and unsatisfying. We came here two weeks ago, and while we enjoyed our meal, we still left hungry. Maybe I will give them a 2nd try, but not now!

Friends were craving Japanese BBQ so we popped into Yakiniku Gen for dinner.  I've had Korean BBQ many times, but this was my first time with Japanese.  I liked it equally as well but definitely a different experience.  I honestly don't know what we ordered!  My friend ordered everything for us and all I can say was that I loved every piece of meat we cooked!  Two people waited on us and did an excellent job.  They made a few recommendations which included going with the house highball rather than one with a more expensive whisky.  The place is small and loud, but not unpleasant.  Most of the patrons were Japanese, which is always a great sign.  Will be back for sure!

I have ordered Yakiniku Gen from Uber Eats before, but this is my first time eating at the restaurant. I have to say, that eating the freshly grilled meat is 10x better. Note that you do have to grill the meat yourself and the dishes on the menu is a mix of Korean and Japanese BBQ.

The restaurant is clean and the service was great. It was a packed night and yet the servers were running around trying to help everyone. My favorite cuts of the night were the marinated diamond cut galbi and pork jowl. The portions are kind of small and we ordered around 4-5 meat dishes for a group of 4. I also recommend getting the Yuzu / Lemon Drop drink (add 2 shots if you really want to feel a buzz) and the sesame sauce salad.

After our meat, we ordered taiyaki and naengmyeon. The taiyaki was soft and the naengmyeon is different from what you expect from usual Korean naengmyeon. My friend who is Japanese, said that it has an authentic Japanese flavor.

Overall, I would recommend trying this place out with friends and to make a reservation prior to coming. There were a few parties waiting when we arrived on a Friday night, but because we made a reservation, we were able to be seated first. It is similar to Gyukaku and the prices were ~$50 pp for a group of 4 (we were also very hungry).
Abit run down atmosphere wise but nice for a quick meal and the meat quality was very good.

Yakiniku Gen in NYC is one of the better steakhouse experiences you can have . We tried various cuts including Miyazaki A5 Wagyu from their own cattle farm in Japan. That's right, they have their own Wagyu farm. It's essentially a Japanese institution as they have several locations across Japan as well. The quality is just exceptional, can't recommend enough

My main server was not the best, she was really nice but kinda forgetting small stuff such as water or turning on the griller.. not a big deal though.
Food was good, my party ordered ala carte. The 5 types of beef is definitely one to try. It's great, but there's another better japanese/korean bbq in the city.

This review is in DEC 2022

Bottom line:

Delicious food on the expensive side with service miscues.

The Breakdown:

-Very good food quality -

We ordered the basic combo, $50pp.
1. Marinated meat was so tender, delicious. Side note, the smoke eater grills really help keep the smoke smell down, and off your clothes.
2. Bibimbap with crisped rice was nice, though needed some more sauce for flavor. Was served without beef- I get it, but not normal for me.
3. Kimchi, namul (fermented veggies plate) was good and plentiful.
4. Ice cream bowls to finish it off. Suggest going matcha vs vanilla- the vanilla tastes fake and bit too sweet, the matcha tastes legit matcha.

-The service was not attentive.

1. Called 3 times to try to get a reservation and no pickup all 3 times. When we arrived we didn't see a maitre d. When you walk in there's a sensor chime that dings, like at a bodega,  plus they have a desk bell. Sensor chime and desk bell are cheaper than a maitre d. I understand cost perspective, though it's not warm and receptive.
2. The place has 2 servers all night. Maybe they were overrun, but there were a couple free tables. We didn't get our waters until midway through the meal.
3.  Another table waited maybe 10 minutes plus, kept head-turning toward the walking path but they were not attentive to her. She was clearly annoyed. I watched as the patron had to get up and go to the counter to ask them for the check to leave.

-The cost to food ratio is expensive for the patron:

Basic combo at $50 pp.
1. 2 pieces pp of 4 diff types of beef, so 8 pieces of thinly sliced beef each for 2 people.
2. Kimchi plate, namul plate (which they give plenty).
3. One shared bibimbap bowl (which repeats the same veggies on the namul plate) for 2 persons who each ordered the basic combo, which should contain 2 bimbimbap bowls but only given one bowl. The server confirmed that when handed us the bibimbap. This is the same serving size bowl that any other Korean restaurant serves for 1 bibimap order. And here, for 2 people got one bowl. This did not sit well with me but I kept quiet.

I swear I'm not a cheapskate, but this is not a great value meal for 2 for the amount of food served. The "basic combo" that we each ordered priced at 50 bucks pp. Bill came out to $108 w/tax, w/o tip.

My date and I came here after we had happy hour drinks and apps at another place so we weren't starving coming here. I'm glad we had eaten prior.

I likely would not eat here again. The food is good. Though I've eaten at other competitors Japanese BBQ joints and have enjoyed their food for better prices with impeccable service, even in this present inflated economy mind you.

As always think I just gotta say first and foremost, the service was top tier! Really kind, helpful but not saccharine. Really tough time right now for restaurants but also wait staffs so let's give them some love!
Now to the food. Yeah, it was soso good. We each had a Sapporo and did a basic meat set which came with different kimchi's and vegetables for changin up flavors. It also comes with bibimbap (made at your table) with soup and your choice of ice cream! The four cuts of beef were all really good but we also got some scallops and a diamond cut to just switch things up and try more things. It's a great deal of fun and eating delicious, delicious meat made on a fire right in front of you? Amazing.

The meat was good but we could have ordered more without the service. The plate after eating was not taken away, and the baking tray was burnt and did not take the initiative to replace it. The waiter also asked us to use a burnt frying pan for the meat. The indoor ventilation is not good and it is very hot. Waiters have time to chat at the front desk, but they don't have time to look at customers. Do I still need to give tips?

The food is okay but the staff sucks.

I was drunk but I didn't nothing to anyone or the restaurant. I paid but one of their waiter thought I can't afford it. He just held my neck and threw me to the ground.

Great foods, great pricing, and great ambience! Apparently the place is busy weekday nights but it was almost empty when we went at lunchtime on Sunday. Their food is great and this is really a great place to have authentic and decent Yakiniku for very affordable price at the center of Manhattan. I surely will come back!
Excellent!!! We got two premium meat platters (marinated)  and rice with egg, which B was both delicious and savory. Add a lemon chu hi and call it a night! Definitely will come back!!

Unbelievably terrible. Service, cleanliness, food. Where to start? A mystery how this place has so many reviews and stars, it shouldn't have survived after one week of service.

Service: No one cares or wants to talk to you. We made a reservation, but no one was at the front and it took 10-15 minutes for someone to appear and greet us. At our table, no one ever came and checked up on us. We saw plenty of tables with used napkins and plates sitting around for ages without being cleaned. No one ever smiled or looked glad to be alive. The servers all looked like zombies.

Cleanliness: Our booth table's seats were ripped; the menus were sticky with what felt like years of sweat and soda stains; tables were not clean. Worst of all, we saw old rice stuck to our grill because it hadn't been cleaned properly.

Food: Who combines multiple side dishes onto a single plate? They were clearly not freshly made (days old) and definitely all store bought. All the juices combined together and you couldn't taste one thing from another. The meat wasn't fresh, the cuts weren't good, and no one ever explained what ANY of the meats or dishes were. We ordered a meat combo, and the meat arrived on a big plate, but the cuts were indistinguishable. It's hard to mess up stone pot bibimbap, but theirs was one of the worst I've ever had.

STAY FAR AWAY--this place is posing as a restaurant.
Went there for Valentine's Day. Nice vibe good food but the wagyu was a bit underwhelming. Price was subjectively fair for 2 people coming in at about $120 including drinks.

Very authentic Japanese BBQ! It reminds me of the days I spent in Tokyo and the tiny BBQ house next to the hotel. The meat was all well marinated at the right level and very tender no matter how long you cook it. The cabbage salad and rice with egg yolk and scallion were also great pair for BBQ. I would definitely tag this restaurant as a regular one for BBQ.

More like 3.5 stars but I enjoyed the hospitality very much here at Yakiniku Gen. We opted for the Gen Classic Set which is $60pp, along with the cold noodles, lettuce and legacy potato salad.

The course came with kimchi, vegetables, 4 different cuts of beef and beef tongue. I enjoyed the beef tongue alot because it is thinly sliced and very tender and I liked it dipped in the dark sauce that they provide you. Be careful not to over cook it. I also enjoyed the beef tartar that comes with an raw egg yolk, this combination we amazing! We opted for the salt and pepper option instead of the marinated version because we wanted to see how fresh the beef was. There were two slices of meat that weren't too fresh tasting and very gamy, which I didn't enjoy. Also, please pass on the cold noodles if you are expecting it to taste like korean cold noodles. It is definitely one of the more affordable yakiniku spots.

No frills Yakiniku restaurant with a simple menu and really chill atmosphere. Ordered the Diamond Harami and Diamond Kalbi, both of which were tender and very well marinated. We also got the first beef item on that page - I forget what cut it was but it wasn't as soft and marbled, but still a good option. Had the same marinade as the first 2.

We were a party of 2 and had 3 plates of meat between us  and finished with the right amount of food - not hungry but not too full either. Prices were reasonable as well!

If you were hoping for more appetizers and sauces, you might want to look elsewhere. But this is definitely not as commercialized as it's neighbor Gyukaku and would recommend for a quick and simple meal!

Came here with my family last week and it was a hit! It was our first time so we opted to get the pre fix set for $45 pp. you can choose how you like the meat to be seasoned --plain (salt and pepper) or marinated. We decided to go with salt and pepper to test out the quality of the meat. The pre fix came with assorted kimchi style vegetables, bibimbap and ice cream for dessert.

Anyway, we ordered the smallest/cheapest pre fix set to try different kinds of meat. Our plan was to supplement the pre fix with whatever meat we end up liking more (I highly recommend this). To our surprised, we were so full (came with 3 guys) that we ended up not ordering anything else.

Now I wouldn't say that this is the best Japanese bbq place I've been to but the quality of the meat was pretty decent. The quality + price + portions= 5 stars in my book. Can't wait to go back!

AS OF MAY 2018, There is NO MORE HAPPY HOUR!!

I came by on a Thursday around 545pm in May, and I was hoping to try their happy hour since reviews kept talking about it. We stopped by and it was not busy at all. We sat down and looked at the menu... There's no happy hour menu. We asked the waitress for the happy hour menu and she said THEY NO LONGER HAVE HAPPY HOUR!! Darn.

So we order from the regular menu. The beef set combo, the seafood combo, and the veggie combo. We also ordered the garlic fried rice.

The garlic fried rice was not that good. Bland.

The bbq food was not bad. Enjoyable. Not exactly filling u less u plan on spending alot of money. Luckily, I had just ate a whole bunch of snacks like an hour ago so I wasn't too hungry.
I would probably not come back again.
Wonderful cuts of various meats, including the thick cut beef tongue. Great service as well. Would visit again!

Decent spot in Midtown for some yakiniku. The happy hour menu is worth it, but their regular dinner menu is pricey and the service was slow. You'd wonder why ordering one beef plate would take over 15 minutes to come out?

I came with a group of 8 on a reservation and unfortunately we didn't think it through (no fault to the restaurant), but we had to be split up into two tables for two grills. Even though the tables were next to each other, they were still too far apart, which made it difficult to talk to anyone at the other table. This restaurant is probably not the best spot for a large party if you want to socialize/catch up with everyone.

As for the food, the beef here is high quality, but the portion sizes are small. The assorted combination plates are the way to go though...different cuts of meat for a lower price!

My bf and I decided to go here for our anniversary and we were not disappointed! I used to love Yakiniku in the east village but sadly they'd closed. This location is located right next to Totto Ramen in midtown east.

We ordered four BBQ meat dishes - beef tongue, diamond cut chuck rib, outside skirt, and beef tartar. I highly recommend you ask for salt and pepper seasoning. The meat itself is sooo good you don't need any sauce. Their beef tartar was definitely one of the best I've tried.

We also ordered the Korean veggie platter, Kalbi soup, and Garlic Fried Rice (yeah we went a bit overboard) and they were also very good.

We paid around $60 after tax and tips which is fair for the quality.
Great Yakiniku in Japanese style.  This is run by Japanese so not like the places in Korean town.   Great quality meats and service.    Would definitely recommend.

This spot was pretty good. I felt like it was really a korean bbq spot masquerading as a japanese Yakiniku. That being said, the beef tongue that we ordered ( premium one ) was really, really good. I also like that they have a lot of vegetable side dishes. ( which, if this was a korean spot, would have come free as side dishes... but... it's not a korean spot as I said earlier )

They had kalbi, bibimbap, Naengmyun on the menu and lots of different cuts of beef. You can also get an assortment of sakes, soju's, and other alcoholic drinks.

It felt like you were in a private underground restaurant. So I liked that.

Friendly staff and this place can be pricey with small portions of the meat. I had ordered the premium beef tongue, wagyu and the heart sashimi. Although the wagyu was small portions, it melted in your mouth.

Ordering the combo would be worth it. Please keep it mind that you will be cooking the food yourself.

I came here for my birthday with my friend. We started order a lot of meet because the meat here are reasonable prices. Good quality of meats. They do have some daily promotion on weekdays. Before I finish I thought my bill will end up with the expensive bill but There are NOT I only pay less with these good quality of meat.
Ps. Me and my boyfriend were very happy

Swung in on a saturday night because Totto Ramen, right next door, was full. I didn't come in with many expectations, there was no wait and we were seated immediately at 6:45ish. We were handed a full menu as well as a happy hour menu! Granted, the happy hour menu prices were still about $14 for a few slices of meat, but we weren't really sure how much each order came with. My friend and I went with the Kalbi (4 pieces), short rib, rib finger meat, and an order off the regular menu ... Wagyu.

Everything was good, surprisingly, the rib finger meat was the best of the meats that wasn't Wagyu. The wagyu was the best. So Marbley... order it. It's worth the $38.

I randomly walked in here one day after walking past it for weeks and it definitely wasn't what I was expecting. I didn't even know Japanese BBQ was a thing and now I'm obsessed! From the outside, this place looks like a random hole in the wall, but the inside is more spacious than expected, with a very clean and warm ambiance. We came around 7pm on a Saturday and were seated immediately, though the tables around us began to fill up pretty quickly. Everything was super delicious and portion sizes were quite reasonable!

There is a really large assortment of different meats and dishes, I was a little overwhelmed so we ordered the assorted beef platter (around $50)for more variety. I was really intrigued by the egg and scallion rice ($3) so we got that as well as well as an egg soup.

Beef platter: 5/5 Reasonable size for 2 people and SUPER HIGH QUALITY meats!! I was really impressed with the freshness, texture, and flavors of the meats. Although it doesn't seem like there was a lot of seasoning and marinade, it was all super flavorful which really speaks to the quality of the meat. Here, you get 5 different cuts of beef.

Scallion and Egg rice: 5/5 nothing bad to say. The egg is raw FYI.

Egg Soup: 5/5 Definitely some of the best egg drop soup I've tasted. I think they added sesame oil in it, or it definitely has an ingredient I don't normally taste in egg drop soup that just adds a more profound flavor.

I eat a lot of korean BBQ, and compared to Japanese BBQ, KBBQ is definitely a lot more sweet while Japanese BBQ has a lot more emphasis on the natural flavor of the meat and thus, I believe the meat is better quality and fresher than most of the KBBQ places I've been to. The prices are actually really good for the quality of the meat!

Overall, I throughly enjoyed my experience!

One of the affordable Japanese yakiniku place in NYC after Yakiniku west closed. It was my first time going there non happy hour. (I think they stopped having happy hour any more???) My favorite point of the restaurant is they carry liver sashimi! I love liver sashimi but it's harder to find a place to eat in Japan. I'm very happy I can still eat it here. Glass of sapporo is $3.5 always. Everyday, they have different meat to be special price too. I went there on Wednesday so kalbi was the special. Their negitan is delicious which will be special price on Monday. Kimchee was little to sweet for me. It was like very Japanese kimchee not spicy like Korean one.
I give only three stars because around the entrance area to down stairs bathroom area were little stink.
Bad customer service.  Made a mistake, then when I asked about it to be confirmed, Then she Yelled at customers. I won't go again anymore. Very sad.

After walking past this place many times, I knew I had to try as there was always a wait and the entrance area was always filled with people. I called the day before to make a reservation and the phone attendant immediately told me that it would be difficult to seat us for a Friday Night. We were "lucky" to get fit in so we had a reservation for 6:30PM and when we arrived, the restaurant was only about 30% full.

It was our first time and we were rushed to order, not having the chance to fully review the menu, we asked the waitress of recommendations which she gave and we agreed to. In addition, we ordered a noodle soup dish, garlic fried rice, lots of meats, chicken, veggies and shrimp and scallops for the grill.

As soon as I was finally feeling comfortable, the slew of raw meats filled our table without any explanation of how to properly cook. The grill needed to be changed repeatedly and we had to ask for water refills several times. At no point in the dinner were we asked how things were. The first official greeting was "you have 30 minutes, so if you want anything else, please order now". Cool, after about 15 minutes, we asked for the check and we paid and signed and they were still rushing us out even though we were supposed to be allotted 2 hours for the meal.

We got up and there were other open tables which was frustrating. Our party tried to make the most of it, but after the traumatizing experience, I'm surprised how this place can be so popular. Overall, food was okay, but there are definitely plenty of other BBQ places that give you more bang for your buck. Average without drinks you are already spending over $50.00/head and that's not including tip yet.

Grade: C-
Not a good restaurant- underwhelming food and service. Generic all around. Poorly prepared and presented food.

Got to finally try this place out and it was really good!
Great selection of meat and great service.  We had a little variety of everything. From Waygu to some seafood options like shrimp, scallops and crab claws.  The meats were really fresh and nicely portioned.  

We had some great service, they always came by to help us change out the grill and teach us a little a bit about the menu items.

I say go with a nice group that can eat and enjoy some nice grilling !

Probably one of the best open-grill BBQ spots in the city.  The restaurant is snugged between Totto Ramen and another joint so it's easy to miss but if the ramen line is too long and you're hangry, you're in good hands in Yakiniku Gen.

Cabbage Salad is super yummy and the meats are marinated nicely. It is a little pricey in retrospect to the atmosphere but the quality speaks for itself. If you're craving simple, grilled meat and a side of greens, this place hits all the marks.
One of my favorites still left in NYC, highly recommend,  always fresh meat, worthy of Last Supper

We walked in a little after 5pm without a reservation. The server said night is fully booked, but he can get us seated if we can finish by 7pm.
So we ordered as soon as we were seated and food came out pretty quickly. We ordered 3 beef dishes (Harami, Nakaochi Kalbi, and Kalbi),tecchan (large intestine), and sam gyup sal (pork belly).
Also ordered onions and rice on the side.
Generally speaking, 2-3 dishes per person seems appropriate. Food was good and they do offer a variety of meat selections, but I'd rather go to Gyu-Kaku during happy hour.
Great services from the beginning till the end!!! The meat was great, other menus were also great. They even changed the grill just like we do it in Japan!! The prices are reasonable too.

Very good Japanese BBq spot. Quality of the meats are excellent. A little on the small portion side but it allows you to try out more varieties. Not cheap but definitely worth a try. Will be back again for another visit.

Ate here last night with my best friend.  

We ordered
- A bottle of the montepulciano (delicious)
- The uni and kalbi rice (worth the splurge, delicious)
- Assorted kimchi (a little too saucy for my taste, but i know some people like that)
- The cabbage salad (so simple, so delicious, comes with miso ginger dressing on top)
- The assorted 5-meat plate (came with 4 pieces each and fantastic)

All of this was enough for the two of us.  We probably could've gotten away with ordering another meat dish a la carte, but I'm glad we stopped here for fear of being overly full.  I'd come back for the uni and kalbi rice.

This review was based on the last time I went, which was back in December 2019: love yakiniku in general and have come here to fulfill the yakiniku craving ever since yakiniku west in st marks closed due to a fire. The location here is not as busy and bustling as st marks, which I like. I like the side dishes that come with the set meals since it feels more like a full meal with some fiber. You can grill your own meat here like other yakiniku places, and the waiting staff can help you with bibimbap (no spicy, mild, or spicy). This is my go-to place for yakiniku, and I look forward to the day when the doors open up again when it is safer.

I would definitely recommend this restaurant but it's not for the faint of heart.. Meaning they have a very unique menu of intestines, liver and beef tongue to grill Japanese style.  My friend and I stuck to the more common items to BBQ like Short ribs (ask for the sauce marinade which is slightly sweet), Wagyu Japanese beef which was INSANE and perfectly marbled and tender, organic chicken thighs and the shrimp.  I would have LOVED to order the pork belly to try but my friend was not a fan so we passed.  Because we were spending time catching up with a lot of chit chat, BBQ and chatting worked perfect together.  We grilled as we went which is a lot of fun but ended up with no pictures.. Just didn't think of it..

We started with the spicy edamame which I really LOVED and the assorted kimchee which was ok.   Don't miss the spicy edamame if you want a little kick with your sake.  

We also ordered the Korean cold noodles and the garlic fried rice as extras to go with our BBQ.  My friend LOVED the garlic fried rice which was just a simple mix of garlic, rice, eggs and scallions.  I thought the Korean cold noodles were ok.  A nice to have but not a need to order for sure.  

I would recommend trying this little restaurant out.  It's quaint with an interesting menu, very good service and great quality meats to BBQ.

They recently updated their menu so I think this review would reflect their current quality pretty well (went 7/12/2019).

The menu got rid of $3 Sapporo beer which is a pity. It also replaced their single offering of wagyu beef with a three-type wagyu combo, which was too much for us (couple) as you might know wagyu has quite a lot of fat. We also tried their new $45 uni beef brisket don (sea urchain + beef brisket over rice) but I have to admit their uni tasted bitter which made me doubt its freshness. We actually had never tasted uni like that elsewhere. Maybe they fire-sprayed the uni?

Overall the food was good and the service was excellent as usual, but we'll be careful with ordering the correct dishes with their new menu next time.

We happened in on this place and it turned out to be really delicious.  The meat was all really good, very high quality, with the cutest little cast iron skilled of lobster and butter as well.  Pricey, to be sure, but it was a gorgeous spread and we felt like it was a really special occasion.

Knocking off a star because service was pretty lax, and we had to ask several times for things like water.  Everyone was very nice, though.

Only been here twice. First time, I came to have ramen because Totto Ramen's line was out the door. To be honest, the ramen wasn't that good and I would have probably rather waited on the long line next door. Second time, I came during happy hour and dinner. Happy hour menu is a bit limited but is a really good deal!

As far as grilled food, I wish I knew what we ordered. My Japanese coworkers helped me to order and I have no idea what each thing was called on the menu. I tried beef tongue for the first time. It was surprisingly good! They said they ordered ribs for us which was really good and flavorful. There was another meat that was really chewy and hardly edible. I'll update my review next time I go again and actually know what I'm eating. Sorry guys!

But as far as my ramen experience and my grilling overall experience, it was only mediocre. I've had better ramen and better consistent grilled foods before in Midtown East so probably this wouldn't be the first choice.

It was my first experince with Japanese food ( yep food of chinese looking people- eh!) and t'was great!!! After watching Deadpool at 84/t AMC on Valentines day night, i landed here with my date but total accident! We came to Totto Ramen instead went here since i saw a big of meats they serve.  Good thing they also served Ramen. Totto and Gen are right next to each other. One of the meats at Gen is called HARAMI ( which in my langugae with same spelling means "Bastard". I knew i am not making a mistake, and i was right. Their food was great my date explained me all and inloved Wagyu beef. We got 4 diff kinds. Their cocktails are well priced, service can be improved, food quality was good expecially their sauces.
Had a tea and icecream in dessert which were great too.

Overall highly recommended place!!!!!!!!

Yakiniku Gen you are most certainly incredible, I had a wonderful experience here today. Reasonably priced and quality. Terrific food, Sapporos was fantastic without a doubt. This Sapporos was prepared just perfectly. Nice people as well. Would love to go back soon!

This used to be an amazing place for take-out Japanese style food. The people were very polite and professionals. They cared about the customers and understood that in the restaurant business customers mean jobs. Times have changed. The last time I was there, I asked the woman taking my order if the lunch special came with both soup and salad like on the menu. She said yes. I told her that I did not get salad my two previous visits. She told me don't worry, it's okay. She never apologized and did not seem to understand why I was upset even after I showed her what the menu said. Skipping the  salad was not okay. She then refused to give me brown rice with my lunch bento even though I have had meals with brown rice for many years. She told me that the bento only comes with white rice. I guess I had been imagining the brown rice in past years. I told her to forget about my order and walked out.

This time, I did not see her when I entered, but the man there was taking a nap. I guess I should have apologizde for interrupting his nap by ordering lunch. He accepted the brown rice request but told me that I could have soup or salad. I did not bother to explain that the menu does not say soup or salad for the lunch bento; I knew that I would lose that argument (a different menu-based argument several weeks ago got me nowhere, I was told that the menu was wrong). At least I got my brown rice. When the food arrived, the woman from two weeks ago took my money. She very politely returned a dollar that I had overpaid. I thanked her. All seemed well until she counted the change. She did not understand that two quarters and two nickels equal 60 cents. We argued over the coins and I walked out once again upset.

I really miss the previous workers. I have no idea why they are not there any more, but the place has gone down hill these past few months.

Wonderful, wonderful, wonderful!
Food, ambiance, service, all amazing.
Very highly recommended.

Great food, poor service. If it hadn't been for the lamb fassoulia and mamooul,  we would not have had a good time.

There were customer service issues and a weird restroom setup that resulted in male and female customers using the wrong bathrooms. On top of that, we felt our water ignored us for long periods of our meal and was only prompt when we decided to leave and pay the check. All in all a mixed experience, with good food but poor service.

Met new friends for lunch, and they suggested this place; they'd been here for dinner but never for lunch, so new experience all around!

Ambiance is cool, quiet, upscale.  Frankly, I was pleasantly surprised by the more casual, both price and food, menu for lunch.

Very tasty food!  Hubby and I don't eat beef or lamb, but they have chicken, fish, and vegetarian options galore.  Two of us had the falafel wrap, one had chicken shwarma wrap, and I had the beet falafel wrap.  Everyone was very pleased with their lunches.  Warning, the wraps are messy to eat!  I think all the tahini sauce for mine was on the outside; when I unwrapped the foil, it was whitish and drippy - but tasty!  Many of the wraps, including the one chicken shwarma at our table, have fries included - IN the wrap.  The ones of us who had falafel wraps chose them partly because they do not have fries incorporated in the wraps.

No rush, we were chatting as we ate, but it was more than half empty when we arrived so hey were quite tolerant of our leisurely meal.  But when we were done, we *had* to see the dessert menu.  Oh, boy, lots of yummy choices there!  Our friends shared one order of baklava, and we shared one order of namoura, something we've never had before.  It's a dense, syrup-soaked, absolutely delicious, cake.  They serve 6 little chunks on a plate, so he had 3 & I had 3 and that was quite satisfying to the sweet tooth.  One person had Lebanese coffee - in a tiny espresso-size cup, looked like mud to me!  The other 3 shared a pot of fresh mint tea.  This was served from an elegant, polished silver (stainless steel?)  teapot, into small, cut-glass cups on cut-glass saucers.  The tea was dramatically poured from a height, maybe a foot?, above the cups.  Waiter didn't spill a drop.  When we had emptied our little teacups, I poured more for each of us, and I was trying to emulate the waiter; he was walking past our table and commented, "higher!"  So fun!

Now husband and I will have to come back for dinner; we're thinking we'll order several of the vegetarian mezzes that sound amazing and probably won't disappoint.

Deceptively small place from the outside, several tables filled up while we were eating, spacious dining room.  GO!

Great for large groups! I came with 25 people for a work dinner and the staff was so accommodating and patient with us. I ended up ordering a bunch of mezze for the table and everything was a hit. I particularly enjoyed the falafel and labneh, and the pita came in abundance. Highly recommend.

Best Lebanese food in Manhattan. Must order the fattoush salad, cauliflower kibbeh, koussa and the black tea with mint.
Service was good. Nothing outstanding, but the waiters were very efficient.
Music was excellent, good ambience. Not too upscale, but not low scale either. Perfect for a birthday celebration or intimate evening.
Overall, I would return again.

Overall fantastic restaurant. Went with family and ordered several vegetarian appetizers. The waiters had great recommendations and did not try to make us to get too much food, which we appreciated. Delicious hummus and other dips, unique beet falafel, warm pita bread - it was a wonderful sampler! Also, the restaurant is beautiful and spacious, extremely well designed.

The 6 of us had a good selection to try. As mentioned their hummus is very good, and also as mentioned the shawarma is a bit dry and needed a sauce to wake it up.  Portion was small so needed the apps and pita to fill up.

Also as mentioned the service is weak.  They were pretty busy and I needed to request the Tzatziki sauce multiple times. We also needed to wave down servers a few times. It's a very nicely decorated main room which is great for talking until they turn music up to a very uncomfortable lever to sing at a table. They have a nice little bar area downstairs in case you have a wait and want a drink.

We felt the apps were just ok, which included the Grilled  Halloumi (good), grape leaves (so-so), Yara Fries (good, MUCH better than the side fries).

Wife enjoyed the lamb chops ($42) but no other dishes were noted as outstanding.  I would rate 2.5 stars if available.
Although Lebanese food is not my favorite the food was great especially fries. came in with a big party and the service was good.

Decent Lebanese place. The servers friendly and efficient. The dips were great, although the pita was a bit lacking. We shared a bunch of bigger plates and the lamb tartare was fantastic! Highly recommend trying if in the area.

This restraunt was so nice on the inside. The owner is Lebanese and It was such a nice vibe.

The mixed grill was really good and so was the spicy potato. They also had live music. I felt like the prices were good. Prepare to pay around $50 a person after appetizers and drinks and entrees. I really like the spicy potatoes and the beef hummus. Service was fast as well.

Excellent service by the owner himself. Took my husband here for his birthday.

For starters we ordered their hummus, baba ganoush, and chicken liver. For the main we had their mixed grill. For dessert the owner wanted to surprise my husband and I and he brought us their panna cotta with some pistachio cookies and baklava with a candle and sang happy birthday for him which was beyond sweet and thoughtful.

I loved their chicken liver and baba ganoush. My husband enjoyed their hummus. The mixed platter was decent. However, their pita was a bit dry. I wish they had that thick, soft, buttery pita but nevertheless cute spot, with a modern and a rustic feel. A good place for conversations, and some good food. Will return to try other items on the menu.

I have eaten at Yara three times. That indicates its quality.

I selected it initially because of location. That is an important consideration of course. I use Yelp sometimes when I happen to be someplace I do not know, and I have no regular spot. Reliability is a significant criteria for restaurants, and this satisfies the standard. But sometimes you need to try new venues. To experiment with food makes you better as a person, in my book, and I confess I may be less enthusiastic about making friends with those who are unwilling to try new cuisines. So I found this place here on Yelp. I often am in mid town for business, then headed back home to Queens. This is en route. Then after an exploratory dinner, I concluded I could trust this place as fun and festive, with excellent food and respectful service (polite and unobtrusive, willing to offer recommendations).

It would be irrational to come here alone or with people unwilling to share plates. That is the only disadvantage, and even that comment is directed more at dining companions than this establishment. Tapas, dim sum, and other small plate styles of feasting demand a crowd. So I would not consider coming here alone, unless I were prepared to take home enormous amounts of leftovers (two meals worth).

The last time I was there was with a friend with whom I have worked a bit (we co-authored an article, or, rather, I was credit with a "with help from"). He had a new boyfriend. He is a native New Yorker, while his date hails from mainland China. They were traveling through the States, having visited Boston and en route to New Orleans.

We had probably ten dishes. My friend is partial to lamb. There are many choices here. They unfortunately were out of the tartare version.

Nonetheless, we enjoyed tabouli (a huge portion, enough for a half dozen), babaghanouj (less pureed than I am accustomed to but very good), moussakaa, grilled halloumi, meat pastry, kefta, and baklawa, among what I recall and am sure of. On prior visits, I have had beets, hummus, falafel, chicken liver, and fries.

The wine list has moderately priced options. That is a plus. Alcohol is expected to be marked up. I am not enough of a connoisseur to appreciate the pricey selections, nor wealthy enough to indulge.

I have Yara on my list of favorites. They have no idea who I am, because I visit only infrequently. I am pleased to commend it. If you need to get over the 59th street bridge afterward, you're set.

Great Lebanese joint. Newly opened but food was spectacular - they made one error by putting strawberries with kunafe (cheesy stretchy dessert soaked in sugar syrup). Otherwise, a beautiful menu with home cooked meals by a Lebanese chef. Try the kibbe nayeh (raw meat) like a tartare - exquisite.

Their lower level might be my future venue for networking events and parties, both personally and professionally (writing this down as we speak).

I'm not going to do the culture justice as I say this (and perhaps this is the Jersey kid in me talking), but their "empanadas" matched perfectly with the Lebanese beers the bartender recommended.

This may be a gateway for more Mediterranean in my future.

Amazing Mediterranean Lebanese place!

The inside was bit exotic (in a good way), eccentric and warm and cozy and welcoming.

Have some interesting and unique items on the menu.

The mouhamara was delightful - great combination of sweet, tart, and spicy. Grounded walnuts adds a great texture and flavor to the whole dish's profile.

Grilled Halloumi has a chewy and dense texture kinda like extra form tofu. Well seasoned with olive oil some spices and paired well with the sliced tomatoes.

Lamb okra was very thiccc, flavorful and hearty.

Upon walking in we were immediately impressed with the ambiance. I made a reservation for 6 people as I had visitors in town and we wanted a quiet yet filling brunch. The restaurant was fairly empty which was great so we could have conversations and hear each other. We were also seated at a circular table which makes it easier to converse

We ordered the fried halloumi, Yara fries, and hummus for the table which were delicious. the halloumi was definitely a hit we ordered two. I got the kefta for myself which came dry but after adding hummus and green sauce it brought out the flavors. The servings here are a little on the smaller side I wish the sandwich came with complimentary fries or salad.

In terms of the service this is why im giving Yara 2 stars. Our hostess/server was not attentive at all - we had to hunt her down to place a food order. Never checked in to see how the food was either. What really tipped me over is when we were ready for the check we waved at her and she very rudely gave us a pointer finger gesturing to stop talking. When we entered the restaurant another party came after us and she assisted them before us. Will not be returning purely out of the service here.

Been here few times, price to portion size is not the best but tasty. The place is very unsuspecting from outside but very nice and low key inside.

Busy nights can leave you waiting for a waiter but they're all great. Never had an issue finding a table or reservation.

The music can sometimes be loud for conversation but if you get seated somewhere towards the back it's great for conversation

I visited here for Easter, the restaurant was quiet and very very spacious. My husband, sister, baby, and I were seated towards the front of the restaurant on the side so the stroller wouldn't get in anyones way, the restaurant was quite accommodating in that sense, however the wait staff seemed easily irritated and were very pushy.
We ordered some mezze and sandwiches for our lunch: shankleesh, meat sambosa, hummus, zatar fries, fatoush salad, and the falafel, chicken shawarma, and regular shawarma sandwiches. For dessert we ordered baklava, Turkish coffee, and mint tea.

The food was certainly not impressive, not memorable, and lacked depth. The shankleesh was way too chunky, the feta pieces were so huge it was hard to eat. The meat sambosa was a little *too* meaty, and the hummus lacked depth. The zatar fries were delish, and the fatoush salad was also pretty good but also somehow the most expensive thing we ordered, certainly not worth $16?!
The sandwiches were also just ~ok~ nothing special, and the shawarma sandwiches had way too many pickles, and just overall way too many competing flavours.

The restrooms were a little weird... you walk in and there's a Mens door on one side, womens on the other, but essentially everyone's walking into the same bathroom. It was clean and did the job but a little strange.

I don't think I'd go back with better Mediterranean options in the city!

great atmosphere and ambiance, food was delicious and the drinks came out fairly quick!
The owner of the restaurant was incredibly friendly and was consistently checking in on us as well as other tables!

This Lebanese restaurant is amazing! Definitely recommend you check it out. The food is so good and authentic. We ordered Hummus, Tabouleh, Shish Taouk, and Shawarma. It all tasted incredible.

The service was also solid. The owners of the restaurant made my girlfriend and I feel right at home and doted on us, wanting to ensure that everything was up-to-standard. Lastly, we loved the decor of Yara and the atmosphere while there!

All in all, it's hard not to give this restaurant 5-stars. Wish we had something like Yara in Boston. Anyways, can't wait to be back!

I was craving middle eastern food, and this place was in the area of where we were, and it had really good reviews. I had never heard of this place before, but thought we would give it a shot! We made a reservation for two people on a Tuesday night.

EXPERIENCE
We were seated within 10 minutes. The service that night was very slow. Their kitchen randomly got overwhelmed, and the food was taking a while to come out. They did their best to keep us updated, and apologized many times. They even compensated our dessert, which was very kind of them. I wouldn't blame them as this seemed to be an unique circumstance, but it was kind of strange for a Tuesday night. Maybe they were not expecting it either. I would give them another chance though, and they did seem sincere in their apologies.

FOOD
(4/5) Hummus (chickpea puree, tahini, garlic, lemon juice) - This is a big portion. Probably better for 4+ people. Pretty creamy and tasty, I enjoyed it.
(5/5) Yara Mixed Grill Plate (grilled chicken, fillet mignon, kefta, shrimp, lamb chop) - The shrimp was not really anything special, it was fine. The chicken was pretty good, but I've had better elsewhere, it was boarder line over cooked. The fillet mignon was cooked really well, nice texture and juicy, The kefta was amazing, one of the best I've ever had! It was super soft and flavorful, it somehow melted in my mouth. It had a lot of good seasoning and I wish there was more!
(5/5) Kenafa (baked cheese topped with bread crumbs, crushed pistachio, yara syrup) - The dessert was great, if you haven't tried this dessert before, you must. Its cheesey, and has the intense sugar syrup on top. Theres always a really nice cheese pull, it is kind of heavy, but worth it.

OVERVIEW
The food here was very good, and the portions are quite large. The staff are very kind, and the ambiance was gorgeous! I would definitely come here again. I am hopeful that their kitchen will be better prepared to handle the volume of orders. Really solid spot.

I wish I could give 4.5/5. I really enjoy Yara and go frequently. The mezze are very good. The kebabs are more than just grilled meat, they have great seasoning and flavor. The other mains are interesting and very good. I'm going to keep going.

Great ambience and the menu had something for everyone no matter your preference or liking of Mediterranean food.  Service was prompt and attentive.  I would definitely return again.  The only complaint would be table size and lack of space for the large platters or a la carte items. Otherwise, I highly recommend! Prices reflect typical NYC prices but honestly with 4 alcoholic drinks 2 platters and 2 appetizers, our bill was under $300.

Food was delicious. Really loved the beet falafel, smoky baba ghanouj, mudardara, and tabouli. Fatayir and sambosik were just ok, I'd skip those next time. Washed it down with a Lebanese lager. The space is big and airy and service was good. I'll be back.

We really enjoyed our meal at Yara. I had read some reviews about inattentive service but that was far from my experience. We were seated immediately, our food came out quickly, the water was always filled- the service was excellent.

The food was amazing too. All the meat was delicious. The lamb chops were our favorite but the hummus with beef was a close second. We also really enjoyed the mixed grill. They also have really good halloumi. It's not over salty like what I usually end up finding at other places.

We also enjoyed the dessert. I recommend the knafeh. While it is a bit different from regular knafe (crumb topping vs semolina) it is still very good.

We really enjoyed our experience at Yara. We came in for a very early dinner and did not have a reservation. We were seated right away. The dining room is beautifully decorated. There are interior brick walls with chic wall hangings. The waiter was attentive, and the service was prompt but not rushed.
We ordered the Lebanese beers, which were great! For starters, we had the hummus, eggplant salad dip, and falafel. The hummus was delicious. The pita is the really thin (almost crunchy) kind. We prefer a fluffier pita. The eggplant salad dip was fantastic and flavorful. We loved the falafel! The tomatoes on the side were very fresh. The pickled radish on the side was a bit too sour.
For our main course, we split the mixed grill platter. All of the meats were amazing!! I loved all three! The vegetables and rice were very good, as well. One complaint was the dipping sauce. There was a white creamy garlic sauce on the side, and it was potently garlicky to the point that we could not find it palatable. It was acidic and intense. We did not need the sauce to enjoy the meal. The meal was lovely otherwise. Very delicious and hearty. We were very full! I would recommend checking out Yara.

Very good Lebanese food with no fuss. The environment is very friendly and the service was great. We had the hummus, a lentil appetizer and the
Mixed grill between two people it was more than enough. I would definitely return, all the food was so flavorful.
The parking garage right next to it is great as well. Under $20 for the night when they have the weekend special.

For our last meal in NYC, my wife and I grabbed lunch at Yara before heading to the Airport.  

What a delicious meal that was filling, while also light enough so we were not uncomfortable traveling.  The owner was an absolute gem and made us feel so welcome.

We used to go to this Lebanese establishment when it was Al Bustan...however attended recently for an event celebrating my daughter's acceptance to medical school....I was sorely disappointed...albiet I am also Lebanese....never felt at home" at all......  waiter was aloof, and very misleading....price was not what we were quoted......in fact we paid double....disgusting and greedy....they are a complete rip off...stay away from this restaurant....asked for all leftovers, as our party of 10 had plenty, they gave us one tiny dish of humus  and one tiny dish of chicken ...sad...Not to mention the cake we gave them to store in freezer for this big event was completely melted...sad and criminal...stay away from this establishment, My advice.. as a NYC Lebanese...go to Balade Restaurant instead.....trust me......doctors know best and would definelty NOT recommend...:)

Yara is a high end Lebanese restaurant located in Midtown with tasteful interior decor and white linen tables. Given their location and intended clientele, the menu was a little on the pricey side, but not unreasonable for a higher end Mediterranean restaurant.
My friends and I shared four of the small Mezze plates and also two entrees. The dishes they did well were amazing: the babaghanouj was delightfully smoky, while their lamb chops were still juicy and tender while cooked to a medium well. All the ingredients were fresh and of a high quality, however overall taste was a tad bland. I really wanted to love everything a lot more, but unfortunately have had better falafel and shawarma at more unassuming restaurants.

Amazing service and huge variety of great dishes! Ordered delivery for a work event and food came promptly and they listened to all additional comments (re: allergies and sauce/ pieces on the side). They were also really helpful when I called with questions about dietary restrictions before ordering. Food came packaged well and nothing spilled. Hot food was separated from cold too!

I got the sfiha with lamb, which was a bit dry. But everyone else loved their food and their baklava was great. Will be back to try their hummus and other appetizers!

I came on a Friday night and place was packed. Service was meh but I think it was because there was only 2-3 servers for the whole top floor. We waited a very long time for our meals.

For apps, we got the beet falafel which was the best thing we had. Highly recommend. We also got the muhamra and halloumi which were pretty good. Honestly I would come back for these apps.

For entree, I got the vegan okra. They didn't have many vegetarian options for entrees. This was okay,and most likely wouldn't get again.

Cute ambiance, and the downstairs floor is a cute intimate bar lounge for drinks.
Delicious food and great service - recommended by a colleague, located in Midtown.  Enjoyed some appetizers, the Lemon Sole and some traditional ice cream for dessert.

Yara is a traditional Lebanese restaurant with all the classical specialties.
I had baba ghanouj (excellent), taboulé, and kibbe to start.
Followed by shawarma, also very good.
Excellent service. Good place for a quiet business lunch (I hate noisy restaurants!)
Will be back!

My mom is lebanese, so I'm always looking for good lebanese 'comfort' food. I ordered delivery on a rainy day at work and the food was very good. I don't exactly understand the new craze with lebanese food of adding jalapenos and other accoutrements to kibbeh nayeh, but perhaps it's just not the way 'my family' does it. The kibbeh was solid, definitely a 'tide me over' until I can get home to mom. The fattoush was great, there's some spice that I can't identify that I wasn't used to, but overall something I would order again. The menoushe was very good, but I can make the same at home.

Overall, I'm glad I found Yara and will order again, but fancier than the 'mom's home cooking' that I was looking for.

Stumbled upon this spot because another restaurant in the area was full. Was greeted by the owner which was nice! The inside is so elegant and intimate, I almost felt like I was at a wedding.

Babaghanouj - 5/5 - The babaghanouj itself was spectacular! Smooth and chunky at the same time, had a Smokey finish which I always enjoy. The bread that it came with tasted stale however. I could just imagine if the bread was thicker, softer, and more fresh... this would be a 6/5!

Filet Mignon - 4.5/5 - I love their seasoning and the amount of char on each bite without compromising tenderness. Vegetables were seasoned well, I've never had a taste quite like it. Sad because the amount of rice to meat ratio was low :(

Shawarma Chicken - 4/5 - Good! Could use more pita. LOTS of chicken, very generous. Could definitely share this! The fries were good too.

Milk Pudding - 6/5 - Oh my goodness, where has this dessert been all my life?! First time trying mahalabia and I'm glad I tried it here first. The milk pudding was so decadent with the pistachio and the hint of rosewater really shined through. Creative to put little strips of cotton candy on the top! We devoured the plate clean.

They also have pretty good affordable lunch specials! Would probably keep this in rotation if I worked or lived in the neighborhood. Yummy!

I came here with my friends for a birthday dinner. The food and service was amazing! The restaurant is very nice inside as well. Everything tasted so fresh and the cocktails were made perfectly. I definitely would recommend this restaurant!

Made a reservation but the restaurant didn't honor it. They said the place was closed for a private event.  We had to find another place for dinner on a busy night without a reservation. Not cool, Yara!

Seriously great food.  From the basic hummus to the more elaborate mixed grill, shawarma, salmon, and chicken livers!  Just excellent and unique in their preparation and quality.  Was at a business gathering, and we were in their downstairs section: Nicley appointed bar area, and very comfy seating where we could talk and enjoy these superior presentations of traditional Mediterranean dishes.

We went for lunch on a weekday and it was completely empty. Sometimes that's nice but I think it resulted in us getting a bit too much attention from the waiter (who may have been the owner?) and it became a bit uncomfortable. So kind and I'd recommend this place to everyone, but I think the restaurant's vibe is actually better for dinner when it's more filled up. They have great cocktails, great mezze, and great mains. I'd recommend the hummus for sure and the salmon.

My wife and I took family and friends to Yara as a celebration for our daughter's graduation from NYU (Master's degree).  Twelve people attended the dinner.

First, we were seated in a semi-private area in the back of the restaraunt, which was perfect for our group. The table was a large square so everyone could see and be seen and could even communicate across the table.

Appetizers were chosen for the table and one was better than the next. There was a large variety to choose from, multiple plates of each came out of the kitchen and all plates returned empty; the food was devoured.

Each person ordered their own entree. The dishes were beautifully prepared and displayed, and tasted amazing.  I had lamb chops, one of my favorite dinners, and they were tender, had great flavor, and prepared perfectly medium-rare, just like I ordered. Others ate the Lemon Sole, Grilled Salmon, Sautéed Shrimp, and everyone raved about their food.

Additionally, the drinks were great; both wine and cocktails. The deserts were fabulous too. My first ever Milk Pudding with ground pistachio was killer.

Finally, the wait staff was warm and attentive, on top of all of our requests, the food was served hot, and the drinks flowed as the night went on. The restaraunt was full of people and bustling but not at all overwhelming.

We would strongly recommend Yara to anyone who would listen!

Joshua and Sandy Cohen

I'm very pleased to know that there are such great restaurants near my work like Yara. This Lebanese restaurant is a true gem of the midtown east! I've been here for a group lunch and I have to say the service here is outstanding! We were met by the restaurant manager who personally assured that we were taken care of. Yara truly cares about your experience!

The food here is 5 star +! We ordered variety of appetizers such as babaganous, hummus, falafel, haloumi,etc. everything tasted great but especially hummus. Really the best! Their kabab is also really delicious, tender and flavorful. There is nothing on the menu that does not meet the expectation. Beyond great!

Food is ok . No really a good flavor more on the plain side . The waitress no very gracious. She was not impolite but was in a hurry and we didn't feel welcome. The ambiance is nice, clean and modern . Love the Lebanese music .
This is the real deal! It's not just hummus and Kebobs. They serve food that my grandmother cooks. And they do it almost as good. The ambiance is elevated and the service is super friendly.

4.5*

I was looking for a restaurant on the Upper East Side, an area I rarely visit, and came across Yara and its excellent reviews.  I ended up having dinner there with my cousin, and we were extremely impressed.

She had arrived a few moments before I had and was waiting for me at a booth in the white table-clothed, elegant upstairs dining room.  There were bowls of pickled radishes and heavily fried pita chips already adorning the table.  I munched on these snacks while sipping my Fidora Organic Pinot Grigio from Veneto, IT.  The crisp white wine was refreshing, had a mild acidity, and offered light notes of fruit (pear & apple) and flowers.  

We soon transitioned to our entrees, both ordering the Shish Tawook.  The grilled chicken chunks were tender and perfectly seasoned.  While there were a decent number of poultry pieces, the sides were miniscule.  There were only 4 pieces of grilled vegetables (zucchini and red pepper), a slice of fresh tomato, and a small mound of rice.  The rice had great flavor, but contained a few hard clumps.  There was a side of garlic aioli on the plate as well, which provide an intense blast of garlic that was as delicious as it was strong; it acted as a great sauce for the rice.  

Overall, we were very pleased with the flavor of the food.  But, when it came to the service, the waiter was polite, but also seemed frazzled and ready to rush us out.  We would definitely return, but I felt that there were a few minor tweaks that could have improved our experience.
Food and ambience were great.  Waiters could have come by more often, but all in all, we had a great dinner and a nice evening.  Really liked this place.

Really enjoyed the food and vibe here. Felt like someone's home, there were live guitarists and the whole crowd was very diverse/cultured/vibrant. The service was slow hence the 4 stars but I'd recommend this place!

What an amazing Mediterranean spot in the city! We truly enjoyed our dinner experience at Yara and I can't recommend it enough.

My husband and I met my friend at Yara for dinner. We wanted to share a bunch of vegetarian mezze and enjoy drinks and luckily we were able to do exactly that. Between the 3 of us, we shared an order of hummus, cauliflower, beet falafel, bhabab ghanoush, stuffed grape leaves, and a spanakopita type mezze called sambosik cheese. Everything was so good and fresh and we definitely ordered the right amount of food.

We also lucked out from a drinks perspective! Our server told us it was Happy Hour until 8 PM (not advertised) and they made an exception to grant us HH prices even though we weren't seated at the bar. Great customer service! Their drinks are really good and you can't beat the price for New York. The ambience inside is also very nice. They do a great job of keeping the restaurant looking nice and classy.
